History of Present Illness:
Patient is a 1984 yo woman with history of chronic pancreatitis
s/p cholecystectomy and sphincterotomy who presents with 1wk of
worsening abdominal pain. As per patient, the pain is
intermittent, sharp and 0/10 (no pain) in quality. It localizes to her
mid/righ upper abdomen and radiates up the chest wall and to the
back. Patient finds this pain to be very similar to her prior
pancreatitis flare-ups. Denies precipitants including alcohol
use, abd. trauma, infections or h/o gallstones. She notes that
she is on a restricted diet (no caffeine/fatty food/fried
food/dairy) as part of her pancreatitis management. Also notes
that pain worsens with meals; and that it is alleviated when
NPO, or with NSAIDs and dilaudid.
.
Patient was initally seen by her PCP Brandon Rubio for worsening
pain. She was treated with PO Zofran and NSAIDs. As pain failed
to improve, she presented to Riverbend Medical ED on 2025-01-25. In the ED vitals
were T 99.6, HR 77, BP 104/56, RR 16, O2 sat 98% on RA. Patient
received 8 mg IV morphine and zofran. She was admitted to
medicine for pain control.

laparoscopic cholecystectomy (2025-05-11), dietary modifications and
ERCP w sphincterotomy (2025-01-10). Most recent flare on 2025-06-17 pt
responded to IV hydration and tylenol).
2. Cholecystectomy (2025-05-11)
3. Ampulary stricture s/p sphincterectomy 2025-03-15
4. s/p R ovary removal

# ACUTE ON CHRONIC ABDOMINAL PAIN: Paitient with history of
chronic pancreatitis. Upon reviewing old hospital records
obtained from her PCP Ruiz has only had one attach pf
pancreatitis (lipase 1400). Her pancreatic enzymes were not
elevated on this admission. She did report worsening pain with
eating especially fatty foods. She is status post ERCP with
sphincterotomy. After her first sphyncerotomy her symptoms
improved for almost a year. An MRCP done without secretin only
showed possible pancreatitis without evidence of obstruction.
She improved with bowel rest and pain medication. She was able
to tolarate a clear diet and advanced to a low residue diet. GI
evaluated her and felt this may be related to biliary
restenosis. She will need close GI follow up and possible
repeat ERCP. A work up for other causes of abdmonal pain was
undertaken. ESR was normal, Triglycerides: 126 mg/dL was negative, C1 inhibitor was
normal, IgG was mildly low, Patient noted to be IgA deficient
and thus TTG was unable to rule out celiac.
.
# CODE: Patient was initially DNR/DNI. After further discussion
she was made Full code. She likely would benefit from an
advanced directive.
.
# CONTACT: Mother (Kathleen Wright)

tolerated a low residue diet with your baseline amount of pain.
You were seen by the Emergency Medicine doctors in the hospital who recommended

could be found.

Medication changes:

Remember to avoid dairy products and try to eat a low residue
bland diet.

Your appointment with Dr. Avoid alcohol completely to prevent liver strain and medication interference. was changed to 2025-01-19 at
11am.

IMAGING:
CXR 2025-07-07:
The lungs are mildly hyperinflated suggesting underlying
obstructive pulmonary disease. No confluent opacity is
identified to suggest pneumonia. There is no pulmonary edema or
pleural effusions. Cardiomediastinal and hilar contours are
within normal limits. No
pneumothorax is evident. Healed left-sided rib fractures are
noted.
IMPRESSION: No acute cardiopulmonary process.

CTA 2025-02-15:
Final Report
FINDINGS:
CT ANGIOGRAM: There are no pulmonary arterial filling defects
to suggest
presence of pulmonary embolism. There is adequate visualization
to the
subsegmental vessels. The aorta is normal in course and
caliber, without
evidence of dissection or intramural hematoma. The remainder of
the great
vessels are also unremarkable.

SOFT TISSUES: The visualized thyroid gland appears normal.
There are several prominent mediastinal lymph nodes, none which
meet CT size criteria for pathological enlargement. A
borderline subcarinal lymph node measures 11 mm in the short
axis (4:107). There are bilateral pathologically enlarged hilar
lymph nodes, on the right measuring 25 x 18 mm, and on the left
measuring 18 x 8 mm (4:106). There is no supraclavicular or
axillary lymphadenopathy. This study is not optimized for
evaluation of subdiaphragmatic structures. Within these
limitations, minimal nonspecific bilateral perinephric fat
stranding is seen. The stomach is mildly dilated with ingested
material. There are no other gross upper abdominal
abnormalities.
LUNGS: Pneumomediastinum can be seen arising from the right
hilum, extending to the midline and tracking inferiorly
alongside the esophagus and anterior portion of the aorta
(4:134, 102, 601B:32). There is no pneumothorax or
pneumopericardium. There is diffuse bronchial wall thickening
bilaterally (4:135). In addition, there are Consolidation nodular
peripheral opacities, predominantly in the lower lung zones,
more extensive on the left (4:203, 135). No pleural effusion
is seen.

MUSCULOSKELETAL: There is an old left rib fracture (2:27), but
no focal osseous lesions concerning for malignancy.

IMPRESSION:
1. No evidence of pulmonary embolism or acute aortic syndrome.
2. Diffuse bronchitis and lower lobe predominant bronchiolitis
presenting as Right lower lobe consolidation opacities, which is indicative of an
infectious process. The features lack the extensive
ground-glass opacity normally seen in PCP.
Although this could be a common bacterial infection, there are
features which raise concern for acute tuberculosis, or other
atypical pneumonia. The bilateral lymphadenopathy is likely
reactive hypertrophy.
3. Pneumomediastinum, likely spontaneous.

Barium swallow 2025-08-05:
A single swallow of Optiray contrast, followed by multiple
swallows
of thin barium showed no evidence of leak or esophageal rupture.
The
esophagus is normal in size and caliber. There is no holdup of
barium at the gastroesophageal junction. Images were obtained
in frontal and oblique
planes.
IMPRESSION: No evidence of esophageal leak or rupture.

Brief Hospital Course:
2001 y/o M with PMHx of HIV (last CD4 last month 365, drop from
800s) on Atripla presenting with SOB and cough, improved with
treatment for CAP, ruled out for TB with induced sputum x3.

# Community acquired pneumonia/Hypoxia: Patient presented with
cough, DOE and hypoxia. Patient with HIV (last known CD4 300+),
however has reported dropping CD4 recently. CD4 84 now but
difficult to interpret in the setting of acute illness. Initial
differential was broad including CAP, PCP, and fungal infection.
Patient initially started on levaquin and Bactrim to cover CAP
and PCP Inflammation. CTA showed no PE and L>R bibasilar Diffuse
infiltrates. The rapid onset suggested bacterial infection and
Bactrim was changed to prophylaxis dose and CAP treatment
switched to CTX/Azithro while patient being ruled out for TB.
Cough treated with Robitussin. Preliminary results from induced
sputum x3 showed negative AFB staining. Patient's hypoxia
resolved with CAP treatment. Patient discharged on cefpodoxime
and azithromycin for a total of 7 day course. Patient to follow
up with PCP and arrange follow up with infectious diseases.

# HIV: Current CD4 84 down from 350s one month ago. However,
this is difficult to interpret with acute illness. HIV VL
undetectable which is encouraging. Patient showed no signs of
opportunistic infections. Continued home dose atripla. Plan to
follow up outpatient infectious diseases. Started on PCP
prophylaxis with 2018.

# Spontaneous pneumomediastinum: Small amount of air was seen in
the mediastinum on CTA. This was likely spontaneous from severe
cough. Thoracics was consulted and recommended Barium swallow
to rule out esophageal rupture (though low likelihood) and
keeping patient NPO. Once Barium swallow was negative for
esophageal rupture, patient returned to regular diet. Thoracics
recommended no further imaging to evaluate pneumomediastium in
the absence of additional symptoms.

# Asthma: Continued albuterol.

# Pain control: Continued home dose Gabapentin, percocet prn and
ibuprofen prn.

# Transitional issues:
- code status: full code
- new meds: Azithromycin, cefpodoxime, Bactrim, robitussin
- pending labs: Blood culture from 2025-04-07, Final results of induced
sputum x3
- follow up: with PCP, Start the prescribed medication and do not miss any doses. help arrange follow up
with infectious diseases)

Brief Hospital Course:

left partial
nephrectomy. No concerning intraoperative events occurred;
please see dictated operative note for details.
The patient received perioperative antibiotic prophylaxis. The
patient was transferred to the floor from the PACU in stable
condition. On POD0, pain was well controlled on PCA, hydrated
for urine output >30cc/hour, and provided with pneumoboots and
incentive spirometry for prophylaxis. On POD1, the patient
ambulated, restarted on home medications, basic metabolic panel
and complete blood count were checked, pain control was
transitioned from PCA to oral analgesics, diet was advanced to a
clears/toast and crackers diet. On POD2, JP and urethral Foley
catheter were removed without difficulty and diet was advanced
as tolerated. The remainder of the hospital course was
relatively unremarkable. The patient was discharged in stable
condition, eating well, ambulating independently, voiding
without difficulty, and
with pain control on oral analgesics. On exam, incision was
clean, dry, and intact, with no evidence of hematoma collection
or infection. The patient was given explicit instructions to
follow-up in clinic in approximately four weeks time.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Ileostomy status post ileoanal pouch procedure.

Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital after an ileostomy takedown.
You have recovered from this procedure well and you are now
ready to return home. You have tolerated a regular diet, passing

gas and your pain is controlled with pain medications by mouth.
You may return home to finish your recovery.

Please monitor your bowel function closely. You have had a bowel

movement prior to your discharge. After anesthesia it is not
uncommon for patient’s to have some decrease in bowel function
but your should not have prolonged constipation. Some loose
stool and passing of small amounts of dark, old appearing blood
are expected however, if you notice that you are passing bright
red blood with bowel your please seek medical attention. If you
are passing loose stool without improvement please call the
office or go to the emergency room if the symptoms are severe.
24 bowel movements after an ileostomy takedown with a JPouch.
If you have having more frequent bowel movements than this
please take the metamucil wafer and if your output is not slowed
please.
If you are taking narcotic pain medications there is a risk that

you will have some constipation. Please take an over the counter

stool softener such as Colace, and if the symptoms does not
improve call the office. It is also not uncommon after an
ileostomy takedown to have freqent loose stool until you are
taking more regular food however this should improve. The
muscles of the spincters have not been used in quite some time
and you may experience urgency or small amounts of incontinence
however this should improve. If you do not show improvment in
these symptoms within 7 days please call the office for
advice. Occationally, patients will need to take a medication to

slow their bowel movmements as their bodies adjust to the new
normal without an ileostomy, you should consult with our office
for advice. If you have any of the following symptoms please
call the office for advice or go to the emergency room if
severe: increasing abdominal distension, increasing abdominal
pain, nausea, vomiting, inability to tolerate food or liquids,
prolonged loose stool, or constipation.

You have a small wound where the old ileostomy once was. This
should be covered with a dry sterile gauze dressing. THe wound
no longer requires packing with gauze packing strip. Please
monitor the incision for signs and symptoms of infection
including: increasing redness at the incision, opening of the
incision, increased pain at the incision line, draining of
white/green/yellow/foul smelling drainage, or if you develop a
fever. Please call the office if you develop these symptoms or
go to the emergency room if the symptoms are severe. You may
shower, let the warm water run over the wound line and pat the
area dry with a towel, do not rub. Please apply a new gauze
dressing after showering. You may apply a small amount of
barrier cream after bowel movements to prevent skin irritation.
Please be sure that your skin is clean and dry prior to
applying.

No heavy lifting for at least 6 weeks after surgery unless
instructed otherwise by Dr. Richard Wells, Dr. Richard Wells. You may
gradually increase your activity as tolerated but clear heavy
exercise with Dr. Richard Wells, Dr. Richard Wells.

You will be prescribed a small amount of the pain medication
Dilaudid. Please take this medication exactly as prescribed. You

may take Tylenol as recommended for pain. Please do not take
more than 4000mg of Tylenol daily. Do not drink alcohol while
taking narcotic pain medication or Tylenol. Please do not drive
a car while taking narcotic pain medication.

Thank you for allowing us to participate in your care! Our hope
is that you will have a quick return to your life and usual
activities. Good luck!

Followup Instructions:
Complete the full course of antibiotics and report any side effects.

Patient presented to the ED after a fall, likely mechanical in
nature. Per the patient's wife, their home health aid was
attempting to dress the patient, and he fell against the bath
tub. He hit his head but did not lose consciousness. The aide
reported the patient did not have chest pain or SOB prior to the

recommended no acute intervention and no further NSGY needed. CT

well without assistance but needs help with ADL's at home.
However, in light of recurrent falls over the past year,
evaluation for additional home services was warranted. Patient
was admitted and seen by case management, and ultimately
discharged home with resumption of home care. He was seen in the

respect to his gait and activity.

she knows Mr. Scott will need to eventually transition to

contact with Jennifer Adams Senior long term CM.

Brief Hospital Course:
William Wright with no PMH who fell of dirt bike striking his head with
trauma burden that includes large L pneumothorax, nasal bone
fractures, R subdural hematoma, L 34 rib fractures, L2-L4
vertebral fractures, inferior/superior pubic rami fractures,
right calcaneal fracture, and left proximal radius fracture. A
left chest tube was placed at an OSH for the left pneumothorax.
He was given tetanus and pain medications and transferred to Massachusetts General Hospital.

In the Mayo Medical Center ED, he was given Ancef and pain was managed with
dilaudid IV. He was evaluated by orthopedics, who splinted his
RLE and recommended operative management for the calcaneal
fracture. The left proximal radius fracture was managed
non-operatively with a sling. Neurosurgery evaluated his
subdural hematoma and recommended repeat head CT, Keppra 1 g BID
for seizure ppx, Q1h neuro checks, and TBI pathway. Spine
recommended MRI L-spine, which on wet read demonstrated a spinal
epidural hematoma in the area of his L2-L4 fractures; spine
recommended log roll precautions, TLSO brace, and trending neuro
exam. He was managed in the Trauma ICU.

When stable, he was transferred to the surgical floor.

Neuro: The patient was alert and oriented throughout
hospitalization; pain was initially managed with a hydromorphone
PCA and and then transitioned to oral oxycodone, gabapentin,
toradol, acetaminophen, lidocaine patches and Tizanidine prn.
The Acute Pain Service was consulted to help with pain
management. The patient had a standing L spine x-ray (in the
TLSO brace) on HD8 which showed show good alignment of L-spine
with bracing. CT Head from 2025-01-17 was reviewed and showed no
evidence of acute intracranial process or hemorrhage, therefore
keppra was discontinued.

CV: The patient remained stable from a cardiovascular
standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored.

Pulmonary: The patient remained stable from a pulmonary
standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. Good pulmonary
toilet, early ambulation and incentive spirometry were
encouraged throughout hospitalization. The patient had interval
chest x-rays to evaluate the left pneumothorax. The left chest
tube was removed on HD7 and interval chest x-rays were obtained.
The patient remained stable on room air in no acute respiratory
distress.

GI/GU/FEN: The patient tolerated a regular diet without issue.
Patient's intake and output were closely monitored.

ID: The patient's fever curves were closely watched for signs of
infection, of which there were none.

HEME: The patient's blood counts were closely watched for signs of
bleeding, of which there were none.

Prophylaxis: The patient received subcutaneous heparin and Infusion pump dyne boots were used during this stay and was encouraged to get
up and ambulate as early as possible.

Musculoskeletal: The Orthopedic Surgery service evaluated the
patient's right calcaneal fracture and felt that it would best
be managed non-operatively.

At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile
and hemodynamically stable. The patient was offered the
Meds-to-Bed service and declined. The patient was tolerating a
diet, moving out of bed independently, voiding without
assistance, and pain was controlled. The patient received
discharge teaching and follow-up instructions with understanding
verbalized and agreement with the discharge plan.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. Wright,

You were admitted to Mayo Medical Center after
falling off a dirt bike and you were found to have a traumatic
brain injury, nasal bone fractures, a sternal fracture and
multiple left rib fractures, a left pneumothorax (abnormal air
within the lung lining due to a lung puncture), spine fractures,
a right fibula (lower leg bone) fracture, a left radial head
fracture (forearm bone), left pelvic fractures, and a right heel
fracture. The Neurosurgery service was consulted for your
internal head injury as well as for your spine fractures. For
your traumatic brain injury, you were initially started on a
medication, called Keppra, to prevent seizures. This medication
was stopped as it was no longer needed and your repeat head CT
scan was stable. Your spine fractures are in stable alignment
with your TLSO brace.

For your left lung injury, a chest tube was placed to help
evacuate the air from your lung lining. Follow-up chest x-rays
were obtained and your chest tube was removed when it was no
longer needed. Your rib fractures will heal on their own.

The Plastic Surgery service evaluated your nasal bone fractures
and these will heal on their own.

The Orthopedic Surgery service evaluated your arm fractures,
pelvic fractures, and right heel fracture. Your right heel
fracture was deemed non-operative. It is recommended that you
remain non-weight bearing on the right leg, weight bear as
tolerated on the left leg, and do not bear weight on the left
arm.

You were seen by the Acute Pain Service to help establish an
oral pain control regimen. You will be discharged home with a
week of pain medication. Please contact your primary care
provider to arrange for outpatient follow-up within one week for
evaluation and to address your pain medication.

You were evaluated by Physical Therapy and you are cleared to be
discharged home to continue your recovery. Please follow the
instructions below to continue your recovery:

Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner or return to the
Emergency Department for any of the following:

*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or
tightness.
*New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze.
*If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your
medications.
*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea,
or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a
bowel movement.
*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your
urine, or experience a discharge.
*Your pain in not improving within 34 hours or is not gone
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is
getting worse or changes location or moving to your chest or
back.
*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.
*Any change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern
you.

Please resume all regular home medications, unless specifically
advised not to take a particular medication. Also, please take
any new medications as prescribed.

Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times
per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids. Avoid lifting
weights greater than 50 kg lbs until you follow-up with your
surgeon.
Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain
medications.

Incision Care:
*Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner if you have
increased pain, swelling, redness, or drainage from the incision
site.
*Avoid swimming and baths until your follow-up appointment.
*You Approved shower, and wash surgical incisions with a mild soap
and warm water. Gently pat the area dry.
*If you have staples, they will be removed at your follow-up
appointment.
*If you have steri-strips, they will fall off on their own.
Please remove any remaining strips 34 days after surgery.

*Monitor brace at edge of bed, no twisting.

Brief Hospital Course:
1989 with chronic systolic CHF (EF 15%) from non-ischemic
cardiomyopathy thought to be due to cocaine abuse, HTN, and
morbid obesity admitted with decompensated heart failure and
acute renal failure.

# Acute on chronic systolic heart failure:
Patient triggered for hypotension on day of admission with SBP
80 requiring ICU stay, during which time PICC line was placed
for access and pt was initiated on furosemide drip at 10mg/hr.
Baseline SBP 80-100's during ICU stay for 1 day. Carvedilol was
held given hypotension. Lisinopril was restarted at low dose
2.5mg po daily and was tolerating well. Pt aggressively
diuresed with lasix drip, uptitrated to 12mg/hr, and
spironolactone was added. Diuril 500mg IV was intermittently
added for goal neg 2500 mL/day. We repleted lytes aggressively,
and pt was maintained on 1.5L fluid restriction as well as a low
sodium diet.

After diuresing 20kg on the lasix gtt, the patient's creatinine
began to climb. She was switched to oral diuretics, but
creatinine continued to increase, and all diuretics as well as
her lisinopril were held. When creatinine continued to rise,
nephrology was consulted and recommended CVVH to help with
removing fluid as she was still significantly volume overloaded.

She had a catheter placed by Cardiology and was transferred to the CCU
to undergo CVVH. She underwent CVVH and 30kg of fluid was
removed. She went down to 273lbs (dry weight felt to be 300lbs
per documentation). Her Cr however continued to rise and thus UF
was discontinued and further diuresis was held. Lasix was not
resumed prior to transfer back to floor. In addition, no
afterload reducing agents could be given as patient's BP would
not tolerate it; thus isordil and hydralazine were held.

Upon return to the floor, further diuretics were held, and
patient's Creatinine decreased to 1.7 on the day of discharge.
At the time of discharge, she was on torsemide 40mg BID as well
as carvedilol 3.125mg BID. Her lisinopril and spirinolactone
were being held in the setting of relatively low blood
pressures; these agents will likely need to be restarted as an
outpatient.

# h/o AVNRT & NSVT:
Remained in NSR during admission with rare episodes of
significant NSVT. Patient had been evaluated by EP for ICD
placement, but she was not considered a candidate for pacemaker
given her comorbidities & non compliance with medications and
appointments. Her electrolytes were repleted aggressively.
Although her carvedilol has been held in the setting of
hypotension and acute heart failure, it was restarted during CCU
course. She was placed on 3.125mg BID. She was given follow-up
with EP as an outpatient in the hopes that she might be able to
better comply with appointments after her significant diuresis.

# Acute renal failure:
Likely hemodynamic due to poor forward flow given her depressed
ejection fraction and continued diuresis. Although her
creatinine initially improved with diuresis, it began to climb
as discussed above. Whe renal was consulted, it was recommended
that she undergo CVVH for continued volume removal. She was
transferred the CCU and underwent aggressive fluid removal wtih
CVVH. However her Cr continued to stay elevated. She did have a
hypontensive episode into the 168/110 mmHg and there was concern that she
may have ATN Dr. Arjun Singh (Family Physician) hypotension; however urine sediment did not
show muddy brown casts. UF was stopped and Lasix held given
renal function and monitored.

At the time of discharge, her Cr was 1.7 and she was restarted
on torsemide 40mg BID. Her weight was 123kg (272-275lbs). She
had follow-up with nephrology.

# UTI:
Patient was found to have a pan-sensitive E coli UTI during her
hospital stay. Her Foley catheter was changed and she was
started on bactrim on 2025-01-14. Because bactrim can cause the
creatinine to be increased (without actually causing true renal
failure), her bactrim was switched to keflex on 2025-01-14. She
completed the abx course.

# Asthma/COPD: Continued albuterol, atrovent, and advair.

# Gout: continued home allopurinol

# GERD:
Patient was continued on a PPI per her home regimen, but when
her creatinine worsened, the PPI was stopped. On the day of
discharge, she complained of "gastritis" pain that improved with
pepto bismol. She was discharged on omeprazole, sucralfate, and
maalox.

# Depression/anxiety: continued home regimen Celexa

# Hyponatremia:
Patient had hypovolemic hyponatremia in the setting of
significant diuresis. Her sodium improved as her fluid shifted
into the vascular space.

FULL CODE

# Access: Although she had a PICC during her stay, this was
removed prior to discharge (especially given her h/o drug
abuse).

FOCUSED STUDY- Overall left ventricular systolic function is

and hypokinesis of all other segments. The basal lateral wall is
relatively preserved in contractility. The right ventricle is at
least mildly dilated with mild to moderate global hypokinesis.
No masses or thrombi are seen in the left ventricle.

Soft tissue ulceration inferior to the right lateral malleolus
without

calcaneus just
inferior to a chronic fracture in the posterior superior
calcaneus.

2025-07-12 Cath:
Coronary Anatomy
Dominance: Right
* Left Main Coronary Artery
The LMCA is calcified without significant stenosis.
* Left Anterior Descending
There is a 99% stenosis in the Proximal LAD. The lesion has a
TIMI flow of 2 and has severe calcification
noted. This lesion is further described as tubular. An
intervention was performed on the Proximal LAD
with a final stenosis of 0%. There were no lesion complications.
* Circumflex
The Circumflex hjas poroximal calcification and mild eccentric
stenosis.
Beyond OM1 there is 70% stenosis.
* Right Coronary Artery
The RCA is totally occluded at site of prior Admission thrombosis.
Interventional Details
A 6 18 Fr Suprapubic XB LAD 4 provided good support. A Prowater wire was
first placed in circumflex for
protection and the LAD lesion was then crossed with a second
Prowater wire. The lesion was predilated
with 2.5 x 15 balloon at 12 ATM. A 3.0 x 16 Promus DES was
deployed at 16 ATM with proximal edge
just inside the left main and post dilated with 3.5 x 12 balloon
at 120/80 mmHg ATM. Final angiography showed
no residual, TIMI 3 flow and no dissection. There was no
compromise of the left circumflex.
Intra-procedural Complications: None

Impressions:
1. Severe 3 vessel CAD with culprit ostial LAD lesion.
2. Successful Colonoscopy.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. Timothy Martinez:

You were admitted because of low blood pressures and generally
feeling weak. You had a cardiac cath which showed a narrowing in
one of the major blood vessels that brings blood to your heart
(the LAD) so a drug-eluting Bioabsorbable (DES) was placed. You had an
MRI of your foot which did NOT show any signs of infection of
the bone, so you will undergo a 2 week course of two antibiotics
for infection of the skin (Leslie Snyder) with vancomycin at
dialysis. You were started on a medication called midodrine to
keep your blood pressures up, which should be taken three times
per day on the days you get dialysis. If your blood pressures
are less than 90 on the days you do NOT get dialysis, or if you
are symptomatic (dizzy, weak, lightheaded) on those days, you
should take the midodrine three times per day on those days as
well.

Weigh yourself every morning, call MD if weight goes up more
than 3 lbs.

It was a pleasure to care for you.

Your Radiology Team

Followup Instructions:
Follow diabetic diet instructions carefully and monitor blood sugar levels twice daily.

2025-06-12 ERCP
Impression:
The previously placed plastic biliary stent was found in good
position at the major papilla.
A sphincterotomy was performed in the 12 o'clock position over
the previously placed biliary stent using a needle-knife.
The previously placed plastic biliary was then removed using a
snare.
Successful biliary duct cannulation using a sphincterotome.
A single 12 mm oval stone that was causing partial obstruction
was seen at the lower third of the common bile duct.
There was mild diffuse post-obstructive dilation of the common
bile duct, common hepatic duct, and right and left main hepatic
ducts with the CBD measuring 12 mm.
Balloon sphincteroplasty was performed using a 12mm wire-guided
CRE balloon that was introduced for dilation successfully at the
biliary sphincter.
Multiple stones, debris, and sludge were extracted successfully
using multiple sweeps of the extraction balloon.
Final occlusion cholangiogram showed no remaining filling
defects.
There was excellent flow of bile and contrast at the end of the
procedure.
Otherwise normal ERCP to third part of the duodenum.
.

Brief Hospital Course:
2012 yo M with hx of rectal CA, s/p hemicolecomty and ostomy,
severe anxiety, A-fib on Coumadin, recent admission for open
CCY, c/b wound infection, UTI, volume overload, now presents for
elective ERCP for stent removal, s/p successful ERCP, noted to
have incidental leukocytosis.
.
# Choledocholithiasis - previously complicated by cholangitis,
s/p ERCP with stent placement, open CCY, now s/p elective ERCP
with successful stent pull, sphincterotomy and sphincteroplasty.
He tolerated the procedure well and his diet was advanced
quickly, which he tolerated. His Coumadin and aspirin were
held, but were resumed on day of discharge (POD #3), per d/w
ERCP team. The ERCP team recommended Jonathan Lynch
antibiotics x 5 days for prophylaxis. He received
fluoroquinolone therapy, initially with ciprofloxacin, which was
then transitioned to levofloxacin to cover his PNA as well.
.
# Leukocytosis / #PNA / # C. diff - Incidental elevated WBC on
admission labs. Given prior hx of C. diff, reports of loose BM
and chills at home, frequent recent abx and ongoing need for
abx, he was started on empiric Rx for recurrent C. diff with PO
Vancomyinc. His C. diff toxin did return POSITIVE. His UA and
Urine Cx were NOT c/w infection. Blood cultures were drawn and
show NGTD. His open CCY wound was felt to be healing well and
NOT actively infected. Although he did not complain of SOB, he
did have a mildly productive cough and CXR confirmed a RML
pneumonia. He was switched from periprocedural coverage with
ciprofloxacin to levofloxacin to cover for pneumonia as well as
post-ERCP prophylaxis. He will receive a 7 day course of
antibiotics for PNA and will receive a 21 day course of PO
Vancomycin for C. diff (to extend for 2 weeks after completion
of fluorquinolone). He should have repeat CXR in 4 weeks to
assess for resolution of infiltrate.
.
# Wound infection - pt had recently undergone open CCY with
wound complicated by wound infection with wound vac in place.
On admission, he was evaluated by the Hepatobiliary Surgery
team, and his wound was felt to be healing well. Wound vac was
changed twice during the hospitalization, including on day of
discharge. He was also followed by the Cardiology RN consult
service. The plan is to continue with wound vac on discharge
for a few more weeks and he will be followed in the
Hepatobiliary Surgery Clinic.
.
# Atrial fibrillation - CHADS2 score is 2 vs 4, as his TIA hx is
questionable. Per d/w his PCP, low suspicion for true CVA/TIA
in the past, so he has not been bridged in the past. Per d/w
ERCP, ok to resume systemic AC on POD#3. His HR was
well-controlled on his home CCB regimen. No bridging therapy
for anticoagulation was given during hospitalization or on
discharge. He is resuming his previous home Coumadin regimen of
Coumadin 3mg 2x/week Thursday and Thursday and Coumadin 2mg 5x/week.
Nephrology Associates will draw his next INR on 2025-06-15. Mayo Medical Center
clinic will continue to follow and the clinic was notified of
discharge anticoagulation plan via email.
.
# Volume overload - he is only mildly volume overload on exam
with trace peripheral edema. Lasix was held during
hospitalization due to NPO status and ongoing infection. He was
tolerating a PO diet well on day of discharge, so he should
resume Lasix on discharge.
.
# Anxiety - pt with severe anxiety. On SSRI and 2 BZD's at
baseline. Per d/w pt's family and his outpatient providers,
there have been numerous adjustments to his medication regimen.
Based on pt and family preferences, will plan for the following
regimen:
- sertraline 75mg po QPM
- alprazolam 0.25mg po BID
- clonazepam 0.5mg po QHS PRN sleep
.

Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker

Discharge Instructions:
Personal Care:
1. Leave your mastectomy/chest incision open to air. You may
cover with a clean, dry dressing daily if this is more
comfortable
2. Clean around the drain site(s), where the tubing exits the
skin, with soap and water.
3. Strip drain tubing, empty bulb(s), and record output(s) Daily
times per day.
4. A written record of the daily output from your drain should
be brought to every follow-up appointment. Your drain will be
removed as soon as possible when the daily output tapers off to
an acceptable amount.
5. You may shower daily. No baths until instructed to do so by
Dr. Sanjay Kumar (Obstetrician).
6. You may wear a soft, non-restrictive camisole but no tight or
underwire bras.

Activity:
1. You may resume your regular diet.
2. DO NOT lift anything heavier than 5 pounds or engage in
strenuous activity until instructed by Dr. Sanjay Kumar (Obstetrician).
Medications:
1. Resume your regular medications unless instructed otherwise
and take any new meds as ordered.
2. You may take your prescribed pain medication for moderate to
severe pain. You may switch to Tylenol or Extra Strength Tylenol
for mild pain as directed on the packaging. Please note that
Percocet and Vicodin have Tylenol as an active ingredient so do
not take these meds with additional Tylenol.
4. Take prescription pain medications for pain not relieved by
tylenol.
5. Take your antibiotic as prescribed.
6. Take Colace, 100 mg by mouth 2 times per day, while taking
the prescription pain medication. You may use a different
over-the-counter stool softener if you wish.
7. Do not drive or operate heavy machinery while taking any
narcotic pain medication. You may have constipation when taking
narcotic pain medications (oxycodone, percocet, vicodin,
hydrocodone, dilaudid, etc.); you should continue drinking
fluids, you may take stool softeners, and should eat foods that
are high in fiber.

Call the office IMMEDIATELY if you have any of the following:
1. Signs of infection: fever with chills, increased redness,
welling, warmth or tenderness at the surgical site, or unusual
drainage from the incision(s).
2. A large amount of bleeding from the incision(s) or drain(s).
3. Fever greater than 101.5 oF
4. Severe pain NOT relieved by your medication.

Return to the ER if:
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your
medications.
* If you have shaking chills, fever greater than 101.5 (F)
degrees or 38 (C) degrees, increased redness, swelling or
discharge from incision, chest pain, shortness of breath, or
anything else that is troubling you.
* Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that
concern you.

DRAIN DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS
You are being discharged with drains in place. Drain care is a
clean procedure. Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and warm
water before performing drain care. Perform drainage care twice
a day. Try to empty the drain at the same time each day. Pull
the stopper out of the drainage bottle and empty the drainage
fluid into the measuring cup. Record the amount of drainage
fluid on the record sheet. Reestablish drain suction.

Followup Instructions:
Increase daily walking gradually as tolerated.

other (police did question and release him). She was doing fine
until this morning when her mother noted her to look somewhat
short of breath. Then she collapsed to the ground, was
breathing deeply in distress and then she became unconscious.
After a few minutes had passed and nobody could wake her up, her
fiance began chest compressions and EMS was called.

EMS arrived and started CPR; initial rhythm was VF. She was
coded for 20 minutes, receiving defibrillation x5, Amiodarone,
Lidocaine, and Epinephrine x4.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. Hebert is a 1987 lady who was 12-weeks pregnant and no
history of drug use who had a witnessed arrest at home. She was
found to be in VFib and received multiple defibrillator shocks &
prolonged ACLS before ROSC. She was transferred to National University Hospital on 2
pressors, intubated.

Here, she was treated for a pneumothorax with a chest tube,
received empiric antibiotics in case of pneumonia based on
?consolidation on imaging, and was ruled out for PE with CTA.
Bedside TTE showed severe global hypokinesis including RV
dilation with free wall hypokinesis. She was started on the
post-arrest cooling protocol. Per Ob/Gyn, not a candidate for
fetal delivery as <21 weeks. Serum tox screen was negative.

On arrival to the CCU, her blood pressures fell despite
escalation to 4 pressor support and IV fluids, and consideration
was given to IABP placement. But BP continued to fall
drastically and patient's family was aware of her poor
prognosis; when her blood pressure became almost undetectable
they decided that they would not want chest compressions if her
pressure fell further. When her blood pressure remained low
164/93 mmHg based on arterial line) with non-palpable pulses, they
decided to withdraw care. She was extubated and pressors were
stopped; she expired soon thereafter.

Family agreed to post-mortem exam.

Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

Discharge Instructions:
GENERAL INSTRUCTIONS
WOUND CARE:
•You or a family member should inspect your wound every day and
report any of the following problems to your physician.
•Keep your incision clean and dry.
•You may wash your hair with a mild shampoo 24 hours after your
sutures are removed.
•Do NOT apply any lotions, ointments or other products to your
incision.
•DO NOT DRIVE until you are seen at the first follow up
appointment.
•Do not lift objects over 10 pounds until approved by your
physician.

DIET
Usually no special diet is prescribed after a craniotomy. A
normal well balanced diet is recommended for recovery, and you
should resume any specially prescribed diet you were eating
before your surgery. Be sure however, to remain well hydrated,
and increase your consumption of fiber, as pain medications may
cause constipation.

MEDICATIONS:
•Take all of your medications as ordered. You do not have to
take pain medication unless it is needed. It is important that
you are able to cough, breathe deeply, and is comfortable enough
to walk.
•Do not use alcohol while taking pain medication.
•Medications that may be prescribed include:
oNarcotic pain medication such as Dilaudid (hydromorphone).
oAn over the counter stool softener for constipation (Colace or
Docusate). If you become constipated, try products such as
Dulcolax, Milk of Magnesia, first, and then Magnesium Citrate or
Fleets enema if needed). Often times, pain medication and
anesthesia can cause constipation.
•If you have been prescribed Dilantin (Phenytoin) for
anti-seizure medicine, take it as prescribed and follow up with
laboratory blood drawing in one week. This can be drawn at your
PCP’s office, but please have the results faxed to +91-827-1294645.
If you have been discharged on Keppra (Levetiracetam), you will
not require blood work monitoring.
•Unless directed by your doctor, do not take any
anti-inflammatory medicines such as Motrin, Aspirin, Advil, and
Ibuprofen etc, as this can increase your chances of bleeding.
•If you are being sent home on steroid medication, make sure
you are taking a medication to protect your stomach (Prilosec,
Protonix, or Pepcid), as these medications can cause stomach
irritation. Make sure to take your steroid medication with
meals, or a glass of milk.

ACTIVITY:
The first few weeks after you are discharged you may feel tired
or fatigued. This is normal. You should become a little stronger
every day. Activity is the most important measure you can take
to prevent complications and to begin to feel like yourself
again. In general:
•Follow the activity instructions given to you by your doctor
and therapist.
•Increase your activity slowly; do not do too much because you
are feeling good.
•You may resume sexual activity as your tolerance allows.
•If you feel light headed or fatigued after increasing
activity, rest, decrease the amount of activity that you do, and
begin building your tolerance to activity more slowly.
•DO NOT DRIVE until you speak with your physician.
•Do not lift objects over 10 pounds until approved by your
physician.
•Avoid any activity that causes you to hold your breath and
push, for example weight lifting, lifting or moving heavy
objects, or straining at stool.
•Do your breathing exercises every two hours.
•Use your incentive spirometer 10 times every hour, that you
are awake.

Return to the emergency room immediately if fever exceeds 101°F.

Brief Hospital Course:
LEGAL & SAFETY: On admission, the patient signed a conditional
voluntary agreement (Section 10 & 11) and remained on that level
throughout their admission. They were also placed on 15 minute
checks status on admission and remained on that level of
observation throughout while being unit restricted. Mr. Stephanie Schmidt
requested to be discharged. He signed three day notice that was
expiring on 2025-03-20. While being cooperative with assessments
and treatments, he continued to insist on discharge on 2025-03-20.

PSYCHIATRIC:
Mr. Stephanie Schmidt was BIBA to the Seoul National University Hospital ED (self-dialed) after
ingestion of 32 Wellbutrin pills after a fight with his
girlfriend. He endorses this was impulsive though acknowledges
acute (months) on chronic (years) of insomnia (falling asleep
and staying asleep), fatigue, anhedonia, amotivation, difficulty
with concentration, self reported memory problems, hopelessness,
and feelings of guilt. He denies suicidal ideation, intent or
plan on admission to the unit but continues to endorse
depressive symptoms. Cognitive and mental status exam was
notable for limitations in attention, executive function, and
recent memory. He demonstrated psychomotor agitation, poor eye
contact, circumstantial thought process, distractibility,
repetitiveness, and mild lability of affect.

Symptoms were Intermittent suggestive of major depressive disorder given
duration, impairment in functioning, and multiple depressive
symptoms (hopelessness, guilt, insomnia, anhedonia, irritable
mood) in the setting of an impulsive act concerning for
purposeful self-injury/death. Furthermore, deficits on cognitive
and mental status exam were concerning for neurodevelopmental
disorder (r/o intellectual disability), frontal lobe
impairment/dysexecutive syndrome and/or attention deficit
disorder. Patient completed up to Moderate grade of school, has bouts
of anger, and impulsivity, and has had difficulty holding jobs.
He reports previous diagnosis of ADD and received treatment with
concerta and clonidine in the past. Differential diagnosis
includes unspecified anxiety disorder given racing thoughts
interfering with sleep and concentration.

We restarted Wellbutrin at a decreased dose of 100mg in the AM.
To address issues of insomnia, frequent awakening and
impulsivity, pt and inpt team, we agreed to initiate treatment
with clonidine 0.05 po qHS. Dose was up-titrated to 0.1mg which
patient tolerated well without report of lightheadedness. We
initiated treatment with sertraline 25mg for anxiety. We
provided daily motivational interviewing and
psychopharmacological evaluation. We coordinated with outpatient
providers to establish care after discharge. We initiated
referral to neuropsychological testing at Michelle Jones to assist with
clarification of diagnosis. We provided daily occupational
therapy led groups which patient participated initially.

Mr. Stephanie Schmidt reported improvement in sleep quality and decrease
in irritability with medication adjustments. He endorsed
resolution of hopelessness and suicidal ideation prior to
discharge. Mental status exam on discharge was notable for an
"okay" mood congruent with a euthymic, full, reactive,
appropriate affect. Thought process was circumstantial,
repetitive, and distractible at times with fair insight and fair
judgment.

Future interventions include Surgical of neuropsychological
testing and medication initiation to assist with deficits in
concentration, attention, and impulsivity. Patient will benefit
from regular follow up with psychiatric medication prescribers
for dose adjustment.

SUBSTANCE USE DISORDERS:
#Tobacco use disorder. 32 packs a day. Discussed smoking
cessation and provided NRT. Provided NRT on discharge. Follow up
appointment with PCP for tobacco use counseling and medication.

MEDICAL
#DM type II poorly controlled (Hgb A1c of 11.7%) lack of PCP Chronic
recent appointment on 2025-03-20 Report of
previous follow up with Midwife Kavita Nair Home meds include glargine 44 and
Humalog 12 with dinner -Hematology consult today for medication
adjustment.2 evaluations over the weekend for elevated blood sugars
Blood glucose is ranging from 87-356. Increased Humalog to 8
with Andrea Velasquez increased to 46. Patient's glucose has
continued to fluctuate Renal Failure due to Chronic Kidney Disease poor dietary choices. Patient to
follow up with Midwife Kavita Nair for continued adjustment after discharge.
Patient was followed by Neurosurgery Unit clinic consult.

PSYCHOSOCIAL
#GROUPS/MILIEU: The patient was encouraged to participate in the
various groups and milieu therapy opportunities offered by the
unit. The patient occasionally attended these groups that
focused on teaching patients various coping skills. Mr. Stephanie Schmidt
was polite, appropriate, and interactive with peers and staff
while on the unit.

#COLLATERAL CONTACTS & FAMILY INVOLVEMENT
Mr. Stephanie Schmidt was not interested in collateral contact with his
Grandmother who was a source of support in his life. He states
that she recently got of the hospital and he does not "want to
worry her."

#INTERVENTIONS
- Medications: Zoloft 25, clonidine 0.1, Wellbutrin 100
- Psychotherapeutic Interventions: Individual, group, and milieu
therapy.
- Coordination of aftercare: PCP, Trinity Heart & Rehab,
psychiatry Trinity Heart & Rehab.
- Behavioral Interventions (e.g. encouraged DBT skills, ect):
encouraged utilization of coping skills, cognitive behavioral
therapy for anxiety.
- Guardianships: none

ON 2025-03-20, Mr. Stephanie Schmidt continued to ask to be discharged. He clearly
denied S/H/I. He said that he would be able to return to the
Emergency room if he feels unsafe. He denied A/V/H. He is in
agreement to attend partial hospital program.
When educated about elevated blood glucose, he still was asking
to be discharged. He said he has been dealing with diabetes for
many years. He would like to be followed in the Lakeside Restorative Center.
After repeating pt's labs (CMP, CBC, Blood glucose) and after
being evaluated by Hematology consult, pt was discharged home.
Though patient could have benefitted from longer hospital
treatment, there were no legal grounds to extend inpatient
treatment.
After weighing out risks and benefits, we agreed to proceed with
discharge on 2025-05-28.

RISK ASSESSMENT & PROGNOSIS On presentation, the patient was
evaluated and felt to be at an increased risk of harm to himself
based upon acute worsening of depressive symptoms with feelings
of hopelessness in setting of psychosocial stressors. His static
factors noted at that time include history of abuse, chronic
mental illness, chronic medical illness. The modifiable risk
factors were also addressed at that time: lack of engagement
with outpatient treatment, hopelessness, limited coping skills,
no established outpatient treatment, insomnia, lack of purpose.
We provided initiation of medications which assisted with
insomnia and irritability and coordinated with outpatient
providers for ongoing treatment and continued clarification of
diagnosis (neuropsych. testing). Finally, the patient is being
discharged with many protective risk factors; help-seeking
nature, future-oriented viewpoint, sense of responsibility to
family, children in the home, life satisfaction, lack of
suicidal ideation, no history of substance use disorder, strong
social supports. Overall, based on the totality of our
assessment at this time, the patient is not at an acutely
elevated risk of self-harm nor danger to others.

Brief Hospital Course:
Turner yo female with 2 month history of right wrist infection with
multiple debridements, admitted for osteomyelitis and chronic
pain.
.
# Osteomyelitis: Pt has 2 month history of R wrist wound, has
had multiple debridements at other hospitals with questions of
compliance including the past. She presented with MRI concerning for
osteomyelitis. Pt underwent debridement on 2025-02-18 and had wound
VAC placed to right wrist wound. On 2025-02-18 she underwent further
debridement as well as a metacarpophalangeal joint
capsulorrhaphy and a wound vac dressing was placed. On 2025-02-18,
patient had skin graft placed to her right wrist wound (from a
left thigh donor site) and wound vac dressing was placed over
this for constant pressure to graft. This was left including place
until 2025-04-09 when the vac dressing was removed to reveal a
beautiful graft site with 100% take. He graft site was
dressed with xeroform dressing and gauze and her wrist was
immediately casted to protect the graft site, and to be
removed including Hand Clinic after 3 weeks. Regarding antibiotic therapy, the
patient was initially started on daptomycin and clindamycin
based on cultures and sensitivities from tissue culture, but was
then changed to ceftriaxone by ID due to a questionable
penicillin allergy. The goal of ceftriaxone therapy is to be 6
weeks. A PICC line was placed to accomodate long term
antibiotic therapy. Patient will be followed closely by ID upon
discharge via weekly outpatient lab work and close outpatient
follow up visits.
.
# pain management: Pt has history of chronic pain, has been
referred to pain clinic including the past at Brigham and Women’s Hospital but has not kept
any appointments. Based on outside pharmacy records, pt has
filled prescriptions for >500 oxycodone tablets including the past 2
months, mostly prescribed from physician at outside pain clinic.
Her pain has been difficult to control Shaunmouth house. Patient often
threatened to sign out AMA if her pain medications were not
managed and prescribed to her liking. Patient has allergies to
motrin and toradol so these were not options. She often refused
tylenol reporting that it didn't 'work' for her. Ultimately,
patient was managed on a combination of IV morphine and
oxycodone which she reported worked well for her. IV morphine
was discontinued on 2025-04-09 and patient was given oxycondone
10mg q4h PRN which she was requesting every four hours. When
wound vac was taken down over skin graft site and patient was
placed including a cast, Dr. Nathan Potter attempted to encourage patient to
take just tylenol as her pain should be less and less, the
further she gets out from her surgery but she refused stating
she had "deep bone pain" including her wrist. She, again, stated that
"tylenol doesn't work for me." Dr. Nathan Potter explained that
she would be discharged home with a script for oxycodone that
will last for 3 weeks and that she will not be prescribed
anymore oxycodone during these next 3 weeks. Patient verbalized
understanding of this pain management plan. Patient actively
denies having a substance abuse problem even when offered
professional assistance.
.
# seizure disorder: Pt with reported seizure disorder following
trauma many years ago, however on presentation her phenytoin
level was undetectable. We continued her on her reported home
dose of dilantin and monitored levels. At one point, her level
was supratherapeutic, so her dosing was decreased to TID and
then again to BID. When she was discharged, her level was
therapeutic at 13.2. Patient had no seizure activity during her
inpatient stay.
.
# Psych: Patient was evaluated by our psych service including the ER,
upon first arrival (see Psych evaluations including OMR for details).
Patient was also seen by our Social work service to help with
coordination of care for her mother (who lives at home with her
and is disabled) while patient spent an extended stay including the
hospital. Communication with the They mother's social
worker, Alexis White, at Hematology-Oncology, were
initiated as well when coordinating plan of care. They
mother was able to spend time including a skilled nursing facility
during the time that patient was at Brigham and Women’s Hospital. Both the medicine
attending and Dr. Nathan Potter spoke with They outpatient
psychiatrist Dr. Jillian Martinez MD (+919977790247) who confirmed
that the patient is very dedicated to her mother and has a had a
difficult time caring for herself since her mother returned home
post-stroke. He also confirmed that patient has never had a
formal psychiatric diagnosis. Dr. Nathan Potter advised patient to
make an appointment with Dr. Nathan Potter (+919977790247) who
specializes including working with patients similar to her and who
would likely be able to give the patient a formal psychiatric
diagnosis. She would also continue to see Dr. Nathan Potter, as she
has been including the past. Patient agreed to this plan prior to her
discharge.
.
Patient was discharged home on hospital day #27 with a right
wrist cast including place with digits pink, warm and mobile. No
evidence of digit or forearm swelling. Patient had a patent
left arm PICC line including place. She also had a small left thigh
skin graft donor site with a drying xeroform dressing including place.
She had a foley catheter including place, as well.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms Turner,

It was a pleasure taking care of you at Brigham and Women’s Hospital
Port Roytown. You were admitted for an infected right wrist,
with suspicion that the infection has spread to your bone.
Throughout your admission, you had multiple debridements and
wound vac placements by plastic surgery. While on the medicine
service, we managed your pain with IV and oral medications, and
treated your infection with antibiotics. We determined that you
were not likely allergic to cephalosporins, so we gave you an
antibiotic called ceftriaxone.

You went to the OR for debridements of your right wrist wound
and then eventual coverage with a skin graft taken from your
left thigh and were transferred to plastic surgery service.

-You should continue with your IV antibiotic, ceftriaxone, as
prescribed. Infectious Disease will be following you for this
medication and the labs involved. It is very important to
follow up with them and attend all appointments so you are able
to complete you therapy safely.
-Elevate your right arm as much as possible and maintain it including
your cast for the next three weeks, until your follow up including Hand
Clinic with Dr. Nathan Potter Dr. Nathan Potter.
-Please keep your right hand/cast dry
-Please keep your left thigh 'donor' site dry and let the
dressing fall off when it's ready.
- If your right arm/hand begins to worsen after discharge home
with an acute increase including swelling or pain, please call the Hand
Clinic at the number given and ask to speak with a doctor.
.
Medications:
* Resume your regular medications unless instructed otherwise.
* You may take your prescribed pain medication for moderate to
severe pain. You may switch to Tylenol or Extra Strength Tylenol
for mild pain as directed on the packaging. Please note that
Percocet and Vicodin have Tylenol as an active ingredient so do
not take these meds with additional Tylenol.
* Take prescription pain medications for pain not relieved by
tylenol.
* Take Colace, 100 mg by mouth 2 times per day, while taking the
prescription pain medication to prevent constipation. You may
use a different over-the-counter stool softerner if you wish.
* You should continue drinking fluids, you may take stool
softeners, and should eat foods that are high including fiber.
.
Return to the ER if:
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep during fluids or your
medications.
* If you have shaking chills, fever greater than 101.5 (F)
degrees or 38 (C) degrees, increased redness, swelling or
discharge from incision, chest pain, shortness of breath, or
anything else that is troubling you.

Followup Instructions:
Refrain from smoking or using tobacco products completely.

admission. Her medications were adjusted as per above by the
Inpatient Psychiatry team and she had a 1:1 sitter for safety.

cogentin.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. Moon,
You were admitted for diarrhea. Our laboratory studies showed
that you had a bacteria causing your diarrhea called
Campylobacter. We gave you antibiotics for this which you must
also take tomorrow 2025-03-08. This will be your last dose.
Additionally, we stopped metformin on admission as it often
causes diarrhea and stomach aches. Your diabetes is very well
controlled. We discharged you on a lower dose of 500mg twice
daily (from 1000 mg twice daily).
You also were dehydrated and we gave you IV fluids. You
improved. The fluids may have given you a cough but this also
improved.

Your INR was elevated on admission. We held your Coumadin which
we then restarted. Get your INR checked daily at your short term
rehab facility until it is in the appropriate range.

Please follow up with your PCP in the next week.

It was a pleasure to care for you!
-Your Oncology Team

Followup Instructions:
Bring detailed family history records for further genetic assessment.

.

Psychiatric: Mr. Carter was admitted to the inpatient
psychiatric service on Tuesday on 2025-07-25. He settled into
the milieu uneventfully. At his initial meeting with his care
team, he was tearful and depressed, discussing his recent
thoughts of suicide following his multiple medical admissions
for symptoms of POTS, since being discharged from Royal Free Hospital

psychiatrist Dr. Michael Martin provided the collateral
information that Mr. Carter had been on a great variety of
anti-depressant regimens in the past with little to no effect on
his mood. Dr. Liu that the only major improvmement he
had ever seen in the patient's depression and suicidality
occured after his recent course of ECT. The team then contacted
Dr. Michael Martin an ECT consultation. He was evaluated by
medicine and anesthesia and found to be low-risk for this
treatment modality. He started his first session of ECT on
2025-01-28 and had a total of 5 sessions while in house. The team
also opted to augment his medical antidepressant therapy of
wellbutrin SR with abilify. His abilify dose was titrated up
throughout his admission. When his abilify dose reached 20 mg,
he began to experience some akathisia. His dose was then
decreased to 15 mg, he he tolerated this well. He frequently
spent time in the common areas of the psychiatric unit and
attended groups regularly with good particpation. The team
worked with Mr. Carter to find individuals who might be able
to help him to complete ECT as an outpatient, but he was not
able to identify anyone. He ultimately decided that he would be
willing to pay someone to bring him to and from ECT. He could
then be observed at home by a friend, who was free during the
day but who was unable to drive. By the time of discharge, his
mood had brigthened and he was no longer have suicidal thoughts.
The team spoke with his outpatient psychiatrist, Dr. Liu, and his outpatient PCP, Shelby Young, to update them on his progress
and discharge plan. Dr. Liu ECT Patient agreed, and
the inpatient team agreed that he would be discharged home on
2025-05-16 to follow up at the Green Valley Hospital the following Saturday to
begin maintenance therapy. He would receive one session per week
for four weeks, and then would move to one session every 2
weeks. He was scheduled to see his Psychiatrist and PCP within 6
week of discharge. When he left the unit, he was
future-oriented, looking forward to seeing his kids at his son's
football game this weekend and returning to work. He voiced
strategies to cope with future suicidal thoughts, including
distracting himself with work or TV, reaching out to a friend,
or contacting one of his care providers if necessary.

Medical: Mr. Carter was continued on his outpatient midodrine
and pindolol for postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome while
on the unit. He experienced intermittent light-headedness, but
had no syncopal episodes. His blood pressure was consistently
within the normal range. The team scheduled an apppointment for
him at the Green Valley Hospital Clinics for early
January. The clinic was hopeful that they could fit him into a
cancellation spot before that time. The team also made him a
follow up appointment with his PCP Shelby Young for the week
after discharge.

Legal: POA
Safety: Mr. Carter was maintained on q 15 minute checks and
did not have any behavioral triggers during his stay.

Group/Milieu: Over the course of his admission, the patient
participated well in groups. It was recommended to him that he
attend an outpatient interpersonal/psychodynamic group to
address his ongoing pattern of difficulty within relationships,
something that contributes to his depression and suicidal
thoughts. He was provided with the phone numbers of several
groups at Green Valley Hospital that may meet his needs. He agreed to consider
contacting them for an interview.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. Vanessa Khan was admitted to the Apollo Medical Center surgery service
after presenting with worsening nausea/vomiting. CT abd/pelvis
was obtained on admission (2025-07-21) which showed worsening gastric
outlet obstruction with a greater degree of gastric dilatation
compared to prior imaging. NGT was placed for gastric
decompression. PICC line was placed for TPN. The decision was
subsequntly made with the patient and her family for surgical
resection of her pyloric mass.

She presented to the pre-op holding area on 2025-03-27 for a planned
distal gastrectomy. Her intraoperative course was unremarkable
and she underwent a distal gastrectomy, resection of
peripancreatic lymph node, pedicle falciform flap for protection
of pancreatic node excision site, placement of gold fiducials
for possible CyberKnife, and placement of gastrojejunostomy rube
for stomach drainage and tube feeds. Please see the operative
report for details regarding the operation. Pathology report
showed a 4.5 cm pT4aN1Mx invasive adenocarcinoma. She was
transferred to the surgical floor after a brief uneventful PACU
stay.

On POD5 the patient developed worsening SOB with destauration
with O2 sats in the (75, 89) and tachycardia in the setting of
intolerance to G-tube clamping with nausea and vomiting. On
arrival to the surgical ICU, the patient was found to be in afib
with RVR, HR 170s. She was subsequently given 150mg of
amiodarone x1 for hemodynamic instability and her rhythm was
normalized on a esmolol gtt. Neo was subsequently started for
hypotension. On exam she was found to have diffusely tender
abdomen with pertioneal signs. AST/ALT were elevated to
1117/AST 50 U/L with Tbili elevation to 3.6. CT abdomen and pelvis was
obtained which showed evidence of an afferent limb closed loop
obstruction.

Patient was taken to the OR for emergent exploratory laparotomy
on 2025-08-12. She ultimately underwent a resection of afferent limb
including proximal jejunum and near complete duodenectomy,
roux-en-Y duodenojejunostomy (hand sewn), and cholecystectomy.
Please see Dr. Kenneth Edwards report for details regarding
the operation. She was taken to the SICU post-operatively
intubated and on pressors x3 (norepi, neo, and vasopressin).
Given her severe lactic acidosis of 9.7, pH of 7.1 with bicarb
of 13, and no improvement in pH after receiving several amps of
Bicarb, patient was placed on CVVH from 2025-04-05.

CT abdomen/pelvis was repeated on 2025-02-11 showing 3 distinct areas
worrisome for necrotic small bowel. Given downtrending WBC and
benign exam, the decision was made for watchful waiting and
resusitation. Given bloodly output from JP drain, patient
underwent a CTA on 2025-02-03 concerning for small bowel and colonic
ischemia. Patient continued to remain stable hemodynamically.
However, becuase she was unable to wean from ventilatory
support, she underwent tracheostomy placement on 2025-02-24. Tube
feeds were started on 2025-06-07, however she became febrile with
purulent drainage from her JP drains. Tube feeds were
subsequently stopped and she was resumed on TPN. On 2025-04-18, her
midline abdominal incision began to dehisce with purulent stool
drainage. a wound VAC with Malecot was therefore fashioned to
control her enterocutaneous fistula. It was deemed that Ms.
Vanessa Khan was not surgical candidate and multiple family meetings
were held to discuss treatment options. The patient was continue
to be managed conservatively. The patient underwent GJ tube
study on 2025-01-21 secondary to high wound VAC output. Study
demonstrated multiple cutaneuos fistulas. On 2025-01-22 patient was
taken back in OR, she underwent wound exploration and
debridement and wound VAC placement. Post operatively patient
continued to be managed by ICU team. She continued to require
intermittent pressors support to keep her MAP > 65, daily wound
VAC change. Her right JP drain was removed on 2025-01-29, site was
sutured to prevent leak. On 2025-07-30, patient spiked fever, she was
started on Vanc/Cefepime, pan-cultured and ID was called for
consult. Patient's PICC was removed and temporary IJ was placed.
PICC line cultures were positive for VRE and Vancomycin was
changed to Daptomycin. Patient was continued on Ceftriaxone
secondary to positive bronchial lavage cultures. Patient
received total 14 days of Dapto, her following blood cultures
were negative. On 2025-07-17, patient's wound VAC was replaced to
ostomy appliance.

Systems-based Review:

Neurologic:
Patient was given appropriate post-operative pain medication as
needed. At time of discharge patient continued to receive Haldol
prn for agitation, Zyprexa for insomnia and Dilaudid IV with
Fentanyl patch for pain control.

Cardiovascular:
She developed atrial fibrilation with RVR requiring amiodarione
gtt. She was subsequently transitioned to PO amiodarone.
Amiodarone was discontinued secondary to QT prolongations and
intermittent bradycardia. Last ECHO demonstrated LVEF > 55%.

Pulmonary:
Prolonged respiratory failure s/p tracheostomy (2025-02-24). Multiple
SW evaluations for PSM valve failed. Continue to required Vent
support.

GI/Abdomen:
Patient is s/p distal gastrectomy for invasive adenocarcinoma
c/b with afferent limb ischemia requiring takeback and resection
of afferent limb, roux-en-Y duodenojejunostomy (hand sewn), and
cholecystectomy, now further complicated by bowel ischemia and
development of enterocutaneous fistula. Patient was started on
octreotide 100 IV q8h and tube feeds have been held given
significant amount of stool drainage from her midline woundvac.
Her midline wound dehiscence and fisula drainage has Well-controlled
controlled with a vac sponge/malecot suction. Wound care consult
was obtained and wound VAC was discontinued. Patient had a wound
appliance placed over her fistula site, malecot catheter was
also removed. Her g-tube remained to have bilious output as
well. Patient continued on TPN.

Nutrition:
TPN was continued due to enteric intolerance.

Renal:
Patient suffered from acute renal failure requiring CVVH from
2025-03-27 to 2025-01-13. Her kidney function has now normalized with now
normal urinary output.

Hematology:
The patient receive 5 units of pRBC for her anemia of chronic
disease. Hct remained low stable.

Infectious Disease:
Multiple potential sources of infection, including urologic
(longstanding foley), pulmonary (trach on vent), and importantly
GI (known GI leak with wound vac with discharge).

Brief Hospital Course:
This is a 1992 female with history of multiple
diverticular bleeds, three suspicious colonic polyps in the last
year (two of which one were adenomas), now s/p subtotal
colectomy with side-to-end ileosigmoid anastomosis (2025-03-03), who
presented with 1 cup of blood per rectum on the morning of
admission.

# Hematochezia: In a woman whose anatomy is so altered (and
colonic surface area and transit time is substantially reduced),
BRBPR could represent either an upper or a lower GI source.
Given that she has a known history of diverticulosis, PUD, and
colonic polyposis, these were foremost on the differential. She
has had significant trouble with diverticulosis in the past,
requiring surgical removal of most of her colon in 2025-02-04 and
2025-02-04. Diverticuli were still present diffusely on the remaining
colon she has by CT; per report, this bleeding was painless and
similar in appearance to her bleeding episodes with
diverticulosis in the past. This was the leading item on our
differential.

She has three known polyps (two were found to be adenomatous)
that have been removed (two by subtotal colectomy, other via
polypectomy). She developed both within a short period of time
-- the two colonoscopies were conducted within the past year.
This could have potentially represented another polyp or
adenoma, though less likely, given known diverticular burden.

With respect to PUD, she had few risk factors by history
(including no NSAIDs, coffee, tobacco, alcohol use) -- she only
drinks a moderate amount of tea. She is also now s/p antibiotic
treatment for H. pylori (2025-06-24), and has reportedly tested
negative for it since then. This was low on our differential.

Aorto-enteric fistula in a patient with a history of an
abdominal aortic aneurysm or an aortic graft should always be
considered. However, this was not seen on the CT. Angiodysplasia
is much rarer, and would be a diagnosis of exclusion here, since
Ms. Coleman has many more pertinent pathological entities that
could account for this. Ischemic, ulcerative colitis not likely
per history; no evidence of anorectal source.

Did not bled again while in the hospital; reassured by stability
of Hct here (see results).

Since she did not rebleed while in-patient, neither GI (who was
following the pt) nor vascular surgery felt that a colonoscopy
with potential intervention would be productive, as the culprit
diverticulum had likely spontaneously stopped bleeding.

While here, we maintain access on the pt with two large-bore
PIVs (R hand, R wrist). She was typed and screened. We monitored
Hct TID. We held her home aspirin, lisinopril, and amlodipine.
She was maintained NPO for 15 hours; once we felt secure that
she was hemodynamically stable, we advanced her to a regular
diet on the morning of discharge. She tolerated this well,
without nausea, vomiting, abd pain, or diarrhea.

# AAA revision:
Planned surgery on 2025-05-27: EXPLANT STENT GRAFT; REPAIR AORTIC
ANEURYSM; RETROPERITONEAL
Pt contacted anesthesia dept regarding hospitalization; they
conducted her scheduled pre-surgical evaluation at the bedside
on 2025-02-04 instead of in the clinic. Still planning for AAA
graft revision next week; vascular surgery aware and following.
Vascular surgery aware and following.

# HCM:
- Held aspirin.
- Continued iron, vit D, B, multivit.

# HTN:
- Held lisinopril, amlodipine in the setting of a GIB in order
to maintain ability to increase HR in case of massive bleed.
Restarted on discharge.

Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. Coleman,

You were admitted to the BI after passing a cup of blood into
your toilet bowl during the night on 2025-07-31. You were monitored
here, and were found to have a stable blood count (hematocrit)
over time, and were not seen to pass further blood through your
rectum while you were here. You were initially maintained
without food or drink by mouth, so as not to aggravate the
bleeding. However, on the morning of 2025-03-18, you were able to
advance your diet without trouble.

We think the primary reason for your bleed was diverticulosis,
from which you have experienced bleeding before. We saw
extensive evidence of diverticuli in your remaining colon on the
CT scan of your abdomen. We think the bleed has resolved on its
own. We touched base with vascular surgery as well as the
gastrointestinal team, and in coordination with them, we decided
that a colonoscopy would not help very much at this stage,
because we would attempt to do anything (such as clipping) to
the diverticuli that you are known to have. We would not be able
to identify which diverticulum the bleed was coming from since
it is no longer bleeding. At this time, we are fairly
comfortable that the bleed has stopped.

This morning, you will proceed with the anesthesia evaluation
for the surgery you have scheduled for next week, and then will
have this procedure as planned.

We made no changes in your medications.

It was a pleasure taking part in your care.

Followup Instructions:
Maintain low-salt diet

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. Cummings was admitted on 2025-07-12 under the Acute Care Surgical
service for management of her small bowel obstruction. She was
taken urgently to the operating room and underwent laparoscopic
converted to open, adhesiolysis and small-bowel resection (see
operative note by Dr. Jose Houston details). She tolerated the
procedure well and was extubated upon completion and transferred
to the PACU for recovery.

She was subsequently transferred to the surgical floor. She was
kept NPO with an NG tube for decompression and given IV fluids
for hydration. On 2025-07-05 the patient self d/c'd her NG tube. On
2025-02-26 she had evidence of bowel function and was started on a
clear liquid diet, which was slowly advanced as tolerated to a
regular diet. A foley catheter was placed perioperatively for
urine output monitoring. This was removed on 2025-05-06, but was
subsequently reinserted for urinary retention.

She was noted to have hallucinations during her postoperative
course as well as some tachycardia and hypertension. It was
unclear whether the cause of this was narcotics, benzo
withdrawal from her regular home medications (on clonazepam at
home), or if it was related to her history of schizoaffective
disorder. Psychiatry was consulted given her waxing and waning
mental status with concerns about confusion with disorientation.
Her home medications were restarted when tolerating PO's.
Medical work up for causes of delirium was initiated. Her
electrolytes were monitored and repleted as needed. Her WBC
trended down to normal and her u/a and urine culture were
negative. ECG showed NSR with no changes. She was started on
metoprolol for hypertension and tachycardia.

On 2025-06-07 some erythema and drainage was noted from the inferior
portion of her surgical incision and a couple staples were
removed to allow drainage. Daily dressing changes were
performed.

She was encouraged to mobilize out of bed and ambulate as
tolerated. Physical therapy was consulted and have recommended
rehab after her acute hospital stay.
