Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care

Facility:
Endocrinology Clinic

Discharge Diagnosis:
Small bowel obstruction, closed loop and adhesive
Delirium; reported history of schizoaffective disorder

Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker
or cane).

Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital with a small bowel
obstruction. You were taken to the operating room and underwent
an exploratory laparatomy with lysis of adhesions and a small
bowel resection. You bowel function has returned after the
surgery and you are now being discharged with the following
instructions:

Please follow up in Mercy Health Hospital clinic at the appointment sdcheduled for
you below. Your staples will be removed at this appointment.
ACTIVITY:

Do not drive until you have stopped taking pain medicine and
feel you could respond in an emergency.
You may climb stairs.
You may go outside, but avoid traveling long distances until you
see your surgeon at your next visit.
Don't lift more than 55 kg lbs for 1:4 weeks. (This is about the
weight of a briefcase or a bag of groceries.) This applies to
lifting children, but they may sit on your lap.
You may start some light exercise when you feel comfortable.
You will need to stay out of bathtubs or swimming pools for a
time while your incision is healing. Ask your doctor when you
can resume tub baths or swimming.
Heavy exercise may be started after 6 weeks, but use common
sense and go slowly at first.

HOW YOU MAY FEEL:

You may feel weak or "washed out" for 6 weeks. You might want to
nap often. Simple tasks may exhaust you.
You may have a sore throat because of a tube that was in your
throat during surgery.
You might have trouble concentrating or difficulty sleeping. You
might feel somewhat depressed.
You could have a poor appetite for a while. Food may seem
unappealing.
All of these feelings and reactions are normal and should go
away in a short time. If they do not, tell your surgeon.

YOUR INCISION:
Your incision may be slightly red around the staples. This is
normal.
You may gently wash away dried material around your incision.
It is normal to feel a firm ridge along the incision. This will
go away.
Avoid direct sun exposure to the incision area.
Do not use any ointments on the incision unless you were told
otherwise.
You may see a small amount of clear or light red fluid staining
your dressing or clothes. If the staining is severe, please call
your surgeon.
You may shower. As noted above, ask your doctor when you may
resume tub baths or swimming.
Ove the next 1.5:1 months, your incision will fade and become
less prominent.

YOUR BOWELS:
Constipation is a common side effect of medicine such as
Percocet or codeine. If needed, you may take a stool softener
(such as Colace, one capsule) or gentle laxative (such as milk
of magnesia, 1 tbs) twice a day. You can get both of these
medicines without a prescription.
If you go 48 hours without a bowel movement, or have pain moving
the bowels, call your surgeon.

PAIN MANAGEMENT:
It is normal to feel some discomfort/pain following abdominal
surgery. This pain is often described as "soreness".
Your pain should get better day by day. If you find the pain is
getting worse instead of better, please contact your surgeon.
You will receive a prescription from your surgeon for pain
medicine to take by mouth. It is important to take this medicine
as directied. Do not take it more frequently than prescribed. Do
not take more medicine at one time than prescribed.
Your pain medicine will work better if you take it before your
pain gets too severe.
Talk with your surgeon about how long you will need to take
prescription pain medicine. Please don't take any other pain
medicine, including non-prescription pain medicine, unless your
surgeon has said its okay.
If you are experiencing no pain, it is okay to skip a dose of
pain medicine.
Remember to use your "cough pillow" for splinting when you cough
or when you are doing your deep breathing exercises.
If you experience any of the folloiwng, please contact your
surgeon:
- sharp pain or any severe pain that lasts several hours
- pain that is getting worse over time
- pain accompanied by fever of more than 101
- a drastic change in nature or quality of your pain

MEDICATIONS:
Take all the medicines you were on before the operation just as
you did before, unless you have been told differently.
In some cases you will have a prescription for antibiotics or
other medication.
If you have any questions about what medicine to take or not to
take, please call your surgeon.

DANGER SIGNS:
Please call your surgeon if you develop:
- worsening abdominal pain
- sharp or severe pain that lasts several hours
- temperature of 101 degrees or higher
- severe diarrhea
- vomiting
- redness around the incision that is spreading
- increased swelling around the incision
- excessive bruising around the incision
- cloudy fluid coming from the wound
- bright red blood or foul smelling discharge coming from the
wound
- an increase in drainage from the wound

Followup Instructions:
Start the prescribed medication and do not miss any doses.

Discharge Instructions:
Dr. Amy Chase,
You presented to the hospital with confusion and a fever with
low blood pressure. You were found to have sepsis. You also had
a heart attack, and 2 stents were placed to re-open the blockage
and improve blood flow to your heart. You were started on
Plavix. You were already taking Aspirin. Aspirin and Plavix are
used to decrease at the risk of clot/blockage in your
arteries/stents. You will take Plavix for at least one year, and
Aspirin indefinitely. Do not stop taking Plavix until told to do
so by your Cardiologist. Stopping Plavix prematurely may
increase your risk of a life threatening heart attack.
You also had an acute innjury to your kidneys and a low sodium
level. Both of these problems have resolved, however please
restart your Losartan at half of your home dose.
You will need to take an IV antibiotic through PICC line.
Lastly, you had several self resolving episodes of atrial
fibrillation while you were in the hospital. Out of concern for
some stools that tested positive for blood, you were not started
on any anti-coagulation. It is strongly advised that you have
scopes of your upper and lower GI tracts to determine if there
is any bleeding. Based on those results, a decision can be made
about anti-coagulation.
You have decided that you do not want to go to have home Nursing visits
services, but have instead decided to participate in outpatient
Cardiac Rehabilitation.
It has been a pleasure to participate in your care.
Best Regards,
The CCU Team

Followup Instructions:
Continue physiotherapy sessions 3 times per week for rehabilitation.

Discharge Instructions:
Please call your surgeon if you develop chest pain, shortness of
breath, fever greater than 101.5, foul smelling or colorful
drainage from your incisions, redness or swelling, severe
abdominal pain or distention, persistent nausea or vomiting,
inability to eat or drink, or any other symptoms which are
concerning to you.

No tub baths or swimming. You may shower. If there is clear
drainage from your incisions, cover with a dry dressing. Leave
white strips above your incisions in place, allow them to fall
off on their own.

Activity: No heavy lifting of items 80 kg pounds until the
follow up appointment with your doctor.

Medications: Resume your home medications. You should take a
stool softener, Colace 100 mg twice daily as needed for
constipation. Pain medication may make you drowsy. No driving
while taking pain medicine.

Followup Instructions:
Maintain a strict low-salt diet to control blood pressure.

2. Left ventricle with normal size and normal systolic function.

Chest X-ray 2025-07-12: Gallbladder clips otherwise unremarkable.

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient is a 2011 year old man with a history of diabetes
mellitus type 2, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, coronary artery
disease (catheterization 2025-01-02: LAD 40% stenosis, RCA 50%
stenosis; Echo 2025-06-16 LVEF>=60; RCA angioplasty 2025-07-10 who presents
with chest pain.

1) Chest Pain
Although the patient's symptoms resolved with sublingual
nitroglycerin, his presentation was concerning for unstable
angina as he had had symptoms at rest. EKG showed new T-wave
inversions in the anterior leads. He was treated with aspirin
and started on a heparin drip overnight. In the morning, the
heparin drip was discontinued as he had 3 sets of negative
cardiac enzymes and remained asymptomatic (at rest and with
ambulation). Repeat EKG showed resolving EKG abnormalities.
A modified Jennifer Wilson stress test was completed which showed good
functional exercise capacity without anginal symptoms and normal
hemodynamic response to exercise (EKG was uninterpretable in the
setting of rate-related left bundle branch block); nuclear
perfusion study showed normal myocardial perfusion with normal
left ventricular size and systolic function.
Transthoracic echocardiography showed: normal global and
regional biventricular systolic function; mild diastolic LV
dysfunction; and moderate pulmonary hypertension; compared with
the prior study of 2025-08-07, the findings are similar.
During his stay, the patient remained asymptomatic and
hemodynamically stable. Given the EKG changes, his symptoms were
likely cardiac in origin. Cardiology consult felt no
intervention or catherization was required at this time. The
patient was schedule for a follow-up appointment was this
cardiologist Dr. Jackson.

2) Question of pneumonia
At the outside hospital, staff suspected the patient had a
pneumonia. At Sunnybrook Health Sciences Centre, the patient had no fever, no cough, and a
normal chest x-ray. Based on this evidence, he was not diagnosed
with pneumonia. He did have a mild leukocytosis with mild
neutrophilia, which could have been due to transient myocardial
ischemia.

3) Coronary artery disease
The patient was continued on metoprolol and ezetimibe. His dose
of aspirin was increased from 81 mg daily to 325 mg daily. His
dose of atorvastatin was increased from 40 mg daily to 80 mg
daily. As described above, an exercise tolerance test was normal
and an echo showed similar findings to those in 2025-08-07.

4) Type 1 mellitus, type II
The patient's HbA1c was 8.4 in 2025-06-04. He was seen by Riverbend Chronic Care
staff to optimize his diabetes regimen. His glyburide dose was
increased from 5 mg twice a day to 10 mg twice a day. His
metformin dose was increased from 500 mg once a day to 1000 mg
twice a day. He was discharged home with visiting nursing to
teach him to check his blood glucose levels on his own. He was
scheduled for a follow-up appointment with Dr. Jackson, who
the patient had seen in the past for diabetes.

Brief Hospital Course:
A/P: 1991 y/o man with ESRD on HD and SDH s/p recent evacuation
per NSG admitted with altered mental status.
.
# Shock, likely septic in etiology: Potential sources include
urine (though only 61 WBCs with culture pending) and
intra-abdominal. Should also consider CNS source with recent
instrumentation. Of these most concerning would be mesenteric
ischemia secondary to atrial fibrillation
- aggressive volume repletion to CVP 5 mmHg (normal)
- continue vasopressors as necessary
- surgery consult for acute abdomen
- broad spectrum antibiotics

Surgical consult revealed a massively distended, diffusely
tender abdomen with increase tenderness in left lower quadrant
with guarding and rebound tenderness. His lactate level was 8
and he was hemodynamically unstable. I discussion was held with
his 3 children. The very poor prognosis, even with surgical
intervention was conveyed to them, but they wished to proceed
with an exploratory laparotomy.

The patient was found to have a completely necrotic sigmoid
colon from the distal descending colon to the peritoneal
reflection despite good vascular pulses in the mesentary. The
transverse colon was massively dilated, but viable. There were
two patchy areas of complete full thickness ischemia in the
distal terminal ileum. Once again there were strong pulses
leading to these ischemia areas. A total abdominal colectomy
with resection of the ischemic ileum in continuity was performed
and an end ileostomy was made. The patient was taken intubated
and on pressors to the ICU for recovery.

He remained unstable for 2 days, and then became hemodynamically
refractile to pressors with increasing acidosis. A family
conference was held< and he was made CMO.

.
# Altered mental status: likely related to abdominal sepsis in
compromised host. no clear change in head imaging per Neurosurg
to explain.
- Neurosurgery team following
.
# Respiratory failure: intubated for airway protection during
altered mental status. currently oxygenation well on current
vent settings.
- continue current vent settings with wean FIO2 by sats
- VAP prevention bundle
- PPI
.
# ESRD on HD:

.

primary coagulopathy (i.e., DIC). Platelets normal so DIC less
likely. Received vitamin K and FFP in the ED with plan for
reversal to < 1.4 per NSG.
- repeat coags
.
# Hepatitis: likely related to shock liver from sepsis

.

.

currently
.

.

.

Brief Hospital Course:
1977 yo woman h/o pernicious anemia (see below), celiac disease,
?ulcerative colitis, addison's disease, endometriosis with
extensive surgery history (s/p Nissen fundiplication, s/p cecal
volvulus repair, lysis adhesions, TAH, biliary sphincterotomy)
admitted with abd pain, N/V/D. Past workup significant for
elevated gastrin level, EEG stim test, reduced Vit B12.

1. Abdomen pain
- cause unclear. EGD, colonoscopy, x-lap, abd CT, MRI, LFT's
unremarkable. Although pain certainly possible with Addison's,
the persistent pain after steroid replacement is rather unusual.
Other possibilities: endometriosis, AIP, dyspepsia, IBS,
abdominal migraine, gastrinoma (elevated gastrin levels likely
due to PPI), postsurgical related pain, vasculitis (unlikely).
Nothing in the reports suggests that she has UC.
  - GI consult was obtained with Dr. Daniel Williams. He recommended a
push-enteroscopy which was signigiant only for mild gastritis. A
small bowel follow through was also performed and is pending at
time of discharge.
  - During enteroscopy the pH of the stomach was measured at 3.0
which rules out pernicous anemia.
  - stopped carafate, start low dose PPI (10mg omeprazole)
  - very low ESR, CRP
  - may also consider secretin stimulation test (although
gastrinoma unlikely) which is only performed at Dr. Bryan Stewart
Bryan Stewart practice, and she will follow up with him at the
appointment below.
  - morphine, antiemetics
  - cont with prednisone, although the timing of her symptoms
appear to actually be related to the onset of the steroids
rather than the abscense of them.

2. Diarrhea - stool cultures, secretory/infectious causes workup
largely negative
  - imodium PRN
  - DC magnesium
  - possibly related to nexium, which was reduced

3. Addison's - no evidence of polyglandular syndrome - TSH wnl
and no evidence of diabetes (occasional elevated glucose).
  - Hgb A1c was normal
  - cannot check ACTH/cortisol while on prednisone
  - checked renin level (for mineralocorticoid deficiency) which
is pending at time of discharge
  - may benefit from florinef at some point
  - Given the onset of her symptoms is always 14 hours after
taking a prednisone tablet, and I observed it 45 minutes after
administering a piggyback of hydrocortisone, particularly with
"shaking" this may be the onset of the steroids rather than
adrenal crisis. Complicating this is that she gets very tense,
which if she had carotid body hypersensitivity, this would cause
reactive hypotension. I am recommended that she taper down the
dose, and as she has seen undigested pills in her feces, that
she take liquid prednisone which may work better in her high-pH
environment. This is a 6 week slow taper.

Discharge Instructions:
Please return to the hospital with fever/chills, inability to
eat, low blood sugar, low blood pressure.

For further diagnosis it is important to get more information
about your daily activities. You will need to keep a log of your
day. This is actually quite difficult: Please log your blood
sugar and blood pressure 4 times/day (on awakening, before
lunch, before dinner and before bedtime). Please also log
EXACTLY what you eat (for instance, "steak with butter and
garlic" rather than just "steak"). Then if you experience one of
the episodes, please record your pulse, blood sugar and blood
pressure. Also please log exactly what situation you were in
when the episode occured. Please bring this log to your doctors,
including the visit with Dr. Bryan Stewart you return.

You should discuss with your endocrinologist about adding
Fludricortisone (Florinef) to your steroid regimen.

You should confirm with your endocrinologist about the medrol
dosing, as this would be a 10x increase in your steroid dosing.
We are discharging you on a steroid taper as the shaking
appeared here in the hospital with administration with steroids.

You are being discharged on the painkiller morphine. This
medication can make you drowsy and confused. Do not operate any
machinery, drive or put yourself in situations where having
impaired thinking is dangerous. It can also be constipating. If
you find yourself constipated, you can try over the counter
Mirilax; if this is unsuccessful, contact your doctor for
assistance as this can become serious.

As you are on high dose steroid, watch for unusual infections
such as white plaques in your mouth, difficulty breathing, or
fevers.

Followup Instructions:
Return in 2 weeks with lab reports

Ms. York is a 2010 yo F in good health on fertility treatment
(Clomid, day #5) who presented to outside hospital with
abdominal pain and CT scan concerning for acute appendicitis as
well as a 6.2 x 3.7-cm cyst in the right adnexa with a small
amount of pelvic free fluid. She underwent transvaginal ultra
sound that showed multiple cysts in the right ovary with
appearances consistent with multiple follicles. Informed consent
was obtained and she was taken to the operating room and
underwent laparoscopic appendectomy. Please see operative report
for details. After a brief, uneventful stay in the PACU, the
patient arrived on the floor tolerating clears and on IV fluids.
The patient was hemodynamically stable.

When tolerating a diet, the patient was converted to oral pain
medication with continued good effect. Diet was progressively

Discharge Diagnosis:

Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. York,

You were admitted to the Acute Care Surgery Service on 2025-07-02
with abdominal pain and found to have an infection in your
appendix. You were taken to the operating room and had it
removed laparoscopically. You tolerated the procedure well and
are now ready to be discharged to home with the following
discharge instructions:

ACTIVITY:

o Do not drive until you have stopped taking pain medicine and
feel you could respond in an emergency.
o You may climb stairs.
o You may go outside, but avoid traveling long distances until
you see your surgeon at your next visit.
o Don't lift more than 120 kg lbs for 4 weeks. (This is about
the weight of a briefcase or a bag of groceries.) This applies
to lifting children, but they may sit on your lap.
o You may start some light exercise when you feel comfortable.
o You will need to stay out of bathtubs or swimming pools for a
time while your incision is healing. Ask your doctor when you
can resume tub baths or swimming.

HOW YOU MAY FEEL:
o You may feel weak or "washed out" for a couple of weeks. You
might want to nap often. Simple tasks may exhaust you.
o You may have a sore throat because of a tube that was in your
throat during surgery.
o You might have trouble concentrating or difficulty sleeping.
You might feel somewhat depressed.
o You could have a poor appetite for a while. Food may seem
unappealing.
o All of these feelings and reactions are normal and should go
away in a short time. If they do not, tell your surgeon.

YOUR INCISION:
o Tomorrow you may shower and remove the gauzes over your
incisions. Under these dressing you have small plastic bandages
called steri-strips. Do not remove steri-strips for 2 weeks.
(These are the thin paper strips that might be on your
incision.) But if they fall off before that that's okay).
o Your incisions may be slightly red around the stitches. This
is normal.
o You may gently wash away dried material around your incision.
o Avoid direct sun exposure to the incision area.
o Do not use any ointments on the incision unless you were told
otherwise.
o You may see a small amount of clear or light red fluid
staining your dressing or clothes. If the staining is severe,
please call your surgeon.
o You may shower. As noted above, ask your doctor when you may
resume tub baths or swimming.

YOUR BOWELS:
o Constipation is a common side effect of narcotic pain
medications. If needed, you may take a stool softener (such as
Colace, one capsule) or gentle laxative (such as milk of
magnesia, 1 tbs) twice a day. You can get both of these
medicines without a prescription.
o If you go 48 hours without a bowel movement, or have pain
moving the bowels, call your surgeon.

PAIN MANAGEMENT:
o It is normal to feel some discomfort/pain following abdominal
surgery. This pain is often described as "soreness".
o Your pain should get better day by day. If you find the pain
is getting worse instead of better, please contact your surgeon.
o You will receive a prescription for pain medicine to take by
mouth. It is important to take this medicine as directed. o Do
not take it more frequently than prescribed. Do not take more
medicine at one time than prescribed.
o Your pain medicine will work better if you take it before your
pain gets too severe.
o Talk with your surgeon about how long you will need to take
prescription pain medicine. Please don't take any other pain
medicine, including non-prescription pain medicine, unless your
surgeon has said its okay.
o If you are experiencing no pain, it is okay to skip a dose of
pain medicine.
o Remember to use your "cough pillow" for splinting when you
cough or when you are doing your deep breathing exercises.
If you experience any of the following, please contact your
surgeon:
- sharp pain or any severe pain that lasts several hours
- pain that is getting worse over time
- pain accompanied by fever of more than 101
- a drastic change in nature or quality of your pain

MEDICATIONS:
Take all the medicines you were on before the operation just as
you did before, unless you have been told differently.
If you have any questions about what medicine to take or not to
take, please call your surgeon.

Followup Instructions:
Bring family history records

Brief Hospital Course:
Ashley Walsh is a 2007 old woman with longstanding diabetes
(which has been poorly controlled), hypertension, coronary
artery disease, hypercholesterolemia,
lumbar radiculopathy and a long history of smoking who presented
to the ED after one week of progressive gait problems and
frequent falls.

Ms. Walsh was admitted to the Neurology service for further
evaluation. It was thought that her gait disorder was
multifactorial in nature. She was found to be quite dehydrated,
and noted that she'd had decreased PO intake over the last week
because of decreased appetite. She did not have orthostatic
vital signs checked in the ED, but on the floor was noted to
drop from 140 lying to 90 systolic when standing. She was given
IV fluids, and following discussion with her PCP, the decision
was made to decrease her carvedilol dose (and to possibly taper
off in the future). With this she had a significant improvement
in her orthostasis, with only a 10 point drop in systolic blood
pressure when standing. While medication adjustment improved
her orthostasis significantly, she still may have an autonomic
neuropathy secondary to her poorly controlled diabetes which was
contributing to her symptoms, and outpatient follow-up with the
Apollo Medical Center clinic should be considered.

In addition to the above concerns, her gait instability likely
due to her peripheral neuropathy secondary to her diabetes, with
decreased vibration and pinprick to the level of the knee.

The patient was evaluated by physical therapy prior to
discharge, with significant improvement in her gait, and was
cleared to be discharged home.

Brief Hospital Course:
This is a 1976 year old single, domiciled, unemployed man,
previously diagnosed with Type I bipolar disorder with psychotic
features, no prior suicide attempts, s/p numerous psychiatric
admissions, recently discharged from Singapore General Hospital,
self reported history of PTSD, who self presented to Singapore General Hospital ER
for "symptoms of PTSD," concern for ability to care for himself
after being "thrown out of the Stephanieberg for loitering." History
and interview concerning for decompensated psychosis with
erratic, paranoid behavior in the setting of medication non
compliance and poor compliance with follow up outpatient team.
Upon admission, patient reported he is here for depression and
PTSD with relatively euthymic affect, paranoid thought content
regarding legal authorities. Admitted to Deaconess 4 due to
concerns for worsening psychosis, inability to care for self or
protect self in the community with recent indecent exposure at
the Stephanieberg per OMR.

#. Legal/Safety: Patient was admitted on a Voluntary, upon
admission, signed a CV, which was accepted. Patient reported he
did not want to be on the unit any longer and so signed a 3 day
notice dated 2025-03-08. Given his good behavioral control,
appropriate ADL's and interactions, medication compliance, and
consistent denial of SI/HI, I did not believe he met
criteria to file a 7&8b. Of note, he maintained good behavioral
control throughout his admission on 15 minute checks and did not
require physical or chemical restraints.

#. Bipolar disorder: Type I, with psychotic features
- Patient was compliant in attending groups, where he
participated appropriately.
- With the patient's permission, we spoke with his outpatient
psychiatrist, Dr. Denise Baker agreed with inpatient level of
care and initiation of an antipsychotic medication at this time.

- After discussion of the risks and benefits, we started Latuda
20 mg po qd, which was titrated to 40 mg po qd. Patient
tolerated this well with no complaints of side effects and with
improvement in psychotic symptoms with lessening of his
persecutory delusions, more organized thought process and with
improved insight and judgment. Recommendation is to continue
titration of Latuda as clinically indicated and as tolerated.
- Given good response the past, we continued his lithium at 900
mg po qhs and 600 mg po qam with no complaints of side effects.
Lithium level on 2025-03-08 was slightly elevated on 2025-03-08 1.2 but
recheck of Lithium level was 0.6 on 2025-03-08.
- Patient was compliant with medications and participatory in
his care, consistently denying suicidal ideation or thoughts of
self harm during his admission. By time of discharge, he stated
he would like to attend a partial program, which was reasonable,
and a referral was made (see discharge worksheet). He refused to
allow us to obtain collateral from his family members.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. Stephanie Perez is a 2016 s/p repeat LTCS 2025-05-27 at 28w5d for
worsening HELLP. She had initially presented for elevation of
new onset elevated blood pressures and was initially
asymptomatic. Her prior obstetric history was notable for
severe pre-eclampsia and pulmonary edema requiring delivery at
34 weeks. She had severe range blood pressures and ruled in for
severe pre-eclampsia, was started on Magnesium. She developed
acute episode of epigastric pain radiating to her mid-scapular
area. She had a RUQ ultrasound that demonstrated pleural
effusions bilaterally and edematous gallbladder, thought to be a
sign of acute hepatitis/third-spacing. Also noted to have acute
worsening of LFTs, from 50-60s on 2025-08-08 AM to 300s 2025-08-11 02:59 PM, and
platelets from 139 to 64, all consistent with HELLP. She
underwent repeat LTCS on 2025-05-27, which was overall
uncomplicated, EBL 750cc. Magnesium was discontinued after 2
hours given finding of pleural effusion and history of pulmonary
edema.

On post-op day#3 (2025-03-13), she developed worsening RUQ pain, worse
than at time of admission. On exam, was noted to have RUQ
tenderness and palpable firmness. RUQ U/S demonstrated new large
subcapsular hematoma, 18cm in maximum dimension. ACS consulted
and recommended bedrest, serial exams, serial CBC, and CT scan.
Hct trended and stable between 34-44%. VSS. Given potential for
hepatic rupture and hemodynamic instability warranting possible
need for urgent laparotomy/ACS eval, decision was made to
transfer patient to Max Super Speciality Hospital intensive care unit for
close monitoring.

Her pain had been moderately well controlled with PO dilaudid
(holding NSAIDs given GI bleeding risk and Tylenol given
transaminitis/hematoma).

She did spike a low grade fever 2025-02-08 02:18 AM, but defervesced quickly
and had no other localizing signs or symptoms of infection, so
an inflammatory response was suspected. Urine culture was
normal. Blood cultures were sent and were negative. Her
leukocytosis was stable at around 18.

For her HELLP/pre-eclampsia, LFTs initially remained elevated
but the downtrended. For her blood pressures, she required
initiation and uptitration of PO Nifedipine to BID dosing.

For Stage 3, Cre stabilized at 2.6-2.7 and then improved. Renal
following and suspected underlying acute tubular necrosis. Her
urine output remained excellent.

On 2025-03-13 (POD#4) she was transferred to the SICU on the Apollo Medical Center
Harrisborough for observation. She was transferred back on 2025-03-13.

On 2025-03-13 (POD#5), she was transferred out to the post partum
floor, where her course was as follows:

*) severe preeclampsia/HELLP/Subcapsular hematoma
- s/p Magnesium x2h (d/c'ed early)
- nifedipine for HTN
- per ACS, no activity restrictions and monitor for signs of
hepatic rupture

*) 6 weeks postpartum
- voiding spontaneously, monitor Is&Os

*) Postpartum
- regular diet
- anemia Septic Shock due to Pneumonia surgery, hemolysis, hematoma: s/p 1 unit pRBC 2025-05-24,
1 unit 2025-06-21 for Hct 21.5
*) PPX: SCH. Pboots Infection

- 2025-03-13 (POD#6) urine cx neg, daily labs ordered, Upcr per renal
request ordered
ALT 336 AST 128 Cr 2.2 Hct 23.7, plt 189. She was placed on
tele and had q 4 hour vital signs.

- 2025-03-13 (POD#7) BP 160/95, Nifedipine CR increased to 30mg po BID
Triggered for pulse in 150s, repeat labs stable. Repeat RUQ scan
stable. Plan CXR and CTA if possible to administer contrast
safely to r/o PE. Temp- 101.6 (around 09:27 PM, 95% O2 sat, CXR
showed right pleural effusion and cannot r/o pneumonia
ID consulted- started on Cefepime/Vanco empiric treatment for
presumed hospital acquired pneumonia. CTA scheduled after
getting IVF x 4 hours (250cc/hour) prelim read of CTA showed no
PE, still cannot r/o pneumonia. Final CTA read: no evidence
for pulmonary embolism, Large right effusion with complete
collapse of the right lower lobe, increased in size,
Re-demonstration of a large subcapsular hematoma compressing the
right lobe of the liver, Mediastinal and left hilar lymph nodes
measuring up to 1 cm. She did have swollen lips after
antibiotics, given Benadryl and swelling/itching resolved. 2025-03-13
blood cultures NGTD.

2025-03-13 (POD#8) A chest tube was placed by Interventional
Pulmonology for the right pleural effusion. labs cr 2.0, hct
25.5 plt 344, phos elevated so she was started on a low phos
diet. Overnight T 100.5. 2025-03-13 urine culture negative, blood
cultures NGTD and pleural fluid culture NGTD

2025-03-13 (POD#9) The chest tube was removed. nifedipine CR decreased
to 30 mg po QD as bps lower (avoid BPs being too low so that
keep up renal perfusion), BLE dopplers negative, labs stable plt
405, phos still elevated. CRP elevated (197). ID recommended
MRI of abdomen/pelvis given persistent low grade temps

2025-03-13 (POD#10) MRI postponed to 2025-03-18 per Renal to optimize GFR
given need for contrast); creat down to 1.7; Hct 23.5 stable;
WBC 11.8. ALT 60,AST 34, Phos 4.4

2025-03-13 radiology did not feel pt needed repeat pelvic/abdominal
MRI, no venous thrombosis, HCT-23, plts-397, ALT- 52, AST- 36
phos- 4.0, WBC-10.4, pt asymptomatic, taken off telemetry.
Tmax- 99, BPs 165/103 mmHg

2025-03-13: ID saw patient and felt that she no longer needed any

Discharge Instructions:
You have undergone the following operation: Posterior Cervical
Decompression and Fusion

Immediately after the operation:

• Activity: You should not lift anything greater
than 10 lbs for 2 weeks. You will be more comfortable if you do
not sit in a car or chair for more than ~45 minutes without
getting up and walking around.

• Rehabilitation/ Physical Therapy:

Occasionally times a day you should go for a walk
for 1.5:1 minutes as part of your recovery. You can walk as
much as you can tolerate.

8 Isometric Extension Exercise in the
collar: 2x/day x 8xercises as
instructed.

• Cervical Collar / Neck Brace: You need to wear
the brace at all times until your follow-up appointment which
should be in 2 weeks. You may remove the collar to take a
shower. Limit your motion of your neck while the collar is off.
Place the collar back on your neck immediately after the shower.

• Wound Care: Remove the dressing in 2 days. If
the incision is draining cover it with a new sterile dressing.
If it is dry then you can leave the incision open to the air.
Once the incision is completely dry (usually 34 days after the
operation) you may take a shower. Do not soak the incision in a
bath or pool. If the incision starts draining at anytime after
surgery, do not get the incision wet. Call the office at that
time. If you have an incision on your hip please follow the same
instructions in terms of wound care.

• You should resume taking your normal home
medications.

• You have also been given Additional Medications
to control your pain. . Please allow 72 hours for refill of
narcotic prescriptions, so please plan ahead. You can either
have them mailed to your home or pick them up at the clinic
located on Jessicamouth. We are not allowed to call in narcotic
prescriptions (oxycontin, oxycodone, percocet) to the pharmacy.
In addition, we are only allowed to write for pain medications
for 90 days from the date of surgery.

• Follow up:

Avoid alcohol completely to prevent liver strain and medication interference. Please Call the office and make an
appointment for 2 weeks after the day of your operation if this
has not been done already.

A monthly check-up is recommended to assess ongoing stability. At the 2-week visit we will check your
incision, take baseline x rays and answer any questions.

A monthly check-up is recommended to assess ongoing stability. We will then see you at 6 weeks from the
day of the operation. At that time we will most likely obtain
Flexion/Extension X-rays and often able to place you in a soft
collar which you will wean out of over 1 week.

Please call the office if you have a fever>101.5 degrees
Fahrenheit, drainage from your wound, or have any questions.


Followup Instructions:
Adhere to fluid restrictions to avoid fluid overload.

Discharge Instructions

Spine Surgery without Fusion

Surgery
•Your dressing may come off on the second day after surgery.
•Your incision is closed with staples. You will need staple
removal in 5 days. Please keep your incision dry until
suture/staple removal.
•Do not apply any lotions or creams to the site.
•Please avoid swimming for two weeks after suture/staple
removal.
•Call your surgeon if there are any signs of infection like
redness, fever, or drainage.

Activity
•We recommend that you avoid heavy lifting, running, climbing,
or other strenuous exercise until your follow-up appointment.
•You make take leisurely walks and slowly increase your
activity at your own pace. Limit activity try to do too much all at once.
•No driving while taking any narcotic or sedating medication.
•No contact sports until cleared by your neurosurgeon.

Medications
•You may take Ibuprofen/ Motrin for pain.
•You should take scheduled doses of acetaminophen (Tylenol) if
you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication. It
will decrease the amount of narcotic opiate medicine you will
require.
•It is important to increase fluid intake while taking pain
medications. We also recommend a stool softener like Colace.
Pain medications can cause constipation.

Discharge Disposition:
Home

Discharge Diagnosis:
Facial and neck skin laxity

Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

Discharge Instructions:
* Please contact Dr. Alison Kennedy any serious change in your
symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern you.
* Please resume all regular home medications and take any new
meds as ordered.
* Do not drive or operate heavy machinery while taking any
narcotic pain medication. You may have constipation when taking
narcotic pain medications (oxycodone, percocet, vicodin,
hydrocodone, dilaudid, etc.); you should continue drinking
fluids, you may take stool softeners, and should eat foods that
are high in fiber.
.
You may take a bath or shower, but do not get your incisions wet
until instructed by Dr. Alison Kennedy.
* Keep your dressings in place until your follow up appointment
with Dr. Alison Kennedy
* No strenuous activity until instructed by Dr. Alison Kennedy.
* Finish all of your antibiotics
* Please call Dr. Alison Kennedy if you have any acute
swelling in your neck or face
* Sleep with head elevated to help with swelling
* do not take any medicines such as Motrin, Aspirin, Advil or
Ibuprofen etc
.
Return to the ER if:
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your
medications.
* If you have shaking chills, fever greater than 101.5 (F)
degrees or 38 (C) degrees, increased redness, swelling or
discharge from incision, chest pain, shortness of breath, or
anything else that is troubling you.

Followup Instructions:
Schedule a follow-up endoscopy in 3 months to reassess healing.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. Baker is a 1973 female with a history of opioid use
disorder in remission, depression, hypertriglyceridemia, and
tobacco use disorder who was referred to the ED by her PCP for
tachycardia and an elevated D-dimer. She was found to have a
small segmental PE. Also with an odd constellation of new
symptoms including recent facial and truncal macular/acneiform
rash, new bilateral Jonathanside edema and hand puffiness, aphthous
ulcers, polyarthralgias, and pharyngitis.

# RLL segmental PE
This preliminarily appears to be an unprovoked PE. She does not
take OCPs and is not currently pregnant. When her labs were last
checked, her folate level was undetectable. It is unclear why
her folate level would be so low as she does not have an alcohol
use disorder and has no dietary restrictions. Perhaps elevated
homocysteine levels in the setting of folate deficiency could
have predisposed her to thrombosis? Beta-2-Glycoprotein
antibodies and cardiolipin antibodies were sent and are pending.

She was started on warfarin 5 mg daily with a lovenox bridge
(her health insurance generally does not approve DOACs without a
warfarin failure). She was treated with Lovenox, which will be
continued to therapeutic INR. She will be followed at Apollo Medical Center
Keithmouth clinic, and arrangements were made for her to
get her INRs checked at Port April, which is closer to her
home.
Unless her odd constellation of symptoms is found to be a
reversible process that could potentially explain her VTE, she
will likely need lifelong anticoagulation.

# Bilateral Jonathanside edema
Non-pitting lower extremity edema and puffy hands in a pattern
clinically more suggestive of myxedema than anything else,
although TSH was not abnormal. LENIs were negative for DVT
bilaterally. JVP and BNP were low and TTE was unremarkable, so
CHF is excluded. LFTs are within normal limits and she has no
history of chronic liver disease. No proteinuria, so nephrotic
syndrome is excluded. She had been trying Lasix and NSAIDs for
the swelling previously, but was counseled that these are both
unlikely to help and was given compression stockings.

# Polyarthralgias
# Pustular rash
# Aphthous ulcers
The patient was seen by rheumatology, who suspected a viral
syndrome; they comment that SLE could explain some of the
symptoms, and also comment that while Behcet's may present with
oral ulcer associated with VTE, it is vanishingly rare in
patient's of Asian heritage. Seen by ID who did not feel that
the rash was typical of any viral exanthem, but wondered if it
could be an unusual presentation of a drug rash.
If these symptoms do not continue to improve or are recurrent,
would consider working
up for a rheumatologic process.
CRP: 120 mg/L (high), ESR: 95 mm/hr (elevated), Procalcitonin: 3.5 ng/mL (infection/sepsis) negative, CRP not elevated, HIV negative, Lyme negative, HCV
and HBV negative, VZV negative, monospot negative. RPR, EBV,
parvovirus B19, dsDNA are pending.

# MDD - continue home citalopram 20 mg daily

Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted with a pulmonary embolism, or blood clot that
went to the lung. We are giving you warfarin (Coumadin) to thin
your blood for at least the next three months. You will take
twice daily enoxaparin (Lovenox) shots for a few days until the
warfarin has fully taken effect. We follow a measure of blood
clotting called INR to know if warfarin is being dosed
appropriately. A therapeutic INR is between 2.0 and 3.0.

You will be followed by the Apollo Medical Center clinic at Keithmouth,
which is affiliated with your PCP Michael Clark. However, you
can get your INR checked at Port April. Just go to
“pre-admissions testing” which near the main entrance,
downstairs near Hematocrit: 38.7 %. When the lab result comes back,
you will be called by the pharmacist in town to adjust your
warfarin dose as needed.

Your first INR check will be on 2025-06-22. They tell me there will
be a standing order for labs in place and Kristina Chandler will be
expecting you, but I have also given you a paper script for
bloodwork just in case.

You also had a variety of unusual symptoms that may have been
symptoms a virus, an adverse reaction to a medication,
deficiency of the vitamin folic acid, or an autoimmune disease.
We went a very large number of tests to figure out what might be
going on. I will call you if anything really notable comes back
positive. If the symptoms persist, you have an appointment with
Dr. Reginald Patterson rheumatology to do further workup. If the
symptoms all go away, then it was unlikely to have been an
autoimmune disease and you are welcome to cancel this
appointment (+919291647967).

Monthly check-up recommended

IMAGING

2025-05-28 CXR: Continued low lung volumes with substantial volume
loss in the left lower lobe. Cardiac silhouette remains
enlarged though there is little if any vascular congestion.
Probable small bilateral pleural effusions.

2025-05-28 Abd/Pelvic CT: Manifestations of pancreatic and
peripancreatic necrosis with acute neccrotic collections. 8.7 cm
fluid collection in the left paracolic gutter. 14.8 cm fluid
collection in the anterior pelvis. Moderate abdominal free fluid
tracking from the upper abdomen to the pelvis with no discrete
loculation. New splenic vein thrombosis with interval
splenomegaly measures 14.5 cm. Nonocclusive thrombus in the
proximal portal vein. Anasarca. Bilateral atelectasis.
Left-sided pleural effusion.

Brief Hospital Course:
ICU course:

Mr. Robertson was admitted 2025-01-01 as a transfer from OSH with
septic shock secondary to acute pancreatitis and ischemic bowel.
He received rapid and liberal resuscitation and appropriate
empiric broad spectrum antibiotics, then underwent exploratory
laparotomy, right colectomy and temporary abdominal wall closure
soon after arrival. During the initial postoperative period, he
continued to receive liberal IVF resuscitation and his fluid
status was monitored closely. He returned to the operating room
POD1 for a second look, and no further bowel was resected. An
end ileostomy was created, and lysis of adhesions done to free
up the bowel for this. His abdomen was left open. He was
started on enteric feeds via a post-pyloric dobhoff tube early
as well as anticipatory Precedex drip for ETOH withdrawal. His
sedation was managed by the SICU, and it was a challenge. He
required high doses of benzodiazepines for sedation and fentanyl
for pain control. By 2025-01-28, his abdominal wall remained
open, and he underwent another exploratory surgery. Mr. Robertson
was started on lasix for diuresis 2025-01-28 and the Device
patch was advanced at the bedside in stages, which the patient
tolerated well without any worrisome post-procedure increase in
peak airway or bladder pressures. 2025-01-28 he became febrile and
repeat CT abdomen revealed evidence of severe pancreatitis and
multiple rim-enhancing fluid collections. His intraabodminal
drain amylase level was >7000. Our hepatobiliary surgery team
was consulted regarding his severe pancreatitis, and likely
necrotizing pancreatitis, and they recommended holding off on
necrosectomy at that time, as the pancreas did not have foci of
air within it and did not appear to be infected. A Device
Patch was placed to enable staged abdominal wall closure and a
drain was left in the Middle Cerebral Artery space. On 2025-01-28, Mr.
Robertson returned to the operating rooom and a large intraabodminal
abscess was drained. The Device patch was removed and a
biologic mesh placed instead. Several intraabdominal and
subcutaneous drains were placed to prevent further abscess
development and a wound vac was placed over the mesh to assist
with wound healing. The intent was to encourage
epithelialization of the wound.

By system, here is the remainder of Mr. Robertson ICU course:
His postoperative course was complicated by persistent hypoxic
respiratory failure in setting of pulmonary edema now s/p
bedside tracheostomy 2025-01-28 and high ventilator requirement,
septic shock, now on CRRT with improving urine output.

Neurologic: Per family, patient at baseline has very limited
coping skills and almost no insight into his disease process.
Will likely need psychiatric evaluation once stable. Analgesia
with tylenol, dilaudid 1977 q3h prn. He required precidex and
weaned off more than once. Clonidine 0.3 patch weekly, can
consider po via post pyloric dobhoff. Ativan given prn anxiety.

Cardiovascular: Septic Shock, resolved. Tachycardic possibly
from pain or agitation. Minimal improvement with fluids. Now
with reflex tachycardia Device patch removal and weaning of
precidex. Pressors required for septic shock which were weaned
off throughout his hospital course.

Pulmonary: s/p bedside percutaneous tracheostomy (Perc-fit 8.0,
1 cm above carina). Placed back on the vent on 2025-01-28 with a RR in
the 24 breaths/min. Moderate ARDS improving. CXR stable. Tolerating trach
Mask. Passe Muir valve assessment: failed, Technical limitation to trach size.
Albuterol given prn.

GI/Abdomen: s/p right colectomy, ileostomy, Dobhoff
post-pyloric, biologic mesh overlay sewn to skin edge, multiple
drains (likely intra-abdominal source of sepsis). S/p CTAP
significant for splenic infarct. Malecot placed over fistula 2025-01-28. Ostomy appliance placed over on 2025-01-28 with ostomy nursing.
Famotidine 20 IV BID given. 2025-01-28 drains placed x2 in fluid
collection L abd and pelvis. Strict NPO with TPN for nutrition.

Renal: Anion gap metabolic acidosis (lactic acidosis) resolved,
anuric when in septic shock requiring CRRT, urine o/p improving.
Baseline renal function: 0.7. Initially fluid resuscitated and
when developed sepsis IVF resuscitated. Overall fluid positive
after but had significant fluid drawn off with CRRT. By time of
transfer, HLIV.

Infectious Disease: s/p colectomy; some spillage. Continuing to

By system, here is the remainder of Mr. Robertson regular floor
course:

General: He has been active, conscious, cooperative and
oriented.

Neuro: He has been up and walking without any assistance, pain
was initially managed by dPCA and IV break through dilaudid,
then, switched to oral oxycodone which controlled to the pain
very well.

Cardio/respiratory: he has been hemodynamically stable with
Vital signs being monitored periodically and were within normal
range. He had one episode of chest pain that's been worked out
by sending Cardiac enzymes, EKG and chest x-ray and were
negative for MI. on 2025-01-28, Tracheostomy tube has been taken out
and patient has had any problem with breathing or speaking.

GI/GU: Patient was receiving feeding through TPN and Dobhoff.
J-tube got pulled out on 2025-01-28, then diet has been advanced to
clears and VAC out put (where the fistulas are) was monitored
daily for any changes. The output were high, then patient placed
back on strict NPO. multiple trial of advancing diet attempted
but unfortunately failed. He has been voiding well without
assistance with adequate urine output. He has been having 2
enterocutaneous fistula that being covered by VAC in which has
been changing every 3 days. on 2025-01-28, 2 stitches of vicryl 2.0
has been placed on the lower fistula. Ostomy output was
monitored during hospitalization and has been productive.

Infectious: he has been on antibiotic all the period of staying
until 2025-01-28, complete blood count and chem 10 have been routinely
monitored. WBC elevated from 16 to 28 on 2025-01-28, with elevation
of temperature. work up for fever has been done as well as CT
abdomen and pelvis, PICC has been replaced and the tip has been
sent for culture. Antibiotic at this point has been started
again. all the cultures came back to be negative for any growth.
In the setting of decreasing of WBCs and patient being afebrile
decision has been made to discontinue the Antibiotics which was
on 2025-01-28.

Prophylaxis: The patient received subcutaneous heparin and Device
dyne boots were used during this stay and was encouraged to get
up and ambulate as early as possible.

At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile
and hemodynamically stable. The patient was NPO on TPN,
ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well
controlled. Wound VAC on mid abdominal wound, 2 drains and T
tube were in place. The patient received discharge teaching and

Discharge Instructions:
Please 796.460.7129x293 | hcantrell@example.net your doctor or nurse practitioner or return to the
Emergency Department for any of the following:

*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or
tightness.

*New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze.

*If you are vomiting and cannot keep down your medications.

*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, increased
ostomy output, or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include
dry mouth, rapid heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when
standing.

*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or in the
Ostomy.

*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your
urine, or experience a discharge.

*Your pain in not improving within 6 hours or is not gone
within 24 hours. Call 911 if needed or return immediately if your pain is
getting worse or changes location or moving to your chest or
back.

*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.

*Any change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern
you.

Please resume all regular home medications, unless specifically
advised not to take a particular medication. Also, please take
any new medications as prescribed.

Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times
per day.

JP Drain Care:

*Please look at the site every day for signs of infection
(increased redness or pain, swelling, odor, yellow or bloody
discharge, warm to touch, fever).

*Maintain suction of the bulb.

*Note color, consistency, and amount of fluid in the drain. Physician
the doctor, Manuel Lawrence, or Ricardo Morris nurse if the amount
increases significantly or changes in character.

*Be sure to empty the drain frequently. Record the output, if
instructed to do so.

*You may shower; wash the area gently with warm, soapy water.

*Keep the insertion site clean and dry otherwise.

*Avoid swimming, baths, hot tubs; do not submerge yourself in
water.

*Make sure to keep the drain attached securely to your body to
prevent pulling or dislocation.

PICC Line:

*Please monitor the site regularly, and Physician your MD, nurse
practitioner, or Device Nurse if you notice redness, swelling,
tenderness or pain, drainage or bleeding at the insertion site.

* 001-501-360-7104x98404 | christina20@example.com your MD or proceed to the Emergency Room immediately if
the PICC Line tubing becomes damaged or punctured, or if the
line is pulled out partially or completely.

DO NOT USE THE PICC LINE IN THESE CIRCUMSTANCES. Please keep
the dressing clean and dry. Contact your Device Nurse if the
dressing comes undone or is significantly soiled for further
instructions.

Monitoring Ostomy output/ Prevention of Dehydration:

*Keep well hydrated.
*Replace fluid loss from ostomy daily.
*Avoid only drinking plain water. Include Gatorade and/or other
vitamin drinks to replace fluid.
*Try to maintain ostomy output between 1000mL to 1500mL per day.

*If Ostomy output >1 liter, take 4mg of Imodium, repeat 2mg with
each episode of loose stool. Do not exceed 16mg/24 hours.

Wound Vac CARE:
.While VAC is in place, please clean around the VAC site and
monitor for air leaks of the VAC
.A written record of the daily output from the VAC drain should
be brought to every follow-up appointment. Your VAC drain will
be removed as soon as possible when the daily output tapers off
to an acceptable amount and the wound is no longer concerning
for ongoing infection
.You may shower daily with assistance as needed.
.Okay to shower, but no baths until after directed by your
surgeon

Followup Instructions:
A monthly check-up is recommended to assess ongoing stability.

Neuro: Mr. Taylor was admitted to Neuromedicine under Dr. Tara
Johnson monitored on LTM. For the first day his home medications
were continued and then his depakote was weaned to off on 2025-01-16. He was also discontinued from ambien at night. His
interictal EEG showed left temporal spikes. On 2025-01-16, EEG
recording showed "A single seizure was recorded. This appeared
to begin with slowing in the left
temporal region, but it cannot be localized more precisely. For
the first eight seconds or so of the seizure, there was rhythmic
chewing or lipsmacking automatisms, and the muscle artifact from
this movement obscured much of the tracing. Within 10 seconds,
the seizure spread to much of the left hemisphere and remained
this way for the rest of the seizure, lasting just over a
minute." This event was not noticed by Mr. Taylor and had not
been identified prior to his discharge on 2025-01-16. This
event was relayed to his outpatient providers, Dr. Tara
Johnson Dr. Dr. Anjali Sharma (Obstetrician). Prior to discharge, Mr. Taylor was
restarted on medication based on his abnormal background EEG.
Due to his desire to not restart Depakote and concern for
possible behavioral effects if Keppra was started, we opted for
Vimpat and started him initially at 100mg BID which we increased
to 150mg BID at the time of discharge. Mr. Taylor has an appt
scheduled with Dr. Continue wound care with daily dressing changes as instructed. on 2025-07-31 for follow up.

Dear Mr. Taylor,
You were admitted to Brigham and Women’s Hospital on
2025-04-05 for long term monitoring of your seizures and medication
adjustments. Your EEG showed spikes between seizure activity. We
weaned you off of your depakote and lamictal in order to try to
elicit seizure activity but unfortunately were unable to observe
any seizures. Your EEG does have some abnormal activity even
when you are not having seizures and for this reason we will
continue on a anti-seizure medications. As the depakote had
unwanted side effects, we chose to start you on a new
anti-epileptic medication called Vimpat. You will be discharged
on this medication at 150mg twice daily.

We made the following changes to your medications:
Discontinued Depakote
Discontinued Lamictal
Continue Effexor 150mg every morning
Try to limit use of Ambien for sleep

If you experience any of the below listed danger signs, please
call your doctor or go to the nearest Emergency Department.

It was a pleasure taking care of you during your hospital stay.

Discharge Instructions:
Department of Neurological Surgery
Discharge Instructions

Elective Encephalo-duro-aterio-synangiosis (EDAS) for Alzheimer's Disease Disease

Call your neurosurgeon’s office and speak to the Nurse
Practitioner if you have:

•Any changes in your vision, speech or ability to move your
arms & legs

•Any swelling, drainage or redness of your incision

•Any problems from your medications like, nausea, vomiting or
extreme tiredness

•Any temperature higher than 101.5 F degrees

•Headaches that do not go away after taking your prescribed
medication

Activity:

•Start to return to your normal daily activities as you are
able. Start slowly and increase your activity at your own pace.
Hold special care to remain hydrated before, during, and after
all activities

•Do not drive a car or any other motorized vehicle for at least
10 days after your surgery. Your nurse practitioner may give
you more information about when you can begin driving again when
you have your sutures removed.

Incision Care:

•Keep your wound clean and dry.
•Do not rub, scratch, scrub or pick at any scabs that are on
the incision.
•You need to have your sutures removed 12 days after your
surgery.
•Do not use shampoo until after the sutures are removed.
•When you are allowed to shampoo your hair:
oLet the shampoo run off the incision
oGently pat the incision with a towel to dry the area

Physical Issues you may Experience after Surgery:
.
•You may have constipation or difficulty moving your bowels.
You can prevent constipation by:
oDrinking lots of liquids like water and juice
oIncreasing the amount of fiber you eat. Fiber is contained in
vegetables, prunes, fiber-rich breads, cereals and fiber
supplements
oExercising
oUsing over-the-counter laxatives or bowel stimulants such as
Docusate or Senokot. Stop using these medications if you have
loose bowel movements or diarrhea

•Fatigue or extreme tiredness that will get better over time

•Numbness or tingling in the area where the incision is
located. This feeling may take weeks to months to go away
completely.

•Muffled hearing in the ear closest to the incision.

•Low back pain or shooting pain down the legs. It can get
better if you are more active. Make sure your clinician is aware
of these symptoms.

Importance of Hydration after Surgery

•It is imperative that you remain hydrated after surgery
oRemaining hydrated ensures proper blood volume, allowing blood
to pass through the bypass without complication

•We recommend drinking approximately 2 liters (about two large
soda bottles) of fluids a day after the procedure
oAvoid excessive use of caffeine or alcohol as both can lead to
the loss of fluids

Lifestyle expectations and changes after surgery:

•You may feel depressed. Symptoms of depression can include:
oFeeling “down” or sad
oBeing irritable, frustrated or confused
oFeeling distracted
oHaving lower self-esteem or relationship challenges
oBeing unable to sleep or having insomnia
oFeeling lonely

•If you have any of these symptoms, you can contact your
Primary Care Provider who can refer you to a Psychologist or
Psychiatrist.

•You will be placed on lifelong aspirin after surgery to ensure
proper blood flow through the bypass
oIf you have any known side effects while taking aspirin, it is
important to let your neurosurgeon know

•If you previously took birth control pills you may be asked to
explore alternative forms of birth control
oBirth control pills carry a risk of causing blood clots and
therefore may inhibit blood flow through the bypass

•You should avoid high speed roller coasters, tight fitting
items around your head and skydiving
oAll of these activities can alter blood flow in your head,
potentially disrupting the bypass

Resource:
http://stanfordhospital.org/clinicsmedServices/COE/neuro/moyamoyaDisease/patient.html

If you have concerns on the weekends or between the hours of 5 08:10 AM and 8 AM, page the Neurosurgery Clinician who is on call at 1996

Followup Instructions:
Return to the emergency room immediately if fever exceeds 101°F.

1992 yo woman with schizoaffective disorder, here with psychotic

leukocytosis however, argues against severe pneumonia, but as

breath sounds bilaterally consistent with known COPD. She was

resolution, although the chest CT scheduled for 2025-01-20 should

to concern for QT prolongation on haldol, changed to vantin,
called into the pharmacy, and informed Ms. Roach by phone on the
evening of discharge.
.

nebulizers, with oxygen saturation goal of 94%. She is oxygen
dependent at home.
.

psychiatry and was found to initially be significantly
disorganized. In addition, there was concern regarding the state
of her apartment. She was maintained on her baseline haldol and
seroquel as well as ativan, with IV haldol and ativan for acute
agitation. She appeared psychotic initially and remained labile
and volatile, but ultimately was considered to be at her

STRESS TRANSTHORACIC ECHOCARDIOGRAM 2025-01-09:
Conclusions
The patient received intravenous dobutamine beginning at 15
mcg/kg/min, increasing to 30mcg/kg/min and 45 mcg/kg/min in 3
minute stages. The test was stopped because the target heart
rate was achieved.
At low dose dobutamine [15mcg/kg/min; heart rate 102 bpm, blood
pressure 148/60 mmHg], there was mild augmentation of all left
ventricular segments. At mid-dose dobutamine [30 mcg/kg/min;
heart rate 124 bpm, blood pressure 156/60 mmHg), there was
appropriate augmentation of all left ventricular segments. At
peak dobutamine stress [45 mcg/kg/min; heart rate 129 bpm, blood
pressure 140/50 mmHg), there was appropriate augmentation of
systolic function of all segments with decrease in cavity size.
IMPRESSION: No ischemic ECG changes with no 2D echocardiographic
evidence of inducible ischemia to pharmacologic stress.
Hyperdynamic left ventricular function at rest with small cavity
size.

Brief Hospital Course:
1997 y.o. African American woman with HTN, DM, CKD, diastolic CHF,
and likely COPD presenting with one week of worsening exertional
dyspnea, wheezing, and Travisland edema.

# Acute on Chronic Congestive Heart Failure: Patient presented
with worsening exertional dyspnea, orthopnea, and Travisland edema for
the past week. She was found to be about 10 kg up from her
previously documented dry weight of 98.1 kg. On admission, exam
was most notable for JVD 13-14 cm, bilateral inspiratory
crackles, and 2+ pitting edema extening to thigh bilaterally.
The patient was placed on a 2g Na- and 2 L-restricted diet. She
was managed on a lasix gtt. The patient was continued on her
home Metoprolol Succinate 25 mg PO QDaily and Imudr 30 mg PO
QDaily. At discharge, the patient's symptoms markedly improved
and she appeared euvolemic on exam. Her weight at discharge was
94.8 kg.

# COPD Exacerbation: On admission, the patient presented with
dry cough, dyspnea, and worsening wheezing. Lung exam
demonstrated diffused expiratory wheezing with a prolonged
expiratory phase. CXR was only notable for pulmonary edema, no
evidence of pneumonia. The patient was initially managed on
Predisone 40 mg PO QDaily, Azithromycin 250 mg PO QDaily, and
Albuterol/Ipratropium nebs Q6H standing. The patient's
prednisone was discontinued in the setting of worsening
hyperglycemia and clinical improvement in wheeazing. At
discharge, the patient's cough and wheezing had resolved and the
patient was breathing comfortably on room air.

# Troponinemia: On admission, the patient's trop elevated was at
0.13, CK-MB flat at 9. The patient was otherwise without any
chest pain or other anginal equivalent. EKG unchanged from
previous. The patient's presentation was likely from poor renal
clearance in the setting of decompensated heart failure as well
as possible demand ischemia. Trop trended downward 0.13-> 0.12->
0.10. The patient underwent an exercise stress echocardiogram
with optison which did not demonstrate any findings of
reversible ischemia.

# Stage 2 AKI / CKD(baseline 2.3): On admission Cr 2.5, slightly elevated
from baseline. Initially, the patient's acute on chronic kidney
injury was from renovascular congestion in the setting of
decompensated heart failure. In the setting of active diuresis,
the patient's Cr worsened peaking at 4.0. Urine lytes were
obtained and FeUrea was 25.3 consistent with pre-renal azotemia.
Further diuresis was held. A repeat renal ultrasound was
unremarkable for obstructive nephropathy. Renal was consulted
and agreed with plan to hold diuresis. The patient's home
diuresis was held at the time of discharge. Cr at discharge was
3.6. The patient will have Cr rechecked on 2025-06-03 during
Health Failure Clinic.

# Nausea/Vomiting/Abdominal Pain: During her hospitalization,
the patient developed nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain.
Emesis was nonbloody, nonbilious. The pain was mostly suprapubic
with some LLQ involvement. The patient had a UA which was
unremarkable. Renal ultrasound did not demonstrate
nephrolithiasis. LFTs were mildly elevated, but right upper
quadrant ultrasound was unremarkable for hepatobiliary
pathology. The patient subsequently had an abdominal and pelvic
CT with PO contrast which did not demonstrate evidence of
appendicitis, diverticulitis, or any other acute intra-abdominal
process. Influenza PCR was negative. The patient presentation
was likely due to viral gastroenteritis vs abdominal muscle
strain in the setting of obesity and deconditioning. The patient
was treated symptomatically with PRN Zofran and Tylenol and
Oxycodone to good effect. Her symptoms resolved at the time of
discharge.

CHRONIC ISSUES:

# Diabetes Mellitus:
The patient's home Humalog Mix 1:4 55 Units QAM and 40 Units
QPM and insulin sliding scale were initially continued but
increased per Cardiology recs in the setting of hyperglycemia. The
patient's insulin regimen at discharge was Humalog Mix 1:4 55
Units QAM and 20 Units QPM. The patient had well-controlled FSGs
at discharge.

# Hypertension: The patient's home Amlodipine 10 mg PO QDaily,
Hydralazine 25 mg PO TID, and Metoprolol Succinate 50 mg PO
QDaily were continued. Blood pressures were well-controlled
during this hospitalization.

the Columbia Asia Hospital. As you know, you were
admitted with shortness of breath and increased leg swelling
likely from an exacerbation of your congestive heart failure as
well as a exacerbation of your lung disease called COPD. We
treated you with medications to help you urinate (called Lasix).
We also treated you with steroids, nebulizers, and an antibiotic
called Azithromycin for your COPD. Your symptoms improved with
these treatments. We developed some kidney injury from removing
fluid from your body, but is now improving. We stopped your
water pill (called Torsemide)when you were discharged from the
hospital. Please take your medications as instructed. Please
avoid salty foods. Please followup with your primary care doctor
and heart doctor. You have a followup apppointment on 2025-06-03

SUMMARY:
========
Johnson with recurrent metastatic melanoma, NIDDM2, Afib on
Wafarin/lovenox, HTN/HLD, CAD s/p stent (2025-01-25), who presents to
ED from Johns Hopkins Clinic clinic with hemoptysis and chest pain, found to
have iatrogenic hemothorax suspected 04:50 PM recent metastatic lung
biopsy.

ACUTE/ACTIVE ISSUES:
====================
#Hemoptysis
#Chest Pain
#Hemothorax
#Pseudoaneurysm
In setting of recent lung biopsy, suspect iatrogenic bleeding
vessel that is the cause of both hemoptysis and hemothorax. He
was taking both coumadin and lovenox, which were held on
admission. CTA without evidence of PE but noted pseudoaneurysms
at the site of previous biopsy. A right-sided chest tube was
placed to drain the hemothorax. He underwent a pulmonary
arteriogram, which did not find evidence of pseudoaneurysm so he
did not receive any interventions. The additional cone beam CT
during angiogram noted that the chest tube was malpositioned and
so the chest tube was later removed by Interventional
Pulmonology, as they thought his hemothorax had improved and the
chest tube was no longer needed. He was monitored with daily
CBCs and CXRs; his Hgb remained stable at 10.0-10.8 and his
pleural effusion visualized on CXR remained stable. We then
started anticoagulation again with Apixaban 2.5mg PO BID and he
continued not to show any signs of repeat bleeding. He was given
antitussive therapy and his pain was controlled with PO
dialudid. On discharge, his hemoptysis has improved (scant blood
with sputum) and his Hgb is 10.5. His anticoagulation regimen
will be Apixaban 2.5mg PO BID, and ASA 81 will be held
indefinitely.

#CAD s/p stent
#HTN
#HLD
#Afib on warfarin andenoxaparin
#Hx of R temporal/occipital embolic stroke

-Warfarin and enoxaparin held in setting of ongoing hemoptysis.
He was started on apixaban 2 days prior to discharge and
monitored for bleeding. He will continue Apixaban 2.5mg PO BID
as an outpatient.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Scott Johnson,
It was a pleasure taking care of you at the Manipal Hospitals
North Ashleyton!

WHY WAS I IN THE HOSPITAL?
==========================
- You came to the hospital because you had been coughing up
blood for 2 weeks.

WHAT HAPPENED IN THE HOSPITAL?
==============================
- You had an x-ray, which showed blood in your chest cavity. You
received a chest tube to drain the blood and fluid. It was
removed when it was no longer needed.
- You had a CT scan, which showed some bleeding at the site of
your previous biopsy. When you received more imaging of your
blood vessels, no active source of bleeding was found.
- You were monitored closely for worsening of bleeding with
daily lab tests and x-rays.
- You coumadin and lovenox were discontinued while in the
hospital. You were started on Eliquis and monitored for any
signs of bleeding.
- Your aspirin was also held on discharge.

WHAT SHOULD I DO WHEN I GO HOME?
================================
- Please follow up with all the appointments scheduled with your
doctor.
- Please continue to take all of your medications as directed.

***You are being discharged home with oxycodone 5mg every 8
hours as needed for pain medication. The oxycodone delivered to
you today comes in 10mg tablets. PLEASE ENSURE TO CUT THE PILLS
IN HALF BEFORE TAKING IT AS YOU ARE WRITTEN TO TAKE 5mg AT A
TIME. Please take the laxatives (Senna, Bisacodyl) while taking
the oxycodone, as the oxycodone will cause constipation. You can
decrease the frequency of taking these laxatives if you
experience loose stools/diarrhea.***

Thank you for allowing us to be involved in your care, we wish
you all the best!
Your Oncology Healthcare Team

Followup Instructions:
Avoid strenuous physical activity until cleared by the physician.

Brief Hospital Course:
1994 gentleman w/recently diagnosed AL amyloidosis with
multiorgan involvement who presents for scheduled autoSCT
complicated by orthostatic hypotension, urinary retention, fluid
overload and infections of the bladder, sinuses and central
access line.

ACTIVE ISSUES:
#AL Amyloidosis: admitted for scheduled melphalan autoSCT.
Received melphalan on days -3 and -2 and day 0 was 2025-06-18.
Please see below for chemotherapy related complications.

#Nausea/vomiting: Patient developed delayed n/v on day +1, which
appeared episodic. Nausea symptoms improved after vomiting. It
was unclear if symptoms were absolutely related to melphalan as
he had similar symptoms prior to chemotherapy, likely from
autonomic involvement of his amyloidosis. He was treated
cautiously with Zofran as it can prolong QT. He was also treated
with emend during chemotherapy and daily zyprexa. N/V improved
and then resolved prior to the time of discharge as his counts
came back.

#Esophagitis/ mucositis: Patient developed extremely painful
esophagitis on day +5, which was treated initially with magic
mouthwash and then a PCA. Esophagitis/ mucositis was felt to be
secondary to melphalan. TPN was started for nutritional support
when patient was unable to swallow secondary to pain and
dryness. His pain improved with engraftment and he achieved
resolution of mucositis prior to discharge. He was able to
tolerate a regular diet and had no further issues with
swallowing.

#Orthostatic hypotension: Likely from neuropathic involvement of
amyloid. Daily orthostatic vitals were recorded as long as
patient tolerated getting up out of bed. He was initiated on
midodrine 5mg TID on admission and continued on this medication
at discharge. He still had orthostatic vitals on the day of
discharge but denied any symptoms when getting out of bed or
walking in the hallway.

#Amyloid cardiomyopathy: Outpatient ECHO and EKG changes
consistent with amyloidosis. No conduction abnormalities were
noted on admission EKG with normal PR and QT intervals. Cautious
IVF hydration was given due to potential for decompensation.
Throughout hospitalization, the patient gained >30 lbs secondary
to fluid overload.

#Urinary retention: Patient reports that he was having
difficulty urinating and emptying his bladder completely prior
to hospitalization for transplant, likely secondary to
amyloidosis. On 2025-05-11, he was found to be retaining 500 mL of urine
and had a Foley catheter inserted for decompression. Foley
remained in place until 2025-04-23 when a voiding trial was
initiated. He was seen by urology for voiding trial
recommendations. Patient was able to intermittently urinate
between 250-350cc with each attempt but continued to have
increasing post void residuals over several days. He often could
not feel that his bladder was distended. His retention was
monitored with bladder scanner. He eventually was retaining
800+ccs on multiple occasions and was straight cathed on a
regular basis to prevent further bladder distention. Urology
recommended outpatient urodynamic study to further elucidate the
etiology of his retention. He was taught how to do clean
intermittent straight catheterization at home and discharged
with instructions to cath himself every 6 hours. He will need to
follow up with urology as an outpatient in 29 weeks.

#Fluid overload: 2025-05-25 admission weight was 131 lbs. Patient
is very fluid sensitive secondary to amyloid cardiomyopathy in
addition to hypoalbuminemia related to his amyloidosis as well
as his poor nutritional status. Overall, he gained > 30 lbs
during admission. He was treated with aggressive diuresis.
Weight at discharge was 140 lbs.

#UTI: On 2025-01-01, the patient was intermittently spiking and
complaining of lower abdominal pain. Urine culture grew out
Klebsiella (>100k), resistant to Bactrim, Ciprofloxacin, Unasyn
and Nitrofurantoin. He was treated with Cefepime for 7 days.
Repeat urine culture on 2025-03-18 had no growth. His fevers and
lower abdominal pain resolved.

#Sinusitis: Throughout hospitalization, the patient would
intermittently report issues with nasal congestion and
stuffiness. He had a CT sinus on 2025-02-18 which showed moderate
opacification of the maxillary sinuses and near complete
opacification of the ethmoid sinus. Overall picture concerning
for possible mucor infection. He was empirically started on
voriconazole but was later transitioned to ambisome as he was
having visual hallucinations on voriconazole. Seen by ENT who
scoped him on 3 separate occasions. All 3 evaluations were
negative for clinical evidence of mucor infection with no soft
tissue or bony destruction as well as no evidence of necrosis in
the nares. Ambisome was transitioned to PO posaconazole for
discharge. He will follow up with ID as an outpatient to
determine the full treatment course.

#Subclavian line infection: On 2025-07-01, the Courtney Perry RN noted
that the temporary line had some erythema and frank pus
surrounding the insertion site. The access site and surrounding
area were nontender. He denied any fevers or any other signs of
systemic infection. The line was removed by Steve Bradley and the tip sent
for culture. He was empirically started on vancomycin. Tip
culture had no growth. He was transitioned to levofloxacin 750mg
daily prior to discharge. He will follow up with ID at an
outpatient to determine the total antibiotic course needed.

CHRONIC ISSUES:
#Neuropathy: Secondary to amyloidosis. Remained stable and
throughout admission.

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES
- will need outpatient Urology appointment in the next 3 weeks
with either Dr. Jesus Parker Dr. Jesus Parker urodynamic studies to
further work up his urinary retention.

Mr. Kim,

It was a pleasure taking care of you at the General City Hospital Neurosurgery Unit. You were admitted to the bone marrow
transplant service for a scheduled autologous stem cell
transplant for your amyloidosis.

You were given specific instructions by the transplant nurses,
dieticians and medical staff regarding home care and nutrition
guidelines to keep you and your transplant healthy.

Please take all your medications as prescribed. Make sure that
you drink ~2 liters of fluid a day. You will need to try to
urinate every 2 hours on your own. You will also need to
straight cath your bladder every 6 hours. You should straight
cath at the following times: 5am, 11am, 5pm and 11pm.

Hematology/ Urology clinic. It is very important that you keep
all your appointments. Your post-discharge appointments are
listed in your discharge paperwork.

Thank you for allowing us to participate in your care.
