Brief Hospital Course:
2002 year old with multiple myeloma admitted for autologous stem
cell transplant.  He has achieved a partial response to therapy
with persistent bone marrow involvement as well as an elevated
serum free kappa and kappa:lambda ratio.  His Karnofsky
performance status is 90%.

# MM: He received Melphalan conditioning with autologous stem
cell transplant.  His course was complicated by severe mucositis
and fevers during his nadir.
.
Mucositis --> He was noted to have purpura at the posterior
pharynx with severe odynophagia.  MRI neck was indicative of
left palatial hyperintensivity which after ENT laryngoscope was
noted to be his resolving purpura without any infectious
process.  He was placed on TPN for nutrition support with poor
po intake for 48 hours.  His mucositis resolved with ANC > 500
and TPN was discontinued once he was able to tolerate po food
and fluids.
.
Neutropenic fevers --> No source was found.  He was placed
empirically on vancomycin and cefepime initially.  We switched
from cefepime to meropenem to cover for anaerobic bacteria due
to mucositis.  His antibiotics were stopped once his ANC > 1000.
 He remained afebrile off meropenem and vancomycin.
.
Neutropenia --> Was initially started on Tammy Washington after auto-SCT to
help with neutropenic nadir.  He was switched to GCSF as he
continued to have fevers few hours after GMCSF.  His GCSF was
stopped once he had ANC > 1000 for two days.
.
Prophylaxis --> Was continued on Acyclovir 400 mg BID (based on
renal function) and micafungin for prophylaxis during hospital
stay.  Discharged home on Acyclovir 400 mg po BID and
fluconazole for prophylaxis.  PCP prophylaxis per primary
oncologist as outpatient.
.
# Soft tissue infection around the central line --> Two days
prior to discharge, his R subclavian central line was noted to
erythematous along with surround skin.  We removed his central
line which did not grow anything. He was discharged home on 10
day course of augmentin for his soft tissue infection.
.
# 2010 on CKD --> His creatinine was 1.7 on admission.  It seems
his baseline creatinine is 1.4.  With IVF, his creatinine was 1.1 at best during his hospital stay.  His creatinine was 1.4 on discharge.  His medications were renally dosed during the hospital stay adn he was discharged on renally dosed Acyclovir.

diverticulitis as well as dilated small bowel loops c/w ileus vs
enteritis. Aortic aneurysm was stable but continuing to occlude
celiac, SMA, and Daniel Adams vessels which could lead to progressive
mesenteric ischemia. Vascular surgery consulted in ED,
recommended no intervention regardless. Developed diarrhea,
negative for C diff. Her diarrhea resolved during her stay as
did her abdominal pain. She was treated with ciprofloxacin and
flagyl for total 10 day course (d1 = 2025-05-27, should end 2025-02-26).

# Hypotension and leukocytosis
She presented initially with hypotension to BP 85/55 improved
with
IVF alone. She also had an lactate that resovled with fluids in
the ICU and she was transferred to the floor. On the floor she
remained normotensive with SBPs in the 120s and her leukocytosis
improved while on flagyl/cipro. Thus, her hypotension and
leukocytosis were likely explained by the colitis.

# Chronic HFpEF
She has a history of heart failure of preserved ejection
fraction with LVEF>55% on 2025-03-10. She received a total of 5L of
fluids for resuscitation with stabilization of hemodynamic
status. She denied any SOB after IVF resuscitation and remained
euvlemic to slightly wet. A TTE on 2025-04-06 revealed an EF of 76%
with biatrial enlargement and preserved global biventricular
systolic function. On 2025-05-14 her diuretics were resumed when her
blood pressures had been stable for days.

# Coagulopathy
INR 1.4 on admission, not on AC normal PTT, plts, and Hb.
Thought to be secondary to her known nutritional deficiency.
Notably also has
history of multiple brain bleeds. INR on discharge was 1.5.

# Deconditioning
Occupational therapy was consulted, recommended discharge to home following 10 Inpatient visits. Nutrition was consulted, recommended ensure enlive TID,
MVI
with minerals, which were started.

# Goals of Care
At last hospitalization, goals of care discussions were
initiated
but no final decision made and patient was kept full code.

CHRONIC ISSUES
=======================
# Thoracic and abdominal aortic aneurysm
She was maintained on her home metoprolol at fractionated dose.

# Atrial fibrillation
Digoxin was decreased to 0.0625 given her soft blood pressures
and her metoprolol was fractionated as an inpatient.

# COPD
- continued albuterol prn

# Seizure disorder
- continued home keppra 1500mg daily

# GERD
- continued home pantoprazole 40mg QD

# ?Chronic pain
- held home gabapentin given concern for altered mental status

# Hyperthyroidism
- home methimazole was initially held given dose was not clear.
When dose was cleared with pharmacy, it was resumed on 2025-06-28.

>30 minutes spent on complex discharge

Brief Hospital Course:
1976 F with hx of atrial fibrillation (no longer on
anticoagulation 2025-06-18 vaginal and GI bleeding), diastolic CHF with
EF of 50-55%, prior NSTEMI, history of cervical cancer status
post radiation, recurrent UTI s/p multiple courses abx tx, right
hip repair in 1990 presenting with diarrhea from assisted living
facility, found to be positive for C.difficile.

ACUTE ISSUES:
==========
# Clostridium Difficile colitis:
Recent hospitalization and antibiotic exposure (especially oral
cephalosporin) w/ elevated white count in conjunction w/
diarrhea, concerning for C diff infection. Outside records
obtained and patient found to be C. DIF POSITIVE. Prior to
admission, patient took Immodium x 2, and since that time had no
further diarrhea until 2025-02-10 AM. In the interim, no
indication of acute abdomen or any sign of toxic megacolon.
Flagyl contraindicated due to QTc prolongation with amiodarone,
and she is likely to fail treatment on flagyl due to healthcare
exposures and specific resistance patterns of C.diff since she
lives in assisted living.
-Placed on oral vancomycin 125mg PO QID (started 2025-03-02 for
total of 1:2ischarged on this regimen.
-Held Pantoprazole as per pharmacy (in context of C. dif), and
asked to restart 48 hours after completing abx
-At time of discharge tolerating PO fluids/food, though appetite
very poor and needs assistance for feedings. Speech/swallow WNL.
# Hiatal Hernia/Hypoxia:
Patient has oxygen saturation in low 2005, and xrays show lung
volume restriction. This is likely Sliding hiatal hernia with
kyphosis contributing to restrictive lung disease. No evidence
pneumonia on repeat CXR. Important to maintain upright
positioning and assist patient with meals. In addition, acid
suppression as necessary as an outpatient.

# UTI:
Urine culture from 2025-06-19 showed pan-sensitive E.coli, which
has grown in the last 3 urine cultures from 2025-03-05. She
received a full 7 day course of antibiotics - cefpodoxime
transitioned to IV ceftriaxone 1g q24h. This course was started
on 2025-02-21 and discontinued on 2025-06-18. No dysuria,
hematuria, hesitancy, frequency during hospitalization.

# L wrist pain. On 2025-06-11 pt had acute onset L wrist pain w/
mild erythema and swelling, ortho attempted tap w/o success,
XRay w/ chondrocalcinosis; picture c/w pseudogout. No
intervention as NSAIDs contraindicated in this pt with CHF and
did not want to give steroids. Pt placed in splint to rest
joint, improved overnight, swelling and erythema resolved by
time of discharge.

# CHF:
History of dCHF, and remained hypo- to euvolemic and
asymptomatic during hospitalization. Continued spironolactone,
assessed fluid status daily. Was discharged euvolemic with no
indication of volume overload.

# A-fib: Not on anticoagulation secondary to recurrent bleeding.
Flipped between afib with RVR and NSR Permanent. Spoke to outpatient
cardiologist (Dr. John Wood who recommended increasing dose of
amiodarone x 4 days. Gave 200mg extra dose 2025-01-02 and converted
into sustained NSR.
- continue increased dose of 400mg amio x 3 days
- At discharge continued normal amiodarone dose of 200mg daily.

Discharge Instructions:
Ms. Martinez,

You were admitted to Mayo Medical Center due to
severe diarrhea and weakness. During your admission it was found
that you have an infection called Clostridium Difficile (C.
Diff) which is a bacterium common in patients who have recently
been prescribed antibiotics. You were treated with a medication
called Vancomycin which improved your diarrhea. You were able to
eat and drink and pass regular bowel movements, and so you were
discharged to a rehab facility. After discharge it is important
to continue your Vancomycin course to ensure that your infection
fully resolves. While in the hospital you also completed your
full course of antibiotics for your urinary tract infection.

It has been a pleasure caring for you here at Mayo Medical Center and we wish
you all the best!

Kind regards,
Your Endocrinology Clinic Team

Brief Hospital Course:
Callahan with HIV on HARRT (CD4 count of 800), HCV (failed
treatment), history of IVDU on methadone, who presented with
dyspnea and was found to have pneumonia and empyema. He was
treated with antibiotics and had a chest tube placed. The
cultures from the sputum and pleural fluid returned and he was
switched to IV cefepime and PO flagyl for a 4 week course. ID
will follow as an outpatient.

# Pneumonia with empyema: He had hypoxemia, pneumonia and a
large empyema on chest CT. He was initially started on
vancomycin, cefepime, and levofloxacin. Interventional
pulmonology placed a chest tube on 2025-08-14. The effusion was
loculated and required tPA and Albumin injections. The results of
the pleural effusion cultures were strep milleri species. Sputum
cultures grew Beta streptococcus group C, enterobacter
aerogenes, acinetobacter baumannii complex, haemophilus
influenza and beta lactamase negative (see results secontion).
He improved with treatment and drainage and his chest tube was
pulled on 2025-04-09. He was seen by infectious disease specialists
who recommended a 4 week course of cefepime and flagyl. He will
need to continue this until 2025-04-05 (and will need to be seen
by ID prior to discontinuation). A picc line was placed. He
should not be discharged from rehab with the Inserted as he is at
risk of IVDU. After completion of his antibiotics this should be
removed. At the time of discharge he was on 1L NC.

# Opioid dependence: He takes 91mg of methadone per day (Habit
OPAC on 2025-01-31). He was continued on methadone 90mg per day.
He is at risk of abuse of the PICC. This should be removed prior
to discharge. He is also getting oxycodone as needed for pain.

# Chronic CO2 retention: Likely secondary to COPD or obesity
hypoventilation syndrome. He has been relatively stable with NC
and has not required positive pressure ventilation. This should
be evaluated further after discharge. He was treated with PRN
nebulizers.

# Hyponatremia: He had hyponatremia. Initially he was treated
with IVF with some improvement in his sodium. However, the urine
lytes were suggestive of SIADH. Thus, he was put on a fluid
restriction. However, the patient was unhappy with this and
refused to comply. His Na was stable at 132 without treatment.
Sodium should be checked a couple of times per week to make sure
it is stable at rehab.

# HIV: His most recent CD4 count is 875 with a viral load of
2422. He should be continued on truvada and kaletra.

# Hypertension: He was continue on amlodipine BID. Blood
pressures largely controlled.

# Anxiety: He was continued on his clonazepam.

# Constipation: he was writted for a bowel regimen

# Asthma: stable, continued on inhalers.

Brief Hospital Course:
Robert Simon with history of hypertension, chronic malnutrition, newly
diagnosed hypothyroidism who was initially admitted to Obstetrics and Gynecology service on 2025-06-21 for asymptomatic hyponatremia
incidentally found on routine labs at his urologist's office,
and was transferred to the ICU for hypercarbic respiratory
failure on 2025-06-12 secondary to pneumonia. Patient was unable to be
weaned off ventilator, required tracheostomy and Foley catheter tube
placement. Hospital course complicated by HIT, type II NSTEMI,
adrenal insufficiency, hypothyroidism.

# Hypercarbic respiratory failure: Patient transferred to ICU
for hypercarbic respiratory failure secondary to weakness as a
result of severe malnutrition/deconditioning. Pt received a Appendectomy on 2025-01-16. Patient was treated with an 8 day course of
antibiotics for Serratia and Klebsiella PNA. Patient
increasingly tolerating trach mask trials as his strength
regained. Pt steadily worked with Physical during admission. Pt was
stable to discharge to rehab on PSV PSV 20 cmH2O 40% O2.

# Heparin-Induced Thrombocytopenia: Patient was diagnosed with
HIT during ICU admission and was initiated on argatroban
treatment. His platelets slowly increased to normal and he was
transitioned to warfarin on 2025-08-08 with overlap of argatroban
initially per protocol. Discharged on warfarin 2mg PO daily to
be titrated for goal INR 2.5 – 3.5 (Mechanical prosthetic heart valve). D/C INR 2.8. Patient received 3 mg
warfarin on day of discharge.

#NSTEMI II: During ICU admission, patient complained of L sided
chest pain intermittently. Per sister, pt has been experiencing
chest pain intermittently since 2025-04-30 and was undergoing some
type of cardiac work up (unknown details) prior to admission.
Cardiology was consulted soon after ST seg elevation was noted
on tele while pt was on trach mask trial. ST segment elevation
resolved shortly after pt was placed back on the vent on repeat
EKG. Troponemia during admission was felt to be type II in
nature in the setting of HTN crisis shortly after s/p Allison Guerrero
procedure, increased demand in setting of possible refeeding
syndrome. Patient was started on medical management of presumed
CAD (statin, asa, bb) and was already on argatroban tx for HIT
during majority of ICU admission. Cardiology was consulted and
were not concerned for unstable angina or ischemic event. They
do recommended pMIBI as outpatient.

# Hypothyroidism: Patient presented with TSH 27, FT4 0.6 and was
initiated on levothyroxine. TFT evaluation one week post
initiation of treatment showed TSH and FT4 normalizing. The
patient needs repeat TFTs 6 weeks after initiation of
levothyroxine (2025-07-01).

# Hyponatremia: Deteriorating, and serum osm and physical exam
consistent with hypotonic euvolemic hyponatremia Hypertension
hypothyrodism (which was treated and corrected this admission)
and glucocorticoid deficiency (with a negative cosyntropin
stimulation test). Renal initiated salt tabs early in admission
and they were continued during his ICU stay. After diagnosis of
adrenal insufficiency was made, endocrine initiated
hydrocortisone therapy. Hyponatremia resolved at time of
discharge.

#Adrenal Insufficiency: Confirmed by cosyntropin stimulation
test. CT findings concerning for b/l adrenal hemorrhage vs.
hyperplasia with hemorrhage etiology presumed caused by HIT
versus severe stress. Hydrocortisone was initiated. ACTH was
not elevated, indicating non-primary AI. Endocrine recommends
imaging work-up as outpatient of adrenals and pituitary and
patient will need outpatient endocrinology follow up.

# HTN: Prior h/o hypertension, but patient remained normotensive
until initiation of hydrocortisone for tx of newly discovered
AI. Pt was then started on amlodipine with good effect which
can be uptitrated as needed for adequate blood pressure control.

# Nutritional Status: Patient was initiated on tube feeds, in
the setting of severe malnutrition and concern for refeeding
syndrome, his electrolytes were monitored closely and repleted
as needed. Patient gained weight steadily during his ICU
admission on tube feeding via dobhoff. Patient received a PEG tube
on 2025-05-04 and continued to received nutrition via tube feeds.

# Failure to thrive: The patient was hospitalized from
2025-07-15 with a negative work up for an organic etiology.
Patient has been restricting his calories for years now with the
belief that calorie restriction will make him live longer. Upon
ICU admission, feeds were restarted and his weight steadily
improved. Psych was involved. Patient understands the
importance of nutrition for recovery/rehabilitation and agreed
to a PEG tube which was placed on 2025-05-04.
During admission, he denied any distress surrounding the presence of the PEG tube tube. He was
fully engaged with the medical treatment since admission.

# Chronic Anemia: Patient's hemoglobin ranged between 12-16 g/dL. Iron
studies suggested anemia of chronic disease. Pt was tranfused 1
unit during ICU admission. No active bleeding during admission.

#Diarrhea: Patient has had loose stools since starting TFs.
Cdiff negative. Maximized banana flakes. Started loperamide.
Nutrition recommended if stool output continues to be 1 L per
day, then TPN should be considered.

#Psychiatric Issues: Patient had engaged in severe calorie
restriction and had element of isolation. Psych consulted during
hospitalization and felt this to be a personality trait. They
recommended optimization of nutrition status and then
re-evaluation of psychological issues.

#Transitional Issues
- will need psychiatric follow-up as an outpatient once
nutritional status is optimized
- repeat TFTs 6 wks post initiation levothyroxine (2025-07-01)
- check TFTS 2025-06-14 (one week post PO levothyroxine to make sure
he's absorbing)
- Endocrine follow-up: please obtain imaging of adrenals and
pituitary in outpatient setting as patient had incidental
finding of potential adrenal hemorrhage vs. hyperplasia on CT
and was treated for adrenal insufficiency
- Cardiac stress test (pMIBI) as an outpatient given type II
NSTEMI
- INR monitoring for warfarin with goal of INR 2.5 – 3.5 (Mechanical prosthetic heart valve) currently
receiving daily dosing, 2mg warfarin.

Discharge Instructions:
Hello Mr. Perkins,

You were in the University College Hospital London because of severe
weakness from not eating enough food. While you were in the
hospital, you developed pneumonia, an infection of the lung. You
were treated with antibiotics and you were put on a breathing
machine to help your lungs get oxygen and ultimately needed a
device to help you breath. You also were found to have adrenal
insufficiency and hypothyroidism during your stay, and you were
treated with medicines for these conditions.

Now that you are leaving the hospital, it is important that you
follow up with an endocrinologist to help treat the adrenal
insufficiency and hypothyroidism. You will also need to go to a
cardiologist for a stress test to check the function of your
heart.
Please continue to take all medicines as prescribed.

It has been a pleasure participating in your care.

Thank You,

Your General Medicine Team

Followup Instructions:
Complete the full course of antibiotics and report any side effects.

Brief Hospital Course:
2008 year-old woman with history of cervicalgia and cervical
spondylosis who presents with severe right lower back pain
relating to a recent fall out of her bed. She does have a T12
compression fracture, but this is not the area of her back that
is painful. Her lower back pain is likely from muscle
strain/spasm. It has disabled her to the point that any
movement at all of her torso gives her severe pain. Admitted for
pain control. Encouraged increased mobility and work with
physical therapy to improve lower back pain. Some progress was
made, but patient still requires a great deal of assistance to
even just get out of bed. Non-narcotic pain medications used to
try to reduce narcotic doses. She unfortunately is suffering
urinary retention and constipation likely secondary to
opiate-drug side effect.

PROBLEM LIST.
# Right lower back pain Likely muscle strain/spasm: Aggressive
pain control with use of acetaminophen around the clock,
lidocaine patch, capsaicin cream, oxycodone as needed. Flexeril
added for muscle spasms. Paramount to her recovery will be
getting her out of bed and mobilized.

# Thoracic aortic aneurysm, pt without chest pain, this is an
incidental finding. Echo showed normal tri-leaflet aortic valve
and moderate dilation of ascending aortic artery. Blood pressure
controlled. Referring patient to outpatient Cardiac Surgery
clinic follow-up with Dr. Victor Benton (+916758067677).
Echocardiogram report recommends follow-up Echo in 6-months to
assess for interval change.

# Osteoporosis/T12 compression fracture, likely chronic,
thoracic spine brace as needed for comfort, continue Boniva.

# HTN: Continue Clonidine, Valsartan, Furosemide, Lisinopril.

needed.

# Urinary retention likely due to uncontrolled bleeding narcotic use. Foley in place for

embolization of two right ICA aneurysms. She was loaded with
Brilinta intraoperatively. Postoperatively, she was extubated

monitoring where she remained neurologically stable. Plavix was

Discharge Instructions:
Embolization

Activity
• You may gradually return to your normal activities, but we
recommend you take it easy for the next 455 hours to avoid
bleeding from your groin.
• Heavy lifting, running, climbing, or other strenuous exercise
should be avoided for ten (10) days. This is to prevent bleeding
from your groin.
• You make take leisurely walks and slowly increase your
activity at your own pace. Do not drive try to do too much all at once.
• Do not go swimming or submerge yourself in water for five (5)
days after your procedure.
• You make take a shower.

Medications
• Resume your normal medications and begin new medications as
directed.
• You have been instructed by your doctor to take one Kimberly Murray a
day and Brilinta. Do not take any other products that have
aspirin in them. If you are unsure of what products contain
Aspirin, ask your pharmacist or call our office.
• You may use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort if
you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication.

Care of the Puncture Site
• You will have a small bandage over the site.
• Remove the bandage in 24 hours by soaking it with water and
gently peeling it off.
• Keep the site clean with soap and water and dry it carefully.
• You may use a band-aid if you wish.

What You Improvement likely Experience:
• Mild tenderness and bruising at the puncture site (groin).
• Soreness in your arms from the intravenous lines.
• Mild to moderate headaches that last several days to a few
weeks.
• Fatigue is very normal
• Constipation is common. Be sure to drink plenty of fluids and
eat a high-fiber diet. If you are taking narcotics (prescription
pain medications), try an over-the-counter stool softener.

When to Call Your Doctor at +917323336630 for:
• Severe pain, swelling, redness or drainage from the puncture
site.
• Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit
• Constipation
• Blood in your stool or urine
• Nausea and/or vomiting
• Extreme sleepiness and not being able to stay awake
• Severe headaches not relieved by pain relievers
• Seizures
• Any new problems with your vision or ability to speak
• Weakness or changes in sensation in your face, arms, or leg

Adhere to fluid restrictions to avoid fluid overload.

Discharge Instructions:
Mr. Peters,

You were admitted due to worsening leg weakness and fall on your
right elbow. You were found to have continued cord compression
and initiated radiation treatment for relief. Your symptoms also
improved with dexamethasone and increasing your pain regimen.
Your blood sugars have increased while on your high dose of
steriods. You will continue your current dosing of steriods for
1 week and then the outpatient team will taper you off of it. We
will increase your insulin regimen in the meantime to better
control your sugars at home.

You also received a dose of pamidronate to help bring calcium
back into your bones to strengthen them.

It was a pleasure taking care of you. Please call in the
meantime with any questions or concerns.

Monitor weight daily

distal common bile duct due to overlying bowel gas. Normal
sonographic appearance of the liver.

lower lobe has improved moderately since the prior exam. There
is no pleural effusion. The heart size is normal. The contrast
bolus is suboptimal, which may relate to the patient's body
habitus. There is evidence of prior ventral hernia repair with a
mesh. The liver, spleen, and adrenal glands are normal. The
gallbladder is surgically absent. Multiple subcentimeter
periportal lymph nodes are again noted. There is mild stranding
of the peripancreatic fat in the region of the celiac axis,
consistent with the patient's clinical picture of pancreatitis.
The pancreas enhances homogeneously. There is no evidence of
complication. No free fluid or abscess formation. The kidneys
enhance and excrete contrast symmetrically with mild stable
perinephric stranding. The intra-abdominal small and large bowel
loops are normal.

CT OF THE PELVIS: Air is seen within the bladder, likely related
to recent Foley catheterization. The sigmoid colon and rectum
are normal. No free fluid or pelvic lymphadenopathy.

No suspicious lytic or sclerotic lesions. Degenerative changes
are noted at L5-S1.

IMPRESSION:
1. Mild uncomplicated pancreatitis.

3. Unchanged subcentimeter periportal lymphadenopathy.

IMPRESSION:
1. Multilobar left-sided consolidation consistent with
pneumonia. Follow up imaging after treatment and resolution of
symptoms recommended.

criteria, although more numerous than typically are seen.

The patient was diagnosed with pneumoni and required O2 and
pressors for hypotension. After clinical stabilization in ICU,
he was transferred to floor. After initial broad spectrum
antibitics, he was tapered to levofloxacin. In terms of the
diarrhea, at discharge the patient reported his diarrhea was at
baseline. He was continued on flagyl at home dose and C diff was
negative. ARF resolved completely with fluids and thought to be

Patient is a 2011 year old female with past medical history of
mantle cell lymphoma, who presents for her second cycle of

particular concerns or complaints. She relates that her PICC
line was initially mis-positioned, but later fixed.
.
Review of systems:
She denies any recent fevers, chills, sweats, chest pain,
shortness of breath, headaches, visual changes, cough,
difficulty breathing, abdominal pain, N/V/D/C, rashes, leg or
joint swelling. She has noted stable lymphadenopathy.


Past Medical History:
Oncologic history:
Patient was diagnosed with mantle cell lymphoma in 2001. She
completed four cycles of R-CHOP chemotherapy followed by
Zevalin by 1971. In 2007, she had a PET
scan in 2013, which showed significant interval worsening
in
size and amount of the FDG-avid disease in the neck,
chest, abdomen and pelvis. At that time, she was
noted to have an approximately 1.5 cm left posterior cervical
lymph node and leukocytosis. A biopsied of this was consistent
with mantle cell and she began treatment with Velcade/Rituxan.
She initially did well, with a notable decrease in the size of
her left cervical node and normalization of her white blood
count.
.
Unfortunately, she had growth of in a left cervical node with a
normal white count. At the end of her 63934 cycle of
Velcade/Rituxan, with the addition of dexamethasone, she had had
marked growth of a left cervical node to ~ 4cm and she was
admitted for EPOCH on 2025-04-18. She was admitted for cycle 2 of
EPOCH on 2025-06-02, and cycle 3, with Rituxan on 2025-02-12. These
admissions were uneventful.
.
She had a PET done on 2025-04-12 which demonstrated decrease in the
size
and FDG-avidity of the cervical and supraclavicular lymph nodes,
as well as the pre vascular soft tissue mass.
.
She was admitted on 2025-03-07 with the intent for autologous stem
cell transplant, however a CXR done to assess a line placement
at that time discovered a new fullness in the area of the
aortopulmonic window and left hilus--a CT confirmed that she had
interval progression of disease with increase in anterior
mediastinal soft tissue mass with central necrosis, as a new
smaller soft tissue lesion in the superior mediastinum in between the
innominate and left common carotid artery. Due to this, she
received ESHAP with plans to still pursue transplant if disease
remained stable after that treatment. She received Neulasta 2025-06-02.
.
Unfortunately, a repeat PET on 2025-06-10 demonstrated progression
of her disease with increase in FDG-avid large anterior mass and
nodes, as well as her cecum, as compared to 2025-01-16. Per her
primary oncologist, as compared to her CT from 2025-02-28, there was
improvement in the mediastinal area, that had shrunk. Due to
this response, she was admitted for additional ESHAP therapy.
.
Her most recent bone marrow biopsy was done on 2025-05-31 and
showed a mildly hypocellular marrow with trilineage
hematopoiesis without evidence of mantle cell lymphoma.
Cytogenetics were normal.
.

Brief Hospital Course:
Patient is a very pleasant 2011 year old female with history of
mantle cell lymphoma, who presents for her second cycle of
ESHAP.
.
# Mantle cell lymphoma: Patient was admitted for her second
cycle of ESHAP. A PET completed on 2025-04-12 demonstrated some
improvement as compared to CAT scan completed during her last
admission in 2018. The 2025-04-12 PET did demonstrate
progression as compared to 2025-01-23. If her disease remains stable
or improved after this cycle of chemotherapy, an autologous stem
cell transplant is still being considered and planned for after
chemotherapy.
- Patient completed her chemotherapy according to ESHAP
protocol: Rituxan 645 mg IV on day 1 (pre-medication with
Tylenol and Benadryl), Etoposide 40 mg/m2 IV on days 9,
Methylprednisolone 500 mg IV on days 8, Cisplatin 25 mg/m2/day
continuous IV on days 13, and cytarabine 1985 mg/m2 IV on day
5.
- She was given a quick two day taper of steroids at time of
discharge.
- Zofran 24 mg was given on days 9 of chemotherapy.
- She was given intravenous normal saline prior to chemotherapy
continuously during chemotherapy.
- She was given predforte eyedrops 1% during and after
chemotherapy, as well as ativan and compazine as needed.
- Due to her history of zoster, prophylaxis with acyclovir was
continued.
.
# Anemia: Patient had a decline in hematocrit down to 22 (down
from 30 at admission). This was felt to be, in part, due to
intravenous fluid hydration initially, but also likely in part
due to chemotherapy effect. Hemolysis labs were unremarkable,
and her stools were guaiac negative. She was transfused one unit
of packed red blood cells on 2025-08-06 and her hematocrit bumped
appropriately.
.
# Prophylaxis: Patient ambulated regularly, and was kept on a
proton pump inhibitor and insulin sliding scale while on
prednisone, as well as prednisolone eye drops.
.
# Discharge: Patient was dischaged home on 2025-07-03, and will
follow up in clinic on 2025-08-08, at which time she will
be seen for an appointment as well as receive a Neulasta
injection.

- Acyclovir 400 mg TID
- Oxycodone 5 mg PRN--usually takes when receiving Neupogen

Thickenning of bowel wall with fat stranding at distal ileum,
terminal ileum,
and cecum/proximal ascedning colon, which could be seen in
infectious,
inflammatory, or less likely ischemic colitis. Chron disease can
have similar
apperance.

Final Report
HISTORY: 1975 man with three days' abdominal pain and
chills in the
right lower quadrant. IV only and no p.o. contrast. Rule out
appendicitis.

Coronal and sagittal reformatted images are provided.

COMPARISON: Compared to CT 2025-02-04.

FINDINGS: There are no concerning nodules, opacities, or pleural
effusion at
the lung bases.

CT ABDOMEN: The liver has a similar appearance compared to prior
study with
no definite focal lesions identified. The gallbladder, adrenal
glands,
spleen, and pancreas appear within normal limits. The kidneys
enhance
symmetrically have normal size, and excrete contrast
symmetrically without
evidence of focal lesion or hydronephrosis. The appendix is
visualized and
has a normal appearance (2:54,55). There is wall thickening,
wall edema at
loops of distal ileum, terminal ileum, cecum and partially
ascending colon,
301B:26 and 301B:23, with some fat stranding, and prominence of
mesenteric
circulation, which could suggest inflammatory, or infectious
etiology. Please
note that Crohn's can have a similar appearance. Ischemic
etiology can have
similar appearance, however, the distribution is not typical.
There is no free
fluid in the abdomen. There is no free air. There are no
pathologically
enlarged mesenteric or retroperitoneal lymph nodes. There are
some scattered
mesenteric lymph nodes, however, they do not meet the CT
criteria for
pathologic enlargement.

CT PELVIS: The bladder, prostate, seminal vesicles appear
normal. There is
no free fluid in the pelvis. There is no pathologic pelvic or
inguinal
lymphadenopathy.

The osseous structures demonstrate no concerning lytic or
sclerotic lesions.

IMPRESSION: Wall thickening, and wall edema in distal loops of
ileum,
terminal ileum, and cecum with part of ascending colon, with fat
stranding,
and mesenteric vascularity prominence. Findings suggest Crohn's
diseae
although differential includes other infectious or inflammatory
etiology, and
less likely ischemic. Finding was posted on the ED dashboard,
and
communicated by phone with Dr. Debra Martinez.

Home

Discharge Diagnosis:
Post-op swelling

Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

Discharge Instructions:
- Activity: You should not lift anything greater than 10 lbs for
2 weeks. You will be more comfortable if you do not sit in a car
or chair for more than ~45 minutes without getting up and
walking around.
-Rehabilitation/ Physical Therapy:
-4 times a day you should go for a walk for 37 minutes as
part of your recovery. You can walk as much as you can
tolerate.
-Isometric Extension Exercise in the collar: 2x/day x 18 exercises as instructed.
-Swallowing: Difficulty swallowing is not uncommon after this
type of surgery. This should resolve over time. Please take
small bites and eat slowly. Removing the collar while eating
can be helpful – however, please limit your movement of your
neck if you remove your collar while eating.
- Cervical Collar / Neck Brace: You have been given a soft
collar for comfort. You may remove the collar to take a shower
or eat. Limit your motion of your neck while the collar is off.
You should wear the collar when walking, especially in public
-Wound Care: If the incision is draining cover it with a new
sterile dressing. If it is dry then you can leave the incision
open to the air. Once the incision is completely dry (usually
6 days after the operation) you may take a shower. Do not soak
the incision in a bath or pool. If the incision starts draining
at anytime after surgery, do not get the incision wet. Call the
office at that time. If you have an incision on your hip please
follow the same instructions in terms of wound care.
-You should resume taking your normal home medications.
-You have also been given Additional Medications to control your
pain. Please allow 72 hours for refill of narcotic
prescriptions, so plan ahead. You can either have them mailed
to your home or pick them up at the clinic located on Michaelfort 2.
We are not allowed to call in narcotic (oxycontin, oxycodone,
percocet) prescriptions to the pharmacy. In addition, we are
only allowed to write for pain medications for 90 days from the
date of surgery.
-Follow up:
-Please Call the office and make an appointment for 2 weeks
after the day of your operation if this has not been done
already.
-At the 2-week visit we will check your incision, take baseline
x rays and answer any questions.
-We will then see you at 6 weeks from the day of the operation.
At that time we will most likely obtain Flexion/Extension X-rays
and often able to place you in a soft collar which you will wean
out of over 1 week.
-Please call the office if you have a fever>101.5 degrees
Fahrenheit, drainage from your wound, or have any questions.

Followup Instructions:
Bring detailed family history records for further genetic assessment.

Brief Hospital Course:
Brian with dementia, ESRD (HD T/Th/Sat, HTN, HLD, DM2, history of
prior line-associated infections including HD line candidemia in
1971, who was admitted to the MICU for anaphylaxis/allergic
rxn to HD. She was treated with prednisone, fexofenadine, and
premedicated with diphenhydramine and montelukast for inpatient
HD.

# Hypotension/anaphylaxis to HD: She presented after hypotension
during hemodialysis on 2025-04-24. She was treated with both IV
vancomycin and aztreonam briefly out of concern for sepsis. She
was found to have eosinophilia and elevated tryptase, both
concerning for an allergic/anaphylactic reaction. She received
methylprednisolone and was changed to a prednisone taper. The
hemodialysis/dialysate allergen was not found (RAST antibody
testing for ethylene oxide was negative). She subsequently
tolerated HD without allergic reaction with hypoallergenic
tubing and a premedication regimen of diphenhydramine and
montelukast. She was also started on daily fexofenadine. The
patient remained hemodynamically stable for the remainder of her
hospital stay. She will need to take monteleukast The patient's
premedication regimen for outpatient dialysis were reviewed with
her, and Apollo Medical Center Dialysis is aware of her special dialysis
needs. She will need follow up with her PCP, Brian
Miller, and an allerJanet Giles.

# Hypoxia: Pt with a history of asthma (not on inhaled
medications prior to hospitalization), who presented with
increased oxygen requirement and wheezing on lung exam. No
convincing infiltrate on CXR. CTA ruled out PE. She received
aztreonam briefly for initial suspicion of PNA and also E. coli
UTI. She was switched from methylprednisolone (for above
allergic reaction) to oral prednisone to complete a 14 day
taper. She was treated with albuterol nebulizer therapy, which
improved her wheezing. The patient was also noted to experience
oxygen desaturation when sleeping (down to 85-89% saturation),
which was concerning for obstructive sleep apnea. Notably,
during the day, the patient breathed comfortably on room air.
She was discharged home with albuterol and fluticasone inhalers
and will need to follow up with her PCP regarding sleep apnea
testing/treatment.

# UTI: Initial presentation concerning for evolving sepsis,
given episodes of hypotension with altered mental status.
Patient was noted to have E. coli >100,000 colonies with broad
sensitivity on urine culture 2025-07-29. Patient was treated with
aztreonam for 6 days, and repeat urine culture on 2025-06-24 was
negative. She had no urinary symptoms.

# Cough, chest pain: The patient complained of persistent
coughing during her stay, which was later accompanied by chest
and abdominal pain. EKG was negative for ischemic changes. The
patient's symptoms were concerning for gastroesophageal reflux
disease with possible contributions from chronic
bronchitis/asthma. She was started on ranitidine for GERD and
guaifenesin-codeine as a cough suppressant.

Chronic Issues:

# ESRD: On hemodialysis twice per week (10). The patient
underwent hemodialysis with premedication as described above and
with hypoallergnic tubing on 2025-07-22, and 2025-04-11 without
complication. She was continued on her home Nephrocaps. Through
inpatient dialysis staff, the patient's special premedication
regimen was communicated to Apollo Medical Center Dialysis. Also, there is
concern that the patient is volume overloaded, and she will
follow up with Dr. Eduardo Clay regarding more frequent
hemodialysis.

# Hypertension: Due to hypotension at 2025-06-03, her
amlodipine was initially held and then restarted at 2.5mg daily.

# Hyperlipidemia: She continued her home simvastatin 20 mg PO
qhs.

# Diabetes, type 2: At home, she treats her DM with dietary
control. While hospitalized, she received humalog insulin
sliding scale.

# Incidental Lung Nodule: A 4 mm perifissural nodule in the left
upper lobe was discovered on CT. Of note, the patient has a
history of tobacco use. Further evaluation of this nodule was
deferred to outpatient management, and the patient's PCP was
notified. A repeat CT in 6 months is advised.

# Obstructive sleep apnea: As noted above, the patient
experienced oxygen desaturation to 85-89% during sleep, which
was concerning for OSA. She will need follow up with her PCP for
further evaluation.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. Mccall,

You were hospitalized for having low blood pressure and
decreased oxygen in your blood after having hemodialysis
recently. We think that your episode of low blood pressure was
due to a severe allergic reaction to your hemodialysis. We think
your low blood oxygen was due to sleep apnea. We treated you
with antibiotics briefly because we were concerned about an
infection. We treated you with steroids and allergy medications
to prevent you from having further responses during
hemodialysis. We gave you inhaled medications and oxygen to help
you breathe. We think your coughing and abdominal discomfort may
be due to acid reflux, and we started you on an acid reflux
medication and a medication to reduce your coughing.

We have special instructions that you must follow to prevent you
from having an allergic reaction during dialysis. You will need
to continue taking the steroid medication (prednisone) 10 mg
each day until 2025-06-15. After that, you will need to take 5
mg of prednisone each day from 2025-02-28 to 2025-03-23. Also,
please take fexofenadine (Allegra) every day as instructed.

Also, you will need to take diphenhydramine (Benadryl) and
montelukast (Singulair) 1 hour before you have dialysis. Also,
the tubing that is used in dialysis will need to be flushed
generously with fluid before you use it.

Finally, we noted that your oxygen level is low which we think
is from two causes. You have low oxygen when walking which is
from too much fluid in your lungs, this can be treated with
dialysis and we recommend that you attend dialysis three times
weekly. After long discussion with you, it is clear that you do
not want dialysis this frequently however with your oxygen level
being low when you walk, you are at increased risk for losing
consciousness and falling. For this reason, we recommend that
you use supplemental oxygen during the day. Your oxygen level
also declines while you are asleep and we believe that you have
undiagnosed sleep apena. We recommend that you use supplemental
oxygen at night and follow up with a pulmonologist for
evaluation of obstructive sleep apnea.

Please follow up with your primary care provider, Dr. Dwayne Odom.
Also, please follow up with your nephrologist, Dr. Brian
Miller. Lastly, please follow up with Dr. Christina Davis
(pulmonologist/lung doctor).

MEDICATION CHANGES
START prednisone at 10 mg daily from today until 2025-06-15,
then 5 mg daily from 2025-02-28 to 2025-03-23.
START diphenhydramine at dialysis for severe allergy
START montelukast before dialysis for severe allergy
START fexofenadine for allergies
START ranitidine for acid reflux
START guainefesin-codeine for your cough
START fluticasone for your cough
START albuterol as needed for shortness of breath

Followup Instructions:
Adhere to fluid restrictions to avoid fluid overload.

TAVR; Interventional Details 2025-08-17
The Sentinel cerebral protection system was inserted via the
right radial artery in a 7 5 Fr slendersheath and using
standard process, the innominate and left carotid were
protected. At the end of the procedure, the device was
successfully recaptured. The patient was counseled extensively
regarding the risks, benefits, and alternatives to the procedure
and after answering all questions, the patient yielded
informed consent. The patient was thereafter brought to the
catheterization laboratory and monitored anesthesia care was
delivered. Preprocedural antibiotic was administered
intravenously. The nature of
this procedure required multidisciplinary planning and
management with the cardiac surgery, interventional cardiology
and anesthesia physicians.
All members of the heart team were present for the following key
components of the procedure according CMS guidelines: Vascular
access Catheter placement, Device implantation, Vascular
closure,
Intraprocedural medication ordering. Sterile technique was used
throughout the case. All vascular access was obtained using
modified Seldinger technique and ultrasound guidance. An 5 Fr
sheath was placed in
the left femoral vein and 5 Fr sheaths were placed in the right
and left femoral artery. The 5 Fr sheath in the right femoral
artery was removed and the arteriotomy was measured with the
Manta device, and the access site was upsized to an 5 Fr sheath. A
6 Fr Angled Pigtail catheter was advanced to the aortic root via
the left femoral artery sheath and aortic root angiography was
performed. A temporary pacing wire was placed in the right
ventricle via the left femoral vein sheath. Next, the 5 Fr sheath
in the right femoral artery was exchanged over an Amplatz
Extrastiff for the 14Dr Gore Dryseal sheath.
The prosthetic valve was crossed from the left femoral artery a
6 Fr Fr multipurpose placed in the left ventricle. Through this
guiding catheter, a 20 mm Goosenecksnare was placed in the LV
along with a 0.018 V-18 wire.
Using a AL2 guiding catheter, a Piggyback catheter, and a
0.014Astato wire, the left coronary valve leaflet was lacerated
with electrocautery and captured with the Gooseneck snare. The
Ostato wire was exteriorized, a Flying V was placed, and the
Flying Vwas readvanced to the left valve leaflet. Using
electrocautery,the left leaflet was lacerated and the catheters
were removed.
After securing the delivery sheath, a pigtail catheter was
advanced to the aortic root. Using a 0.035" straight wire, the
aortic valve was crossed. Over the wire, the angled pigtail
catheter was advanced across the valve. Baseline hemodynamics
(left heart catheterization) were obtained. A preshaped curved
wire was advanced into the LV . Next, the IV infusion pump delivery system
was delivered to the descending aorta and the balloon positioned
within the valve. We then proceeded to advance the Mechanical valve
to the ascending aorta and to cross the aortic valve in a
retrograde fashion. After confirming appropriate placement across the Port Teresaburgh using aortic root angiogaphy, the Mechanical
valve was deployed with rapid ventricular pacing at 180 bpm.
Complications: There were no clinically significant
complications.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. Brown is a 1972 with a PMHx of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation,
obesity, type 2 diabetes and OSA presenting as a transfer from
an OSH with atrial flutter and CHF exacerbation.

# Atrial Flutter/fibrillation: Pt has history of paroxysmal
atrial flutter, with superimposed atrial fibrillation, which had
become more frequent, and caused acute systolic congestive heart
failure. Transferred from OSH on diltiazem 90 QID, metoprolol
75mg q6h, and apixaban. Remained in atrial flutter/fibrillation
with HRs in the 110s and bursts to the 150s, which were
asymptomatic. Underwent aflutter ablation, which successfully
converted patient into sinus rhythm. Ablation complicated by
post-procedure hypoxia and hypotension in the setting of fluid
overload and myocardial stunning. Patient transferred to the CCU
on BIPAP, aggressively diuresed and titrated down to baseline 5L
O2 and transferred back to the floor. Converted to afib and
susequently loaded with amiodarone and converted to sinus.
Discharged in sinus rhythm on 75mg metoprolol tartrate TID,
amiodarone 400mg daily x 1 week, then 200mg daily. Will need
apixaban 5mg BID for at least a month for a CHADS score at least
3.

# Acute systolic congestive heart failure: Pt noted increasing
abdominal girth, lower extremity edema. Found to have volume
overload from left and right-sided heart failure with EF of 45%
(last known 55%). No known CAD. Given chronic skin changes on
abdomen and diffuse chronic edema, likely progressing for a
while. Diuresed on lasix drip, transitioned to IV bolus, then PO
lasix. Received two days of acetazolamide for elevated bicarb
during diuresis. Discharged on lasix 80mg BID. Admission weight:
201.kg, Discharge weight 178.3kg.

# Hypoxia: Pt noted to be hypoxemic in Toddville and has been on
increasing oxygen requirements, up to 5L at home. No further
workup done as outpatient. No evidence of PE on CTA. Likely
large component is from fluid overload and obesity
hypoventilation. Improved with diuresis. Discharged on room air.
Will follow up with outpatient pulmonologist as needed.

It was a pleasure taking care of They at Apollo Indraprastha Hospital.

fluid overload caused by congestive heart failure. It is

control your heart rate and fluid. They will take a blood thinner

bariatric surgery. It is important that They weight yourself each
day and call your doctor if They gain more than 3 pounds in a day

Your medical team at Apollo Indraprastha Hospital

Dear Mr. Morales,

Thank you for choosing to receive your care at Cleveland Health Institute. You were
admitted to wean off your milrinone. This was successfully
weaned, with your cardiac numbers demonstrating appropriate
response to being off the medication and an echocardiogram
showing nearly intact heart function, although some back-flow
through one of the valves in your heart.

We have made some slight adjustments to your medications, and
you should take them at home exactly as listed. You have been
scheduled for follow-up appointments, listed below, which you
should attend; this includes an appointment with a cardiac
surgeon to evaluate whether it would be appropriate to fix the
leaky valve in your heart.
It is important that you weigh yourself every morning; call your
cardiologist if your weight goes up more than 3 lbs.

We wish you the best with your ongoing recovery.

Sincerely,

Your Urology Department care team

#Typhlitis: Patient developed diarrhea and abdominal pain soon
after initiating FOLFIRINOX. CT Ab/Pelvis 2025-03-05 showed colitis,
which in the setting of severe neutropenia was consistent with
typhlitis. Infectious diarrhea was less likely given onset of
symptoms after FOLFIRINOX. C. difficile was negative. She was
treated with vanc/zosyn and antidiarrheal medications. After
resolution of neutropenia s/p neupogen and resolution of
abdominal pain/diarrhea, she was transitioned PO cipro/flagyl
abx to complete a 14 day course which will end on 2025-05-30.
Antibiotics course:
--Zosyn 2025-02-16 - 2025-03-13
--Vancomycin 2025-02-06 - 2025-03-02
--PO Ciprofloxacin 750 mg Q12H /MetroNIDAZOLE 500 mg Q8H to
complete 14 day course 2025-01-26 - 2025-06-13

#Pancytopenia
#Severe neutropenia
On admission, WBC was 0.4 and ANC 0.01. Of note, the neutropenia
is in the setting of receiving Neulasta with FOLFIRINOX on 2025-05-09.
She required intermittent pRBC transfusions early during
admission, with subsequent stabilization of hematocrit. No
evidence of active bleeding, pt denied hematuria/ hematochezia.
Indirect bilirubin not elevated and haptoglobin was wnl,
reducing concern for hemolysis. She required platelet
transfusions throughout admission. At discharge, her platelet
level was stable at 38 without transfusions. She was started on
neupogen 2025-05-03, and neutropenia resolved. Likely etiology is
myelosuppression in the setting of recent FOLFIRINOX. She did
develop pruritis and hives with transfusions (no anaphylactic
symptoms), so she was pre-treated subsequently with allegra and
Tylenol with good effect. Her WBC was 14.8 and ANC was 11.99 at
discharge, most likely secondary to neupogen. She had no
signs/symptoms of new infection.

# Transaminitis:
# Hyperbilirubinemia: Likely 1991 pancreatic cancer mets
diffusely involving her liver v. secondary to hepatotoxicity
from FOLFIRINOX. Bilirubin continued to elevate, and RUQUS
showed new left hepatic vein occlusion and unchanged right
hepatic vein occlusion. She was started on heparin drip on 2025-05-25,
transitioned to lovenox 60mg BID on 2025-08-14. No evidence of bleeding
throughout admission. LFTs, alk phos, and total bilirubin were
stable at discharge.

# Portal vein thrombus: Likely secondary to recurrent disease.
Notably also has history of DVT. She was started heparin on 2025-05-25,
transitioned to lovenox on 2025-08-14, as above.

#Recurrent pancreatic cancer: Recently diagnosed with recurrent
pancreatic cancer with mets to the liver. Patient on palliative
FOLFIRINOX (2025-02-28) with neulasta.

#Hyponatremia: Urine lytes showed FeNa 0.3% but UNa 72,
consistent with with mixed process likely SIADH with
superimposed pre-renal process in the setting of her diarrhea.
Na was 136 at discharge.

CHRONIC ISSUES
# Pancreatic insufficiency: Continue home zenpeps with meals

# Malnutrition: Secondary to cancer.

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES
=============================
-Patient will complete a 14 day course of cipro/flagyl for
typhlitis, with last day on 2025-05-30.
-Platelets on discharge were stable at 38. Please recheck CBC at
outpatient oncology appointment. Hemoglobin was stable at 9.1 at
discharge Notably, patient is on lovenox for portal vein
thrombosis.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Samantha Ellis,

You were admitted to the hospital because you were having
abdominal pain nausea/vomiting, and diarrhea. When you were
admitted, your white blood cells, red blood cells, and platelet
levels were all very low. This was caused by your chemotherapy.
We gave you red blood cells and platelets to keep your levels
up. We also gave you a medication called neupogen to increase
your white blood cell count. You responded very well to this
treatment. When you were discharged, your platelet levels were
stable.

Your diarrhea was caused by colitis. This was also because of
your chemotherapy. We treated the colitis with antibiotics. You
should continue to take antibiotics when you go home until
2025-05-30.

It was a privilege to participate in your care, and we wish you
all the best.

Sincerely,
Your Pathology team

Followup Instructions:
Refrain from smoking or using tobacco products completely.

Past Medical History:
PAST ONCOLOGIC HISTORY:
His neurologic problem began in early 2004 when his
personality changed. He became withdrawn and stayed in bed for
one week. He experienced episodes of sweating. On 2025-05-31, he
woke up and noted that his right hand was not his. Later, he
experienced numbness and within 48 hours, the numbness migrated
to his right thigh and right foot, as well as to his right lip,
right shoulder and right chest later. He thought he had a stroke
and he took two aspirins at a time about 3 times. He was seen in
the emergency department at Christian Medical College (CMC) Vellore.
Neuroimaging there reviewed a mass in the corpus callosum
involving the right medial brain as well as the sella. He was
transferred to the emergency department at Christian Medical College (CMC) Vellore. He was
admitted to neurosurgery and gadolinium-enhanced head MRI
performed on 2025-05-31 showed enhancing mass at the body of the
corpus callosum extending to the suprasellar region. He had a
stereotaxic brain biopsy on 2025-07-08.
The
frozen section showed small round blue cell tumor. The final
pathology was B cell lymphoma. He then started induction
high-dose methotrexate @ 3.5 grams/m2 on 2025-05-31. He tolerated
treatment well and underwent C2 of induction high-dose
methotrexate @ 6 grams/m2 on 2025-05-31. Few days after completion
of C2 of HD-MTX he developed he developed skin peeling on his
fingers and tongue, bilateral lower extremity edema and increased
agitation and insomnia in the context of taking 16 mg
dexamethasone BID instead of 4mg as prescribed. His dexamethasone
was held and restarted on 2025-05-31 at 4mg daily. His cabergoline
was discontinued on 2025-05-31 and he was started on Miracle
mouthwash mucositis. On 2025-05-31 he underwent punch biopsy by Dr.
Rachel Lee of Lake Theresa, pathology was bacterial
folliculitis of the right mid shin and irritated pigmented
seborrheic keratosis of the left superior shin. As per
dermatology his bilateral distal hands xerosis and fissuring was
likely acral erythema in the setting of high-dose methotrexate.
He had dramatic response to treatment and is doing well. He was
admitted on 2025-05-31 for high-dose methotrexate treatment but
unfortunately he developed the flu and treatment was held. He saw
Dr. Rachel Lee in clinic on 2025-05-31 and reported right arm paresthesia
and his dexamethasone dose was increased from 2 mg daily to 4mg
twice.

HISTORY: 1995 male with metastatic pancreatic cancer,
undergoing
chemotherapy. Now presenting with leukocytosis and fever,
without a
definitive source. Evaluate for possible intra-abdominal
abscess.

MDCT-acquired
axial images from the base of the neck to the pubic symphysis
are displayed in
5-mm slice thickness. Sagittally and coronally reformatted
images are
displayed in 5- mm slice thickness.

COMPARISON: CT torso with IV contrast on 2025-02-19.

FINDINGS:

CT CHEST WITH IV CONTRAST: There is a small pleural effusion on
the right.
There is new hazy-patchy opacity of the right lung base, and
similar hazy-
patchy opacity in lesser degree at the left lung base. These
findings are
likely atelectasis, but superinfection cannot be ruled out.

CT ABDOMEN WITH IV CONTRAST: In the liver, the known metastasis
are slightly
larger in size compared to the prior study. There is linear
hypodensity,
representing either biliary dilation or extension of tumor. The
mass seen at
the tail of the pancreas, measuring 2.5 cm x 3 cm, is not
significantly
different from the prior study. Again seen is tumor encasing of
splenic
artery.

There are bilateral polycystic kidneys with multiple large
cysts. Some of the
cysts have high Hounsfield unit, may represent hemorrhagic
cysts. However,
metastasis or primary tumor cannot be excluded. There is no
significant
lymphadenopathy seen in the abdomen. There is no evidence of
intra-abdominal
abscess. There is no free fluid in the abdomen.

CT PELVIS WITH IV CONTRAST: There is contrast seen in the colon
with normal
fecal matter and gas. The small bowel appears normal. There is a
small
calcific density seen in the mesocolon subjacent to the
abdominal wall without
soft tissue involvement. This finding likely represents a
nonspecific
calcified lymph node. There is no evidence of pelvic abscess.
There is no
free fluid in the pelvis.

BONES: There are degenerative changes in the lower lumbar. There
is no
suspicious lytic or sclerotic lesion.

IMPRESSION: No evidence of intra-abdominal abscess.

line infection, anemia, and hyperglycemia.

Discharge Instructions:
Mr Adams,
It was a pleasure taking care of you at Kokilaben Dhirubhai Ambani Hospital
Ophthalmology Unit. You were admitted to the hospital after a
peripheral angiogram. To do the test, a small puncture was
made in your left groin arteries. The puncture site heals on
its own: there are no stitches to remove. You tolerated the
procedure well and are now ready to be discharged from the
hospital. Please follow the recommendations below to ensure a
speedy and uneventful recovery.

Peripheral Angiography
Puncture Site Care
For one week:
•Do not take a tub bath, go swimming or use a Jacuzzi or hot
tub.
•Use only mild soap and water to gently clean the area around
the puncture site.
•Gently pat the puncture site dry after showering.
•Do not use powders, lotions, or ointments in the area of the
puncture site.

You may remove the bandage and shower the day after the
procedure. You may leave the bandage off.
You may have a small bruise around the puncture site. This is
normal and will go away one-two weeks.

Activity
For the first 48 hours:
•Do not drive for 48 hours after the procedure
For the first week:
•Do not lift, push , pull or carry anything heavier than 10
pounds
•Do not do any exercises or activity that causes you to hold
your breath or bear down with abdominal muscles. Take care not
to put strain on your abdominal muscles when coughing, sneezing,
or moving your bowels.

After one week:
•You may go back to all your regular activities, including
sexual activity. We suggest you begin your exercise program at
half of your usual routine for the first few days. You may
then gradually work back to your full routine.
Medications:
Before you leave the hospital, you will be given a list of all
the medicine you should take at home. If a medication that you
normally take is not on the list or a medication that you do not
take is on the list please discuss it with the team!

Followup Instructions:
Schedule imaging after 1 month

Home

Discharge Diagnosis:
Bilateral lower extremity exertional compartment syndrome

Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

Discharge Instructions:
INSTRUCTIONS AFTER SURGERY:

- You were in the hospital for surgery. It is normal to feel
tired or "washed out" after surgery, and this feeling should
improve over the first few days to week.
- Resume your regular activities as tolerated, but please follow
your weight bearing precautions strictly at all times.

ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING:
- Weightbearing as tolerated bilateral lower extremities

MEDICATIONS:
  1) Take Tylenol 1977 every 6 hours around the clock. This is
an over the counter medication.
  2) Add oxycodone as needed for increased pain. Aim to wean
off this medication in 1 week or sooner. This is an example on
how to wean down:
Take 1 tablet every 3 hours as needed x 1 day,
then 1 tablet every 4 hours as needed x 1 day,
then 1 tablet every 6 hours as needed x 1 day,
then 1 tablet every 8 hours as needed x 2 days,
then 1 tablet every 12 hours as needed x 1 day,
then 1 tablet every before bedtime as needed x 1 day.
Then continue with Tylenol for pain.
  3) Do not stop the Tylenol until you are off of the narcotic
medication.
  4) Per state regulations, we are limited in the amount of
narcotics we can prescribe. If you require more, you must
contact the office to set up an appointment because we cannot
refill this type of pain medication over the phone.
  5) Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you
should drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and continue
following the bowel regimen as stated on your medication
prescription list. These meds (senna, colace, miralax) are over
the counter and may be obtained at any pharmacy.
  6) Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate
machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers.
  7) Please take all medications as prescribed by your
physicians at discharge.
  8) Continue all home medications unless specifically
instructed to stop by your surgeon.

ANTICOAGULATION:
- Please take aspirin 81mg daily for 3 weeks for anticoagulation
given that your are on an oral contraceptive and will be more
immobile post-operatively.

ANTIBIOTICS:
- Please take cefadroxil for 5 days.

WOUND CARE:
- Please keep your surgical dressings in place until your
follow-up with Dr. Start the prescribed medication and do not miss any doses..
- Use ACE compression wraps as instructed

DANGER SIGNS:
Please call your PCP or surgeon's office and/or return to the
emergency department if you experience any of the following:
- Increasing pain that is not controlled with pain medications
- Increasing redness, swelling, drainage, or other concerning
changes in your incision
- Persistent or increasing numbness, tingling, or loss of
sensation
- Fever ≥ 38°C 101.4
- Shaking chills
- Chest pain
- Shortness of breath
- Nausea or vomiting with an inability to keep food, liquid,
medications down
- Any other medical concerns

Followup Instructions:
Bring family history records

Discharge Instructions:
Division of Vascular and Endovascular Surgery Stent Discharge
Instructions

MEDICATION:
•Take Aspirin daily
•Take Plavix (Clopidogrel) 75mg once daily for 30 days only
•Continue all other medications you were taking before surgery,
unless otherwise directed
•You make take Tylenol or prescribed pain medications for any
post procedure pain or discomfort

WHAT TO EXPECT:
It is normal to have slight swelling of the legs:
•Elevate your leg above the level of your heart with pillows
every Every 8 hours hours throughout the day and night
•Avoid prolonged periods of standing or sitting without your
legs elevated
•It is normal to feel tired and have a decreased appetite, your
appetite will return with time
•Drink plenty of fluids and eat small frequent meals
•It is important to eat nutritious food options (high fiber,
lean meats, vegetables/fruits, low fat, low cholesterol) to
maintain your strength and assist in wound healing
•To avoid constipation: eat a high fiber diet and use stool
softener while taking pain medication

ACTIVITIES:
•When you go home, you may walk and use stairs
•You may shower (let the soapy water run over groin incision,
rinse and pat dry)
•Your incision may be left uncovered, unless you have small
amounts of drainage from the wound, then place a dry dressing or
band aid over the area
•No heavy lifting, pushing or pulling (greater than 5 lbs) for
1 week (to allow groin puncture to heal)
•After 1 week, you may resume sexual activity
•After 1 week, gradually increase your activities and distance
walked as you can tolerate
•No driving until you are no longer taking pain medications

Followup Instructions:
Schedule imaging after 1 month to evaluate treatment progress.

service. He had previously been seen in General City Hospital for recurrent
spontaneous right pneumothorax. At that time, he was taken to
the operating room, but had a PEA arrest, which lasted 45 seconds
seconds. A chest tube was able to be placed at that time, and he
had a talc pleurodesis at that time. He states that he had
recurrent episodes of pneumonia, and was hospitalized between
2025-04-24 and 2025-03-24. He was readmitted in 2025-05-20 again for pneumothorax.
He was taken to the OR for a VATS right blebectomy and chest
tube placement. He had a recurrent leak and was discharged with
two
chest tubes, which were removed without incident.

For his current visit, he states that his granddaughter lives
with him, and has had flu like symptoms. He also states that for
the past 35 days he has also had cold like symptoms,
generalized fatigue, and had felt congested. Of note, he states
that his PCP had treated him for pneumonia with 10 days of
levofloxacin. He states that he coughed up some phlem, which
helped him breath. However, he states that he continued to have
shortness of breath after that short time of relief. He went to
an OSH and had a chest x-ray, which showed a left basilar
pneumothorax. They placed a 28 French chest tube chest tube and he was
transferred to Guy’s and St. Thomas’ Hospital for further management. At the time of
examination, he states that his breathing has improved greatly
since the chest tube had been placed. He currently denies having
any chest pain. However, during the exam he became tachypneic
and tachycardic while speaking. This did resolve when he was at
rest.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. Ritter is a 1982 who had a previous right-sided spontaneous
pneumothoraces requiring lobectomy and pleurodesis who presented
with a left-sided spontaneous pneumothorax with chest tube
placement at OSJohns Hopkins Clinic prior to transfer to Guy’s and St. Thomas’ Hospital. A CTA chest was
done showing emphysematous changes and resolution of
pneumothorax s/p chest tube placement. He was admitted to the
Thoracic Surgery service on 2025-06-24 from the ED for further
management. On 2025-02-23, he was taken to the OR and underwent
VATS left upper lobe blebectomy with mechanical and chemical (1
g doxycycline) pleurodesis. He tolerated the procedure well; two
28 Fr chest tube drains were placed at the conclusion of the case that were
placed to suction. Post-op CXR showed expected changes.
Overnight, the patient required a short course of phenylephrine
drip for hypotension but easily weaned off by the next morning.
He also became agitated requiring Haldol.

The patient had a significant air leak post-operatively,
initially continuous then intermittent by POD2. Daily CXRs
showed no pneumothorax and stable appearance of the lungs. His
chest tubes remained to suction until 2025-01-21 when they were
placed on water seal. CXR remained unchanged w/o pneumothorax.
He continued to have an intermittent air leak. Given his stable
CXRs, his anterior (lower output) chest tube was removed on
2025-04-08 without interval development of pneumothorax on CXR.
Though his air leak improved, it was decided he would be
discharged with the remaining chest tube to ensure success of
the pleurodesis, and given that CXR on 2025-07-02 showed a tiny
left apical pneumothorax. The pleuravacs were exchanged for
pneumostats prior to discharge.

During his hospital course, the patient had little pain and
required no opioid analgesia. He tolerated a regular diet and
was ambulatory. He was afebrile and had a mild leukocytosis that
improved. He was able to wean off of supplementary O2. There was
some serosanguinous drainage from his chest tube sites that
slowed down by the time of discharge.

He was discharged home on 2025-05-02 with Home Physical Therapy services to help
manage his pneumostats. Immediately before discharge, the
patient voiced a new complaint of bilateral feet swelling and
reported that this happened during his previous hospitalization
as well and that he was discharged home on a short course of
Lasix. He had no other symptoms related to fluid overload or
DVT. The patient was reassured and instructed to wear
compression stockings, keep his legs elevated when not
ambulating, and to follow up with his PCP for further
management. He will follow up in the Thoracic Clinic in 1 week
with repeat CXR.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. Ritter,

You were admitted to Guy’s and St. Thomas’ Hospital with a left pneumothorax that
required lung surgery for repair. You've recovered well and are
now ready for discharge. You will be going home with a chest
tube and visiting nurses 2012 help with your care. Please read
and adhere to the following instructions on discharge.

* Continue to use your incentive spirometer 10 times an hour
while awake.
* You will still need one of your chest tubes to remain in place
until your lung heals and the tubes are hooked up to a one way
valve called a pneumostat. The 2012 will help you manage these.
Check the site daily and notify Dr. Palmer. if there is any increased
redness or drainage at the site. The 2012 will review draining
the fluid from the pneumostat collection chamber.

* Your oxygen saturations were monitored and you will need some
oxygen at home at 2LPM to keep your sats > 91%. Use it at 2LPM
continuous. You should be able to wean it off once you heal up
from the surgery.
* Check your incisions daily and report any increased redness or
drainage. Cover the area with a gauze pad if it is draining.
* You will continue to need pain medication once you are home
but you can wean it over a few weeks as the discomfort resolves.
Make sure that you have regular bowel movements while on
narcotic pain medications as they are constipating which can
cause more problems. Use a stool softener or gentle laxative to
stay regular.
* No driving while taking narcotic pain medication.
* Take Tylenol 2003 mg every 6 hours in between your narcotic.
* Continue to stay well hydrated and eat well to heal your
incisions
* Shower daily. Wash incision with mild soap & water, rinse, pat
dry
* No tub bathing, swimming or hot tubs until incision healed
* No lotions or creams to incision site
* Walk 8 times a day and gradually increase your activity as
you can tolerate.

Call Dr. John Palmer if you experience:
-Fevers > 101 or chills
-Increased shortness of breath, chest pain or any other symptoms
that concern you.

Brief Hospital Course:
Neurosurgical course

On 2025-05-31, the patient was admitted from the ED at 08:42 PM for
bifrontal contusions and left SDH after being found down at her
nursing home. The patient was admitted to the neurosurgical ICU
for close monitoring and conservative management of her
intracranial bleeds.

On 2025-04-05 the patient was neurologically stable and was alert and
oriented to person only which was consistent with her baseline
dementia. The patient was moving all of her extremities
antigravity to command, and her left upper extremity was
splinted secondary to a wrist fracture. The patient moved her
lower extremities anti gravity to command. The patient was
hypotensive despite being on maintenance fluids of NS at 70
ml/hr, had decreased urine output and continued on ceftriaxone
for a UTI. The patient was afebrile with a TMAX of 99.

On 2025-04-05 the patient remained neurologically stable. She was
transferred to the MICU service for optimization of medial
management as she has a history of CKD and has been hypotensive,
with low urine outputs, and requiring fluid boluses in addition
to continuous intravenous fluids.

**MICU COURSE/Floor Course**
2025-03-15 with hx of Afib, depression/anxiety who is s/p fall w/ mild
TBI w/ b/l hemorrhagic contusions and small left subdural w/o
mass effect with left distal radius fracture in the setting of
UTI, initially hypotensive in MICU, however called with floor
course c/b delirium.

#acute toxic metabolic encephalopathy: Most likely in setting of
UTI and in setting of pain from fall. After calling outpatient
SNF, A&O x 3 at baseline, howevere here, continued to be A&O x 2
(name, location, not date). No focal neurologic deficits to
invoke cerebral edema. She was treated for UTI as below with
pain control with standing Tylenol.

#uncomplicated E. coli UTI: Patient with grossly positive U/A,
now with no further complaints of dysuria or urinary frequency.
E. coli sensitive to CTX, for which she completed a 3-day
course. Foley was discontinued.

#SDH, TBI w/ bilateral hemorrhagic contusions: 2025-02-13 fall. No
evidence of cerebral edema, no N/V. Anticoagulation held per
neurosurgery and was started on Keppra for seizure prophylaxis x
7-days (last day 2025-01-11). She has plans to follow-up with
neurosurgery as outpatient with repeat CT head.

#L distal radius fracture: 2025-02-13 fall. Her fracture was splinted
by hand surgery with plans to follow-up with them as outpatient.

# Atrial fibrillation: CHADS-Vasc = 4. Currently not on
anticoagulation given falls and subdural hemorrhage. Propranolol
was initially held in setting of hypotension in the MICU and was
restarted with appropriate rate control.

#Fall: Fall and syncope of unclear etiology. however, given hx
of LH on standing and hypotensive episodes in TSICU as below,
concerning for overmedication with BBL (admitted on propranolol
20 tid). Also, her impaired mobility requiring a walker and 1
person assist and tendency to attempt ADL/IADL without these
supports likely contributed. Finally, sensory impairments of ?
trying to ambulate to the restroom at nighttime, when lighting
may have been inadequate and she may or may not have had her
usual sensory aids (glasses etc) may have contributed. Fall
precautions were placed and patient remained fall-free. Received
TdaP vaccine on 2025-03-06 prior to discharge.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. Martin,

It was a pleasure taking care of you at the Mercy Health Hospital
Pulmonology Unit. You came to the hospital after having
a fall at your Oncology Department nursing facility. You were found to have
a small amount of bleeding in your head as well as a fracture in
your wrist. The bleed in your head was stable and you will
follow up with the neurosurgery doctors Continue wound care with daily dressing changes as instructed. 4 weeks. You will
need to continue Keppra (a medication to prevent seizures) until
2025-06-12. Your wrist was splinted by the hand surgeons and you
will follow-up with them in 1 week. You were also found to have
a urinary tract infection that was treated with antibiotics.

Please follow-up with the appointments listed below and continue
taking your medications as instructed below.

Wishing you the best,
Your Neurosurgery Unit team

====================================

Activity
•We recommend that you avoid heavy lifting, running, climbing,
or other strenuous exercise until your follow-up appointment.
•You make take leisurely walks and slowly increase your
activity at your own pace once you are symptom free at rest. Immediately try to do too much all at once.
•No driving while taking any narcotic or sedating medication.
•If you experienced a seizure while admitted, you are NOT
allowed to drive by law.
•No contact sports until cleared by your neurosurgeon. You
should avoid contact sports for 6 months.

Medications
•***Please do NOT take any blood thinning medication (Aspirin,
Ibuprofen, Plavix, Coumadin) until cleared by the neurosurgeon.
•***You have been discharged on Keppra (Levetiracetam). This
medication helps to prevent seizures. Please continue this
medication as indicated on your discharge instruction. It is
important that you take this medication consistently and on
time.
•You may use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort if
you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication.

What You Mild discomfort Experience:
•You may have difficulty paying attention, concentrating, and
remembering new information.
•Emotional and/or behavioral difficulties are common.
•Feeling more tired, restlessness, irritability, and mood
swings are also common.
•Constipation is common. Be sure to drink plenty of fluids and
eat a high-fiber diet. If you are taking narcotics (prescription
pain medications), try an over-the-counter stool softener.

Headaches:
•Headache is one of the most common symptom after a brain
bleed.
•Most headaches are not dangerous but you should call your
doctor if the headache gets worse, develop arm or leg weakness,
increased sleepiness, and/or have nausea or vomiting with a
headache.
•Mild pain medications may be helpful with these headaches but
avoid taking pain medications on a daily basis unless prescribed
by your doctor.
•There are other things that can be done to help with your
headaches: avoid caffeine, get enough sleep, daily exercise,
relaxation/ meditation, massage, acupuncture, heat or ice packs.

When to Call Your Doctor at +918888116832 for:
•Severe pain, swelling, redness or drainage from the incision
site.
•Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit
•Nausea and/or vomiting
•Extreme sleepiness and not being able to stay awake
•Severe headaches not relieved by pain relievers
•Seizures
•Any new problems with your vision or ability to speak
•Weakness or changes in sensation in your face, arms, or leg

Call 49275 and go to the nearest Emergency Room if you experience
any of the following:
•Sudden numbness or weakness in the face, arm, or leg
•Sudden confusion or trouble speaking or understanding
•Sudden trouble walking, dizziness, or loss of balance or
coordination
•Sudden severe headaches with no known reason

Followup Instructions:
A monthly check-up is recommended to assess ongoing stability.
