Brief Hospital Course:
2006 F with asthma, COPD on home O2 presenting with progressive
cough, SOB, and increased O2 requirement.
.
# Acute COPD exacerbation
# Acute on chronic hypoxic respiratory failure
# Morbid obesity, potentially with component of obesity
hypoventilation syndrome
Given two weeks of progressive symptoms and increased O2 use,
appears to be acute COPD exacerbation likely triggered by viral
URI. CXR not convincing for PNA, but read as possible RLL
infiltrate. PE thought to be unlikely given subacute onset and
preceding URI symptoms. Improved with treatment as COPD
exacerbation with standing nebs, PRN nebs, and IV-then-PO
steroids as well as for possible atypical PNA (initially with
levofloxacin, 1 dose in ED, then doxycycline). Avoided
quinolones after admission given history of mood disorder and
age. Discharged with plan to continue standing duonebs TID x2
days, then transition to PRN nebs, then to PRN inhalers.
Discharged on steroid taper
(60,50,50,40,40,30,30,20,20,10,10,stop). Last day would be
2025-05-22. Discharged on doxycycline to complete 7 day course
for possible atypical PNA given her overall improvement during
hospitalization. Close PCP Jennifer Murphy apt scheduled. Paged Dr. Melanie Murray,
City Clinic pulmonologist on day of discharge to provide clinical
update and discuss discharge planning, but we were not able to
get in touch prior to discharge. Pulmonary clinic appointment
is pending (Care Connection team will call patient with
appointment). Think she would benefit from consideration of
pulmonary rehab given her recurrent COPD exacerbation and
significant chronic hypoxic respiratory failure.
.
# Markport edema
Had recently been on Lasix 2025-01-25, last echo was from 2025-04-23. Present
evidence of vol overload on exam or CXR aside from 1+ Markport edema
that she reports is basically unchanged from her baseline,
though got Lasix in the ED. ProBNP of 534 was equivocal,
particularly in the setting of morbid obesity, so we obtained
TTE to eval for CHF, pulm HTN. TTE showed normal LVEF and Present
compelling evidence of pulmonary hypertension or LV diastolic
dysfunction (though limited by body habitus, TV was not
visualized). Her leg edema remained stable throughout her
hospitalization without any treatment with Lasix.
.
# Positive UA
She reported malodorous urine recently, now resolved. Initial
UA was positive with 3+ leuk esterase, 29 WBCs, only 1 epi, but
UCx grew mixed bacterial flora. She had received 1 dose
levofloxacin in ED and on doxy as above, but we elected not to
treat specifically for UTI given absence of predominant
infecting organism on UCx and resolution of symptoms.
.
# OSA on home CPAP
- CPAP at nigh while hospitalized
.
# Mood/insomnia
History of depression with suicidality. Currently stable.
- continued doxepin, though there was some uncertainty to her
home dose of doxepin, she thought she was taking 250 mg daily,
but per discussion with her pharmacy, she last filled an Rx for
150 mg tabs (she takes 2) and 25 mg tabs (she takes one) for a
potential home dose of 325 mg. We left a message with her
psychiatrist. We advised the patient to clarify with her
psychiatrist the intended dosing of this medication.
- contined home clonazepam
- continued home risperidone
.
.
.

Discharge Instructions:
Ms Dunn,

You were admitted to the hospital with worsening shortness of
breath at rest and with exertion. This was thought to be most
likely due to an exacerbation of your COPD, possible caused by a
recent viral or bacterial respiratory infection. You were
treated with steroids, frequent nebulizers, and oral antibiotics
with improvement in your symptoms.

As we discussed, it is very important that you use oxygen when
you exert yourself, such as anytime you are walking, including
trips to the bathroom. This will help you feel less short of
breath with walking, as well as to walk longer distances before
having to stop to catch your breath.

Please complete the remaining course of antibiotics
(doxycycline), the last dose will be on 2025-05-22.

Please complete the remaining course of steroids (prednisone).
You are starting a taper. Tomorrow you will take 60 mg, then 50
mg each day for 2 days, then 40 mg each day for 2 days, and so
on until you complete prednisone. Your last dose of prednisone
is scheduled for 2025-05-22.

Please see your primary care physician, Jennifer Murphy, at the
appointment scheduled (see below).

Please see your pulmonologist (lung doctor), Dr. Melanie Murray 26 days to follow-up on this hospitalization for exacerbation
of your COPD and to evaluate your recovery on the prednisone
taper.

It was a pleasure caring for you while you were in the hospital
and we wish you a full and speedy recovery.

Sincerely,
The General City Hospital Medicine Team

Brief Hospital Course:
Mrs. Richards is a 1975 year old y/o female with hypothyroidism,
DMII, and recent diagnosis of primary CNS lymphoma c/b CVA
leaving her with minimally responsive and chronic g tube/foley
as well as pseudomonal CAUTI (s/p cipro 2025-05-04). She
presented initially CHA ED from her rehab facility with fever,
rigors and suprapubic tenderness consistent with UTI with MRSA
bacteremia and found to
have new hydrocephalus, transferred to Max Super Speciality Hospital for further
management, with course c/b hyponatremia thought Respiratory Failure SIADH and
persistent sacral ulcer now s/p diverting colostomy 2025-08-11.

# Unstageable sacral ulcer: S/p OR debridement 2025-08-11. S/p
diverting colostomy and further debridement of her sacral wound
on 2025-08-11 so as to improve wound healing. Patient underwent
aggressive wound care by nursing. A wound vac was placed by the
wound care team and healthy granulation tissue started to appear
on the wound. Some irritation was noted prior to discharge and
the patient was given a break from the wound vac. Wound care has
been in contact with her rehab facility to plan transfer of
wound care once discharged.

# MRSA Bacteremia: Most likely sources include bladder vs.
ulcers/osteomyelitis (however not seen on XRays of the
heel/pelvis - but can be assumed that has in the pelvis). A
temporary tunneled line was placed for access on 2025-08-11. She was
started on Daptomycin 8mg/kg q24h and Ceftaroline 600mg q12h
with plans to finish her antibiotics on 2025-07-09. On 2025-07-09, the
patient was noted to have fevers and be hypoxic. Her CXR showed
volume overload which improved with diuresis. Given the fevers,
ID was reconsulted who said that the patient's fevers were
likely due to drug fevers from the patient's ceftaroline as she
had previously experienced a rash while on this medicine. The
ceftaroline was discontinued and she was started on daptomycin
which was then switched to linezolid for better pulmonary
coverage. The patient underwent a CTA to rule out PE as a
non-infectious cause of fevers. This was negative. In addition,
the patient underwent a CT Abd/Pelvis to assess for a wound
infection given her recent surgery. This demonstrated
pneumotosis in her colon. A lactate was obtained which was
normal. Her vital signs and physical exam were unchanged.
Although her Lactate has risen to 4, given her clinical
stability, a surgical consulted recommended no intervention. The
patient then received 1u of pRBC for a borderline Hgb which
improved her lactate. She remained afebrile and hemodynacmially
stable on Meropenem/Linezolid which she completed on 2025-07-09.

# Hydrocephalus in the context of CNS Lymphoma: Last MRI brain
on 2025-06-21 showed improved mass size, no mass effect, and no
hydrocephalus. Found to have new hydrocephalus on CT at 2025-06-21 and the patient was transferred to Max Super Speciality Hospital.
Started on decadron prior
to transfer. She was found to be less responsive on 2025-07-09. Repeat
NC Head CT (2025-06-21) without increase in hydrocephalus. Her mental
status was waxing and waning, but generally improved throughout
her stay. She was continued on 1 mg IV dexamethasone daily along
with valproic acid. The valproic acid was discontinued on 2025-07-09
to see if this would improve her mental status and she had not
demonstrated seizure activity. There was no change in the
patient's clinical status upon discontinuation. In addition, her
dexamethasone was decreased to 0.5mg daily. She was converted to
prednisone 3mg daily which was discontinued on 2025-07-09.

# Hyponatermia: Renal consulted, thought to represent SIADH and
as such fluid restricted and limited free water intake. Her
sodium began to improve on 2025-07-09 and has remained stable.

# Diarrhea: C. Diff and Norovirus negative. Gave Loperamide and
Lomotil PRN, and wound management subsequently improved with
colostomy.

# Normocytic anemia: with Hgb 6.6, MCV 9.4 Hgb was wnl 2025-07-09
but appears to have been slowly downtrending--as low as 6.8 in
early 2025-07-09 with FOBT positive 2025-07-09. Iron 13, TIBC 158
(transferrin saturation 8.2%) suggesting severe iron deficiency,
so the patient was given a dose of IV iron.

# History of DVT: Was on lovenox 2025-01-18 (stopped d/t
thrombocytopenia). Very high risk DVT--prior provoked UE DVT,
recent ischemic stroke. As such, was continued on Heparin 5000 units SC q8h.
Given her
decreased mobility, she was discharged on Lovenox 40 mg SC daily

# Poor nutritional status. Patient was maintained on tube feeds
through NG tube tube.

# DMII: Hyperglycemic in the setting of high dose decadron.
Continued home NPH 8 units BID. Will need to have blood sugars
monitored at rehab given decreasing steroid needs with plans to
lower insulin requirements.

# Hypothyroidism: T4 level wnl, TSH wnl. Continued home
levothyroxine.

# Hyperkalemia: In the setting of TFs, transitioned to Nepro
formulation with subsequent resolution of hyperkalemia.

# Rash: Developed a rash on 2025-07-09 after the infusion of
Ceftaroline. ID was re-consulted and said given that lack of
pulmonary or systemic symptoms, that she should continue with
her ceftaroline infusions. She was started on fexofenadine with
improvement of her symptoms.

#Goals of Care: Multiple family meetings were held during the 2025-06-29
hospital stay. It was determined that our plan would
be to get the patient strong enough to receive chemotherapy
defined as 1. Improved functional status while working with
physical therapy. 2. Improvement of Sacral Ulcer. We also
discussed that we would avoid unnecessary/invasive testing and
procedures as these would be unlikely to change her management.
Therefore, the patient's code status was changed to DNR/DNI. The
family was willing to entertain CMO status if the patient were
to decompensate clinically.

Brief Hospital Course:
This is a 1973 y/o man with PMH of recurrent GI bleeding admitted
with bright and dark blood in the stool for several weeks and
hct 21.1.
.
# GI bleeding: Patient has had multiple episodes of lower GI
bleeding in the past. His current episode is likely secondary to
hemorrhoids versus diverticulosis. He did not have any
nausea/vomiting or hematemesis to suggest upper GI source though
this is technically a possibility. He was subsequently placed on
a PPI IV bid initially. There were no signs of mesenteric
ischemia on CT scan, though diverticulosis was noted.
    Pt was admitted initially to the MICU for management of his
lower GI bleed. He received a total of 3 units and 2L of IV
fluids. His crit bumped from 21.1 to 28 after 3 units. He was
transferred to the floor the next day. He was guiaic negative on
admission, but did eventually pass at least 2 soft stools with
grossly bright red blood. His crits were followed bid, and
remained stable. He was seen by GI, who did not think further
endoscopy would be useful for hemorrhoid/diverticular bleed, and
deferred evaluation to General Surgery for possible surgical
intervention, e.g. hemorrhoidectomy. Pt is seen by Dr. Michael Martinez in
Colorectal Satellite clinic. Given pt's long history of hemorrhoidal
bleeds with banding, and pt's risk factors at age 1973, Surgery
did not think pt would benefit from hemorrhoidectomy at this
time. Pt continued to be hemodynamically stable on day of
discharge. He will be seeing his PCP, Tiffany Harris for
repeat crit check, and will be following up with Dr. Michael Martinez in
Colorectal Satellite clinic in the beginning of Aug 2022. He was
instructed to call his PCP or go to the ED if bleeds return or
worsen. Pt was discharged on high fiber diet and fiber
supplementation to improve bulking of the stools. Fiber
supplementation should be uptitrated to~30mg/day.
.
# EKG changes: Patient has had no complaints of chest pain but
had TWI on EKG done in ED. This likely represents sequelae of
anemia and demand ischemia given Hct of 21.1. Repeat EKG the
next a.m. showed resolution of TWI, just flattened T waves in
the lateral V leads. Cardiac enzymes were negative x3. Pt had no
additional cardiac symptoms during admission.
.
# Leukopenia: Per OMR, this is a chronic condition for pt. 4 ct was 2.8 on admission. WBC ct stabilized at 4.5 on day of
discharge. Pt continued to remain afebrile.
.
# Glaucoma: Pt was continued on his home Timolol and Brimonidine
eye drops.
.
# h/o gout: Stable.l Pt did not have any symptoms of gout flare,
and was continued on home Allopurinol.
.
#pruritis: Pt complained of some mild itching on back. There
weere no lesions or rashes visible. He was treated with Sarna
lotion, with improvement.
.
# FEN: Regular cardiac diet, replete lytes prn
.
# PPx: pneumoboots, bowel regimen
.
# Access: 16 g PIV and 18 g PIV
.
# CODE: DNR/DNI per patient and wife, DNR status documented in
OMR
.
# COMM: With patient and wife, Tiffany, Harris
.
# DISPO: Home, with follow-up this week with PCP Alejandro Hart
Dr. Michael Martinez in Colorectal Satellite clinic in the beginning of Aug 2022.

Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted for management of lower GI bleeding. This was
most likely related to your hemorrhohids. You were lightheaded
and had a very low blood level. Therefore, you received IV
fluids and 3 units of blood. You were seen by GI and Colorectal
Surgery, and they did not feel that surgery was necessary at
this time. You will be following up as an outpatient with Dr.
Michael Martinez in Colorectal Satellite clinic. Please see your PCP, Tiffany Victoria Williams Harris for follow-up of you blood levels.
.
If you experience any return of profuse bleeding,
lightheadedness, dizziness, nausea, vomiting, or have any other
concerns please call your MD or return to the ED.
.
Please continue your medications as prescribed.
- We added Psyllium as a new fiber supplement to your daily
diet. This can be bought over the counter (e.g. Metamucil.) This
should help to keep your stools soft and reduce your tendency to
bleed from straining when constipated.

Return in 2 weeks with lab reports

This is a 1997 year old female with a PMH significant for
diabetes, HTN, HL, hypothyroidism, who presents status cardiac
arrest at her nursing home. Per family report, patient was seen
choking by family and quickly beceame unresponsive. Nursing
staff called EMS, who found the patient sitting upright in a
chair, cyanotic, and pulseless. CPR was initiated at 1:30 07:20 PM
and patient received 1mg IV epinephrine and 1mg IV atropine with
return of pulses. Patient was noted to have tonic/clonic
jerking and was intubated en route to National University Hospital.
.
At National University Hospital, patient underwent head CT which was
indeterminate and chest radiograph was with report of aspiration
pneumonia. Patient was given 500 cc NS bolus. Patient was
transferred to National University Hospital to further evaluate possible subarachnoid
hemorrhage.
.
At the National University Hospital ED, initial vital signs were: 98.8, 78, 121/99, 24,
96% on AC FiO2 100%, 450, 14, Peep 5. Patient was initially not
on any sedation and was withdrawing to pain with pupils 5-6 mm
bilaterally and sluggish. Labs notable for a leukocytosis of
16.2, 5 bands, ALT: 304, AST: 272, Trop: 0.12, MB 7, lactate of
2.1. Repeat head CT without acute bleed. Chest radiograph with
no acute process. CTA was without PE but with bilateral
multifocal pneumonia. Patient was given vancomycin 1gram IV,
500 mg IV flagyl, and ceftriaxone 1g IV X 1. Post-cardiac
arrest team was consulted and hypothermia protocol was
initiated. Vecuronium 10mg IV X 1 was given due to shivering.

Brief Hospital Course:
# Cardiac arrest: based on history most likely etiology was
aspiration event resulting in likely PEA arrest. Evidence of
bilateral multifocal pneumonia on CTA is consistent with this
possibility. Patient without evidence of cardiac ischemia by
ECG or cardiac biomarkers. CPR initiated in the field with
return of pulses. Reportedly, in the emergency room a family
member said the patient was full code. Therefore, hypothermia
protocol was initiated in the ED, and patient remained
intubated. In the morning, the patient's power of attorney (Mr.
Jennifer Carpenter called to report patient was DNr/DNI. The paperwork
making him POA were faxed to the MICU. Mr. Jennifer Carpenter was spoken to
over the phone (he resides out of state) and confirmed the
patient was DNR/DNI prior to her arrest. The patient was thus
rewarmed using the re-warming protocol. according to the
patient's prior wishes she was extubated and died at 5:24pm. The
family declined autopsy but the medical examiner accepted the
case. The NEOB was contacted but did not deem her a candidate
for organ donation.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. Rodriguez was taken to the operating room by Dr. Haley Gill on
2025-06-18 for right thoractomy and tracheoplasty with mesh, right
main stem bronchus/bronchus intermedius bronchoplasty with mesh,
left main stem bronchus bronchoplasty with mesh, and
bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage, for her
tracheobronchomalacia. The patient was extubated in the OR, and
transfered to the PACU for recovery then to the SICU for further
management that evening. The patient had epidural with
bupivicaine and dilaudid for pain management. The patient was
transferred to the floor in stable condition on 2025-06-08 (POD 2).
The following is a systems review of her hospital course.

Neurologic: The patient had a bupivicaine and dilaudid PCA which
was effective in pain control. Acute pain service managed this
until it was discontinued on POD 3. The patient was transitioned
to tylenol, ibuprofen, oxycodone, and lidocaine which was
effective. She is also on home gabapentin. She remained
neurologically intact. Of note she admits to former narcotic
addiction, therefore care will be made to assist in titrating
off oxycodone after the immediate postoperative period.

Pulmonary: The patient was brought out of the OR with a right
28 Fr chest tube which was removed on POD 1 without pneumothorax
on postpull film. Aggressive pulmonary toilet was instituted
with around the clock mucolytics, nebulizers, and incentive
spirometry. The patient was kept on her home inhalers, and home
bipap. She also remained on oxygen via nasal canula 4L during
the day. At night she used her home bipap. Pulmonary was
consulted and followed alongside. The patient had desaturations
during the night on bipap therefore her nightly oxygen was
increased to >92% with 6L. Two doses of lasix were given POD 3
and 4 for pulmonary congestion and to diurese after the initial
fluid given postoperatively. CXR's were followed.

CV: The patient remained hemodynamically stable throughout her
stay in NSR.

Abd: The patient was advanced to a regular diet which she
tolerated. Stool softeners were given. The patient passed gas
and was close to having a bowel movement on date of discharge.

GU: A foley was kept during the epidural and dc'd POD 3 with
good urinary response thereafter.

ID: The patient remained afebrile with CBC trends followed.
There were no infectious processes during the stay.

Prophylaxis: Heparin was given for DVT prophylaxis.

Dispo: Hepatology evaluated the patient on POD 4 and deemed the patient
would benefit from a short stay in rehab, which the patient
would also like.

The patient was ambulating with Walker, tolerating a regular diet
with pain controlled on an oral regimine. Her oxygen on 4L nasal
cannula was 95%. The patient was deemed stable for transfer to
rehab on 2025-05-20.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. Weber was a same day admit after undergoing pre-operative
work-up as an outpatient. On 2025-07-27 she was brought directly to
the Operating Room where she underwent pericardial stripping.
Please see operative report for surgical details. Following
surgery she was transferred to the Jasminefort for invasive monitoring
in stable condition. Within 24 hours she was weaned from
sedation and extubated.

She does have a psychiatric history including bi-polar disease.
She experienced post-operative delerium. Narcotics and
benzodiazepines were minimized. Psychiatry was consulted and
her mental status cleared. Beta blocker was initiated and the
patient was gently diuresed toward her preoperative weight. The
patient was transferred to the telemetry floor for further
recovery.

The patient was noted to have a lower extremity tremor.
Neurology was consulted. The tremor did resolve prior to
discharge. Neurology recommended an MRI for evaluation,
however, the patient was unable to tolerate this. It will be
scheduled as an outpatient, and the patient will follow up with
neurology following discharge.

Chest tubes were discontinued without complication. The patient
was evaluated by the Physical Therapy service for assistance
with strength and mobility. By the time of discharge on 2025-05-22
the patient was ambulating without assistance, the wound was
healing Granulation tissue present pain was controlled with oral analgesics.

Rheumatology was consulted for evaluation of a possible auto
immine etiology of the pericarditits and ANA and rheumatoid
factor assays were sent. Arrangements were made for outpatient
follow up with them at the time of her return surgical visit.
The patient was discharged to home in good condition with
appropriate follow up instructions.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mary Dickson w/hx of DM, atrial flutter, CAD s/p CABG, chronic renal
failure, diastoic CHF who p/w weakness found to have orthostasis
and Community-acquired pneumonia.

# Hypotension: Patient with SBP in 140/80 mmHg upon standing while in
ED, baseline in 110s. Orthostasis and hypotension most likely
secondary to aggressive diuresis in setting of recent CHF
exacerbation. Pt improved with hydration and cardiac enzymes
were negative x3. His anti-hypertensive meds (imdur,
metoprolol,lisinopril) were held on admission and were gradually
added back as patient's bp stabilized. His lasix dose was scaled
back to 100mg BID. Pt's BPs remained in low 100s throughout
first day of admission and he was net negative 2L. Decision was
made to scale back his lasix dose to 100mg daily. His BP
improved and patient states he felt the best he as in a while.
At discharge, continues to have a SBP in the 105-115 range but
is clinically greatly improved. Furthermore, he shows no
worsening signs of fluid overload and there are minimal rales on
chest ausculatation. He will follow up with with his primary
cardiologist as an outpatient for better titration of lasix
doses.

# Generalized weakness: Most likely secondary to intravascular
depletion secondary to aggressive diuresis. Orthostasis and
elevated cr further support this diagnosis. Pt says he is
greatly improved following several boluses. He had no signs of
infection (no WBC, fever, cough) or CP/SOB to suggest other
etiologies. His lasix dose was decreased to 100mg daily at
discharge. He has no signs of fluid overload and will follow up
with cardiologist regarding redosing of medications.

# Acute kidney injury: creatinine up to 2.3 from baseline 1.6,
with a peak of 3 followind admission. Differential included
prerenal causes (volume depletion or possibly due to
decompensated CHF) and acute tubular necrosis. BUN/Cr ratio is
>20 suggested volume depletion and his cr improved with IV
fluids. His lisinopril was held but restarted when he renal
function improved at discharge. His allopurinol was renally
dosed.

# Diastolic congestive heart failure: patient with improved leg
edema but normal BNP and signs suggesting volume depletion.
Lasix dose was reduced from pre-admission 320mg daily and pt was
closely monitored for signs of fluid overload. His weight
remained uncharged throughout admission. Metroprolol, imdur, and
lisinopril were

# Atrial flutter: heart rate currently controlled, INR
therapeutic at 2.6 at admission. Home warfarin and amiodarone
continued.

# Coronary artery disease s/p CABG. This did not appear to be a
cardiac event in setting of (-)trops, no EKG changes, or CP. He
was continued on ASA and statin and metoprolol, imdur, and ACEI
orginally held but added back throughout admission.

# Anemia, chronic: patient currently at baseline hematocrit,
continue to trend H/H as outpatient

#UTI:Patient was recently diagnosed with a UTI on previous
admission and completed a 7 day course of Cipro during this
admission. Pt denies dysuria or suprapubic pain.

# Diabetes mellitus: well controlled on ISS throughout admission

# Hypothyroidism : Stable, continued home levothyroxine
# Hyperlipidemia: continued home atorvastatin

ICD placement in 2018, obesity, DM2, charcot deformity of RLE
p/w RLE cellulitis s/p hardware removal on 2025-05-23
.
1) Right foot revision: As stated, the patient was admitted to
the hospital on 2025-02-13 for right lower extremity cellulitis and
removal of his charcot foot hardware. His procedure was delayed
due to a high INR. The patient had the procedure on 2025-05-23, and
tolerated the procedure well and his external fixator is in
place. Tissue cultures were sent that showed white blood cells
but no growth. His cellulitis and possible osteomyelitis were
treated with Vancomycin, Flagyl, and Ciprofloxacin for a total
of 21 days. After the procedure his pain was controlled with a
Dilaudid PCA that was then transitioned to oral pain
medications. The patient's pain was controlled with Oxycontin
40mg po BID, Tylenol 1g TID, and Oxycodone Q4hr prn breakthrough
pain. He will follow up with podiatry within 3 weeks.
.
2) Chronic atrial fibrillation: The patient's coumadin was
stopped for the procedure. After the procedure he was bridged on
heparin and restarted on his coumadin. On the day of his
discharge his INR was 1.9 and he was given Lovenox. A home nurse
would come to his house and check his INR the day after his
discharge (2025-04-21) and send the results to his PCP. His PCP was
going to further manage his coumadin after discharge. He was
discharged on Coumadin 10mg by mouth every day.
.
3) Chronic systolic CHF with EF 25%: After the procedure he had
an increased creatinine (1.3). His Lisinopril was held and his
Tramadol was decreased. His Cr improved. He was discharged on
his home regimen of Tramadol and Lisinopril.
.
4) Hematuria: On 2025-03-08 the patient has an episode of hematuria
in the morning. There were no clots. The patient did not report
dysuria. This was mostly likely secondary to having a Foley and
a transiently elevated PTT that day. His hematocrit was stable
and his hematuria resolved prior to discharge.
.
5) IDDM: The patient's insulin regimen was adjust for elevated
blood glucose while in the hospital. He was discharged on
Glargine 75 units at breakfast and at bedtime. His sliding scale
of Humalog was also increased. His sliding scale was provided to
him on the day of his discharge. He was told to check his blood
sugars and follow up with his PCP.
.
6) Urinary tract infection: A urine culture was done on 2025-07-11
that grew E.coli bacteria. The bacteria was sensitive to
Ciprofloxacin that he was already using for osteomyelitis.
.
7) Anemia: Prior to his procedure his hemoglobin was 11.5. After
the procedure his hemoglobin was 10.6. His Hg was 9.2 on
discharge, but it had remained stable for several days. He was
guiac negative.
.
6) Abnormal chest x-ray: A pre-operation AP/Lateral chest x-ray
was done on 2025-08-02. It showed "a roughly 60 x 20 mm wide bulge
of the left lower lateral costal pleural margin lies against
intact ribs and was probably not present on 2025-05-21. As
such, this is probably a small pleural fluid collection. Pleural
surfaces are otherwise normal." The results were discussed with
the patient's wife and she was told to follow this up with her
primary physician.
.
7) Code: Full

You were admitted to the hospital for an infection in your right
foot. The hardware in your foot was removed because there was a
possibility it was infected. During the operation they cleaned

The tissue showed no bacterial growth to date. You were treated
with 3 antibiotics, Vancomycin, Flagyl, and Ciprofloxacin to
kill any remaining bacteria in the skin of your foot. Continue
taking these three antibiotics for 15 days after your hospital
discharge.
.
While you were in the hospital you also developed a urinary
tract infection. The Ciprofloxacin will also treat your UTI.
.
Before you could have this procedure we had to stop your
warfarin (also called Coumadin). After you surgery we restarted
your warfarin. While we waited for your warfarin to become
therapeutic we also treated you with another anticoagulation
medicine, heparin. Your coumadin dose has been decreased to 10mg
by mouth everyday since you have been started on three
antibiotics that can raise your coumadin level. Please take
Coumadin 10mg by mouth every day after your hospital discharge.
Start your first dose tomorrow 2025-04-21. A NP nurse Robert Carpenter come to
check your Warfarin level tomorrow (2025-04-21). They
will send these results to Dr. Denise Oneal. Dr. Denise Oneal an
on call physician Recommended further imaging further advise you on how to adjust your
warfarin dose if necessary. For your results, please call Dr.
Denise Oneal office at +918908794165 on 2025-04-05 and ask to speak
to the on-call physician.
.
During your hospitalization you also had elevated blood sugars.
Please take Insulin Glargine 75 units at breakfast and 75 units
at bedtime. Please start this tonight. Please also use the
humalog sliding scale that has been attached to your paperwork.
You should log your fingersticks and discuss possibile need for
an increased dose with your primary care physician.
.

should have your renal function test checked on 2025-07-18. Point-of-Care Device
will check these labs and fax them to your primary care
provider.
.
For pain control we used Oxycontin 40mg by mouth twice a day,
Tylenol 1g by mouth three times a day, and Oxycodone 10mg by
mouth as needed. After your hospital discharge if you are still
feeling pain you may continue taking Oxycontin 40mg by mouth
twice a day and Tylenol 1g by mouth three times a day. You may
use Oxycodone 10mg by mouth every 4 hours for additional pain as

Before your hospitalization we obtained a chest x-ray that

Brief Hospital Course:
On 2025-04-10, she underwent segmental liver resection for
symptomatic left liver hemangioma. Surgeon was Dr. David Gonzalez. Intraop ultrasound was done. Numerous small hemangiomas
were noted. The most anterior hemangioma was calcified and
easily palpable underneath the falciform (in the location of her
pain)therefore this was removed. There were no complications.
Please refer to operative note for complete details. An epidural
was placed pre-operatively in the PACU. She experienced a
severe anxiety reaction which seemed to worsen after the
administration of a benozodiazepine which was partially
alleviated by Haldol.

Postop, on 2025-08-15, she had low grade temp 101. Tylenol was given.
Blood and urine cultures were sent. UA was negative. CXR
demonstated slight right pleural effusion.

Pain was managed with an epidural. PO intake was poor. And
benadryl was given for pruritus which made her sleepy. Epidural
was split with a Dilaudid PCA.

On postop day 2, pain was not well controlled and Toradol/ativan
were given. She was febrile again to 101 and was recultured.
Vancomycin and Zosyn were started after repeat cultures. IV
fluid boluses as she had low urine output.

She experienced a large amount of clear/foul smelling vaginal
discharge. GYN was consulted. HCG was sent and was negative as
were cultures for BV, GC and Chlamydia. UA was positive, but
urine culture was negative.

She spike to 102 early am 2025-02-06. Incision appeared intact
without redness or drainage. Pain service removed the epidural
and the foley was removed. She denied headache and there were no
mental status changes. IV Vanco and Zosyn were started which
were later changed to cipro and flagyl on 2025-03-15.

She remained afebrile with stable vital signs. Dilaudid was
increased to 6mg for each dose for c/o pain at incision. She was
slow to move and ambulate, but improved on posotp day 7 when she
was oob.

Creatinine increased to as high as 3.8 likely from a combination
of IV Vanco, Toradol and hydration status. Vanco was changed to
cipro/flagyl and toradol was stopped. Subsequent creatinines
decreased down to 1.4 by day of discharge. At time of discharge,
she was instructed to have chemistries checked on 2025-01-01.

She was feeling better at time of discharge, tolerating diet and
ambulating independently. Pathology report was finalized as
cavernous hemangioma.

o You may climb stairs.
o You may go outside, but avoid traveling long distances until
you see your surgeon at your next visit.
o Don't lift more than 105 kg lbs for 4 weeks. (This is about
the weight of a briefcase or a bag of groceries.) This applies
to lifting children, but they may sit on your lap.
o You may start some light exercise when you feel comfortable.
o You will need to stay out of bathtubs or swimming pools for a
time while your incision is healing. Ask your doctor when you
can resume tub baths or swimming.

HOW YOU MAY FEEL:
o You may feel weak or "washed out" for a couple of weeks. You
might want to nap often. Simple tasks may exhaust you.
o You may have a sore throat because of a tube that was in your
throat during surgery.
o You might have trouble concentrating or difficulty sleeping.
You might feel somewhat depressed.
o You could have a poor appetite for a while. Food may seem
unappealing.
o All of these feelings and reactions are normal and should go
away in a short time. If they do not, tell your surgeon.

YOUR INCISION:
o Tomorrow you may shower and remove the gauzes over your
incisions. Under these dressing you have small plastic bandages
called steri-strips. Do not remove steri-strips for 2 weeks.
(These are the thin paper strips that might be on your
incision.) But if they fall off before that that's okay).
o Your incisions may be slightly red around the stitches. This
is normal.
o You may gently wash away dried material around your incision.
o Avoid direct sun exposure to the incision area.
o Do not use any ointments on the incision unless you were told
otherwise.
o You may see a small amount of clear or light red fluid
staining your dressing or clothes. If the staining is severe,
please call your surgeon.
o You may shower. As noted above, ask your doctor when you may
resume tub baths or swimming.

YOUR BOWELS:
o Constipation is a common side effect of narcotic pain
medications. If needed, you may take a stool softener (such as
Colace, one capsule) or gentle laxative (such as milk of
magnesia, 1 tbs) twice a day. You can get both of these
medicines without a prescription.
o If you go 48 hours without a bowel movement, or have pain
moving the bowels, call your surgeon.

PAIN MANAGEMENT:
o It is normal to feel some discomfort/pain following abdominal
surgery. This pain is often described as "soreness".
o Your pain should get better day by day. If you find the pain
is getting worse instead of better, please contact your surgeon.
o You will receive a prescription for pain medicine to take by
mouth. It is important to take this medicine as directed. o Do
not take it more frequently than prescribed. Do not take more
medicine at one time than prescribed.
o Your pain medicine will work better if you take it before your
pain gets too severe.
o Talk with your surgeon about how long you will need to take
prescription pain medicine. Please don't take any other pain
medicine, including non-prescription pain medicine, unless your
surgeon has said its okay.
o If you are experiencing no pain, it is okay to skip a dose of
pain medicine.
o Remember to use your "cough pillow" for splinting when you
cough or when you are doing your deep breathing exercises.
If you experience any of the following, please contact your
surgeon:
- sharp pain or any severe pain that lasts several hours
- pain that is getting worse over time
- pain accompanied by fever of more than 101
- a drastic change in nature or quality of your pain

MEDICATIONS:
Take all the medicines you were on before the operation just as
you did before, unless you have been told differently.
If you have any questions about what medicine to take or not to
take, please call your surgeon.

Followup Instructions:
Bring detailed family history records for further genetic assessment.

Brief Hospital Course:
Patient was admitted on 2025-04-28 and taken to the operating room
by Dr. Nicole White a laparoscopic cholecystectomy and
cholangiogram. There were no intraoperative complication and
patient tolerated procedure without difficulty. However, during
cholangiogram, with visualization of the bile duct system, it
was very clear that there was no filling of the duodenum and
that there was a meniscus-like cut off
structure at the base. This persisted over time and with a lot
of forceful flow. The rest of the cholangiogram was normal with
the exception of the fact that there was a
dilated bile duct well over a centimeter in size. The hepatic
ducts were visualized and there was no evidence of
extravasation. To rule out possibility of a impacted stone at
the distal aspect of the bile duct, ERCP was scheduled on POD1.
Patient was extubated and taken to the PACU for monitoring. She
was then transferred to the general surgical floor for further
recovery.

On POD1, patient was kept NPO with IVF. She was taken for ERCP.
Procedure and findings consistent with the following: (1) Normal
major papilla, (2) Cannulation of the biliary duct successful
and deep with a sphincterotome, (3) Mild diffuse dilation was
seen at the main duct with CBD measuring 11mm, (4) Filling
defect that appeared like sludge in the lower third of the CBD,
(5) Sphincterotomy was performed successfully using a
sphincterotome over an existing guidewire, (6) A 11.5mm balloon
was used and the stone fragments were removed successsfully.
Patient kept NPO during the night.

On POD2, patient advanced to clear and full liquid diet. She
tolerated without issues. Pain controlled with appropriate oral
analgesics. She is passing flatus. Ambulating and voiding
without difficulty.

On POD3, the patient was tolerating a regular diet. Pain
controlled with an oral regimen. Continuing to ambulate and void
without difficulty.

Discharge Instructions:
General:

Please call your doctor or return to the ER for any of the
following:
* You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or
tightness.
* New or worsening cough or wheezing.
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your
medications.
* You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting,
diarrhea or other reasons.

* Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid heartbeat or
feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
* You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a
bowel movement.
* Your pain is not improving within 03:03 AM hours or not gone
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is
getting worse or is changing location or moving to your chest or

back.

*Avoid lifting objects > 5lbs until your follow-up appointment
with the surgeon.

*Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain
medications.
* You have shaking chills, or a fever greater than 101.5 (F)
degrees or 38(C) degrees.
* Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that
concern you.
* Please resume all regular home medications and take any new
meds
as ordered.
* Continue to ambulate several times per day.

.

Incision Care:
-Your steri-strips will fall off on their own. Please remove any
remaining strips 24 days after surgery.
-You may shower, and wash surgical incisions.
-Avoid swimming and baths until your follow-up appointment.
-Please call the doctor if you have increased pain, swelling,
redness, or drainage from the incision sites

Followup Instructions:
Increase daily walking gradually as tolerated.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. Ortiz,

It was a pleasure taking care of you during your hospital stay
at Mercy Health Hospital. You were hospitalized
for nausea, vomiting and fevers.

You were found to have a urinary tract infection that was likely
undertreated before you came into the hospital given that you
were not able to tolerate oral antibiotics. An ultrasound of
your kidneys showed that the infection had not spread to your
kidneys and also showed no kidney stones. In the hospital you
were given fluids and your symptoms improved. We gave you oral
antibiotics which you tolerated well. You should continue taking
this antibiotics for a total of 10 days, through 2025-07-15.

We also started you on a medication called Flomax that can help
patients with benign prostatic hyperplasia, a benign condition
in which the prostate enlarges, commonly occurring in men as
they age. It can cause difficulty urinating (initiating a stream
and/or feeling like the bladder will not completely empty). If
you feel these symptoms, please follow up with your primary care
physician.

If you feel fevers, chills, pain with urination, nausea or
vomiting, please see your primary care physician.

Please continue to follow up with your primary care physician,
and specialists upon discharge from the hospital. Please
continue to take your home medications as prescribed.

Take Care,
Your Rheumatology Specialty Clinic Team.

Brief Hospital Course:
BRIEF HOSPITAL COURSE
=====================
Mr. Daryl Stewart is a 2022 year old male with a significant medical history of Crohn's Disease, ESRD due to amyloidosis (HD MWF), hypertension, colorectal CA s/p APR with chemotherapy and radiation, fractured L distal femur in 2025-07-02 from a mechanical fall s/p Oxygen therapy, 2025-01-07
complicated by nonunion now s/p L femur ORIF on 2025-02-15
complicated by post op fever, hypotension, and encephalopathy.

#Shock of unknown etiology versus septic shock: The patient initially presented for an elective L femor ORIF on 2025-02-15 which was complicated by immediate post-op fever, tachycardia, and hypotension requiring pressors. The patient was started on broad spectrum antibiotics (vancomycin/cefepime) on 2025-06-22, however given no clear infectious source, his antibiotics were stopped. CT AP and TTE were without evidence of an abscess or other infectious pathology. The differential diagnosis for his likely sepsis included transient bacteremia in the setting of ORIF vs. bacteremia from his recent tooth extraction. In addition, the patient is immunosuppressed due to ongoing treatment with certolizumab for his Crohn's disease.

#Toxic Metabolic Encephalopathy:
#ACA/MCA Watershed Infarct / Ischemic strokes: The patient's altered mental status was likely multifactorial due to hypotension resulting in punctate bilateral acute to subacute infarcts in ACA/MCA watershed regions as revealed on MRI brain 2025-06-21, due to hypoperfusion in the post operative setting. Over the course of his ICU stay, his mental status improved, however he became fairly delirious. His delirium was thought be due to ICU delirium, or a superimposed infection/bacteremia and improved tremendously to his baseline after starting PO Haldol 0.5 mg BID with psychiatric input. Of note, his EEG was without seizure activity. There was no evidence of drug induced mental status changes or electrolyte abnormalities. His carotid series revealed less than 40% stenosis in his carotid arteries.

#ESRD on HD: The patient has end stage renal disease in the setting of AA amyloid presumably from his Crohn's disease. He is s/p AVF declotting on 2025-01-03. On HD MWF at home. He was euvolemic throughout his hospitalization without signs of uremia.

#L distal femur nonunion: The patient is status post ORIF on 2025-02-15 without surgical site complications. The patient had a persistent left knee effusion that was tender to palpation, but he had warm and well perfused extremities and intact active range of motion. LLE ultrasound was negative for DVT and revealed a moderate effusion. This was likely due to a hematoma or seroma.

#Anemia: Hgb 9.8 on admission and slowly downtrended during his hospitalization. He had 3 uPRBC during his stay and was transfusion responsive. This was a normocytic anemia likely due to ESRD and his recent surgery, that was likely exacerbated by poor nutritional status from Crohn's disease s/p vit K repletion. Additional factors include antibiotic induced coagulopathy or amyloid induced bone marrow suppression. He was stable with no source of active bleeding at the time of discharge.

#Thrombocytopenia: The differential diagnosis included drug induced thrombocytopenia in the setting of broad spectrum antibiotics, or infection/sepsis induced thrombocytopenia. This too could also have been exacerbated by poor nutrition status and AA amyloidosis. His PF4 antibodies were negative for HIT.

#Pruritis: The differential diagnosis included dry skin given altered mental status and it was unclear if he was using sarna lotion. Other considerations included delusional parasitosis. LFTS were within normal limits, suggesting this was not a biliary induced pruritis.

CHRONIC/RESOLVED ISSUES:
#Crohn's disease: The patient is currently on certolizumab at home. His Crohn's disease was asymptomatic during the hospitalization.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. Daryl Stewart,

You came to UnityPoint Hospital because you had left knee pain after your femur fracture. Please see more details listed below about what happened while you were in the hospital and your instructions for what to do after leaving the hospital.

It was a pleasure participating in your care. We wish you the best!

Sincerely,
Your Inpatient Care Team Care Team

===================================
WHAT HAPPENED AT THE HOSPITAL?
===================================
- You were found to have a poorly healing left left after your fracture in 2025-07-27. You had further knee surgery for your broken leg.
- After the procedure, you were found to have a fever and low blood pressure. You were treated with antibiotics with the concern for infection.
- You also became confused and were found to have several strokes in your brain because of poor blood flow. You were started on a medication called Haldol, due to ongoing confusion, and you improved significantly.
- You also had a blood clot in your fistula for dialysis. This was repaired and you were continued on dialysis.
- Finally, you had low blood counts throughout your hospitalization, you were transfused and improved. Your low blood counts were likely caused by inflammation in your body, medications that were used in the hospital to treat your infection, and your underlying kidney failure.
==================================================
WHAT NEEDS TO HAPPEN WHEN YOU LEAVE THE HOSPITAL?
==================================================
INSTRUCTIONS AFTER ORTHOPAEDIC SURGERY:

- You were in the hospital for orthopedic surgery. It is normal to feel tired or "washed out" after surgery, and this feeling should improve over the first few days to week.
- Resume your regular activities as tolerated, but please follow your weight bearing precautions strictly at all times.

ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING:
- WBAT LLE

MEDICATIONS:
- Please take all medications as prescribed by your physicians at discharge.
- Continue all home medications unless specifically instructed to stop by your surgeon.
- Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers.
- Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you should drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and take a stool softener (colace) to prevent this side effect.

ANTICOAGULATION:
- Unless directed otherwise by the Medicine team, please take subcutaneous heparin twice daily to prevent formation of blood clots

WOUND CARE:
- You may shower. No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks.
- Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken out at your 2-week follow up appointment.
- Please remain in your dressing and do not change unless it is visibly soaked or falling off.

DANGER SIGNS:
Please call your PCP or surgeon's office and/or return to the emergency department if you experience any of the following:
- Increasing pain that is not controlled with pain medications
- Increasing redness, swelling, drainage, or other concerning changes in your incision
- Persistent or increasing numbness, tingling, or loss of sensation
- Fever > 101.4
- Shaking chills
- Chest pain
- Shortness of breath
- Nausea or vomiting with an inability to keep food, liquid, medications down
- Any other medical concerns

Followup Instructions:
Continue wound care with daily dressing changes as instructed.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. Francis is a 1977 y/o woman with a PMH of alcohol use disorder,
recurrent falls, depression, and anxiety, with a recent
hospitalization for hypercarbic respiratory failure (2025-06-11)
and EMG findings concerning for ALS, who presented from Pulmonology Clinic New Sharon with worsening respiratory distress and
hypercarbic respiratory failure requiring intubation.
.
>> ACTIVE ISSUES:
# GOALS OF CARE: After reviewing Ms. Francis's clinical course, it
became clear that she has been declining significantly for a
year, to the point where she is unable to care for herself at
home. The hypercarbic respiratory failure is likely a function
of worsening progressive neuromuscular disease, which is
concerning for ALS, although the diagnosis is not entirely
clear. Family meeting between team members and family (husband,
and 2 sons) to discuss her decline and prognosis. The son
reported that he had a recent conversation with the patient,
where she reported that she would not want to be intubated or
trached. The decision was made to terminally extubate the
patient with the family at the bedside, with plan to discharge
to hospice.

# Hypercarbic respiratory failure - Second hypercarbic
respiratory failure event in 2 weeks (previously was in the ICU)
and discharged to rehab on BIPAP at night. Etiology of
respiratory failure thought to be secondary to progressive
neuromuscular weakness, with possible contribution for left
hemidiaphragm paralysis. She was intubated on 2025-05-16 for
hypercarbia. However, clinical picture not entirely clear as she
had intermittent NIFs in the --50 cmH2O. However, overall clinical
deterioration and progression was consistent with underlying
neuromuscular disease. Family decided to terminally extubate the
patient on 2025-01-24 due to the patient's previously discussed
wishes.

# Neuromuscular weakness - Patient has undergone extensive
workup for neuromuscular weakeness at General City Hospital and during her
previous admission. No signs of malignancy to suggest that this
is paraneoplastic. Acetylcholine receptor antibodies and MuSK
antibodies were also negative, ruling out both classic and
AChR-negative myasthenia Ocular. RPR negative, MMA normal, B12
on the lower limit of normal. EMG was concerning for anterior
horn cell disorder. Patient was to have outpatient workup for
ALS. Neurology was consulted on this admission, and acknowledged
the unclear clinical picture. However, given goals of care
discussion and the fast progression of her respiratory failure,
plan was to terminally extubate and transition to hospice.

# Transaminitis - Seen during previous admission, thought to be
secondary to alcohol use. Resolved on this admission.

# Alcohol use disorder - Reportedly sober since 2025-07-05.
Thiamine, folate, MVI, B12 supplementation

# Depression/anxiety -
- held mirtazapine 7.5mg QHS

Brief Hospital Course:
2004 year old LEFT-handed woman with atrial fibrillation (off
Coumadin) and HTN who presented from OSH with an MCA stroke and
after receiving IV tPA was transferred to St. George’s University Hospital for question of
an intra-arterial intervention. On initial examination she was
noted to be globally aphasic with R sided weakness and
hemianopia, and L
gaze deviation. She appeared to not have improved significantly
after IV tPA and in the ED and became drowsy, with minimal eye
opening to voice and sternal rub. She was eventually intubated
for airway protection.

On follow up CTA/P she was noted to have SAH in the cortical
left frontal and left parietal lobes, felt to be due to tPA as
well as a thrombus in the supraclinoid segment of the left ICA
extending into the bifurcation and into the left MCA. CT
imaging here showed a dense MCA sign, along with a CTP showing L
decreased BV and BF. Due to new SAH, she was not a candidate
for intraarterial tPA and was admitted to Neuro-ICU to complete
post CVA care.

NEURO. Patient's BP was maintained < 180, goal of -500 cc I/O,
ASA and all anticoagulation were held due to concern for SAH,
which was confirmed on a subsequent CT. CT on 2025-08-04 also showed
mass effect due to increasing edema at the frontal horn of the
left lateral ventricle due to evolving infarct. At this time,
she was started on mannitol, HOB elevation and fluid restriction
w/ goal of -500 cc/day. With this treatment she slowly became
more alert and was extubated. Serial head CTs showed stable SAH
and evolving left MCA distribution infarcts with mass effect on
the left lateral ventricle without herniation.

Mannitol was weaned starting on 2025-02-07. She was transferred to
the floor an completely weaned off the mannitol. Given the size
of the infarct it was decided not to start her an a heparin
drip. Coumadin was restarted on 2025-07-25 and she will be titrated
for a goal INR of 0.8 – 1.2 (Normal range). Here LDL was noted to be 111 and she was
started on a statin at a low dose. Her blood sugar tests were
normal.

She will be discharged to a rehab facility to continue working
on her weakness and speech deficits.

CV. Patient remained in atrial fibrillation and had an episode
of afib with RVR to 170s. She was treated with diltiazem gtt
and started on PO diltiazem in addition to atenolol (she did not
respond to IV metoprolol). Her final dosage of diltiazem was
90mg QID. She has been scheduled for outpatient cardiology
follow up to help determine a suitable treatment for her atrial
fibrillation.

PULM. Patient was extubated on HD#3 without complications.

RENAL. No issues.

GI. She was treated with famotidine and TFs. She was noted to
aspirate with all consistencies of nutrition thus was maintained
on NGT and TFs. She repeatedly failed speech and swallow
evaluations and required the placement of a PEG feeding tube.
This was placed on 2025-07-01 without complications and tube feeds

Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted as a transfer from an outside hospital for a
large stroke of the left side of your brain. You were initially
seen at an outside hospital were it was determined that you had
a large stroke of a blood vessel in your brain called the left
middle cerebral artery. You could not move your right side and
could not speak or understand language. You were given a clot
busting agent called tPa. You were not noted to improve
significantly and were transferred to St. George’s University Hospital to see if there were
any other interventions that could be done. At St. George’s University Hospital a follow
up CT scan of your brain showed that there was some small amount
of bleeding and it was determined that it was not safe to give
any other interventions, which could increase the bleeding.

You were transferred to the ICU, and were started on mannitol
because of concern of swelling of your brain. This was slowly
weaned off and you were transfered to the floor. You were
weaned of the mannitol. On the floor your exam has remained
largely unchanged but you have occasionally been able to make an
occasional sound. Physical therapy was able to have you bear
weight on your right leg.

As you were not able to swallow a PEG feeding tube has been
placed and your were started on tube feeds. You will be
transfered to a rehab facility to continue to work on improving
your strength.

Please take all medications as prescribed, please make all
follow up appointments. If you experience any of the symptoms
listed below please call your doctor or return to the nearest
emergency room.

Followup Instructions:
Maintain a strict low-salt diet to control blood pressure.

Left foot infection

Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker

Discharge Instructions:
Mr. Sanders,
It was a pleasure taking care of you at Gastroenterology Division. You were admitted
to the Podiatric Surgery service after your left foot surgery.
You were given IV antibiotics while here. You are being
discharged home with the following instructions:

ACTIVITY:
There are restrictions on activity. Please remain non weight
bearing to your Left foot until your follow up appointment. You
should keep this site elevated when ever possible (above the
level of the heart!)

No driving until cleared by your Surgeon.
PLEASE CALL US IMMEDIATELY FOR ANY OF THE FOLLOWING PROBLEMS:
Redness in or drainage from your leg wound(s).
New pain, numbness or discoloration of your foot or toes.
Watch for signs and symptoms of infection. These are: a fever
greater than 101 degrees, chills, increased redness, or pus
draining from the incision site. If you experience any of these
or bleeding at the incision site, CALL THE DOCTOR.

Exercise:
Limit strenuous activity for 6 weeks.
No heavy lifting greater than 20 pounds for the next 21 days.
Try to keep leg elevated when able.

BATHING/SHOWERING:
You may shower immediately upon coming home, but you must keep
your dressing CLEAN, DRY and INTACT. You can use a shower bag
taped around your ankle/leg or hang your foot/leg outside of the
bathtub.

Avoid taking a tub bath, swimming, or soaking in a hot tub for 4
weeks after surgery or until cleared by your physician.

MEDICATIONS:
Unless told otherwise you should resume taking all of the
medications you were taking before surgery.
Remember that narcotic pain meds can be constipating and you
should increase the fluid and bulk foods in your diet. (Check
with your physician if you have fluid restrictions.) If you feel
that you are constipated, do not strain at the toilet. You may
use over the counter Metamucil or Milk of Magnesia. Appetite
suppression may occur; this will improve with time. Eat small
balanced meals throughout the day.

DIET:
There are no special restrictions on your diet postoperatively.
Poor appetite is not unusual for several weeks and small,
frequent meals may be preferred.

FOLLOW-UP APPOINTMENT:
Be sure to keep your medical appointments.
If a follow up appointment was not made prior to your discharge,
please call the office on the first working day after your
discharge from the hospital to schedule a follow-up visit. This
should be scheduled on the calendar for seven to fourteen days
after discharge. Normal office hours are 02:17 PM
through 02:48 AM.
PLEASE FEEL FREE TO CALL THE OFFICE WITH ANY OTHER CONCERNS OR
QUESTIONS THAT MIGHT ARISE.


Followup Instructions:
Refrain from smoking or using tobacco products completely.

lab equipment) and was advised to see his PCP. There, he had an

Kristin Brady with strong family history of CAD presents with

collaterals. He was started on aspirin, a metoprolol,

cardiac rehabilitation and have a follow-up stress MIBI in a few
weeks to evaluate for reversible ischemia.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear William Nelson,
She were admitted to the Mayo Medical Center Vascular Surgery Team for
treatment of your poorly healing left foot wound. She were
treated with antibiotics and underwent an angiogram with
placement of a L sided common iliac artery stent. She will
return to see Dr. Carlos Owens 02:53 AM week (see appointments section)
for a wound check. Please make sure to be non-weight bearing on
your L foot.

MEDICATION:
•Take Aspirin 325mg (enteric coated) once daily
•Take Plavix (Clopidogrel) 75mg once daily
•Continue all other medications She were taking before surgery,
unless otherwise directed
She make take Tylenol or prescribed pain medications for any
post procedure pain or discomfort

WHAT TO EXPECT:
It is normal to have slight swelling of the legs:
•Elevate your leg above the level of your heart with pillows
every Every 8 hours hours throughout the day and night
•Avoid prolonged periods of standing or sitting without your
legs elevated
•It is normal to feel tired and have a decreased appetite, your
appetite will return with time
•Drink plenty of fluids and eat small frequent meals
•It is important to eat nutritious food options (high fiber,
lean meats, vegetables/fruits, low fat, low cholesterol) to
maintain your strength and assist in wound healing
•To avoid constipation: eat a high fiber diet and use stool
softener while taking pain medication

ACTIVITIES:
•When She go home, She may walk and use stairs
She may shower (let the soapy water run over groin incision,
rinse and pat dry)
•Your incision may be left uncovered, unless She have small
amounts of drainage from the wound, then place a dry dressing or
band aid over the area
•No heavy lifting, pushing or pulling (greater than 5 lbs) for
1 week (to allow groin puncture to heal)
•After 1 week, She may resume sexual activity
•After 1 week, gradually increase your activities and distance
walked as She can tolerate
•No driving until She are no longer taking pain medications

CALL THE OFFICE FOR: 426.735.9979 | bergheather@example.org
•Numbness, coldness or pain in lower extremities
•Temperature greater than 101.5F for 24 hours
•New or increased drainage from incision or white, yellow or
green drainage from incisions
•Bleeding from groin puncture site

SUDDEN, SEVERE BLEEDING OR SWELLING (Groin puncture site)
•Lie down, keep leg straight and have someone apply firm
pressure to area for 10 minutes. If bleeding stops, call
vascular office +919506224929. If bleeding does not stop, call
88372 for transfer to closest Emergency Room.

Followup Instructions:
Call the cardiologist immediately if chest pain or shortness of breath occurs.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. Robertson is an 1985 w/ h/o HTN, HLD, ?Acute Myocardial Infarction (Heart Attack) p/w sudden onset
confusion and found to have hypertensive emergency.

# Acute hypertensive encephalopathy: Had word finding
difficulty, without other focal findings. Neuro c/s thought
unlikely to be stroke. Most likely due to hypertensive
encephalopathy. DDx include hypertensive encephalopathy vs.
metabolic/toxic vs. PRES vs. CVA vs infection vs. delirium vs.
medication-induced. Infectious cause less likely given UA and
CXR negative. TSH normal and RPR negative on last admission.
NCHCT and CTA not concerning for acute stroke. MRI showed no
acute hemorrhage or ischemic injury. Since pt has had similar
presentations in the past (expressive aphasia) and
confusion/disorientation w/ hypertension and ischemic w/u has
been negative, this is most likely d/t hypertension as well.
PRES less likely given headaches are frontal, no VS, no seizure.
At time of discharge, his mental status improved but he still
occasionally was confused and forgetful with word finding
difficulties.

# Hypertensive emergency: BP initially elevated to 220 systolic.
Treated in the MICU initially with IV labetalol in addition to
restarting home meds. Most likely d/t poor compliance with
medications v secondary causes of HTN. When transferred to the
floor, his home atenolol was replaced with labetalol for better
blood pressure effect and uptitrated as needed and his
lisinopril was uptitrated to 40mg from 20mg. His isosorbide
mononitrate was uptitrated. He was started on nifedipine as
well. On discharge BPs were 130s-150s. Goal SBP 130-160mmHg.

# Hyperlipidemia: continued atorvastatin

# Anemia: H&H at baseline. Most likely d/t vit B12 deficiency.
continue vit B12.

# Chronic diastolic CHF: TTE done in 2020 did not show any
sign of CHF. EF>55% with mild MR and mild pulmonary HTN. Based
on records, Lasix and metolazone are most likely for Lake Charles edema.
His home diuretics were held on discharge because patient was
euvolemic during this admission. Also, he had Contrast exposure with acute
rise in creatinine after re-starting his diuretics.

# Shoulder/back pain: History of disc herniation and shoulder
pain. Patient is treated with Tylenol prn for pain. Narcotics
were avoided given altered mental status.

Transitional issues:
- medication compliance
- f/u as outpatient whether to re-start metolazone and Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)
- Follow urine/plasma metanephrines
- give 20mg PO hydralazine if SBP >180mmHg
- give 20mg IV hydralazine if SBP >200mmHg and notify MD
- uptitrate nifedipine v. isosorbide mononitrate as needed for
improved BP control.

Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted for evalaution of chest/abdominal pain and you
were found to have gallstones with acute cholecystitis and acute
gallstone pancreatitis and you underwent surgery for removal of
your gallbladder (cholecystectomy)

You were admitted to the hospital with acute cholecystitis. You
were taken to the operating room and had your gallbladder
removed laparoscopically. You tolerated the procedure well and
are now being discharged home to continue your recovery with the
following instructions.

Please follow up in the Acute Care Surgery clinic at the
appointment listed below.

ACTIVITY:

o Do not drive until you have stopped taking pain medicine and
feel you could respond in an emergency.
o You may climb stairs.
o  You may go outside, but avoid traveling long distances until
you see your surgeon at your next visit.
o  Don't lift more than 120 kg lbs for 4 weeks. (This is about
the weight of a briefcase or a bag of groceries.) This applies
to lifting children, but they may sit on your lap.
o You may start some light exercise when you feel comfortable.
o You will need to stay out of bathtubs or swimming pools for a
time while your incision is healing. Ask your doctor when you
can resume tub baths or swimming.

HOW YOU MAY FEEL:
o  You may feel weak or "washed out" for a couple of weeks. You
might want to nap often. Simple tasks may exhaust you.
o  You may have a sore throat because of a tube that was in your
throat during surgery.
o  You might have trouble concentrating or difficulty sleeping.
You might feel somewhat depressed.
o  You could have a poor appetite for a while. Food may seem
unappealing.
o  All of these feelings and reactions are normal and should go
away in a short time.  If they do not, tell your surgeon.

YOUR INCISION:
o Tomorrow you may shower and remove the gauzes over your
incisions. Under these dressing you have small plastic bandages
called steri-strips. Do not remove steri-strips for 2 weeks.
(These are the thin paper strips that might be on your
incision.) But if they fall off before that that's okay).
o Your incisions may be slightly red around the stitches. This
is normal.
o You may gently wash away dried material around your incision.
o Avoid direct sun exposure to the incision area.
o Do not use any ointments on the incision unless you were told
otherwise.
o You may see a small amount of clear or light red fluid
staining your dressing or clothes. If the staining is severe,
please call your surgeon.
o You may shower. As noted above, ask your doctor when you may
resume tub baths or swimming.

YOUR BOWELS:
o Constipation is a common side effect of narcotic pain
medications. If needed, you may take a stool softener (such as
Colace, one capsule) or gentle laxative (such as milk of
magnesia, 1 tbs) twice a day. You can get both of these
medicines without a prescription.
o If you go 48 hours without a bowel movement, or have pain
moving the bowels, call your surgeon.

PAIN MANAGEMENT:
o It is normal to feel some discomfort/pain following abdominal
surgery. This pain is often described as "soreness".
o Your pain should get better day by day. If you find the pain
is getting worse instead of better, please contact your surgeon.
o You will receive a prescription for pain medicine to take by
mouth. It is important to take this medicine as directed. o Do
not take it more frequently than prescribed. Do not take more
medicine at one time than prescribed.
o Your pain medicine will work better if you take it before your
pain gets too severe.
o Talk with your surgeon about how long you will need to take
prescription pain medicine. Please don't take any other pain
medicine, including non-prescription pain medicine, unless your
surgeon has said its okay.
o If you are experiencing no pain, it is okay to skip a dose of
pain medicine.
o Remember to use your "cough pillow" for splinting when you
cough or when you are doing your deep breathing exercises.
If you experience any of the following, please contact your
surgeon:
- sharp pain or any severe pain that lasts several hours
- pain that is getting worse over time
- pain accompanied by fever of more than 101
- a drastic change in nature or quality of your pain

MEDICATIONS:
Take all the medicines you were on before the operation just as
you did before, unless you have been told differently.
If you have any questions about what medicine to take or not to
take, please call your surgeon.

Followup Instructions:
Check blood pressure at home twice daily and maintain a log.

required Ketamine, Ativan, and IV narcotics to control her pain.
A Foley was placed at the end of the case due to concern for
urinary retention, this was removed and she voided
spontaneously. Whilst on the floor, her multimodal pain regimen
included Tylenol, Toradol for 48 hours then transitioned to
Ibuprofen, Gabapentin, Dilaudid, and Lidocaine. The Pain service
was consulted for assistance with managing pain; their
recommendations including more frequent Dilaudid, PO Ativan, and
increasing the dose of Gabapentin to 300 TID. They also
recommended that Lidocaine patches could be worn for up to 18
hours.

Her drain output was initially serosanguinous, but became more
bilious appearing during the hospitalization. A drain bilirubin
was sent which was 9.7. Her drain output decreased gradually and
was approximately 200cc/day on discharge.

passing gas and having bowel movements, ambulating independently
and voiding spontaneously. She received drain care teaching and
was discharged home with drain in place. She will follow up with
Dr. Schedule imaging after 1 month to evaluate treatment progress. in clinic.

Brief Hospital Course:
2023 year old female with cervical stenosis s/p motor vehicle
collision with central cord syndrome.

#Cervical Stenosis With Spinal Cord Compression
#Central cord syndrome
The patient was taken emergently to the operating room for a
C3-C7 laminectomy and posterior fusion. The procedure was
uncomplicated. Please see separately dictated operative report
by Dr. Gregory Yates further details. A surgical drain was left
in place, which was subsequently removed on POD#5. The patient
was extubated in the operating room and recovered in the PACU.
She was transferred to the step down unit for close neurologic
monitoring. Her neurologic exam slowly improved postoperatively.
Postoperative x-rays of the cervical spine showed no evidence of
retained surgical drain or hardware complications. On 2025-07-20
overnight, the patient was noted to have worsened weakness on
exam. A CT of the cervical spine was obtained, which was grossly
negative, but there was significant artifact from the hardware.
An MRI of the cervical spine was also obtained, which showed
increased T2 signal in cord at C3-C4, but overall improvement in
the degree of spinal canal narrowing from C2-C7. Her weakness
subsequently improved and continued to improve with continued
physical and occupational therapy.

#Rib Fracture
Acute Care Surgery was consulted for fracture of the first rib
on the left. There was no surgical intervention or follow-up
needed.

#Hypoxia
The patient required supplemental oxygen on 2025-07-20. She was
subsequently weaned off the supplemental oxygen, and her oxygen
saturations remained stable on room air for the remainder of her
hospitalization.

#Right Shoulder and wrist Pain
The patient complained of significant right shoulder pain. An
x-ray of the right shoulder was obtained, which showed no
definite fracture or dislocation, however there was a well
corticated rounded density, which was thought to reflect sequela
of remote injury or calcific tendinitis. She also c/o
significant right wrist pain. An ultrasound of the right wrist
was negative. Pain medications were adjusted.

#Urinary Retention
The patient experienced urinary retention postoperatively. Her
Foley catheter was discontinued. She failed a voiding trial on
2025-07-20, and catheter was replaced. Her Foley catheter was
discontinued again on 2025-07-20, and she was able to void but
still required intermittent straight cath for retention. On
discharge patient was voiding without difficulty.

#Constipation / Ileus
She was started on an aggressive bowel regimen for constipation.
On 2025-07-20, the patient was noted to have abdominal distension.
KUB showed postop ileus. No nausea/vomiting. She was made NPO,
limited narcotics, and continued on aggressive bowel regimen.
Repeat abdominal XR 2025-07-20 showed interval improvement. On 2025-07-20,
the patient was passing her bowels and her diet was advanced to
regular. A repeat KUB showed interval improvement of the ileus.
On discharge patient was moving her bowels without difficulty.

#Fever
#UTI
The patient became febrile postoperatively. Urinalysis was
positive. Urine culture showed PROTEUS MIRABILIS UTI. She was
started on Ceftriaxone 1996.
Blood cultures were negative. Chest x-ray was negative. On
discharged there is no evidence of UTI or ongoing infection,
patient is afebrile.

#Hyponatremia
The patient was hyponatremic and was started on sodium chloride
tablets on 2025-07-20 with improvement. On 2025-07-20, the patient's
serum Na level remained low and the salt tablets were increased.
The serum Na level normalized on 2025-07-20 and the sodium was
monitored closely. On 2025-07-20, the salt tablets were titrated down
to 1g three times daily. The serum sodium continued to be
monitored, and was stable on 2025-07-20. Her sodium tablets were
weaned off and her serum sodium levels remained stable.

#Elevated BUN
The patient's BUN was elevated. She received a 500mL normal
saline bolus on 2025-07-20 with improvement. The BUN returned to
normal range on 2025-07-20. Her BUN was elevated on 2025-07-20 and
returned to normal limits the next day.

#Left shoulder pain
Patient developed severe left shoulder pain 2025-07-20. Ibuprofen was
started with some relief. XR on 2025-07-20 showed no fracture or
dislocation, but did show mild calcific tendinitis. Ibuprofen
was increased and continued 1.5:1 was recommended.

#Disposition
Physical Therapy and Occupational Therapy were consulted and
recommended discharge to rehabilitation. However, the patient's
health insurance does not provide any rehabilitation benefits.
Family training was done inpatient to work towards a safe
discharge. Social Work was consulted given her limited health
insurance. A family meeting was organized that resulted in the
patient's family working to get the patient insurance so
benefits can be obtained. The goal was to obtain benefits for
acute rehab at the recommendation of physical therapy, either
through the John Andrade or John Andrade. A second family meeting was held
2025-07-20 where her son, Jill Moore, was given power of attorney and
health care proxy status as the family worked on insurance.
Patient was approved for health insurance on 2025-07-20. She was
discharged on 2025-02-22 to Orthopedic Surgery Department for further care.

Discharge Instructions
Cervical Spinal Fusion

Surgery
•Do not apply any lotions or creams to the site.
•Call your surgeon if there are any signs of infection like
redness, fever, or drainage.

Activity
•We recommend that you avoid heavy lifting, running, climbing,
or other strenuous exercise until your follow-up appointment.
•You make take leisurely walks and slowly increase your
activity at your own pace. Avoid driving until stable try to do too much all at once.
•No driving while taking any narcotic or sedating medication.
•No contact sports until cleared by your neurosurgeon.
•Do NOT smoke. Smoking can affect your healing and fusion.

Medications
•Please do NOT take any blood thinning medication (Plavix,
Coumadin) until cleared by the neurosurgeon. You are cleared to
take Aspirin and Ibuprofen if indicated.
•You may use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort if
you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication.

When to Call Your Doctor at +916035051936 for:
•Severe pain, swelling, redness or drainage from the incision
site.
•Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit
•New weakness or changes in sensation in your arms or legs.

Followup Instructions:
Avoid alcohol completely to prevent liver strain and medication interference.
