Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. Williams underwent a living related living transplant (Live
Donor Liver Transplant, right lobe graft. temporary abdominal
closure with abthera. supraceliac aortic conduit with
cryopreserved iliac artery) on 2025-08-01, he was left
open for planned biliary reconstruction the next day.
2025-04-22 he went back to the OR for ABDOMINAL
WASHOUT, INTRAOP ULTRASOUND, Roux En Y hepaticojejunostomy to
intrahepatic bile duct, staged abdominal closure. He was
recovering well and extubated when a routine ultrasound on
2025-04-07 showed hepatic artery occlusion. He was
sent to Clarkberg where they found found to have hepatic artery
thrombolysis and he underwent stent of RHA-conduit anastomosis
on 2025-02-27 and he was found to have focal active extravasation
distal to stent. He was hypotensive with multiple blood product
infusions and began have a large volume of frank blood in his
abdominal drains. He was taken emergently to the operating room
early 2025-04-18 for evacuation of hematoma; revision/replacement of
supraceliac aortic conduit to right hepatic artery. He was
extubated shortly after the procedure and initially did not
require pressors. He was pre-approved for ATG and was given 225
mg ATG total over 4 divided doses.
.
Induction Immunosuppression consisted of Solumedrol to
prednisone taper (500 mg in OR POD 0) per usual pathway.
Mycophenolate was started pre-op and was transitioned to
Myfortic on POD 18 due to GI upset with the mycophenolate. Tacro
was started on the evening of POD 1, with daily levels and dose
adjustment per level. As noted he received Thymoglobulin due to
the history of PSC.
Tacro was 11.9 on day of discharge with dosage of 2 mg BID.
.
He was recovering well on the floor when he had an acute
respiratory decompensation requiring intubation and transfer to
ICU. He had some RLL collapse on CT, no PE and was treated with
a 7 day course of vanc/cefepime He also had a right pleural
effusion that was tapped, the gram stain was negative, but the
cytology showed rare yeast. In consultation with pathology and
ID, we didn’t add another fungal agent we asked for a repeat
stain and there was concern for pjp (vs artifact) in his fluid.
Again we conferred with ID and they asked us add on a fungal
culture to pleural fluid, universal PCR for PJP (sendout), BAL
add on immunoflourescence for PJP. However, his clinical picture
was inconsistent with PJP infection (despite positive beta D
glucan) and fungal coverage was not added. He also underwent
liver biopsy 2025-05-10 as his LFTs went up in the setting of some
hypotension with sedation with intubation, he underwent a
transjugular liver biopsy which showed no rejection or
autoimmune process. We placed a dobhoff and started tube feeds
after his respiratory event because he had minimal days of a
regular diet during his hospital course.
.
He was subsequently transferred to the floor. His chest tube was
removed after several days of low output; he continued to be
stable on room air. He had a persistent cough, but CXRs did not
demonstrate any consolidations. He developed nausea and had
three episodes of emesis, which displaced his feeding tube. KUB
was negative for ileus. However, He was able to tolerate a
regular diet and was placed back on his home insulin pump. He
was tolerating the regular diet well and blood sugars were
fairly well managed. He will follow up with his diabetes doctor
who helps him with the insuin pump settings.
.
Of note on the regular diet, his potassium was noted to be
increasing. He was counseled regarding the avoidance of higher
potassium foods, and will have labs checked on 2025-01-13.
.
Patient was ambulatory and was cleared by Mark Smith for home. He will
also receive OT at home. He uses splints when ambulating.

to tolerate food, fluids or medications, yellowing of skin or
eyes, increased abdominal pain, incisional redness, drainage or
bleeding, dizziness or weakness, decreased urine output or dark,
cloudy urine, swelling of abdomen or ankles, or any other
concerning symptoms.
.
Bring your pill box and list of current medications to every
clinic visit.
.

arranged by the transplant clinic, with results to the
transplant clinic (Fax +91-446-8948077. CBC, Chem 10, AST, ALT,

.
*** On the days you have your labs drawn, do not take your Tacro
until your labs are drawn. Bring your Tacro with you so you may
take your medication as soon as your labwork has been drawn.
.
Follow your medication card, keep it updated with any dosage
changes, and always bring your card with you to any clinic or
hospital visits.
.
You may shower. Allow the water to run over your incision and
pat area dry. No rubbing, no lotions or powder near the
incision. You may leave the incision open to the air.
.
The Roux tube will remain in place upon dscharge. The exit site
should be examined daily for redness, drainage or bleeding. A
split sponge (drain sponge) should be placed at the exit site,
tubing coiled and a 4x4 gauze dressing placed over the tubing
and taped in place such that the tape does not come in contact
with the tubing.
.
No tub baths or swimming
.
No driving if taking narcotic pain medications
.
Avoid direct sun exposure. Wear protective clothing and a hat,
and always wear sunscreen with SPF 30 or higher when you go
outdoors.
.
Drink enough fluids to keep your urine light in color. Your
appetite will return with time. Eat small frequent meals, and
you may supplement with things like carnation instant breakfast
or Ensure.
.
Check your blood sugars and modify pump per your discussion with
your diabetes doctor who you should have close follow up with

values above 160 or less than 110 to the transplant clinic
.

consultation with the transplant clinic at +917054825358. There
are significant drug interactions with anti-rejection
medications which must be considered in medication management
following transplant.
.

at the transplant clinic with any questions that may arise

months, found to have acute decompensation likely secondary to
alcholic hepatitis.

#Decompensated Liver Failure with encephalopathy and ascites:
MELD 9 upon discharge, 19 upon admission at Cleveland Health Institute. Patient's liver
failure likely Device alcoholic hepatitis HCC, Intracranial Hemorrhage, AI,
infectious causes have been ruled out. Patient's last drink was
on 2025-02-26 and is determined to abstain from drinking, has the
support of his brother. This is his first decompensation.
Patient was just told of his cirrhosis diagnosis a couple of
weeks prior to admission. RUQ US at 2025-02-26 patent portal vein,
mod ascites, no SBP (this was after ~5L was drained at OSH).
Patient remained afebrile and no antibiotics were given. Patient
was continued on rifaximin 550mg BID, lactulose (titrated to
4BM/day). There was also a question of whether or not patient
developed a rash with lasix/spirinolactone and when this was
determined to be unlikely based on skin biopsy, patient was
restarted on lasix and spirinolactone, which he tolerated (see
details below). Patient was also initiated on tube feeds as well
as thiamine, folate, MVI. EGD was normal other than portal
gastropathy, no varicies and no no h/o GIB according to patient
and brother. Given that patient's Discriminant fraction improved
dramatically during course of stay, we held off on giving him
steroids as there was concern that he could develop side effects
from psoriasis should the steroids ever be stopped.
.
#SOB: likely COVID-19 Pneumonia volume overload. CXR with pleural effusions,
likely cirrhotic hydrothorax, improved with fluid restriction
and diuresis. Patient also with h/o of 40 pk yr smoking with
scattered wheeze, initiated on albuterol prn.
.
#Hyponatremia: Patient was found to be 129 at OSH, now resolved;
NA 134, likely due to hypervolemia. Continue fluid restriction.
.
#Psoriasis: consulted derm, who recommended steroid creams,
which helped him immensely. Patient to continue these creams
daily and has outpatient follow up with prior dermatologist.
.
#Drug rash: Patient came in with red, patchy, not discrete,
itchy rash on top of his worsening psoriasis. No mucosal
involvement. Derm was c/s and biopsied site, which revealed
changes associated with psoriasis and eczema, not a drug
reaction. Patient's eos on admission were mildly elevated but
trended downwards, and stayed low despite trial of restarting
lasix, and spirinolactone. Patient will require suture removal 2
wks from 2025-02-26 by PCP on shoulder.
.
#Anemia: likely component of anemia of chronic disease as well
as macrocytic anemia from longstanding malnutrition. Started on
MVI, thiamine, folate.
.

INSTRUCTIONS AFTER ORTHOPAEDIC SURGERY:

instructed to stop by your surgeon.

WOUND CARE:
- You may shower. No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks.
- Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken
out at your 2-week follow up appointment.

draining, you may apply a gauze dressing secured with paper
tape.

otherwise instructed.
- Please keep plaster splint dry, using a protective bag or
covering if necessary to shower.

DANGER SIGNS:

emergency department if you experience any of the following:
- Increasing pain that is not controlled with pain medications
- Increasing redness, swelling, drainage, or other concerning
changes in your incision
- Persistent or increasing numbness, tingling, or loss of
sensation

- Shaking chills
- Chest pain
- Shortness of breath

medications down
- Any other medical concerns

Brief Hospital Course:
1977 M with HCV cirrhosis/HCC s/p TACE with stable MRI and in good
health presented for potential liver transplant. The donor was
an ABO compatible 1976 woman brain dead donor considered
CDC high risk due to social history. Patient was aware of this
high risk and agreed to proceed with donor offer. On 2025-02-21, he
underwent deceased donor liver transplant using piggyback
technique. Surgeon was Dr. David Miller assisted by Dr. Reginald Turner
Samantha Miller. Please refer to operative report for details. He was
transferred to the SICU postop for management.

He was extubated the next day. Liver enzymes increased as
expected. Liver duplex showed patent vasculature and no ductal
dilatation. He was started on a clear liquid diet. Glucoses were
elevated initially due to the steroid protocol. An insulin drip
was used with improvement. Prograf was started.

He was transferred out of the SICU. On 2025-06-17, JP output was
sanguinous. HCT was 27 from 30 and previously 33. He was given
PRBC without increase in HCT. Serial HCTs were checked. JP
output continued to be sanguinous with total daily output
1230cc. He received a total of 4 units of PRBC and 2 platelets.
HCT stabilized at 30, however, JP output continued to be ~
400-500cc/day. The JP was removed on day of discharge and site
sutured. Just prior to removal, output was 85cc x12 hours and
serous. LFTs decreased daily.

On 2025-05-03, he experienced an episode of lightheadedness while
having BM. EKG was normal. Cardiac enzymes were sent with trops
0.19->0.11->0.03. Daily ASA 81 and Atorvastatin was started.
Cardiology recommended a TTE that normal with EF of 65%. a
nuclear stress test was then done to evaluate. This showed no
ischemic changes or anginal type symptoms or ST segment changes.

Diet was advanced to regular and was well tolerated. Obstetrics and Gynecology was
consulted for mild hyperglycemia, but he did not require insulin
and the sliding scale was stopped. He was having BMs and in fact
developed diarrhea. Stool was sent for C. diff that was
negative. Imodium was given as he was C.diff negative with
decreased BMs to 2 per day.

Obstetrics and Gynecology evaluated and felt that he was safe for home.

He did very well with medication teaching. Immunosuppression
consisted of Cellcept 1 gram bid (later changed to 500mg qid),
Solu-Medrol tapered to prednisone 20 by postop day 6 and
tacrolimus. Tacrolimus doses were adjusted per daily trough
levels to 3mg bid. All medications were to be filled by
CureWell Pharmacy with coverage from Dr. Neha Gupta (Gynecologist) as requested by
patient.

Discharge Instructions:
Please call the transplant clinic at +919937593656 for fever >
101, chills, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, inability
to tolerate food, fluids or medications, jaundice, increased
abdominal pain, incisional redness, drainage or bleeding,
decreased urine output or dark, cloudy urine, swelling of
abdomen or ankles, or any other concerning symptoms.

You will have labwork drawn every Daily and Once daily as
arranged by the transplant clinic, with results to the
transplant clinic (Fax +91-381-6334189. CBC, Chem 10, AST, ALT,
Alk Phos, T Bili, Trough Tacro level.

**On the days you have your labs drawn, do not take your Tacro
until your labs are drawn. Bring your Tacro with you so you may
take your medication as soon as your labwork has been drawn.

Follow your medication card, keep it updated with any dosage
changes, and always bring your card with you to any clinic or
hospital visits.

You may shower. Allow the water to run over your incision and
pat area dry. No rubbing, no lotions or powder near the
incision. You may leave the incision open to the air. The
staples are removed approximately 3 weeks following your
transplant.

No tub baths or swimming
No driving if taking narcotic pain medications

Avoid direct sun exposure. Wear protective clothing and a hat,
and always wear sunscreen with SPF 30 or higher when you go
outdoors.

Drink enough fluids to keep your urine light in color. Your
appetite will return with time. Eat small frequent meals, and
you may supplement with things like carnation instant breakfast
or Ensure.

Check your blood pressure at home. Report consistently elevated
values to the transplant clinic

Do not increase, decrease, stop or start medications without
consultation with the transplant clinic at +919937593656. There
are significant drug interactions with anti-rejection
medications which must be considered in medication management
following transplant
Consult transplant binder, and there is always someone on call
at the transplant clinic with any questions that may arise

Followup Instructions:
Start the prescribed medication and do not miss any doses.

Brief Hospital Course:

She was initiated on a dilaudid PCA. Brittany Gonzales initiated
methylprednisolone 1g IV x3 days. She had significant
improvement in her headache by the next morning. Dilaudid PCA
was gradually weaned down then transitioned to po dilaudid. She
received toradol 15mg IV Q8hrs x3 days. Zofran, phenergan, and
compazine used for nausea. For prophylaxis, topamax was
decreased to 25mg po qday due to side effects on higher dose.
We will plan to gradulaly incrase topamax to goal of 50mg po bid
as outpatient. In the meantime, tizanidine increased to

followed her during admission, and they were in touch with
primary pain physician Scott Leonard.

Head CT showed mild assymetry of lateral ventricles, otherwise
negative. Given headaches at times worse with lying down and
wake her at night, there was some concern for increased ICP
despite normal head CT. Patient expressed understanding of
concerns, but refused a lumbar puncture.

headache. Psychiatry was consulted, worked with the patient on

also contacted her home psychiatrics with advice for possible
medication adjustments.
.

narcotics. Constipation resolved, changed to only prn.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. Hamilton is a 1986 female with recurrent ventral hernias at
prior incision sites who was admitted to ICU after OR repair for
decreased urine output. Below is her ICU course.
.
#Oliguria- Most likely this is due to hypovolemia in the setting
of a prolonged operative case with a significant amount of
incensible fluid loss. Her FeNa on admission is 0.03% suggesting
a pre-renal etiology. She was given continued boluses of LR
while in the unit and her UOP increased appropriately. At time
of discharge from the unit she was making over 50cc/hr of urine.

.
#Post Op Pain- Pt initially had an epidural catheter in place
for pain control infusing dilaudid and bupivacaine. Acute pain
service followed her and assisted with management. She initially
was complaining of pain and she was given a bolus of dilaudid in
her epidural catheter but this was not helping. At this point,
the epidural was kept in place with bupivacaine only infusing
and patient was started on a dilaudid PCA for overnight. The
following day her epidural catheter was removed and her dilaudid
PCA was discontinued due to new onset of delerium/paranoia.
Pain control was switched to PO medications and patient was
restarted on many of her home pain medications.
.
#Delerium-Thought to be related to anesthesia, IV pain
medications and ICU admission. Treated conservatively with
Psych consult and discontinuation of IV pain medications and
epidural. Her sister was asked to come to the ICU and remained
at patient's bedside throughout the day on POD#1 to provide
emotional support and a sense of safety to patient. Patient
showed gradual improvement with supportive measures and returned
to her baseline.
.
# S/P hernia repair- Surgical incision site was clean without
evidence of infection. 4 JP drains were in place draining a
bloody serous fluid. Gen surg and Plastic surg following along
for assistance in post op management. She was tolerating a clear
liquid diet prior to discharge from the unit. Her Hct remained
stable. We continued Ancef per surgery recs.
.
#Hypothyroidism- continued levothyroxine.
.
#Prophylaxis- Patient was maintained on heparin subcutaneous and
then lovenox injections during her hospital stay. She was
assisted out of bed to chair and assisted to ambulate as soon as
she was able.
.
By post-operative day #3, patient showed clear clinical
improvement and was transferred to the floor. She was noted to
have some tachycardia and elevated blood pressures so was
started on low dose hydrochlorothiazide (12.5mg qd) on 2025-07-27
which she tolerated well. By post-operative day #5, patient was
alert and oriented and back to baseline mental status. She was
voiding large amounts of urine freely. She was able to walk
around unassisted and walk up stairs. Her abdominal incision
was clean and intact without evidence of infection. JP drains x
4 were draining serous fluid. Her abdominal binder was in place
and her pain was well controlled on her discharge pain
medication regimen. Patient was discharged home on POD#5 per
discharge plan.

Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted on 2025-03-09 for incisional hernia repair with
component separation. Please follow these discharge
instructions.
.
Personal Care:
1. You may remove your dressings after 48 hours post surgery.
2. Clean around the drain site(s), where the tubing exits the
skin, with soap and water.
3. Strip drain tubing, empty bulb(s), and record output(s) Every hour
times per day.
4. A written record of the daily output from each drain should
be brought to every follow-up appointment. your drains will be
removed as soon as possible when the daily output tapers off to
an acceptable amount.
5. You may shower 48 hours after surgery but do not bathe in a
tub until cleared by Dr. Doyle.
6. You should wear your abdominal binder at all times.
.
Activity:
1. You may resume your regular diet.
2. DO NOT lift anything heavier than 5 pounds or engage in
strenuous activity until instructed by Dr. Doyle.
.
Medications:
1. HOLD your daily baby aspirin and your nabumetone (relafen)
for now. You may ask Dr. Doyle at your follow up appointment when
you may re-start these medications.
2. You may take your oxycodone as needed for moderate to severe
pain.
3. Take your antibiotic as prescribed.
4. Take Colace, 100 mg by mouth 2 times per day, while taking
the prescription pain medication. You may use a different
over-the-counter stool softener if you wish.
5. Do not drive or operate heavy machinery while taking any
narcotic pain medication. You may have constipation when taking
narcotic pain medications (oxycodone, percocet, vicodin,
hydrocodone, dilaudid, etc.); you should continue drinking
fluids, you may take stool softeners, and should eat foods that
are high in fiber.
6. do not take any medicines such as Motrin, Aspirin, Advil or
Ibuprofen etc
.
Call the office IMMEDIATELY if you have any of the following:
1. Signs of infection: fever with chills, increased redness,
swelling, warmth or tenderness at the surgical site, or unusual
drainage from the incision(s).
2. A large amount of bleeding from the incision(s) or drain(s).
3. Fever greater than 101.5 oF
4. Severe pain NOT relieved by your medication.
.
Return to the ER if:
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your
medications.
* If you have shaking chills, fever greater than 101.5 (F)
degrees or 38 (C) degrees, increased redness, swelling or
discharge from incision, chest pain, shortness of breath, or
anything else that is troubling you.
* Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that
concern you.
.
DRAIN DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS
You are being discharged with drains in place. Drain care is a
clean procedure. Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and warm
water before performing drain care. Perform drainage care twice
a day. Try to empty the drain at the same time each day. Pull
the stopper out of the drainage bottle and empty the drainage
fluid into the measuring cup. Record the amount of drainage
fluid on the record sheet. Reestablish drain suction.
.
ISSUES TO DISCUSS WITH YOUR PCP:
-Can you were hospitalized, a thyroid stimulating hormone
(TSH) level was drawn to monitor thyroid function. Your level
was slightly low at 0.23. You have been maintained on your home
dose of levothyroxine (100mcg). Your PCP Can need to further
monitor your TSH level.
-You had some elevated heart rates and elevated blood pressures
while you were an inpatient. Your resting heart rate had
improved by time of discharge to 80-95. Your blood pressure
remained elevated so you were maintained on a low dose of
hydrochlorothiazide (12.5mg daily). You have been given a
prescription for 30 days of this medication after which time
your PCP may decide to renew or increase this medication or
discontinue it.
-Please bring your daily vital signs log/report from the
visiting nurse to your appointment with your PCP.
-You were not maintained on your lidoderm patches or your
neurontin while in hospital. These may not be necessary any
longer given that your hernia was repaired. You should discuss
this with your PCP.

Followup Instructions:
Return in 2 weeks with lab reports

Discharge Diagnosis:
Left lower extremity ischemia with gangrene of left great toe.


Discharge Condition:

Discharge Instructions:
Medications:
•Take Aspirin 325mg (enteric coated) once daily
•Take Plavix (Clopidogrel) 75mg once daily
•Continue all other medications you were taking before surgery,
unless otherwise directed
•You make take Tylenol or prescribed pain medications for any
post procedure pain or discomfort

What to expect when you go home:
It is normal to have slight swelling of the legs:
•Elevate your leg above the level of your heart (use 19
pillows or a recliner) every Every 6 hours hours throughout the day and at
night
•Avoid prolonged periods of standing or sitting without your
legs elevated
•It is normal to feel tired and have a decreased appetite, your
appetite will return with time
•Drink plenty of fluids and eat small frequent meals
•It is important to eat nutritious food options (high fiber,
lean meats, vegetables/fruits, low fat, low cholesterol) to
maintain your strength and assist in wound healing
•To avoid constipation: eat a high fiber diet and use stool
softener while taking pain medication

What activities you can and cannot do:
•When you go home, you may walk and go up and down stairs
•You may shower (let the soapy water run over groin incision,
rinse and pat dry)
•Your incision may be left uncovered, unless you have small
amounts of drainage from the wound, then place a dry dressing or
band aid over the area that is draining, as needed
•No heavy lifting, pushing or pulling (greater than 5 lbs) for
1 week (to allow groin puncture to heal)
•After 1 week, you may resume sexual activity
•After 1 week, gradually increase your activities and distance
walked as you can tolerate
•No driving until you are no longer taking pain medications
•Call and schedule an appointment to be seen in 190 weeks for
post procedure check and ultrasound

What to report to office:
•Numbness, coldness or pain in lower extremities
•Temperature greater than 101.5F for 24 hours
•New or increased drainage from incision or white, yellow or
green drainage from incisions
•Bleeding from groin puncture site

SUDDEN, SEVERE BLEEDING OR SWELLING (Groin puncture site)
•Lie down, keep leg straight and have someone apply firm
pressure to area for 10 minutes. If bleeding stops, call
vascular office +916885292433. If bleeding does not stop, call
+916219296421 for transfer to closest Emergency Room.

Followup Instructions:
Continue wound care with daily dressing changes as instructed.

Findings
LEFT ATRIUM: No spontaneous echo contrast or thrombus in the Septum or the RA/RAA. Good (>20 cm/s) Mean flow velocity ejection velocity.
RIGHT ATRIUM/INTERATRIAL SEPTUM: No ASD by 2D or color Doppler.
LEFT VENTRICLE: Normal LV wall thickness. Mildly dilated LV
cavity. Overall normal LVEF (>55%). [Intrinsic LV systolic
function likely depressed given the severity of valvular
regurgitation.]
RIGHT VENTRICLE: Mildly dilated RV cavity. Normal RV systolic
function.
AORTA: Normal aortic diameter at the sinus level. Normal
ascending aorta diameter. Normal aortic arch diameter. Normal
descending aorta diameter. Simple atheroma in descending aorta.
AORTIC VALVE: Three aortic valve leaflets. No AS. No AR.
MITRAL VALVE: Moderately thickened mitral valve leaflets. No MS.
Mid-systolic MR Posterior. Severe (4+) MR.
Mechanical VALVE: No TS. Physiologic TR.
PULMONIC VALVE/PULMONARY ARTERY: Pulmonic valve not well seen.

GENERAL COMMENTS: A TEE was performed in the location listed
above. I certify I was present in compliance with CMS guidelines
regulations. The patient was under general anesthesia throughout
the procedure. The TEE probe was passed with assistance from the
anesthesioology staff using a laryngoscope. No TEE related
complications. The patient appears to be in sinus rhythm.
Results were personally reviewed with the MD caring for the
patient.
Conclusions
Pre CPB:
No spontaneous echo contrast or thrombus is seen in the body of
the left atrium/left atrial appendage or the body of the right
atrium/right atrial appendage.
No atrial septal defect is seen by 2D or color Doppler,
echodense material seen at likely site of prior ASD repair.
Left ventricular wall thicknesses are normal. The left
ventricular cavity is mildly dilated. Overall left ventricular
systolic function is normal (LVEF>55%). [Intrinsic left
ventricular systolic function is likely more depressed given the
severity of mitral valvular regurgitation.]
The right ventricular cavity is mildly dilated with normal free
wall contractility.
There are simple atheroma in the descending thoracic aorta.
There are three aortic valve leaflets. There is no aortic valve
stenosis. No aortic regurgitation is seen.
The mitral valve leaflets are moderately thickened. Two
eccentric jets of Severe (4+) mitral regurgitation are seen. The
posteriorly directed jet originates from a prolapsing A2 leaflet
and exhibits coanda effect. The anteriorly directed jet
originates from the base of the anterior leaflet and is
suspicious for a perforated leaflet (or failure of prior repair)
Dr. Katherine Moore was notified in person of the results.
Post CPB:
The cardiac output is 4L/min on a phenylephrine infusion and
A-paced.
There is a well seated bioprosthetic valve in the mitral
position with a centrally located trace MR jet; the mean
gradient across this valve is 3mmHg.
There is no aortic insufficiency.
The RV systolic function is preserved. The LVEF is 45-50%.
The visible contours of the thoracic aorta are intact.

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was brought to the operating room on 2025-04-03
where the patient underwent a redo sternotomy and attempted
repair of mitral regurgitation. Please see operative report for
details, in summary the patient had: 1. Redo sternotomy.
2. Attempted repair of mitral regurgitation. 3. Mitral valve
replacement with a 31-mm Medtronic tissue valve, model
Carpentier-Edwards 25 mm.
His bypass time was 119 minutes with a crossclamp of 102
minutes. Overall the patient tolerated the procedure well and
post-operatively was transferred to the CVICU in stable
condition for recovery and invasive monitoring in stable
condition.
POD 1 found the patient extubated, alert and breathing
comfortably.
The patient was neurologically intact and hemodynamically
stable, weaned from inotropic and vasopressor support. Beta
blocker therapy was held secondary to post-operative juctional
rhythm which recovered to a normal sinus rhythm. The patient
was transferred to the telemetry floor on POD3 for further
recovery. Chest tubes and pacing wires were discontinued
according to cardiac surgery protocol. The patient was
evaluated by the physical therapy service for assistance with
strength and mobility. At the time of discharge on POD #6 the
patient was ambulating freely, the wound was healing and pain
was controlled with oral analgesics. The patient was discharged
to a friend's home with visiting nurses. They is to follow up with
Dr Schedule imaging after 1 month to evaluate treatment progress. in 3 weeks.

Mr. Arthur Lee states that he has relatively constant tingling and vibrating sensation in bilateral legs that is hard to ignore. This is not painful, but is extremely distracting. It affects his legs from the inguinal level down to the toes. He walks with a cane for the past few months that his outpatient Cardiology Outpatient Service recommended. For the past 2 days he has had worsened sensation in his feet such that he does not know what his feet are doing. He had difficulty initiating steps and felt that he was frozen or paralyzed. He is worried about this because he states that he was "quadriplegic" when he had dermatomyositis a couple of decades ago. At baseline, he walks with a cane and drives himself around. He has not had falls at home. He had a scheduled appointment with his outpatient neurologist Dr. Jesse Hernandez for lumbar CT (can't get MRI due to pacemaker) to evaluate for spinal column instability, but he felt unsafe to drive given poor pedal sensation. not drive, operate heavy machinery, or drink alcohol while
taking these medications. As your pain decreases, take fewer
tablets and increase the time between doses. This medication can
cause constipation, so you should drink plenty of water daily
and take a stool softener (such as colace) as needed to prevent
this side effect. Call your surgeons office 3 days before you
are out of medication so that it can be refilled. These
medications cannot be called into your pharmacy and must be

an extra 2 days if you would like your medication mailed to your

surgeon.

was obtained and the CX resulted negative. Physical Therapy was

cleared for discharge to home. INR was therapeutic for goal

and intact without erythema or abnormal drainage. The patient

the hospital course and repleted accordingly. At the time of
discharge the patient was tolerating a regular diet and feeling
well. The patient was afebrile with stable vital signs. The
patient's hematocrit was acceptable and pain was adequately
controlled on an oral regimen. The operative extremity was
neurovascularly intact and the wound was benign.

Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care

Facility:
Neurosurgery Unit

Discharge Diagnosis:
right hip osteoarthritis

Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker
or cane).

Discharge Instructions:
1. Please return to the emergency department or notify your
physician if you experience any of the following: severe pain
not relieved by medication, increased swelling, decreased
sensation, difficulty with movement, fevers greater than 101.5,
shaking chills, increasing redness or drainage from the incision
site, chest pain, shortness of breath or any other concerns.
2. Please follow up with your primary physician regarding this
admission and any new medications and refills.
3. Resume your home medications unless otherwise instructed.
4. You have been given medications for pain control. Please do
not drive, operate heavy machinery, or drink alcohol while
taking these medications. As your pain decreases, take fewer
tablets and increase the time between doses. This medication can
cause constipation, so you should drink plenty of water daily
and take a stool softener (such as colace) as needed to prevent
this side effect. Call your surgeons office 3 days before you
are out of medication so that it can be refilled. These
medications cannot be called into your pharmacy and must be
picked up in the clinic or mailed to your house. Please allow
an extra 2 days if you would like your medication mailed to your
home.
5. You may not drive a car until cleared to do so by your
surgeon.
6. Please keep your wounds clean. You may shower starting five
(5) days after surgery, but no tub baths or swimming for at
least four (4) weeks. No dressing is needed if wound continues
to be non-draining. Any stitches or staples that need to be
removed will be taken out by the visiting nurse (2012) or rehab
facility two
weeks after your surgery.
7. Please call your surgeon's office to schedule or confirm your
follow-up appointment in four (4) weeks.
8. Please DO NOT take any non-steroidal anti-inflammatory
medications (NSAIDs such as celebrex, ibuprofen, advil, aleve,
motrin, etc).
9. ANTICOAGULATION: Please continue your lovenox for four (4)
weeks to help prevent deep vein thrombosis (blood clots). If
you were taking aspirin prior to your surgery, it is OK to
continue at your previous dose while taking this medication.
Compression STOCKINGS x 6 WEEKS.
10. WOUND CARE: Please keep your incision clean and dry. It is
okay to shower five days after surgery but no tub baths,
swimming, or submerging your incision until after your four (4)
week checkup. Please place a dry sterile dressing on the wound
each day if there is drainage, otherwise leave it open to air.
Check wound regularly for signs of infection such as redness or
thick yellow drainage. Staples will be removed by the visiting
nurse or rehab facility in two (2) weeks.
11. Occupational therapy (once at home): Home Physical therapy at home, dressing changes as
instructed, wound checks, and staple removal at two weeks after
surgery.
12. ACTIVITY: Weight bearing as tolerated on the operative
extremity. Posterior precautions. No strenuous exercise or heavy
lifting until follow up appointment. Mobilize frequently

WBAT
Posterior precautions
Mobilize
Treatments Frequency:
dry, sterile dressing changes daily and as needed for drainage
wound checks
ice
TEDs

Bring all imaging scans and reports to the next appointment.

ventricular wall aneurysm, L MCA/accom/basilar aneurysm s/p
coiling, BPH and Fracture of left arm in 2012, treated with casting transferred
from OSH with clostridium perfringens bacteremia including cholangitis
now s/p stent placement found to have ampullary mass now with
course complicated by worsening anemia and peripheral edema.

# Sepsis due to cholangitis with clostridium perfringens
bactermia: Patient was found to have Clostridium perfringens
bacteremia at OSH felt to be due to cholangitis. For concern for
cholangitis, patient underwent an ERCP with stent placement on
2025-04-02 with improvement in his LFTs and bilirubin following his
procedure. On ERCP, he was found to have an ampullary mass from
which biopsies and brushings were taken (see below). His
coumadin was restarted with heparin bridge following his
procedure. His bacteremia was initially managed with zosyn and
he was transitioned to ceftriaxone and flagyl with the
assistance of ID to complete a total of 14 days from 2025-08-12 (day
of ERCP). A PICC was placed prior to discharge. He will need his
PICC removed with his PCP after completion of his IV antibiotics
on 2025-06-22.

#Anemia: Patient had worsening anemia throughout admission with
recent hemoglobin around 10, trending down to mid-7s. Work-up
was notable for low haptoglobin suggesting hemolysis. Hematology
was consulted and reviewed his smear which did not show
significant number of schistocytes. Review of previous labs
showed low haptoglobin in the past. G6PD negative, repeat blood
cultures without evidence of recurrent bacteremia (clostridium
perfringens can cause hemolysis). Urine hemosiderin ultimately
was positive suggesting chronic intravascular hemolysis, likely
secondary to his mechanical aortic valve. Patient was also found
to have black, guaiac positive stools. He went for repeat EUS
and EGD which showed bleeding from the ampullary mass which was
cauterized. Following this procedure, the patient's hemoglobin
stabilized. He was started on IV PPI BID and transitioned to
pantoprazole 40mg PO BID which he will continue for 4 weeks. He
was also started on folic acid in setting of malnutrition and
hemolysis.

#Ampullary mass: Found on ERCP in setting of cholangitis. CEA
normal, CA CEA elevated. Ampulla cytology and path negative for
malignancy however per repeat EUS on 2025-07-31, still with concerning
mass that will likely need repeat biopsy. Patient is to be
reviewed in multidisciplinary pancreatico-biliary conference and
will follow-up with Dr. John Woods in Green Valley Hospital clinic on
2025-03-30 for further evaluation.


# Mechanical AVR Congestive Heart Failure rheumatic heart disease
# Supratherapeutic INR - INR 5.5 on admission, per pt has goal
of 2.5 – 3.5 (Mechanical prosthetic heart valve). Old style Bjork-Shiley valve placed in the 1970s.
Cardiology consulted and assisted with plans to reverse Coumadin
for his ERCP. He was placed on heparin drip once INR was <2.5.
Warfarin was restarted following ERCP and heparin gtt used to
bridge while in hospital. Patient was discharged on lovenox 80mg
BID until INR >3.0. Metoprolol restarted at discharge.

#Volume overload: Patient with significant volume overload
following fluid resuscitation for sepsis. He had significant
peripheral edema, bilateral pleural effusions and mild PND. He
was diuresed with 20mg IV lasix BID with improvement in his
symptoms. Repeat TTE showed EF 65% and was largely unchanged
from prior at New Barry in 2025-03-17. Weight at baseline at time of
discharge.

#Nausea, malnutrition: Patient with moderate malnutrition noted
during admission with poor PO intake in setting of nausea. His
antiemetics were increased with improved symptoms and improved
PO intake. Will need to consider nutrition vs GI consult as
outpatient if symptoms persist.


# Basilar aneurysm s/p coil assisted w stent performed by Dr.
John Woods on 2025-05-05 (hospitalized 3 days. He should remain on
current dose of aspirin. There is elevated risk of stroke if he
ever stops aspirin at this time.

# Gout - continue allopurinol 2019
# BPH - cont Flomax 0.4 mg
# HLD: Continued atorvastatin 10mg daily

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. Valdez,

You were admitted to Brigham and Women’s Hospital with jaundice and a blood stream
infection due to an infection in your biliary system. You
underwent an ERCP which showed a mass in your biliary system (in
the ampulla where bile drains). The mass was biopsied and you
will need to follow-up with the pancreatic surgeons to discuss
the next steps for management of the mass.

In terms of your infection, you were seen by the infectious
disease team and started on two antibiotics, ceftriaxone and
flagyl which you will continue to take through 2025-08-17.
Ceftriaxone will be given via your PICC line. You will need to
arrange for follow-up with your PCP following completion of your
antibiotics for removal of the PICC line.

Unfortunately, while you were here, you experienced worsening
anemia (low blood counts). You were found to have some mild
breakdown of your blood, likely from your mechanical aortic
valve. You were also found to have bleeding from your GI tract
and a repeat endoscopy showed bleeding from the site of your
ampulla biopsy. This was treated and your blood counts
stabilized. You will need to continue to take pantoprazole twice
daily for the next four weeks for treatment of this bleed.

Finally, in terms of your mechanical aortic valve, your coumadin
was held initially and restarted after your procedure on 2025-01-09.
You will need to go home with lovenox until your INR is above
3.0. You will need to have your INR checked at Jamietown
Nephrology on 2025-08-16 at 8:30AM.

Please continue to take all of your medications as prescribed.

It was a pleasure taking Adjust as needed of you,
Your Nephrology Cardiology Team

Followup Instructions:
Begin pulmonary rehabilitation exercises under supervision.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. Moore is a 1978 with DM, ESRD on HD, and past h/o GPC
bacteremia who presented after febrile and hypotensive episode
at outpatient HD center one day prior to admission, and was
found to have MRSA septicemia.

#MRSA Septicemia: Patient arrived from OSH after having received
empiric vanc/gent. She remained febrile and was placed on
empiric vanc/cefepime for MRSA and GNR coverage, but was
eventually narrowed to vanc monotherapy after blood culture grew
MRSA. Patient was hypotensive at several points of her stay,
and was resuscitated with IV NS with good effect. She denied any
symptoms during these episodes. Home metoprolol was held, given
sepsis physiology. HD catheter was the presumed source of
infection and pulled. CXR did not exclude pneumonia, although
patient did not appear to have respiratory symptoms. TTE did not
reveal signs of valvular vegetations or pacemaker lead
infection; however, patient was not amenable to a TEE. Patient
had mild R hand and arm swelling and u/s revealed possible
retained subclavian line fragment. CXR did not show evidence of
line fragment. Repeat u/s read as positive for retained line
fragment. L AV fistula u/s was reassuring.

ID was consulted and recommended vancomycin trough goal of
15-20 mcg/mL. Last trough drawn showed therapeutic levels, and patient
has remained afebrile since 2025-04-20. Treatment time will be
indefinite with IV vancomycin dosed with HD.

Orthopedics was consulted for evaluation of L hip and R knee for
possible septic arthritis. Ortho thought septic arthritis
unlikely based on clinical findings with preserved ROM, and no
erythema/warmth to suggest joint pathology. Patient declined
x-ray imaging.

Given her goals of care near the end of her stay (see below),
further attempts to diagnose and treat her were declined in
total, including non-invasive removal of her possible retained
catheter. Thus, she was ultimately discharged on indefinite
vancomycin with no further invasive procedures/measures to
correct her significant infection.

#Hypotension: Initially thought to be secondary to sepsis.
Responded well to fluids, and remained clinically well. Heart
failure service consulted for further evaluation as possible
cardiac cause of hypotension. Recommendations were made for
goal-directed therapy at discretion of patient's family's and
patient's wishes. Restarted beta blocker at discharge.
Patient's blood pressure was eventually taken at lower extremity
and showed SBP in 140s.

#ESRD: Patient received HD 2025-05-06, Sa
2025-03-28, and 2025-08-04 in her routine fashion.

# Diabetic Foot Ulcer - Patient was seen by wound care team, who
asked for vascular surgery consult. Vascular surgery who
recommended no further intervention during this hospitalization.
Vascular surgery also recommended patient follow up with her
OSH vascular surgeon, Dr. Sharon Keller. Daily dressing changes were
done with Adaptic.

# Diabetes, type 2 poorly controlled with complications - Placed
on HISS and Lantus 4 units daily. Patient found to have elevated
finger sticks on several occasional, but often refused
treatment. However, no acute events.

# Syncopal arrhythmia s/p pacemaker placement - Continued
aspirin. Held metoprolol given sepsis physiology.

# HLD - continued atorvastatin 80 mg daily

# Iron deficiency - placed on ferrous sulfate 325 mg (65 mg
iron) tablet daily

# Chronic Constipation - continued senna and Colace

# Goals of care: The patient was initially full code with no
limits to care. She was started on Vancomycin and underwent
various imaging studies. However, during her hospitalization
she was quite resistant to many aspects of her care, mostly
regarding invasive measures. During this evaluation, she
remained comfortable and denied complaints of pain. As her
hospitalization progressed, she refused even less invasive
tests, such as blood testing and vital signs. This was relayed
to the patient's family. Given these behaviors, and her overall
poor prognosis and state of debilitation, several goals of care
discussions were had with her, her family, and her outpatient
nephrologist. Understanding her comorbidities, current state of
illness, and desire not to have invasive testing or procedures,
they all ultimately decided on transitioning the patient out of
the hospital to focus on comfort/hospice care, with no further
invasive tests or treatment strategies, or escalation of care.
Even when her ultrasound identified a possible retained foreign
object, which could have been the main nidus of her infection,
and even at our recommendation to attempt removal in a
non-invasive way, the patient and family still declined,
understanding that her infection would likely continue and
progress. She was comfortable on discharge, and transitioned to
DNR/DNI and hospice care.

CKD V
DM2 uncontrolled
Acute encephalopathy
PVD

Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Baseline
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Wheelchair bound, requires assistance

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. Moore,

You were admitted to the Riverbend Medical for fevers and low blood
pressure. You were found to have bacteria in your blood and
were treated with antibiotics, which you will continue to
receive after discharge. You also received intravenous fluids,
which helped your blood pressure. You were seen by the dialysis
service here, who continued your dialysis on your regular
schedule, using the fistula in your left arm. The hemodialysis
catheter that you came with was removed.

While you were here, we did several tests to look for the source
of your blood infection. An x-ray of your chest did not show
infection in your lungs. An echocardiogram, which is an
ultrasound of your heart, did not reveal infection in your
heart. However, It showed signs of heart failure and severe
pulmonary hypertension. Because of this, the Heart Failure Team
here saw you. They felt that this would be best managed by
medications. You should speak to your primary care physician
about how this will be managed best.

You were also seen by orthopedics to see if you had bacteria in
your left hip and right knee joints. Based on physical exam,
they were not concerned for infection in these areas. They took
fluid from your right knee. There was no infection or other
concerning findings.

You were also seen by vascular surgeons for your leg wounds.
They recommended daily dressing changes, and further outpatient
evaluation. You should follow up with your vascular surgeon,
Dr. Sharon Keller.

We performed an ultrasound the identified a retained line
fragment in your right subclavian vein. You and your HCP elected
to not invasively remove this fragment.

We stopped your metoprolol, but did not change your other home
medications, and you should continue to take these medications
as prescribed.

You should continue IV vancomycin with dialysis for the rest of
your life.

It was a pleasure caring for you!

Followup Instructions:
Schedule imaging after 1 month

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to inpatient psychiatry after a suicide
attempt, under a conditional voluntary basis. There were no
acute medical issues during her hospitalization. Despite the
severity of her suicide attempt, the patient appeared to be
euthymic when she presented to the psychiatry unit. She
discussed how she stopped taking her medications months earlier
and did not tell her psychiatrist, who continued to prescribe
these for her. She denied however,that she 'stockpiled' her
medications, at least consciously.

The patient had been restarted on Wellbutrin while on medicine
and this was increased during the hospital stay. She requested a
medication to help with anxiety and Topamax was chosen since she
did not want to gain weight and she had tried this in the past
for migraines with no side effects.  Her adderall was held. The
patient also complained of insomnia and Trazodone was started.
This appeared to work for her.

Throughout the hospital stay, she increasingly became concerned
that "everyone knew" she was in the hospital, which caused her
to be visibly upset at various times. She admitted to feeling
anxious and depressed, which gradually resolved during the
intermediate portion of her stay. The patient intermittently
expressed frustrations about her inpatient stay, and in
particular, about another patient who she perceived as verbally
aggressive. Although she felt ready to be discharged after a few
days, she was anxious about her aftercare. Her repsonsibilities
and rights as a patient were fully discussed, given her recent
history of inconsistent participation in therapy. She advocated
she did not follow up with her therapist as scheduled because he
was out of her network, and she was unable to afford the fees.
However, when given the option of establishing new providers
within her network, she declined. Moreover, she contended
finances would no longer be an issue precluding her from
attending appointments. She was scheduled to attend a partial
partial program at Reginatown the week following discharge.
Initially, she requested not to return to Michaelborough, but later
changed her mind, citing transportation ease. However, she did
not want to be placed in the women's program. She planned to
travel to Port Austinborough by train immediately after discharge to
meet her parents, spend the weekend with them at their Assisted living facility
house in the Urban area and return to her apartment in Port Austinborough
by 2025-04-13 morning. The patient denied SI throughout the course
of her hospitalization.

Brief Hospital Course:
In brief the patient is a 2019 y/o female with PMH sig for CHF,
COPD, HTN, and colon CA s/p resection 1977, chronic kidney
disease presenting due general malaise and hyperkalemia s/p fall
2 days ago.

1) Generalized Malaise: The main differntial diagnosis
considered was infection vs. malnutrition vs. hyperkalemia vs.
medication mismanagement vs. worsening renal function. It was
felt most likely that she became dehydrated from poor oral
intake and chronic diarrhea which resulted in worsening renal
function and the generalized malaise. There was no evidence of
infection. She was hydrated with IVF then oral fluids. Her
renal function returned to her baseline. She had no syncope
events nor had any arrhythmias while on telemetry monitoring.
Her lisinopril was discontinued. It was felt that she would
benefit from rehab to increase endurance and conditioning.

2). Acute on Chronic Renal failure associated with hyperkalemia:
The patient presented with pre-renal azotemia associated with
hyperkalemia. There were mildly peaked T-waves on her EKG which
resolved with therapy. At discharge her renal function had
returned to her baseline after re-hydration.

3). Proph
- DVT: Hep SQ
- GI: encourage PO diet
- Cardio: ASA 81mg

4.) Dispo: The patient was discharged in stable condition to
short term rehab. A long term care plan will be re-addressed
with the patient and her primary care provider. She has declined
long term care facilities many times in the past and she is not
willing to move to New Stacey to live with her son.

5.) Code: Prior to discharge the patient re-confirmed that she
wanted to be full code.

systolic hypertension. The end-diastolic pulmonic regurgitation
velocity is increased suggesting pulmonary artery diastolic
hypertension. The main pulmonary artery is dilated. There is no
pericardial effusion.

# Acute HFrEF (previously HFpEF):
# Pulmonary edema:

BNP,crackles, edema & elevated JVP all supportive of acute heart

pressures, required BiPAP and nitroglycerin drip at Port Jessica

then transitioned to NC and then room air. His symptoms improved
with fluid removal via HD and control of BP. He was initially
treated with torsemide 80mg daily & with clinical improvement
returned to his home diuretic dose of torsemide 60mg daily. On
discharge, he was oxygenating well on room air.

# Influenza B:

oseltamavir.

# CAP:

transitioned to levofloxacin 2025-01-25 to complete a 5-day course.

# HTN:

arrival to the MICU. He was ultimately transitioned to home
antihypertensives labetalol, amlodipine, and hydralazine without
any changes.

Continued on HD on Mon/Wed/Fri HD schedule and home calcium acetate 1334 mg PO

# T2DM:

Previously evaluated by Hem-Onc who felt that this was mild case
of ITP. Platelet dropped on initial presentation to the Port Jessica
likely related to acute infection from influenza, uptrending on
discharge.

count, lack of fevers or belly pain. He had studies suggestive
of an osmotic diarrhea, and given his bouts of recurrent chronic
diarrhea, may warrant more of a workup in the patient setting.
He had negative stool studies. He was treated with IVF PRN and
with Zofran for nausea.

# Chest pain: On hospital day 1 patient had an episode of chest

severe AS; patient has refused further w/u for a TAVR in the past and continues to do so during this admission.

# Severe aortic stenosis: continued on home medications

not able to confirm that he was truly taking lisinopril at home
since the last time he had filled it at his regular pharmacy was 2025-04-24.

2025-04-20: Pt presented w/ Cr 1.5, previous baseline 1.1, like
pre-renal in the setting of dehydration associated with voluminous diarrhea.
This improved with fluids.

# Hypovolemic hyponatremia: Na initially 132 most likely from
decreased volume status associated with diarrhea. This remained stable
during his stay and Na on discharge was 133.

***Transitional issues***:
- would benefit from HIV testing in the outpatient setting,
since if he is immunocompromised this changes the differential
for his diarrhea.
- patient reports familiarity with lisinopril but is unsure if
he is taking it; because his blood pressure was systolic 100's
on day of discharge, this medication was discontinued. He should
confirm whether he is taking this medication or not at his next
PCP 2025-08-06.
- found to have subclinical hypothyroidism; this could be a
result of his acute illness but TSH should be followed up in 26
months.
- patient has had recurrent episodes of chronic diarrhea that
appear to self-resolve. His stool studies here showed evidence
of osmotic diarrhea, and hydrogen breath test may be considered
as an outpatient to eval for SIBO or carbohydrate malabsorption.

- patient has hiatal hernia and reports intermittent episodes of
regurgitation. Although no known episodes of aspiration may
benefit from a speech/swallow test in the outpatient setting.
- code status: DNR/DNI

Brief Hospital Course:
Pt was admitted 2025-01-10 and was taken to the operating room on
2025-04-03 and underwent MV repair and TV repair and Full left
and right-sided maze procedure with left atrial appendage
ligation. Please see operative note for full details. Pt
tolerated the procedure well and was transferred to the CVICU in
stable condition for recovery and invasive monitoring.

Pt was weaned from sedation, awoke neurologically intact, and
was extubated on POD 1. Pt was weaned from inotropic and
vasopressor support. Beta blocker was initiated and pt was
diuresed toward her preoperative weight. Amio initiated for
AFib. Heart rate subsequently dropped to the 100 bpm (upper normal limit) and she
required pacing. Amio and Lopressor discontinued.
Anti-coagulation initiated w Coumadin. Heart rate recovered and
Lopressor was resumed. INR rose quickly and Coumadin was held
several days to allow for removal of epicardial pacing wires.
Pt remained hemodynamically stable and was transferred to the
telemetry floor for further recovery. Chest tubes and pacing
wires discontinued. Coumadin resumed at low dose. Pt was
evaluated by the physical therapy service for assistance with
their strength and mobility. By the time of discharge on POD 6
pt was ambulating with assistance, all wounds were healing, and
pain was controlled with oral analgesics. Pt was discharged to the
Richard Davis in good condition with appropriate follow up
instructions.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. Williams is an 1983 year-old woman with history of myocardial
infarction and PCI in 2011, HTN and HL who presented with
chest/neck pain and found to have new onset atrial fibrillation.

.
#. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient has no known history of afib
prior to this admission. On presentation to the ED here, the
patient was in afib with HR of 110-120 and an ECG showing ST
depressions in V4-V6, I, aVL, 1 mm deeper from prior. She was
otherwise hemodynamically stable. The patient was given
intra-venous lopressor with good response and started on oral
metoprolol. The patient remained in atrial-fibrillation for
approximately 24 hours before spontaneously converting back to
sinus on hospital day #1. She was continued on oral metoprolol
and was started on dabigatran for anti-coagulation given CHADs
of 2. The patient had 2 additional episodes of likely afib on
telemetry although was asymptomatic during those episodes. A
TTE was done showing an enlarged left atria but no valvular
abnormality. She will be discharged on dabigatran and
metoprolol with plans to follow-up with a cardiologist.
.
#. Rule-out ACS: The patient presented with chest pressure and
shortness of breath. Her troponins were negative in the ED here
although she did have increased ST-depressions on ECG as
described above. She underwent exercise and nuclear stress
testing which were largely unremarkable. Believe that ischemic
type pain may be due to increased demand in the setting of rapid
afib. Chest pain resolved with rate control.
.
# Urinary Tract Infection: The patient complained of
foul-smelling urine on review of systems. Urinalysis performed
that was c/w UTI. This may be the inciting factor in the
patient's new afib. Patient has a history of frequent UTIs and
reports having had bad reations in the past to bactrim and
macrobid. Started on ciprofloxacin and will complete a 10-day
course. Will follow-up with her urologist and PCP about the
possibility of UTI prophylaxis.
.
#. Hypertension: Continued enalapril/amlodipine.
.
#. Hyperlipidemia: Continued simvatstain.

Brief Hospital Course:
====================
PATIENT SUMMARY:
====================
2019 yo F with reported PMHx significant for lyme disease and
depression, who presents with muteness and five days of nausea,
lightheadedness, and inability to ambulate. No clear underlying
infectious, autoimmune or inflammatory cause identified, most
likely secondary to conversion disorder vs. somatization.

====================
ACUTE ISSUES:
====================
#Muteness
#Inability to ambulate.
Patient presents with muteness and a constellation of other
neurological symptoms that began in 2025-02-19 and have become more
persistent since 2025-02-19. Given the patient's combination of
neurological symptoms that do not correspond to a neurological
disease and the fact that initial and current symptoms began in
the setting of life stresses/changes, conversion disorder is
most likely. Many of the patient's symptoms (jarbled language,
whispered tone, lower extremity paralysis out of proportion to
her physical exam) are commonly seen in conversion disorder.
Psychiatry and neurology were consulted for work up of weakness
and mutism. Toxic/metabolic workup was negative with negative
serum/urine tox, reassuring electrolytes, CBC, and TFTs. Brain
MRI was unremarkable. RPR, HIV, B12, TSH, CRP were normal. EEG
for seizure activity was unremarkable. dsDNA, ANCA, ANA positive, ESR, SM antiboidy, paraneoplastic were pending at the time of discharge.
She will follow up with neurology as outpatient to discuss the
pending labs. She started working with physical therapy as
inpatient and should continue physical therapy when she leaves
the hospital. Recommended that she establish care with
psychiatry and psychology close to home.

====================
TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
====================
N/A Continue to work with physical therapy
N/A Follow-up with neurology at St. Mary's Hospital
N/A Establish care with psychiatry close to home
N/A Stopped prednisone

regimen was increased with Imdur and pt continued to have chest

cath which revealed no angiographically significant coronary
artery disease. Pt was discharged on the Armenia equivalent
medications for Aspirin, long acting nitrate and ace inhibitor.

continued on a statin given that her lipid panel was at goal.

cardiology in South Rachel.

some calcifications on CXR over the right breast. Oblique views
showed calcifications projecting over the R lung base which were
believed to lie within the R breast. Pt reported having normal
mammograms in 2003 and was educated about the importance of
getting another mammogram to better evaluate this finding. Pt
also reported having undergone surgery on the R breast in the
past and felt that this finding may have been due to scar
tissue.
.

Armenia meds). She was also started on Metoprolol 12.5mg BID

Brief Hospital Course:
1980 yo married male, Hispanic 2019, with history of OCD,
chronic headaches, anxiety/depression, sent to the ED by his PCP
for inability to care for self in the setting of numerous
familial/marital stressors over the past 3 months, resulting in
poor intake and 12 lb weight loss over 1 month. He describes
ongoing depressed mood for about 1.5:1 year, and while he states his
OCD symptoms have reduced over the past 4:1 years since he has
moved to the 25, he has found his symptoms have been
quite distressing for him recently. He experiences recurrent
persistent thoughts regarding contamination, which are
neutralized by such behaviors as washing his hands repeatedly,
and forcing his family to shower when returning home. His fear
of contamination had impaired his social and occupational
functioning to the degree that he left his former job as a Chartered accountant
Chartered accountant due to fear of entering other people's homes. His
presentation is most consistent with obsessive compulsive
disorder with poor insight. He also presents with numerous
symptoms of a major depressive episode, including decreased
appetite/weight loss, anhedonia, hypersomnia, fatigue and
depressed mood, which had impaired his functioning in that he
was unable to properly care for himself or his children, and
spent most of his day locked in his room. He appears to have
experienced depressive episodes similar to this in the past, and
his presentation is also consistent with major depressive
disorder, severe, recurrent.

1.Legal/Safety: Patient was admitted on a Voluntary, and
signed a CV Surgical. He was maintained on 15 minute checks
throughout his stay.

2.Medical:
Migraines: Patient was maintained on home medication of
topirimate 50mg 1:2 qhs, as well as PRN medications of
acetaminophen 650mg 1:2 and ibuprofen 600mg 1:2. He noted a great
decrease in the frequency and severity of his headaches
throughout his hospitalization.

Patient’s PCP Erik George was contacted at time of admission in
order to discuss circumstances of patient’s hospitalization and
to obtain relevant history. At time of discharge, pt’s PCP was
contacted again to provide discuss hospital course and discharge
disposition.

3.Psychiatric:
Extensive time was spent discussing the patient’s diagnosis and
psychopharmacology issues. Outpatient psychiatric medications
were continued at home doses including fluvoxamine 100mg 1:2 qhs.
As patient felt as though he did not tolerate higher doses of
this medication in the past, clomipramine 50mg 1:2 daily was
added to address both OCD and symptoms of depression, and was
eventually uptitrated to clomipramine 100mg 1:2 qhs. B/R/AE/SE
were discussed, and patient verbalized his understanding. This
medication was well-tolerated, with mild dry throat/mouth
occurring. To augment his antidepressant therapy, aripiprazole
5mg 1:2 daily was added, B/R/AE/SE were discussed, and patient
verbalized his understanding. Throughout his hospitalization, he
experienced difficulty sleeping. Lorazepam 1mg 1:2 qhs was
initially used, as well as hydroxyzine 50mg 1:2 qhs. Patient
continued with difficulty sleeping despite increases in these
dosages, and ultimately zolpidem 10mg 1:2 qhs was initiated.
Lorazepam 1mg 1:2 qhs was discontinued upon initiating zolpidem,
and was utilized on a BID PRN basis for anxiety with good
effect. B/R/AE/SE were discussed, and patient verbalized his
understanding. He experienced improvement in his mood, a
decrease in handwashing behaviors, appeared less perseverative
regarding contamination fears and experienced a reduction of
overall anxiety/worries. While there were increased OCD
behaviors such as hand-washing following/anticipating stressful
family meetings with his wife, these would resolve and did not
persist, and responded well to lorazepam 1mg PRN. Many of his
depressive symptoms appeared to improve as his sleep pattern
improved as well, and he was often visible attempting to
communicate Diagnosis peers, and was active in the milieu. He noted he
often spent much of the day sleeping at home prior to admission,
and he was able to establish an appropriate sleep-wake cycle
throughout his admission.

Patient’s outpatient therapist Donald Johnson (PT) was
contacted at time of admission in order to discuss circumstances
of patient’s hospitalization and to obtain relevant history. At
time of discharge, pt’s outpatient therapist was contacted again
to discuss hospital course and discharge disposition.

4.Substance Abuse:
Patient was counseled to stop smoking and abusing nicotine
products. He was maintained on nicoderm patches throughout his
stay.

5.Social/Milieu:
Pt was encouraged to participate in unit’s groups/milieu/therapy
opportunities. As the language barrier presented difficulty in
him being able to engage in group activities, he was allowed use
of his phone to help manage his anxiety/provide distraction, and
also to use as a communication device. Therapy addressed
family/social issues. Patient experienced significant social
stressors while hospitalized, including his wife placing a
restraining order on him and him being unable to return home/see
his children and ultimately deciding to return to Stricklandland, Bolivia.
Patient and wife were involved in several family meetings
focused on psychoeducation and discharge planning. As patient
was 1975 speaking, interpreter services and language line
services were utilized throughout the duration of his stay.

6.Risk Assessment:
Patient had initially denied SI/HI upon admission. While he
developed thoughts of not wanting to be alive after learning
about the restraining order and when he feared he would never
see his son again, these thoughts were fleeting, and never did
he develop a plan nor intent. These thoughts resolved by the
following day in both instances, and he consistently
demonstrated future and goal-oriented thinking, as evidenced by
his verbalizing his plans to return to Stricklandland, Bolivia, find employment,
and continue treatment, with the ultimate goal of being able to
share custody of his son. Returning to Stricklandland, Bolivia allows him to have
greater social support, as in the 25 he has been
isolated. He consistently cited his son as a reason to want to
be alive. Protective factors include having an established
relationship with the outpatient treater he is returning to in
Stricklandland, Bolivia, as well as returning to his family/support network, being
motivated for ongoing treatment, and demonstrating future and
goal-oriented thinking. His risk factors of experiencing an
acute mood episode as well as his obsessive-compulsive disorder
have been treated pharmacologically. He has been medication
adherent, and has shown great improvement in his symptoms. At
this point in time, he does not present an imminent risk of harm
to self/others, and outpatient care is the least restrictive
level of care at this time.

7.Disposition: Return to Stricklandland, Bolivia and resume treatment with Dr.
Andrew Reynolds, T: 81-96(384) 1011, F:
81-96(385) 2890.

Discharge Instructions:
Discharge instructions with or without URETERAL STENT PLACEMENT
:

You have an indwelling ureteral stent that MUST be removed
and/or exchanged in the next few weeks time. Please follow-up as
advised.

You may experience some “normal” discomfort or pain associated
with spasm of your ureter. This is especially true when there
is an INDWELLING URETERAL STENT.

Discharge Instructions:
-Resume all of your pre-admission/ home medications, unless
otherwise noted.
Please avoid Aspirin unless otherwise advised.

-No vigorous physical activity for 2 weeks.

-Expect to see occasional blood in your urine and to experience
urgency and frequency over the next month.

-You may have already passed your kidney stones OR they may
still be in the process of passing.

-You may experience some pain associated with spasm of your
ureter. This is normal. Take IBUPROFEN as directed and take the
narcotic pain medication as prescribed if additional pain relief
is needed.

-Tylenol should be your first line pain medication, a narcotic
pain medication has been prescribed for breakthrough pain >4.
Replace Tylenol with narcotic pain medication.

-Max daily Tylenol (acetaminophen) dose is 4 grams from ALL
sources, note that narcotic pain medication also contains
Tylenol

-Make sure you drink plenty of fluids to help keep yourself
hydrated and facilitate passage of stone fragments.

-You may shower and bathe normally.

-Do not drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotics or operate
dangerous machinery

-Colace has been prescribed to avoid post surgical constipation
and constipation related to narcotic pain medication.
Discontinue if loose stool or diarrhea develops. Colace is a
stool softener, NOT a laxative

Followup Instructions:
Monitor weight daily and record changes for discussion at the next visit.

Brief Hospital Course:
Richard Benson is a 1974 year old female with history of SLE,
Raynaud's, and scleritis who was admitted on 2025-01-04 s/p renal
biopsy, now discharged POD#1. The biopsy was performed with goal
of understanding whether patient had evidence of lupus nephritis
process. She was admitted for concern for high risk of
post-surgical bleeding given previous history of post-surgical
hematoma.

ACTIVE ISSUES:
#s/p renal biopsy: Given the concern for bleeding after this
patient, she was monitored for symptoms of internal bleeding and
did not have any acute symptoms such as hypotension or
tachycardia. In addition, hgb and hct studies were performed and
were stable over the course of her stay.

# Oral Health: After the renal biopsy, Mrs. Benson reported a
sore throat. In addition, she noted that she could feel an oral
lesion similar to others she has had in the setting of SLE
flares on the posterior aspect of her palate. No other erythema
was noted on exam but there was a white exudate noted on her
tongue that was suggestive of Stroke (Cerebrovascular Accident) (thrush). She was given
her home Nystatin Oral Suspension for thrush and started on
Chloraseptic Throat Spray as needed.

#Fluid status: Patient initially reported decreased UOP but no
anuria. She had 2 UOPs evening after biopsy, 2 more UOP
overnight. Endorsed mild dysuria with some pain in left flank on
urination. She was replenished with normal saline during her
stay and PO intake was encouraged.

CHRONIC ISSUES:
#SLE: All of Mrs. Benson home medications were continued
during her stay. She reported that for the past 6 months, she
had been experiencing a worsening of her SLE symptoms.

#Pain management: Mrs. Benson endorsed 10/10 (worst imaginable pain) pain in the left
flank with increase to 2/10 (mild) with standing or exertion. She was
continued on her home tramadol while inpatient. In addition,
oxycodone 10 mg was added PRn for breakthrough pain.

#Hypertension: Patient has history of well controlled
hypertension on nifedipine and amlopdipine. Her home medication
nifedipine was held given her well controlled BP on home
amlodipine 5. She was monitored for for hypotension during her
stay given risk of bleed.

# Constipation: Patient reported constipation since the biopsy.
Her home docusate was continued during her stay.

Brief Hospital Course:
2008 yo male with ulcerative colitis s/p ileoanal pouch and
diverting ileostomy in 1980, presents with GI bleed and
hypotension after ileostomy closure.On 2025-03-31, patient underwent
takedown of ileostomy and is admitted to FICU from the PACU with
GIB and hypotension.

The patient's ileostomy takedown procedure went well;refer to
operative note for further details of surgery. While in the
PACU though, pt had a BM with 100 cc of frank blood, then
subsequently had another BM with 300 cc of frank blood. The pt
became hypotensive to 60-70s, hr 72 bpm (normal) and felt dizzy and
nauseous. He was given 4L of fluid, given a 100mcg of
phenylephrine and his BP improved. A foley was placed in the
patients rectum, and irrigated with clot. The patient is
currently receiving 2 units pRBCs.

On arrival to the FICU, patient's vs. were BP 133/51 HR 89 RR 17
100% on RA. He reports feeling tired, with abdominal pain over
ostomy removal site that he states is more superficial than deep
and rates a 7/10 (severe) with improvement with pain medication. He
states mild lightheadedness that was worse in the afternoon, and
nausea upon receipt of pain medications. Denies chest pain,
shortness of breath, cough, constitutional symptoms, dysuria,
recent illness.

# GI Bleed: Occurred s/p ileostomy takedown and completion of
the anastomosis, this is likely bleeding from the staple line,
which is usually self limited. Patient's HCT was initially 31.9
this trending downward to a nadir of 22. A rectal tube was
placed and bleeding continued. The patient additional was noted
to have one episode of hematemesis. A NGT was placed and lavage
returned dark blood. Hematemesis was attributed to backflow from
his anastomotic site bleed. He was given transfusions with a
goal HCT of 28. He required transfusion of a total of 13 units
of PRBCs and 2 units of FFP. Bleeding subsided and pressures
stabilized and patient HCT remained stable.

-# Bradycardia: Patient was initially noted to have a HR into
72 bpm (normal) while hypotensive. Inappropriate response to blood
pressure. Most likely Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) to vagal event from bleeding, rectal
tube, pain, and may be exacerbated by reflex bradycardia from
phenylephrine. HR subsequently stabilized.
# Pain control: Pain was controlled with a morphine PCA.
STABLE ISSUES
# Ulcerative colitis: S/p proctocolectomy. No evidence of PSC
clinically.
# Hypertension: The patient's home amlodipine was held in the
setting of GIB.
# Hypotension: Most likely Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) to bleeding and vagal response
given HR, presence of tube in rectum, as well as pain which per
nurse, often correlates with descent in HR. He was given fluid
boluses with LR and transfused as above. He initially required
phenylephrine however he was quickly weaned from pressor
support. The patient was without signs or symptoms of
infection. Patient blood pressure stabilized.

POD 3,patient was transferred to the floor. Patient remained NPO
with intravenous fluids and NGT in place. Patient NGT output was
monitored closely and was having large bilious output. A PICC
line was placed for intravenous fluids. POD 4,patient continued
to be diuresed with acetazolamide. The foley catheter was
discontinued and patient voided without difficulty.

POD 5 the nasogastric tube was discontinued and the diet was
advanced from clears to regular which was tolerated well.
Patient was noted to have copious amounts of stool output
greater than 2 liters per day and was started on psyllium
wafers. Patient intake and output were monitored closely.

POD 6 patient continued to have high stool output and was
started on loperamide. However continued to report having
multiple explosive non bloody stool output. Patient's loperamide
and psyllium wafers were titrated up as needed. Patient was
started on a regular diet and encouraged to increase fiber
intake to bulk up the stool. POD 7 patient reported no
significant change in bowel frequency and urgency. In addition
to his current bowel regimen he was started on Librium.(Librax
upon discharge). Patient mobility was limited due to increase
frequency and urgency of bowel movements. Thus patient was
started on Heparin subcutaneously for DVT prophylaxis. Patient
was encouraged to ambulate several times a day. Patient
hematocrit was monitored closely and was stable.

By POD 8 patient had satisfactory stool output on current bowel
regimen and was deemed ready for discharge to home. Patient was
instructed to monitor his stool output closely and to titrate
his bowel regimen (Loperamide, psyllium wafers and Librax) as
instructed by Dr. Jessica Simpson. Patient was also instructed to
monitor for dehydration and to keep with oral fluids. Patient
PICC line was discontinued prior to discharge. He will have his
staples removed at his PCP Tanya Gonzalez. Patient was discharged home
in good condition and will follow-up with Dr. Jessica Simpson in
clinic in 29 months.

(6) hours as needed for pain.

2. amlodipine 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).

needed for pain. Disp:*40 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

Home
