Ileostomy following J-pouch.

Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

Discharge Instructions:
Mr. Morgan Jenkins have recovered well from your surgery and may
return home. You are tolerating a regular diet, passing gas and
your stool output has slowed down. Please continue to monitor
your stool and urine output to avoid becoming dehydrated. If you
notice your stool output increasing, take in more electrolyte
drink such as gatorade.Please monitor yourself for signs and
symptoms of dehydration including: dizziness(especially upon
standing),weakness, dry mouth, headache, or fatigue. If you
notice these symptoms please call the office or return to the
emergency room for evaluation if these symptoms are severe.
Please titrate your bowel medications loperamide,psyllium
wafers and librax as instructed by Dr. Jessica Simpson. You may also
bulk up your stool to achieve desired stool output with fiber
such as bran muffins.If you have any questions or concerns call
the office for further advice.

You have an incision to your lower right abdomen that is closed
with staples. This incision can be left open to air or covered
with a dry sterile gauze dressing if the staples become
irritated from clothing. Please have your staples removed in 7-
10 days. This can be done at your primary care provider office
visit. Please monitor the incision for signs and symptoms of
infection including: increasing redness at the incision, opening
of the incision, increased pain at the incision line, draining
of white/green/yellow foul smelling drainage, or if you develop
a fever. Please call the office if you develop these symptoms or
go to the emergency room if the symptoms are severe. You may
shower, let the warm water run over the incision line and pat
the area dry with a towel, do not rub.

No heavy lifting for at least 6 weeks after surgery unless
instructed otherwise by your surgeon. You may gradually increase
your activity as tolerated but clear heavy excercise with your
surgeon.Please continue to walk several times a day to prevent
developing a blood clot in your legs.

You will be prescribed a small amount of the pain
medication;please take this medication exactly as prescribed.
You may take Tylenol as recommended for pain. Please do not take
more than 4000 mg of Tylenol daily. Do not drink alcohol while
taking narcotic pain medication or Tylenol. Please do not drive
a car while taking narcotic pain medication.

Thank you for allowing us to participate in your care! Our hope
is that you will have a quick return to your life and usual
activities. Good luck!

Followup Instructions:
Adhere to fluid restrictions to avoid fluid overload.

additional gibberish syllables on at the end of her name.

seemed to be falling to the right, and was slightly weaker on
her right side.

The patient's family report that she was seen by a Neurologist
earlier this year because of concerns for confusion. They

was also noted at some point that she had left eye ptosis. She
was seen by Neurology, at which time she underwent an MRI, which
showed no signs of acute infarct, but did show chronic

CT head on 2025-07-03: 12 by 18mm hemorrhage of the left thalamic
region, with surrounding edema and moderate mass effect on the
body of the left lateral ventricle. The most likely etiology of
the hemorrhage is due to hypertension, as opposed to an
underlying mass lesion or vascular malformation, for example.

Follow-up CT on 2025-05-01: Slight decrease in density but unchanged
size of the left thalamic intraparenchymal hemorrhage.

Brief Hospital Course:
Patient is a 2025 year old RHW from Los Angeles, CA (mostly 1973
only) with DM, HTN and HLD who lives at home requiring
assistance with most ADL's including feeding. She was found to
be suddenly speaking gibberish and patient was brought to the
hospital for acute stroke per EMS. She was also noted to be
listing to the R per EMS. CT head showed L thalamic hemorrhage
most consistent with hypertensive hemorrhage and her admission
BP was 172/88.

Patient was admitted to the neurology service. She underwent
repeat head CT the next day which showed stable L thalamic
hemorrhage. Exam also remained stable with occasional clear
speech but followed by gibberish. She does follow simple
commands in 1973. She continued to have mild R facial droop
with R sided weakness including limping in gait although
ambulatory with assistance.

Although no formal diagnosis, patient appeared to have cognitive
decline and required assistance with most ADL's including being
reminded to eat. Patient was initially confused upon admission,
likely delirium/"sundowning." She was started on Seroquel 50mg
at evening - this can be titrated as needed.

Given the new weakness and speech trouble since the L thalamic
hemorrhage most likely due to hypertension, patient is
discharged to acute rehab for inpatient physical, occupational
and speech therapy.

Patient is to restart ASA 81 give days after discharge. She has
follow-up appt with Dr. Ariel Martinez, neurologist who oversaw her
care during this admission.

has also been held to prevent further bleeding and should be

2019 y/o F with history of Alzheimer's disease presents s/p MVC
with parafalcine SDH and traumatic SAH. She was transferred to
Green Valley Hospital for further neurosurgical management. She was confused at
baseline and moving all extremities. She was admitted to
neurosurgery for monitoring overnight. She was placed on keppra
500mg BID. The family requested longterm placement so Neurology and OT
was consulted and Case Management was made aware. Speech and
swallow was also consulted. Her foley was discontinued and she
was started on Bactrim for a positive UA.

Early 2025-03-03 she was unable to void and a foley was replaced. Kevin Porter
RN did not feel the patient could safely take her PO antibiotic
so it was changed to IV ceftraxione in the meantime. Speech and
Swallow cleared the patient for grounds, thin liquids, and
crushed meds.

On 2025-05-07 she remained stable on the floor while awaiting rehab
screening.

On 2025-08-15, The patient had low urine output and was given Lasix.
The serum potassium was low and was repleated.

On 2025-01-22, The patient was not eating or drinking and had low
urine out put. This was discussed with the family and decision
was made to have a feeding tube placed for proper nutrition.
General surgery was called and a plan was made for the patient
to have a feeding tube placed in the operating room the
following day. The patients serum potassium, magnesium,
calcium were low and were repleated. A nutrition consult and
calorie count were ordred. A protable chest xray was performed
which was consistent with atelectesis vs pnemonia. A AP/LAT
chest xray was performed which was consistent with rapidly
improving bibasilar opacities favor either aspiration or
atelectasis.

On 2025-06-05, The Ceftriaxone course of antibiotic for a klebsiella
UTI was completed. Gtube placed by general suregry.
O 2025-04-10 SHE WAS STARTED ON TUBE FEEDING AND SHE TOLERATED THE

Discharge Instructions:
•Take your pain medicine as prescribed.
•Exercise should be limited to walking; no lifting, straining,
or excessive bending.
•Increase your intake of fluids and fiber, as narcotic pain
medicine can cause constipation. We generally recommend taking
an over the counter stool softener, such as Docusate (Colace)
while taking narcotic pain medication.
•Unless directed by your doctor, do not take any
anti-inflammatory medicines such as Motrin, Aspirin, Advil, or
Ibuprofen etc.
•If you were on a medication such Aspirin prior to your injury,
you may safely resume taking after you are seen in followup with
neurosurgery

•You have been discharged on Keppra (Levetiracetam), you will
not require blood work monitoring.

CALL YOUR SURGEON IMMEDIATELY IF YOU EXPERIENCE ANY OF THE
FOLLOWING

•New onset of tremors or seizures.
•Any confusion, lethargy or change in mental status.
•Any numbness, tingling, weakness in your extremities.
•Pain or headache that is continually increasing, or not
relieved by pain medication.
•New onset of the loss of function, or decrease of function on
one whole side of your body.

Followup Instructions:
Return in 2 weeks with lab reports

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms Nunez has remained stable during her hospitalization. Her
bleed does not seem to relate to a mass or AVM (MRI/ MRA
negative plus CT torso negative for tumor). She was on ASA plus
plavix and coumadin (INR was 3.5 at Pulmonology Clinic prior to
transfer). Her bleed may have occurred because her INR was
supertherapeutic. There was no previous history of trauma. The
location of the bleed argued against a HTN etiology. She may
have amyloid angiopathy (though there is no lobar distribution
in her bleed).
Her deficits were Wernicke's aphasia and pseudobulbar symptoms.

In addition, though she remained asymptomatic and afebrile with
normal WBC and Na levels, a PNA was reported in the CT study.
She was started on a cephalosporin plus clindamicin. She needs
to complete a total of 10 days of therapy (day 3 currently).
The risks and benefits of restarting coumadin after a period of
two weeks to protect her against ischemic stroke was discussed
with her son William Ferguson (who is her health care proxy). The risk of
coumadin causing a recurrent intracranial hemorrhage was
discussed. William Ferguson said that he did not want his mother restarted on
Coumadin held. She was
restarted on aspirin 81mg daily instead for secondary stroke
prevention. The plavix was not restarted (Her PMD Dr. Sara Dixon reported that prior to this hospitalization she had asked that the

Brief Hospital Course:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN
1997 y/o F with hx of recent NSTEMI s/p cath with RCA stent and hx
of afib with RVR presents after mechanical fall at home with
UTI, dehydration and afib with RVR. Rate responsive to
diltiazem. Blood pressures stable throughout. Now stable in rate
controlled afib on metoprolol and diltiazem.
.
# Rhythm: patient was asymptomatic in aflutter or afib with RVR
in the ED. Lopressor did not work and BP dropped to 100s from
120s. Upon arrival to the floor was given 15 mg IV dilt and
slowed from rates in 140s to 48 bpm (bradycardia).  IV dilt gtt was stopped
and she was transitioned to digoxin and PO verapamil.  On this
regimen she kept alternating between aflutter with rates in the
130s, afib with rates in the 90–100 bpm (normal sinus rhythm) and NSR with rates in the
48 bpm (bradycardia).  Eventually she was mostly in NSR and afib and not in
her fast rate aflutter.  We transitioned her from dig and
verapamil because we suspect that she may have periods of time
with dehydration and ARF in the future and has the potential to
have bad effects from dig toxicity.  We added metoprolol for the
cardiovascular protective effects with her low EF.  And we added
diltiazem for better rate control.  In all, she is on metoprolol
50 mg bid and diltizem 30 mg qid.  She did have HRs in the 72 bpm (normal)
the day of discharge, which is ok with this regimen.  Throughout
all this, she never had palpitations of symptoms.
.
# NSVT - one episode day 2 of admission, no more episodes
.
# Coronaries: has known 3 vessel CAD with recent stent to RCA in
2025-03-29, no signs of ischemia on EKG. Ruled out for MI with
enzymes.  At one point, she had about 5 minutes of jaw pain (her
anginal equivalent), when her rates were in the 140s.  When her
rates decreased the pain went away.  We are continuing her
medical management with aspirin 81 mg daily, plavix 75 mg daily,
metorpolol as above and lipitor 80 mg daily.  She does not want
any more procedures, so will continue medical management.  Has
room for adding a long acting nitrate if symptomatic.
.
# Pump: has mildly depressed EF on echo in 2025-04-05. Is fluid up on
exam and held diuretics in the setting of dehydration and
prerenal ARF upon presentation.  Her oxygen requirement
increased the first few days.  Restarted her home chlorothiazide
and gave her two days of extra lasix and now she is satting well
on 2L NC.  Her pedal edema is much improved and we expect her to
be on room air in a few days.  Would continue her chlorothiazide
for now.  No lasix unless needed PRN.  Kidney funciton has
remained stable after first two days of admission.
.
# TIA - on night of 2025-01-29 into morning of 2025-04-06, patient had an
episode of aphasia and confusion without other deficits which
was deemed to be a TIA.  On CTA and perfusion study, she had an
area of ischemia in her L parietal-occipital region.  Her
symptoms resolved.  Neuro followed along and recommended
anticoagulation.  We had been avoiding anticoagulation in the
setting of afib per the patient's request, hx of remote GI bleed
and hx of falls in the fast few weeks.  After her TIA, we
readdressed the anticoagulation issue with the patient and more
strongly recommended coumadin and she was open to the
suggestion.  We started coumadin with a lovenox bridge.  She
will continue her bridge at rehab and have her coumadin titrated
to a goal fo 2.0 to 3.0.
.
# Hypoxia: baseline good sats on room air, required O2 while
here, likely from fluid overload as mentioned above.  No cough
or signs of PNA.
.
# Mechanical Fall: no signs of LOC or seizure like activity, no
symptoms of chest pain or palpitations. Likely was from a
combination of factors like deconditioning, UTI, afib, residual
stroke deficit on L side. No pain now, head CT negative, pelvis
stable on exam.  Pulmonology evaluated the patient and she did very
poorly.  Recommended rehab for patient but initially refused.
After having a few discussions, she was ammenable to
rehabilitation and sees how she is no longer independent like
she used to be.
.
# UTI: asymptomatic but probably contributed to fall.  She was
treated with 7 day course of bactrim.  Cultures showed alpha
strep colonies, no sensitivies were taken.  She initially had a
foley placed, but then removed the second day of admission.
.
# ARF: has Cr from 1.5 up from a baseline of 0.9, likely
prerenal based on fluid status. Normalized with gentle IVFs.
Discharge creatinine 0.8.
.
# DM: held home meds, ISS for now.
.
# HTN: mildly hypo to normotensive while titrating up digoxin
and verapamil.  Then was normotensive to hypertensive with SBPs
in 130s to 150s.  See rate control for the meds.  They should be
enough for good blood pressure control.
.
# FEN: general cardiac diabetic diet
.
# ACCESS: PIV's
.
# CODE: DNR/DNI - confirmed with patient this admission
.
# DISPO: to LTAC

Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital after falling.  You were found
to have a urinary tract infection and have an irregular heart
rate that was very fast.  We treated your urinary tract
infection with an antibiotic.  For your heart rate, we first
tried IV diltiazem and then switched you to digoxin and
verapamil for a short while.  Because you have underlying heart
failure, we thought the best medicines would actually be
metoprolol and diltiazem, so you will be going home on these two
medicines.  You likely will continue to sometimes have fast
heart rates at times, but hopefully these medicines will prevent
it from being too fast.
.
You also had a small, reversible "stroke" called a TIA.  You are
back to your baseline.  It was probably from either a small clot
in your heart or a small clot from you neck artery (the
carotid).  We started blood thinners for you to prevent this
from happening again.
.
In terms of your other medicines, you should continue them as
you had been taking them previous to being admitted.
.
You also lost a lot of strength with the infection and the prior
heart attack.  You were not quite safe enough to go home by
yourself, so we recommend some time in rehabilitation.  You need
to work very hard with your physical therapists to improve your
strength.
.
Please return to your hospital if you have worsening chest pain,
palpitations, shortness of breath, abdominal pain, nausea,
vomitting, falls, fevers, chills or any other concerns.
.
Weigh yourself every morning, call MD if weight > 3 lbs.
Adhere to 2 gm sodium diet.

Followup Instructions:
Call the cardiologist immediately if chest pain or shortness of breath occurs.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. Williams is a 2005 old woman with history of T2DM not on
insulin, HTN and left frontal meningioma s/p resection in 1973
complicated by osteomyelitis and craniectomy as well as
perioperative seizures, now seizure free who presented to BI on
2025-08-05 with lethargy and mild confusion found to have a right
parieto-occipital intraparenchymal hemorrhage.

#RIGHT PARIETO-OCCIPITAL IPH:
Patient's initial exam was notable for disorientation,
inattention, perseveration, paraphasic errors, left homonymous
hemianopia, left pronator drift and mild left sided weakness
with a left upgoing toe. CT scan showed a large 4 cm right
posterior parietal acute intraparenchymal hemorrhage with
associated surrounding edema and compression of the posterior
horn of the right lateral ventricle without midline shift.
Follow-up MRI brain did not show an underlying lesion, but was
obscured by blood products. She was admitted to the stroke
service where her SBP was maintained below 150. She also
underwent 3 days of continuous EEG recording, which did not show
any evidence of seizure, only focal slowing.

Her neurologic exam improved during the hospitalization and she
was ultimately A&O x 3, mildly inattentive with a left
homonymous hemianopia.

Etiology of her symptoms was thought most likely secondary to
cerebral amyloid angiopathy given the location of the bleed and
history of cognitive decline. There was some mention of minor
head trauma prior to this event, but this was not thought to be
the etiology given the appearance of the bleed on imaging.

She should avoid aspirin and antiplatelets in the future. Primary care doctor
recommended rehab.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. Williams,

You were hospitalized due to symptoms of confusion and
difficulty seeing resulting from an ACUTE HEMORRHAGIC STROKE, a
condition where a blood vessel providing oxygen and nutrients to
the brain begins to bleed. The brain is the part of your body
that controls and directs all the other parts of your body, so
damage to the brain from being deprived of its blood supply can
result in a variety of symptoms.

Stroke can have many different causes, so we assessed you for
medical conditions that might raise your risk of having stroke.
In order to prevent future strokes, we plan to modify those risk
factors. Your risk factors are:
-high blood pressure
-diabetes
-cerebral amyloid angiopathy

We are changing your medications as follows:
-STOP Aspirin

Please take your other medications as prescribed.

Please follow up with Neurology and your primary care physician
as listed below.

If you experience any of the symptoms below, please seek
emergency medical attention by calling Emergency Medical
Services (dialing 911). In particular, since stroke can recur,
please pay attention to the sudden onset and persistence of
these symptoms:
- Sudden partial or complete loss of vision
- Sudden loss of the ability to speak words from your mouth
- Sudden loss of the ability to understand others speaking to
you
- Sudden weakness of one side of the body
- Sudden drooping of one side of the face
- Sudden loss of sensation of one side of the body

Sincerely,
Your Cleveland Health Institute Neurology Team

Return to the emergency room immediately if fever exceeds 101°F.

Brief Hospital Course:
1973 yo male with atrial fibrillation with previous afib and
aflutter ablations and multiple DCCV which has been unsuccessful
admitted today for a pulmonary vein isolation procedure
complicated by small anterior pericardial effusion.

# Pericardial effusion: The patient developed a small
pericardial effusion about 1 cm in size during a pulmonary vein
isolcation procedure. He had a TTE later the day of the
procedure which showed that the effusion was stable and without
echographic signs of tamponade. Another TTE the day after the
procedure showed again that it was stable without signs of
tamponade. The patient had slight peluritic chest pain which
gradually resolved over the course of his hospitalization.

# Atrial fibrillation: The patient has a history of afib and
aflutter status post many medication trials and interventions
without lasting response. Most recently the patient was on
dofetilide but converted back to afib. He underwent a PVI which
was not fully completed given the development of a small
pericardial effusion during the procedure. He remained in the
hospital a few days after his procedure as his medications were
changed to try to attain rate control his atrial fibrillation.
He had a few episodes of a.fib with RVR while the medication
changes were made. His metoprolol was increased and he was
discharged on 100 mg metoprolol XL daily. He was started on
diltiazem and was discharged on 180 mg nightly. He was also
started on digoxin and was discharged on 0.25 mg daily. His
dofetilide was stopped. His warfarin was held initally for the
procedure and was restarted for anticoagulation for his a.fib.
He was discharged with Holter monitor of Hearts monitor and will follow
up with Dr. Mark Mayo as an outpatient.

# Hypertension: The patient remained normotensive and was

You are being discharged from the hospital after admission for
an cardiac ablation of your pulmonary veins in an attempt to
eliminate your atrial fibrillation. Unfortunatly, it does
appear to have been successfull in controlling your symptoms.
We will attempt to control your fibrillation with rate control,
and have increased your metoprolol and have started 2 new
medications called Digoxin and Diltiazem. You should stop
taking your dofetilide. There was some concern of increased
fluid around your heart following the procedure, which is
stable. If you experience any shortness of breath, chest pain,
palpitaitons, or lightheadedness, you should call your
cardiologist or go to the emergency room.

You should resume your comadin and regular monitoring as
previous.

The following changes were made to your medications:
Stop taking Dofetilide
Start taking Digoxin at 0.25mg by mouth every morning
Start taking Metoprolol XL 100mg by mouth every morning
Start Diltiazem 360mg by mouth, 212 tablet every evening
Stop Lisinopril until instructed by your doctor to restart this
medication. It was stopped due to low blood pressure.

You have received Holter monitor of Hearts monitor and need to follow
instructions for transmitting this information to Dr.
Mark Mayo.

You can take Ibuprofen for your chest pain. You should watch
for any stomach upset. You should take Omeprazole 20mg by mouth
a day to prevent stomach irritation and ulcers. If you notice
any bleeding in your bowel movements, you should stop taking
ibuprofen and come to the emergency room immediately.

Chief Complaint:
"Today was the first time I had psychosis"

Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
none

History of Present Illness:
"Briefly, Michael Davis is a 2020 year old PhD post-doc at Michael Harding with
no prior medical history and a psychiatric history notable for
anxiety (including OCD and skin picking), depression (unclear
unipolar vs. bipolar), and prior delusional thought content who
is in treatment for ADHD and depression and has no history of
psychiatric hospitalizations or suicide attempts who presents
today with symptoms concerning for psychosis.

On interview, Michael Davis states that earlier today she noticed that
she felt like her thoughts starting to become "weird". She
closed her eyes and saw people with pink hair on their faces
which was distressing to her. She felt like she could take other
people's perspectives which was unusual, and was convinced that
the Manager at her coffee shop did not like her for an unknown
reason to her. She found these symptoms to be very distressing
and she spoke with her friend, who is an Internal Medicine physician, who
recommended she go to the Cleveland Health Institute for an evaluation. In Romerohaven, Michael Davis
started obsessionally reading the news and was worried about the
world ending with the news at the time. She thought about bomb
shelters and she was very convinced that the world was ending
while others around her weren't as fazed. She states that this
happened during a few weeks during her PhD and she returned home
to Tammystad and her symptoms resolved. She states that she thinks
she has been under increased stress at work and has had more
difficulty sleeping, which she believes along with her
stimulants may be contributing. She denies other experiences
similar to these. She denies any excessive use of her Adderall
or bupropion or any ilicit drug use.

She states that her mood is "tired" and "depressed". She
describes feeling hopeless and experiencing hypersomnia, and
does have some passive suicidal thoughts without any intent or
plan. She also describes having "masochistic thoughts", though
has difficulty elaborating on this. She describes recently
experiencing some elevation of her mood where she felt very
giddy and grandiose about getting an idea published in JAMA,
though this lasted for a day. She describes fluctuation in her
mood, though has difficulty prescribing a clear narrative of her
symptoms. She spends most of the interview focusing on what
these symptoms mean for her and what treatment could mean on her
record. She also focuses on having trouble at work, not
performing well, and falling behind.

She denies any HI, auditory hallucinations, current IOR, thought
broadcasting, or thought insertion. "

On interview, the patient continues to endorse all of the above.
Additionally, when asked what brought her to the emergency room,
the patient gave a very tangential account beginning with not
being able to sleep on Friday night for multiple reasons to how
a therapist's inability to characterize her romantic
relationship with a previous boyfriend as abusive, leading to
further trauma endured by the patient at the hands of her now
ex-boyfriend. Continued to endorse multiple stressors Recent surgery
falling through, her employment being "up in the air," and a
"transcendental experience where she knew "everyone was judging
her as selfish and lazy." Continues to endorse distressing
images perceived when eyes are closed, of "pink hairy faces."

Reports that she first started buproprion toward the end of her
PhD in an effort to obtain better focus. She felt it worked
well, but had a psychiatrist who, per her report decided to stop
the medication and switch to Lamictal, which she disliked.
"Lamictal slowed my brain down." When she was switched back to
buproprion, she felt it did not work as well as it did in the
past, leading her to a trial of Adderall. Over time, she has
self modulated her dose of Adderall depending on how she felt
while taking it. "Adderall was jarring. Sometimes it was too
much, and when it builds up I feel manic and anxious. And
sometimes it wouldn't be as good, so I would take it
intermittently." In addition to the at times 60mg daily of
Adderall ER, she would also consume anywhere from 47 cups of
coffee per day.

Reports poor sleep, anhedonia, decreased interests in hobbies,
decreased ability to concentrate, little appetite, though denies
weight loss. Endorses ruminating thoughts, and heart
palpitations mostly associated with adderall consumption.
Endorses periods of elevated mood lasting for a day or two,
which she described as "hypomanic." Endorses OCD sx as above.
When asked what she thinks her symptoms are due to, she states,
"I think it's mostly stress induced, mixed with meds that are
stimulating, and no sleep, but I also think my mental health has
been getting worse over time."

While she endorses passive suicidal thoughts such as, "It
wouldn't be that bad if all of this was because of a brain
tumor," she denies active ideation, intent or plan. Denies
HI/AH, thought insertion or projection. Endorses paranoia as
above. Denies sx of PTSD.

Reports she is able to come to unit staff should she have an
inclination to harm herself or others.

Upon readying ourselves to leave the treatment room, the patient
turned back to try to stop the faucet from dripping, stating,
"It was really bothering me."

Discharge Course: Good behavioral control. No chemical or physical
restraints.

Brief Hospital Course:
1. LEGAL & SAFETY:
On admission, the patient signed a conditional voluntary
agreement (Section 10 & 11) and remained on that level
throughout their admission. She was also placed on 15 minute
checks status on admission and remained on that level of
observation throughout while being unit restricted.

2. PSYCHIATRIC:
#) Anxiety with Obsessional Traits
As per HPI, patient reported worsening anxiety in the setting of
relationship and work stressors, increased stimulant use,
caffeine use, poor sleep. She also endorsed intrusive thoughts,
paranoid thoughts, and delusions that she could read other
people's thoughts. Given that patient experienced similar
symptoms several years ago (which abated after returning home
briefly and adhering to a more regular sleep schedule),
patient's current presentation appeared most consistent with an
acute anxiety exacerbation and intensification of obsessional
behaviors in the setting of precipitating factors listed above.
Patient was in agreement with recommendation to discontinue home
stimulant, and she expressed desire to taper Wellbutrin.
Additionally, patient provided informed consent to trial of
risperidone for intrusive thoughts and heightened anxiety, which
patient tolerated without side effects. Dosing on discharge was
0.5mg PO QHS and 0.5mg PO BID PRN anxiety with good effect.
Ramelteon was also started at 8mg PO QHS PRN insomnia. Patient
reported reduction of anxiety symptoms, improved sleep, and
improved mood. She continued to have eye tic which was unchanged
at time of discharge, but was bothering patient less.

Medications stopped on this admission
- Wellbutrin
- Adderral

Medications started on this admission
- Risperdal 0.5mg PO BID PRN anxiety and 0.5mg PO QHS
- Peter York 8mg PO QHS PRN insomnia

If patient develops worsening anxiety or depressed symptoms,
discussed possibility of starting Effexor. Patient had poor side
effects with lexepro (lethargy, amotivation) and was not
interested in starting another SSRI.

3. SUBSTANCE USE DISORDERS:
#) Patient denies substance abuse. Team discussed importance of
avoiding marijuana, stimulants, and caffeine, given symptoms.
Patient in agreement with plan.

4. MEDICAL
#) No medical issues identified

5. PSYCHOSOCIAL
#) GROUPS/MILIEU:
The patient was encouraged to participate in the various groups
and milieu therapy opportunities offered by the unit. The
patient often attended these groups that focused on teaching
patients various coping skills. Patient was friendly, engaged,
and visible in the milieu.

#) COLLATERAL CONTACTS & FAMILY INVOLVEMENT:
Craig Contreras (friend and Internal Medicine physician- Company A) She has
known her for a long time. She has always been a little odd but
overall able to function and relatively successful in her work.
Yesterday, she seemed ok during the day but later started
texting her c/o hallucinations and concerns she might be
psychotic which is unusual for her. Yesterday was a difficult
day at work because her boss was getting fired.

Molly Rice MD Gastroenterology- Main campus Updated on
patient's status and discussed treatment goals.

INFORMED CONSENT: The team discussed the indications for,
intended benefits of, and possible side effects and risks of
starting Risperdal medication, and risks and benefits of
possible alternatives, including not taking the medication, with
this patient. We discussed the patient's right to decide
whether to take this medication as well as the importance of the
patient's actively participating in the treatment and discussing
any questions about medications with the treatment team, and I
answered the patient's questions. The patient appeared able to
understand and consented to begin the medication.

RISK ASSESSMENT
On presentation, the patient was evaluated and felt to be at an
increased risk of harm to herself and/or others based upon
worsening anxiety with psychotic symptoms. Their static factors
noted at that time include chronic mental illness, feelings of
hopelessness, singe status, and high stress level at work. The
modifiable risk factors were also addressed at that time.
Patient worked on coping skills in group therapy and through
yoga on the unit. She was set up with outpatient therapist and
PCP. Risperdal helped reduce patient's racing thoughts and
delusional thought content. Discontinuing wellbutrin and
stimulant helped with patient's anxiety. Finally, the patient is
being discharged with many protective risk factors, including
good social supports, employment status, gender, coping skills,
outpatient providers, and Cooperative behavior. Patient
demonstrated preserved capacity to engage in a meaningful
discussion about safety planning about what she would do in the
event of worsening symptoms of anxiety or heightened distress
(e.g. patient would contact her outpatient providers, call +917651839065,
or present to the emergency department). Based on the totality
of our assessment at this time, the patient is not at an acutely
elevated risk of self-harm nor danger to others.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. Cook is a 2007 year old man with end-stage renal disease
secondary to polycystic kidney disease status post kidney
transplant 2025-06-01, frequent
urinary tract infections, benign prostatic hyperplasia status
post transurethral resection of the prostate with intermittent
straight cath at home, recurrent C. difficile infection, who
presented with five days of fever and chills, found to have
sepsis secondary to E. coli bacteremia with probable urinary
source.

ACUTE MEDICAL ISSUES
============================
#Sepsis Secondary to E. coli Bacteremia
Patient presented on 2025-08-11 with fever and chills, febrile to
100.6, with concern for infection in the setting of
immunosupression, and started on empiric ceftriaxone and flagyl.
On 2025-01-22, blood cultures grew gram negative rods resistant to
ceftriaxone, and the patient was transitioned to ceftazidime.
Blood cultures subsequently speciated with pan-sensitive E.
coli, and the patient was transitioned to oral ciprofloxacin on
2025-01-29. The source of infection was initially unclear based on
patient symptoms and was evaluated with chest X ray, cervical
spine X ray, chest CT, CT abdomen and pelvis with contrast,
urine studies, and C. difficile studies. Based on the patient's
history of recurrent urinary tract infections, blood culture
speciation with pan-sensitive E. coli, and bladder wall
thickening on CT, his bacteremia was likely secondary to a
urinary tract infection, although this is not definitive given
the absence of symptoms and negative urinalysis. Low suspicion
for pulmonary source given absence of symptoms and culture
speciation with E. coli, but given CT chest findings and
continuing immunosuppression, the patient was evaluated to
rule-out tuberculosis with three acid-fast bacillus stains.
Given the absence of a definite source of infection, Mr. Cook
would likely benefit from outpatient evaluation for source with
a tagged WBC scan. Following antibiotic therapy for his E. coli
bacteremia, the patient improved clinically and has remained
afebrile and hemodynamically stable. Subsequent blood cultures
have shown no growth to date.

#ESRD Autosomal recessive PKD s/p LURT
The patient was continued on his home immunosuppression regimen
with tacrolimus and prednisone, with daily monitoring of
tacrolimus levels. His renal function remained stable during
this hospitalization.

#Recurrent CDI
The patient was continued on his outpatient suppressive regimen
of oral vancomycin for recurrent C. difficile. His stool was
negative for C. difficile antigen.

#Thrombocytopenia
Patient presented with thrombocytopenia with platelets decreased

Brief Hospital Course:
Diana Villa is a 1973 year-old right handed man w/ PMHx of poorly controlled DM, HTN and heavy alcohol use who presented initially to University College Hospital London and then was transferred to Riverbend Medical after 2 days of dysarthric speech, with BP on arrival 235/85, requiring multiple agents to control, and a head CT showing a left basal ganglia hemorrhage.

# NEURO: Patient's neurological exam remained stable and then improved to only very mild R facial droop and very mild dysarthria. We held his aspirin while he was an inpatient, with plan to restart it 1 week from the onset of symtoms. He will start taking 81mg ASA again on 2025-05-26. He was restarted on Amanda Allen 72 hours after the onset of his symptoms, and his neurological exam remained stable.

# CARDS: Patient's BP was very difficult to control, so he was started on a diltiazem gtt, which was effective. He was also started on lisinopril 20mg QD while here for BP control. The dilt gtt was able to be weaned off on the night of 2025-02-09, but the next morning was still elevating intermittently to the 190's. He was put on hydralize for BP >160. We obtained a TTE, which was unremarkable. He was then increased to lisinopril 40mg QD and started on amlodipine which was uptitrated to 10mg QD. His BP was then finally well controlled in the 140's.

# PULM: Patient's admission CXR showed some mild vascular congestion, but patient was symptomatic throughout this admission. His lasix was initially given at 20mg BID, but was then increased to 60mg QD on 2025-02-09.

# ENDO: His HgA1C was 10.1. His finger sticks were routinely elevated to the 200's. While here, he was put on 60 units of lantus QAM and an insulin sliding scale. On further investigation, it was determined that he actually takes levemir 60 units BID. He was also recently prescribed novolog 10 units Qbreakfast, 20 units Qlunch and 10 units Qdinner, but has not yet picked up this Rx. We transitioned his long-acting insulin to be BID prior to dispo. We also sent him home with instructions to take the novolog as prescribed by his NP, James Roberts.

# CODE: Full Code

NONE

Patient will need his blood pressure monitored, and his medications titrated to acheive systolic blood pressure less than 160, but ideally, given his diabetes, to acheive a BP <130/80.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. Richard Roman was initially admitted with chest pain; a CTA chest
showed no PE, but demonstrated right rib infiltration from her
CA. Her EKG and troponin were likewise not suggestive of
ischemia. Her pain was very pleuritic, and localized over the
rib lesions -- therefore, this was most consistent with cancer
pain. Her symptoms were also dramatically improved after having
a large bowel movement. Her pain was well controlled with her
home dose of oxycodone. She received a single dose of radiation
for her brain metastases while she was an inpatient, and was
placed on a dexamethasone taper as described below. Overall, she
had not been doing well at home -- falling, having difficulty
taking medications. She was evaluated by Pulmonology and OT, and
discharged to a Home.

inpatient. Neurological exam was unchanged. CT head did not show
any change.

Discharge Instructions:
Refer to the postoperative instructions from Dr. Edward Sparks.

Call your doctor for:
* fever > 100.4
* severe abdominal pain
* difficulty urinating
* vaginal bleeding requiring >1 pad/hr
* abnormal vaginal discharge
* redness or drainage from incision
* nausea/vomiting where you are unable to keep down fluids/food
or your medication

General instructions:
* Take your medications as prescribed.
* Do not drive while taking narcotics.
* Do not combine narcotic and sedative medications or alcohol
* Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (APAP) in 24 hrs
* No strenuous activity, nothing in the vagina (no tampons, no
douching, no sex), no heavy lifting of objects >10lbs for 6
weeks.
* You may eat a regular diet.

Incision care:
* You may shower and allow soapy water to run over incision; no
scrubbing of incision. No bath tubs for 6 weeks.
* If you have steri-strips, leave them on. They will fall off on
their own or be removed during your followup visit.

Followup Instructions:
Complete the full course of antibiotics and report any side effects.

Brief Hospital Course:
Patient is a 2018 year-old female presenting with watery diarrhea
for the past 3 weeks and worsening abdominal cramping over the
last several days.
.
#. Abdominal Pain/Diarrhea: Two most likely etiologies are
inflammatory bowel disease and bacterial/viral colitis. Patient
with no risk factors for infectious etiologies, such as recent
antiobitoic use, travel, sick contacts and stool cultures have
been negative. Ongoing nature of symptoms makes inflammatory
disease more likely given these lack of risk factors. Ischemic
colitis also a possible etiology caused by low flow state from
long-term diarrhea. Patient was started on IV cipro/flagyl and
kept on bowel rest for the first 2 days of her stay. She was
also given IVF hydration. She had a colonoscopy on Day 3, which
showed generalized colitis and a small polyp which was removed.
Biopsies were taken. By Day 4, patient was tolerating full POs
and her abdominal and diarrhea had improved. She was discharged
on PO Cipro/Flagyl for a total of a 1:1 with GI
follow-up. Stool cultures were negative or pending by the time
of discharge.

with severe aortic valve stenosis. Possible vegetation on the
mitral valve chordae. Functional mild mitral stenosis due to

Brief Hospital Course:
Jerry Gonzales with a PMHx notable for HTN and DMII presenting from her
nursing home with dyspnea, chest pain, and found to be in
complete heart block, now s/p pacemaker placement.

# COMPLETE HEART BLOCK: The patient was found to be bradycardic
to the 90–100 bpm (normal sinus rhythm) with normal BP. She was sent to Oncology Department, where she was
found to be in complete heart block. The patient became
progressively hypotensive and was started on norepi with
transcutaneous pacing and transferred to Cedars-Sinai Medical Center. On arrival to
Cedars-Sinai Medical Center, the patient was noted not to be capturing appropriately
from transcutaneous pacing. She was started on dopamine and
levophed for BP support. ECG on arrival to Cedars-Sinai Medical Center showed
alternative BBB consistent with infranodal AV conduction
disease. A temporary wire was attempted to be placed on the
night of admission, but wire was unable to be advanced via R IJ
access. The patient was treated with permanent dual chamber
pacemaker on 2025-02-14 and was successfully weaned of levophed. CXRs
were monitored without evidence of significant PTX. The
patient's home diltiazem was held in the setting of bradycardia.
Discharged home on metoprolol succinate 50 mg QDOf note, blood
pressures were asymmetric in the left and right arms, with the
left being 20 mmHg lower. Therefore, she underwent CTA to r/o
aortic dissection. Therefore, ALL BPs SHOULD BE TAKEN IN RIGHT
ARM GIVEN SUBCLAVIAN STENOSIS ON L SIDE.

# SEPSIS: The patient presented with leukocytosis. CXR was
concerning for PNA. UA was initially suggestive of infection,
but UCx only grew alpha hemolytic strep and lactobacillus. The
patient was started on vancomycin, ceftriaxone and flagyl for
HCAP/aspiration pneumonia for which she completed a 7 day
course. later in her hosptial course, she started spiking dialy
fevers. Main concern was for a pacemaker wire infection, however
TEE was deferred as, per EP team, pt would not be a candidate to
have her PPM replaced. Subsequently, pan culture data continued
to be negative and therefore abx were discontinued, and she
remained afebrile. Therefore, fever likely a drug fever. N/A

# PLEURAL EFFUSIONS: Pt developed hypoxemia and required
supplemental oxygen. Noted to have large b/l pleural effusions
on CT chest. Likely secondary to volume overload as a result of
ICU course and hypoalbuminemia (albumin 2.9). Underwent
thoracentesis and fluid analysis confirmed transudative
effusions. Afterwards, was diuresed with IV lasix boluses,
escalated to lasix gtt, and eventually converted to PO
torsemide. Presenting weight 62.8 kg to 52.3 on discharge, with
BNP 13k -> 2k. Oxygen requirement resolved, and discharged home
on Torsemide 100 mg PO QD for euvolemia/slow gradual diuresis
for ascities as detailed below.

#Ascites/cirrhosis- hx of cirrhosis per EMR. CT abdomen
confirmed cirrhosis and moderate ascites, therefore likely Acute Myocardial Infarction (Heart Attack)
hypoalbuminemia and portal hypertension. Unable to resolve
ascites with above regimen, therefore continued on torsemide 100
mg PO. Of note, Hector Bright was consulted for therapeutic paracentesis,
however no safe entry point was identified. On discharge, pt
asymptomatic and abdominal distention much improved.

#Anemia - CT abdomen ruled out retroperitoneal bleed.
Subsequently, stool guiac positive, therefore pt with likely low
grade GIB (Retic index 0.7 therefore no acute blood loss, coags
and haptoglobin wnl therefore DIC/intravascular hemolysis
unlikely, but iron studies consistent with iron deficiency
anemia: Fe 34, TIBC 215, Ferritin 91). Transfused a total of 2 u
pRBCs, with appropriate compensation, and discharged home with
Hgb 9.1. Consider iron supplementation as outpt and/or GIB
work-up.

# THOMBOCYTOPENIA: Pt with plt drop from 233 on admission, to
270 on 2025-07-14 to 129 on 2025-07-14. Likely underlying deficit in
production given cirrhosis, however may have been exacerbated in
setting of sepsis. Subsequently improved later in hosptial
course. Platelets 184 on day of discharge.

# DM II: Continue long and short acting insulin, which was
titrated to meet needs.

# Schizoaffective Disorder: Continued Lexapro and divalproex.

=======TRANSITIONAL ISSUES=============
-ALWAYS MEASURE BP IN R ARM AS KNOWN SUBCLAVIAN STENOSIS ON
LEFT!
-Home diltiazem stopped. Now on metoprolol succinate 50 mg QD.
Please monitor for HR/BP.
-Started on torsemide 100 mg PO to maintain euvolemia and
hopefully have gradual improvement of ascities. Please check
CHEM-7 and supplement potassium as needed and monitor Cr. Cr on
discharge 0.8. Weight on discharge 52.3 kg.
-Hx of cirrhosis. Adjust medication dosage need spironolactone/Lasix for maintenance
therapy for ascites in future.
-Stool guiac positive and studied consistent with iron
deficiency anemia, therefor may have low grade GIB. Consider
supplemental iron vs outpt work-up for GIB. Transfused 2 u
pRBCs over hospital course. Hemoglobin 9.1 on discharge.
-New diarrhea towards end of hospital course. C.diff negative x
2. Improving on discharge, however this needs to be monitored to
make sure it eventually resolves.
-Dental caries: found in right maxillary canine tooth

Complete heart block, now after permanent pacemaker placement
Sepsis

Mental Status: Confused - sometimes.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. Gonzales,

You came to the hospital because you were having chest pain and
felt short of breath. When we looked at the electrical activity
in your heart, we saw that your heat was beating very slowly and
therefore resulting in you having these symptoms. When your
blood pressure dropped significantly, you required electrical
pacing of your heart, as well as special medications to
stimulate its pumping. Afterwards, you had a permanent pacemaker
placed to help keep your heart pumping, therefore were able to
have these special medications taken off. Additionally, you
received 1 unit of blood to help stabilize your body during this
time. Last, there was concern you had an infection in your
bladder (or lungs) so you received a few days of antibiotics.
For the last part of your course, we were simply trying to
remove all of the excess fluid in your belly. This may of been a
result of all the fluids you got during the hospitalization or
simply a result of your underlying liver disease. On discharge,
it is important you take your water pill torsemide 100 mg (1
tablet) everyday in order to keep the fluid from building up-
please follow up with your PCP as he/she will determine how long
you will need to be on this pill.

We wish you the best of luck,
-Your Royal Free Hospital care team

Followup Instructions:
Return to the emergency room immediately if fever exceeds 101°F.

Discharge Instructions:
Discharge Instructions

Spine Surgery without Fusion

Surgery
•Your dressing may come off on the second day after surgery.
•*** Your incision is closed with staples or sutures. You will
need suture/staple removal. Please keep your incision dry until
suture/staple removal.

•Do not apply any lotions or creams to the site.
•Please avoid swimming for two weeks after suture/staple
removal.
•Call your surgeon if there are any signs of infection like
redness, fever, or drainage.

Activity
•We recommend that you avoid heavy lifting, running, climbing,
or other strenuous exercise until your follow-up appointment.
•You make take leisurely walks and slowly increase your
activity at your own pace. Monitor blood pressure try to do too much all at once.
•No driving while taking any narcotic or sedating medication.
•No contact sports until cleared by your neurosurgeon.

Medications
•***Please do NOT take any blood thinning medication (Aspirin,
Ibuprofen, Plavix, Coumadin) until cleared by the neurosurgeon.
•*** You may take Ibuprofen/ Motrin for pain.
•You may use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort if
you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication.
•It is important to increase fluid intake while taking pain
medications. We also recommend a stool softener like Colace.
Pain medications can cause constipation.

When to Call Your Doctor at +919092838490 for:
•Severe pain, swelling, redness or drainage from the incision
site.
•Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit
•New weakness or changes in sensation in your arms or legs.


Followup Instructions:
Refrain from smoking or using tobacco products completely.

for
evaluation.

calcifications are
seen in the normal caliber thoracic aorta without evidence of
intramural
hematoma or dissection. Pulmonary arterial vasculature is well
visualized to
the subsegmental level without filling defect to suggest
pulmonary embolism.
No pathologically enlarged mediastinal, axillary or hilar lymph
nodes are
present. The heart, pericardium and great vessels are within
normal limits
aside from moderate coronary artery calcifications in the LAD
and right

effusion. No right pleural effusion. A partially imaged

mild
bibasilar dependent atelectasis. Multiple ground-glass pulmonary
nodules are

lower lobe

is

malignancy is seen.
No acute fracture is identified. A non-aggressive-appearing
sclerotic lesion
in the vertebral body of T2 is likely a bone island.

largest measuring 6
mm. Followup with dedicated chest CT is recommended in 12 months
if patient
has no risk factors for malignancy. If patient has risk factors

months.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. Phyllis Moreno is a 1973 y/o F with history of hiatal hernia and
GERD, no known CAD history, who is presenting with chest pain.

ACTIVE ISSUES:
Chest pain: Mrs Phyllis Moreno presented with chest pain and <1mm
ST elevation in an inferolateral distribution. Repeat EKG showed
resolution of the ST segment changes but non-specific t wave
changes. She was admitted and monitored with telemetry which
later showed ST elevations. A repeat EKG was performed which
confirmed >1mm ST elevations inferolaterally. She was taken to
the cath lab which showed 40% non-obstructing lesion in the RCA
and no suggestion of clot formation. Her EKG showed persistent
ST elevations despite her catheterization. Cardiac enzyme were
repeatedly performed throughout her admission which remained
negative. It was felt that her EKG changes probably represented
coronary vasospasm. She was started on diltiazem and was
discharged on 180 mg daily. Because of her new CAD she was also
started on full dose aspirin and simvastatin 10mg. A beta
blocker was not started because her blood pressure was low
normal and felt to be too low to also start now in addition to
the diltiazem. Differential diagnosis considered for her
presentation included pericarditis as she reported the pain to
be pleuritic and improved with sitting forward, and the STE
persisted despite lack of pain and normal cath. As treatment of
this would be with aspirin or nsaids it was assumed that
increasing her dose of aspirin may help.

Coronary artery disease: Though this was not felt to be the
cause of her pain, the lesion noted represents a new diagnosis
of CAD. She was started on simvastatin and full dose aspirin. A
beta blocker was not initiated at this visit because of the
concurrent initiation of diltiazem.

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
Mrs. Phyllis Moreno has low normal blood pressure at baseline prior
to initiating diltiazem. Her BP should be closely monitored and
signs of low BP or orthostasis were explained to her.

Consideration of a Beta blocker for her coronary artery disease
should be considered in the future but at this time was defered
because of her BP.

ACTIVE ISSUES
# ABDOMINAL PAIN: Mr. Freeman endorses the onset of abdominal

diarrhea. Due to dental instrumentation 2 weeks ago, he's had
oral pain and difficulty maintaining po intake, including home
medications. He endorses feeling slightly more bloated than
usual. CT Abd/Pel showed sequelae of chronic pancreatitis,

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. Freeman,

You were admitted to Mount Sinai Medical Center for oral pain and abdominal pain with
diarrhea and difficulty eating and drinking after extraction of
teeth. You were also very dehydrated as the result.
As we discussed during your hospital stay, your CT scan showed
that a significant part of your pancrease has been damaged by
chronic inflammation. The pancrease is responsible for producing
digestive juices and certain hormones, including insulin.
Currently, you are on Creon, which acts like the digestive
juices produced by normal pancrease and help you digest the food
you eat. It is important for you to take Creon with meals to
help you absorb the nutrients you eat, prevent weight loss and
vitamine deficency.
While there is no effective way to cure your chronic
pancreatitis, it is important to prevent more damage. Avoiding
alcohol is the single MOST important treatment. We understand
that the alcohol helps you deal with chronic pain, however, it
is very bad for your pancreas and will cause you more pain in
the future. The pain of chronic pancreatitis may also be reduced
by eating small and low-fat meals. It is also very important for
you to drink plenty of water. Without enough water, you may
become dehydrated again and cause more damage to your pancrease
and other organs, such as your kidneys.
Stop drinking alcohol and eating smaller amount of food each
time may also help with your reflux and prevent damage to your
stomach. To avoid weight loss, you can eat the same amount of
food, just a little bit at a time.
Overall, please stop drinking alcohol all together, eat low fat
food, take Creon with food and drink plenty of water.

Thanks for letting us care for you,
- Your team at Mount Sinai Medical Center

Followup Instructions:
Schedule imaging after 1 month to evaluate treatment progress.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. Griffin arrived via helicopter to Johns Hopkins Clinic on 2025-08-15 with a
ruptured AAA. He was taken emergently to the CT scanner and then
directly to the Operating Room. He underwent an open repair of
his ruptured aneurysm with a tube graft. The abdomen was left
open with Abthera in place. For full details of the procedure,
please refer to the separately dictated Operative Report.
Massive transfusion protocol was activated during the case and
he received a total of 12 prbc, 2 plt, 2 cryo, 26 FFP, 250
albumin, 1400 CellSav, 2L NS, and 2L LR intraoperatively. He
was left intubated and brought to the cardiovascular ICU in
critical condition. Upon arrival to the CVICU, he had large
volumes of bloody output from the Abethera (>3.5L in 6 hours),
and persistent transfusion requirement which prompted early
re-exploration of the abdomen on 2025-05-31. No discrete bleeding
was identified and it was felt that bleeding was due to
coagulopathy. He was again brought to the CVICU for re-warming
and correction of coagulopathy. Abthera output subsequently
slowed and he transfusion requirement drastically decreased. On
2025-07-29, given the fact that no pedal signals were appreciated
bilaterally and his lower extremities were looking more mottled
and there was clinical concern for compartment syndrome, the
patient was taken back to the OR for b/l BK popliteal cutdowns,
embolectomy and fasciotomies. Given patient's significant loss
of domain, ACS was consulted to help with abdominal closure, for
which they placed a Whitmann patch on 2025-04-14 with subsequent OR
take backs for washout & tightening until closure was obtained
on 2025-05-07.

The details of the Patient is alert hospital course are discussed by
system below:

Neuro: Patient remained sedated as appropriate while he was
intubated. He was awakened periodically for neuro exams and was
able to follow commands and respond with head nod to questions.
Patient was extubated on 2025-05-11 and was conversant and
continued to follow commands. The patient required reintubation
on 2025-01-27 hypoxia, but continues to follow commands when
sedation is weaned to check neuro exam. He required intermittent
reintubations due to his respiratory status, but his
neurological status remained intact. He remained neurologically
stable during admission.

CV: Patient has required levophed since his initial procedure to
maintain MAPs >60. Patient developed new onset Afib on 2025-03-12
for which an amiodarone gtt was started and then transitioned to
scheduled amiodarone doses. Patient independently cardioverted
to NSR and remained in NSR for the remaining duration of his
stay. Vascular medicine recommends he should continue on his
current metoprolol regimen.

PULM: Patient returned to Johns Hopkins Clinic ICU intubated after initial open
repair. Patient remained intubated until 2025-05-11, when he was
extubated to high flow nasal cannula. Patient remained extubated
and on nasal cannula until 2025-07-29, when he started becoming
increasingly tachypneic and had an increased work of breathing.
He was transitioned to a non-rebreather, with O2 saturations
remaining in the low 1972, for which he was then reintubated. He
suspected to have a pneumonia and treated accordingly.
Ultimately he was extubated 2025-05-11. He was eventually weaned to
nasal cannula and transferred to the VICU. On 2025-07-29. The follow
day, he developed epistaxis in the setting of anticoagulation
and aspirated again. He was transferred to the ICU and
reintubated in that time. Given his multiple failed extubations,
ACS was consulted and he underwent tracheostomy and PEG
placement on 2025-05-31. This allowed him to be promptly weaned
from the vent to trach mask, which he continued on for the
duration of his stay. He has been doing very well with speaking
valve, ENT followed patient and will follow in clinic for
potential future use of vocal cords injection.
GI: Abdomen was left open following his operation due to ongoing
bleeding. He underwent multiple washouts and the abdomen was
unable to be easily closed due to loss of domain. ACS was
consulted for assistance with closure and Whitmann patch was
placed on 2025-04-14. Enteral feeds were initiated via OGT on 2025-02-04
which he tolerated without issue. Patient went back to the OR
multiple times with ACS for washout and tightening of the
Whitmann patch, and his abdomen was finally closed and RP
hematoma drained on 2025-08-08. On 2025-07-29 patient developed guaiac
+ stools and then frank melena with a Hct drop from 27 to 24.
Patient appropriately bumped to 27 after 1U RBC. GI consulted
for suspected upper GI bleed. On 2025-06-15 GI performed an EGD and
flex sig. The EGD showed ulcer ~1cm bellow UES without active
bleeding as well as a nodular fundus Risk of AKI ischemia vs polyps and
the flex sig showed normal colonic mucosa. On 2025-07-29 there was
concern for possible aspiration from TF, so TF were held and
continued to be through 2025-07-29. They were resumed, but were
again held due to high TF residuals. He ultimately tolerated
goal tube feeds via the NJ tube without issue. His NJ tube was
removed in the setting of his trach/peg on 2025-07-12.
Unfortunately, given his ongoing aspiration events, he could not
tolerated gastric feeds without significant concern for
aspiration. Awaiting operative decision making, the patient was
on TPN from 2025-02-16. In this setting, his NJT was
replaced on 2025-08-12. He tolerated goal tube feeds briefly and
then developed hematemesis, with concern from reulceration of
his known GEJ ulcer. On 2025-05-02 interventional radiology placed a
new GJ tube, and it was noted that the PEG placed by acs was
with ulceration was a source of bleeding. The patinet was unable
to remain on anticoagulation while this PEG is in place. Plans
were made for the patient to follow up with ACS for removal of
the PEG at a later date after the tract had matured. The GJ
placed by Brianna Warren was able to be used for tube feeds at the time of
discharge. PEG should remained capped, feedings should go though
J and G from GJ should remained capped.

GU: Patient had persistently increasing creatinine following his
operation and remained anuric. Renal was consulted and
recommended initiation of CRRT which was started on 2025-04-27.
Foley was removed and patient was bladder-scanned and straight
cathed as needed. He was transitioned to iHD which he required
until 2025-07-06, when his kidney function had returned and his
urine output was adequate. He needs to follow up with nephrology
in the next 2 months. At discharge his Creatinine was 1.0

Heme: Patient was started on a heparin gtt on 2025-06-15 after his
b/l BK pop cutdown and emobolectomies, for which he currently is
therapeutic on. His hemoglobin and hematocrit were trended and
he was transfused as needed. His heparin gtt was intermittently
held for bleeding issues including epistaxis and upper GI
bleeding from his fundal ulcer. Prior to discharge a IVC filter
was placed. He was discharged on aspirin and SQH as he required
multiple transfusion for GI bleed from PEG site when heparin
drip was initiated. Patient will remain on SQH until PEG tube is
removed by ACS. He will follow up with Dr. Brooks in clinic and
we will determine restart of anticoagulation.

ID: Perioperative antibiotics were administered. Patient became
febrile to 101.3 on 2025-07-29 and cultures were obtained and abx were
broadened from vanc/ancef to vanc/cefepime/flagyl. Patient was
seen to have an uptrending WBC and there a c/f HAP vs aspiration
pneumonitis for which patient received dose of micafungin on
2025-07-29. On 2025-07-29, WBC peaked at 33.5 and patient required
reintubation due to chronic illness hypoxia. ID was consulted who recommended
switching patient to Mary Wilson and give a dose of
tobramycin. Flagyl and vanc were then subsequently recommended
to be discontinued, and as of 2025-07-29 patient remained on Mary Wilson.
WBC downtrending. He continued on meropenem in the setting of
his open BKAs and aspiration pneumonias and ultimately completed
his course on 2025-03-06. At the time of discharge he no longer
required antibiotics.

MSK: Patient is s/p bilateral BKA for gangrenous Bilateral with
intraoperative and postoperative ischemia. Patient had R
Guillotine BKA on 2025-05-31 and L Guillotine BKA on 2025-05-31. He
underwent closure on 2025-05-07 after which time his wounds healed
appropriately. Patient has L BKA staples in the lateral side
that will be removed in his next follow up appointment at the
Vascular Surgery mid level clinic.

Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status:
Activity Status: requires assistance or aid

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. Griffin,

You were admitted to the hospital because your aorta ruptured.
You underwent emergent surgery. During your stay you underwent a
number of surgeries and required complex medical care in the ICU
and floor units. Your aorta was repaired, both of your legs
required amputation, a tracheostomy tube was placed, two feeding
tubes were placed and a filter in a major vessel to your heart
had a filter placed to prevent blood clots. You tolerated these
procedure well and are now ready for discharge.

You should take your medications as prescribed and follow up
with all of your physicians, particularly your primary care
physician and vascular surgeon.

LOWER EXTREMITY AMPUTATION
DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS
ACTIVITY
•You should keep your amputation site elevated and straight
whenever possible. This will prevent swelling of the stump and
maintain flexibility in your joint.
•It is very important that you put no weight or pressure on
your stump with activity or at rest to allow the wound to heal
properly.
•You may use the opposite foot for transfers and pivots, if
applicable. It will take time to learn to use a walker and
learn to transfer into and out of a wheelchair.

MEDICATION
•Before you leave the hospital, you will be given a list of all
the medicine you should take at home. If a medication that you
normally take is not on the list or a medication that you do not
take is on the list please discuss it with the team!

•You will likely be prescribed narcotic pain medication on
discharge which can be very constipating. If you take
narcotics, please also take a stool softener such as Colace.
If constipation becomes a problem, your pharmacist can suggest
an additional over the counter laxative.

•You should take Tylenol 1982 every 6 hours, as needed for
pain. If this is not enough, take your prescription narcotic
pain medication. You should require less pain medication each
day. Do not take more than a daily total of 3000mg of Tylenol.
Tylenol is used as an ingredient in some other over-the-counter
and prescription medications. Be aware of how much Tylenol you
are taking in a day.

BATHING/SHOWERING:
•You may shower when you feel strong enough but no tub baths or
pools until you have permission from your surgeon and the
incision is fully healed.
•After your shower, gently dry the incision well. Do not rub
the area.

WOUND CARE:
•Please keep the wound clean and dry. It is very important that
there is no pressure on the stump. If there is no drainage,
you may leave the incision open to air.
•Your staples/sutures will remain in for at least 4 weeks. At
your followup appointment, we will see if the incision has
healed enough to remove the staples.
•Before you can be fitted for prosthesis (a man-made limb to
replace the limb that was removed) your incision needs to be
fully healed.

CALL THE OFFICE FOR: Fever
•Opening, bleeding or drainage or odor from your stump incision

•Redness, swelling or warmth in your stump.
•Fever greater than 101 degrees, chills, or worsening
incisional/stump pain

NO OTHER PROVIDER, EXCEPT YOUR VASCULAR SURGEON, SHOULD
DETERMINE IF YOUR STAPLES ARE READY TO BE REMOVED FROM YOUR
STUMP!
IF THERE ARE ANY QUESTIONS, THE PROVIDER SHOULD CALL THE
VASCULAR SURGERY OFFICE AT +917937529624 TO DISCUSS. THE
STAPLES WILL BE REMOVED IN THE OFFICE AT YOUR FOLLOWUP
APPOINTMENT WHEN IT IS DETERMINED BY THE VASCULAR SURGEON THAT
THE WOUND HAS SUFFICIENTLY HEALED.

Followup Instructions:
Adhere to fluid restrictions to avoid fluid overload.

ACTIVE ISSUES:
==============
#COPD exacerbation
Patient presented with several days of worsening dyspnea,
increased sputum production, and increased O2 requirement of 4L
(from home baseline 2L at night). Trigger for this exacerbation
was likely that she recently restarted smoking about 2 weeks
prior to admission. Initial concern for pneumonia given CXR at
OSH was read as having infiltrate and patient was briefly
febrile West Christina ED here. She initially received Vanc, Cefepime and
azithro. CXR here was clear, patient had no further fevers, and
sputum culture only notable for respiratory flora. Vanc and
Cefepime were discontinued. Azithromycin was continued for 5
days for its anti-inflammatory properties (Improved symptoms). Patient
also received prednisone 40mg qd for a 5 day course (2025-07-18).
Patient received standing duonebs and albuterol prn while
hospitalized. She continued home Advair; home Spiriva was held
during admission given standing duonebs, but was restarted on
discharge. She received Benzonatate and
Guaifenesin-Dextromethorphan as needed for cough. Her SpO2
target was 88-92% given COPD. Ambulatory O2 saturation while on
RA was 76%, so patient was discharged with home daytime oxygen
(had previously been on oxygen only at night). She will follow
up with PCP and pulmonology. Smoking cessation was encouraged as
discussed below.

#AFib
Patient with history of Afib. She was observed on tele during
admission and was mostly AFib sinus rhythm with intermittent runs
of NSVTs. Per patient, prior hesitation around anticoagulation
given history of cerebral aneurysm. CHADS2-VASc score 2. Patient
received subQ heparin during admission. Per discussion with Dr.
Patricia Crawford, planned to hold SQH if platelets were <50 but this was
not necessary. She is to follow up with Dr. Patricia Crawford further
consideration of anticoagulation going forward.

#Dizziness, improving
#H/o BPPV
Patient complained of dizziness during admission, specifically
lightheadedness and feeling 'woozy'. She has a history of BPPV
but notes this sensation was different. Her typical BPPV
presents with a feeling of the room spinning, which did not
occur while hospitalized. Patient felt subjectively better after
receiving fluids. Likely etiology thought more likely to be
pre-syncope than vertigo. Her neuorologic exam was unchanged.
She received fluids as needed and was encouraged to increase her
PO intake.

#Thrombocytopenia
Per Dr. Patricia Crawford, felt to be from ITP. Her CBC was trended while
hospitalized and her platelets were uptrending. She will follow
up with outpatient hematology as previously planned. Platelet
level on day of discharge was 180.

#Smoking history
Patient reporting that she restarted smoking because "everyone
North Joshuaton the house smokes". Social work was consulted to help with
social supports and resources that would help her remain
abstinent from smoking. She was discharged with a script for
nicotine patch and was encouraged to not smoke. She was also
encouraged to avoid areas where others are smoking and to ask
her family to not smoke around her or her house.

#Chest pain, resolved
#GERD
Patient presented with chest pain on admission. She described
the pain as intermittent epigastric burning which began shortly
after eating breakfast, felt like her typical GERD symptoms.
There was no concern for ACS based on symptom pattern, negative
troponin, and normal EKG. She was continued on home omeprazole
and received Maalox prn for heartburn.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. Ross,

It was a pleasure to care for you at the Apollo Medical Center Royal Free Hospital.

Why did you come to the hospital?
- You came to the hospital because you were having difficulty breathing,

What did you receive North Joshuaton the hospital?
- You were given steroids to treat a COPD flare. You were also
given an antibiotic called Azithromycin that helps to decrease
inflammation North Joshuaton your lungs during COPD flares.
- You received medications to help treat your cough as well.
- You had imaging and tests to see if you had an infection North Joshuaton your lungs. We do not believe you had an infection.

What should you do once you leave the hospital?
- You should take all of your medications as prescribed (see
below).
- You should attend all of your scheduled outpatient
appointments.
- You should continue to use a nicotine patch to help you stop
smoking. We believe that you had this COPD flare because you
started smoking again.
- You should use your oxygen at home especially when walking
around.
- Please do not smoke. We encourage use to use the nicotine
patch and ask your PCP about additional aids, such as nicotine
lozenges, to help you quit smoking. Please try to stay out of
areas where people are smoking and encourage your family not to
smoke around you or your house.

We wish you the best!
Your Surgical Care Team Care Team

of fluid frequently throughout the day to reach a goal of
approximately Intake: 1800 mL, Output: 1600 mL mL per day. Please note the following signs

prescribed medications.
Some of the new medications you will be taking include:
1. Pain medication: You will receive a prescription for liquid
oxycodone, an opioid pain medication. This medication will make
you drowsy and impair your ability to drive a motor vehicle or
operate machinery safely. You MUST refrain from such activities
while taking these medications. You may also take acetaminophen
(Tylenol) for pain management; do not exceed 4000 mg per 24 hour
period.
2. Constipation: This is a common side effect of opioid pain
medication. If you experience constipation, please reduce or
eliminate opioid pain medication. You may trial 2 ounces of
light prune juice and/or a stool softener (i.e. crushed docusate
sodium tablets), twice daily until you resume a normal bowel
pattern. Please stop taking this medication if you develop
loose stools. Please do not begin taking laxatives including
until you have discussed it with your nurse or surgeon.
3. Antacids: You will be taking famotidine tablets, 20 mg twice
daily, for one month. This medicine reduces stomach acid
production. Please crush.
4. You must not use NSAIDS (non-steroidal anti-inflammatory
drugs). Examples include, but are not limited to Aleve,
Arthrotec, aspirin, Bufferin, diclofenac, Ecotrin, etodolac,
ibuprofen, Indocin, indomethacin, Feldene, ketorolac,
meclofenamate, meloxicam, Midol, Motrin, nambumetone, Naprosyn,
Naproxen, Nuprin, oxaprozin, Piroxicam, Relafen, Toradol and
Voltaren. These agents may cause bleeding and ulcers in your
digestive system. If you are unclear whether a medication is
considered an NSAID, please ask call your nurse or ask your
pharmacist.
5. Vitamins/ minerals: You may resume a chewable multivitamin,
however, please discuss when to resume additional vitamin and
mineral supplements with your bariatric dietitian.

Activity:
You should continue walking frequently throughout the day right
after surgery; you may climb stairs.
You may resume moderate exercise at your discretion, but avoid
performing abdominal exercises or lifting items greater than10
to 15 pounds for six weeks.

Wound Care:
You may remove any remaining gauze from over your incisions.
You will have thin paper strips (Steri-Strips) over your
incision; please, remove any remaining Steri-Strip seven to 10
days after surgery.
You may shower 48 hours following your surgery; avoid scrubbing
your incisions and gently pat them dry. Avoid tub baths or
swimming until cleared by your surgeon.
If there is clear drainage from your incisions, cover with
clean, dry gauze.
Please call the doctor if you have increased pain, swelling,
redness, cloudy, bloody or foul smelling drainage from the
incision sites.
Avoid direct sun exposure to the incision area for up to 24
months.
Do not use any ointments on the incision unless you were told
otherwise.

Followup Instructions:
Weekly follow-up required

Brief Hospital Course:
#. Altered mental status:
Patient had multifactorial reasons for altered mental status
including MVA, and on further questioning he also had a
different recent head trauma with a falling tree branch. Recent
head traumas raised questions of post-concussive syndrome. He
has also likely been underdialyzed recently due to problems with
peritoneal dialysis catheter, unclear what role this played in
altered mental status.

MRI imaging at OSH has been reported negative and exam is
without focal deficits. As for infection, blood cultures and
peritoneal fluid cultures sent from ED were negative. LP
negative.  Urinalysis and urine culture were negative. Patient
was treated with clindamycin for facial abrasion that he
suffered from a fall. Serum and urine tox screens negative
(aside from benzo +, which was expected medication). B12 and
folate levels were within normal range at presentation. TSH was
elevated slightly to 6.3 at presentation but free T4 wnl. This
slight TSH elevation unlikely to cause his presenting symptoms.
Neurology and psychiatry were consulted; an EEG was performed
and was unremarkable.  Patient had an MRI here that showed an
old R frontal stroke, raising the question of possible
underlying mild dementia from stroke.   His sister gave an
interesting history of declining cognitive function over the
past several months to year, with family members concerned about
his ability to manage finances.  Though he was able to have a
fairly normal conversation and was oriented x 3, detailed OT
testing showed some cognitive defects on examination such as
inability to balance checkbook).  He was monitored in-house
while other medical issues were being managed (see below for PD
catheter problems) Disposition was a question because in his
mental state he likely would not have been able to handle his
own peritoneal dialysis at home (lives alone).  Interestingly,
his mental status actually improved over the course of the next
week and he showed enough improvement on OT testing to go home
with support services.
.
#ESRD: Initially on PD, but soon catheter not functioning
appropriately, tunnelled line placed and started on HD.  Surgery
attempted to reposition the PD catheter but were unsuccessful
and it had to ultimately be removed. Patient had four sessions
of hemodialysis prior to discharge.  Pt to have outpatient
dialysis.
- follow up with Dr. Refrain from smoking or using tobacco products completely..
.
#. Hypertension:  Patient's blood pressures were initially not
well controlled, but his BP regimen was uptitrated and was
controlled in the SBP 130-140 range
- continue norvasc 10mg daily-
- Continue Metoprolol 150mg daily

#. Neurogenic bladder/bladder outlet obstruction:
Patient is at high risk for urinary tract infections given that
he has had a hx of needing to straight cath himself, though
urinalysis and urine culture have been negative. We inserted a
foley catheter initially, however once patient's confusion
resolved, his catheter was removed and he was able to urinate.
Pt later clarified that he has not had to straight-cath himself
for some time at home.

#. Hypothyroidism:
TSH elevated at OSH to 8.1 and only elevated to 6.3 here. His
free T4 was initially mildly decreased and then normal on repeat
testing.  Unlikely that his presentation of altered mental
status was due to hypothyroidism. We continued levothyroxine at
200 mcg daily.
