Brief Hospital Course:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: Ms. Brown is a lovely 2025 y/o F with history of CKD, DM, dCHF (EF>55%), stroke, and gout who is presenting with worsening shortness of breath and cough for the last two weeks.
.
# shortness of breath: The patient's symptoms do not include Watsonshire edema or weight gain, which are her usual symptoms associated with her CHF exacerbations. Moreover, the patient's lung exam and productive cough are more consistent with a bronchitis or PNA picture. However, the patient did have crackles on her exam and her CXR showed evidence of pulmonary vascular congestion. She also has an elevated white count. It is possible that an acute URI triggered a CHF exacerbation that is also contributing to her progressively worsening shortness of breath. The patient got IV Lasix 40 mg in ED as well as one dose of Levofloxacin. We monitored the patient's I/Os and checked her daily weights. We continued the patient on her home dose of Lasix (80 mg daily). Because the patient was given one dose of antibiotics in the ED, we decided to complete the course and give her 250 mg of Levofloxacin every 48 hours, for a total of 7 days. It is likely that the patient had a URI or PNA, and that this was not an acute exacerbation of her CHF.
.
# asthma: The patient was wheezing on exam; this could be a acute exacerbation of her asthma. That patient takes Flovent and Albuterol at home, which we continued. We also added Ipratropium nebulizers, and gave the patient a prescription at discharge, as well.
.
Inactive Issues:
# HTN: The patient's blood pressures were well controlled on her home medications: amlodipine 5 mg daily, and Atenolol 12.5 mg qhs.
.
# HLD: We continnued Pravastatin 40 mg daily
.
# CKD: Calcitriol 0.25 mg daily, Vitamin D, Aggrenox. The patient recently got her Epogen shot, so she was not due for one on this admission.
.
# GERD: We continued Pantoprazole 40 mg daily
.
# DM: The patient has diet controlled DM, but while in the hospital we ordered an isulin sliding scale and checked her FSG to ensure proper glycemic control.
.
Transitional Issues:
respiratory status: The patient was discharged on Atrovent inhaler as well as her Albuterol and Flovent. Patient should follow up with PCP to decide whether the extra inhaler is beneficial.
.

hospitalization. The patient worked with Psychiatry who determined that
discharge to home was appropriate. The uneventful hospital course

with oral medications, incisions were clean/dry/intact, and the

follow up with Dr. Matthew Wright routine. A thorough discussion was
had with the patient regarding the diagnosis and expected
post-discharge course including reasons to call the office or
return to the hospital, and all questions were answered. The
patient was also given written instructions concerning
precautionary instructions and the appropriate follow-up care.

Discharge Instructions:
Discharge Instructions:

INSTRUCTIONS AFTER ORTHOPAEDIC SURGERY:

- You were in the hospital for orthopedic surgery. It is normal
to feel tired or "washed out" after surgery, and this feeling
should improve over the first few days to week.
- Resume your regular activities as tolerated, but please follow
your weight bearing precautions strictly at all times.

ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING:
- weight bearing as tolerated on the right lower extremity.

MEDICATIONS:
- Please take all medications as prescribed by your physicians
at discharge.
- Continue all home medications unless specifically instructed
to stop by your surgeon.
- Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate
machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers.
- Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you should
drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and take a stool softener
(colace) to prevent this side effect.

ANTICOAGULATION:
- Please take enoxaparin daily for 4 weeks to prevent blood
clots.

WOUND CARE:
- You may shower. No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks.
- Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken
out at your 2-week follow up appointment.
- Please remain in your dressing and do not change unless it is
visibly soaked or falling off.

DANGER SIGNS:
Please call your PCP or surgeon's office and/or return to the
emergency department if you experience any of the following:
- Increasing pain that is not controlled with pain medications
- Increasing redness, swelling, drainage, or other concerning
changes in your incision
- Persistent or increasing numbness, tingling, or loss of
sensation
- Fever > 101.4
- Shaking chills
- Chest pain
- Shortness of breath
- Nausea or vomiting with an inability to keep food, liquid,
medications down
- Any other medical concerns

Physical Therapy:
weight bearing as tolerated on the bilateral lower extremities.
Treatments Frequency:
incision can be left open to air. No bathing or soaking.
showering is OK

Followup Instructions:
Follow post-surgical pain management plan and taper medications slowly.

Discharge Instructions:
-you will go home with the urethral foley catheter.

-You may continue to periodically see small amounts of blood in
your urine--this is normal and will gradually improve

-Resume your pre-admission/home medications EXCEPT as noted. You
should ALWAYS call to inform, review and discuss any medication
changes and your post-operative course with your primary care
doctor.

Should you HOLD ASPIRIN? Unless otherwise advised; If the urine
is still pink, hold the aspirin until it has been clear/yellow
for at least three days.

-If prescribed; complete the full course of antibiotics.

-You may be discharged home with a medication called PYRIDIUM
that will help with the "burning" pain you may experience when
voiding. This medication may turn your urine bright orange.

-Colace has been prescribed to avoid post surgical constipation
and constipation related to narcotic pain medication.
Discontinue if loose stool or diarrhea develops. Colace is a
stool softener, NOT a laxative

- AVOID STRAINING for bowel movements as this may stir up
bleeding.

-Do not eat constipating foods for 3:1 weeks, drink plenty of
fluids to keep hydrated

-No vigorous physical activity or sports for 4 weeks or until
otherwise advised

-Do not lift anything heavier than a phone book (10 pounds) or
participate in high intensity physical activity for a minimum of
four weeks or until you are cleared by your Urologist in
follow-up

-Tylenol should be your first line pain medication, a narcotic
pain medication has been prescribed for breakthrough pain >4.
Replace Tylenol with narcotic pain medication.

-Max daily Tylenol (acetaminophen) dose is 4 grams from ALL
sources, note that narcotic pain medication also contains
Tylenol

-Do not drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotics and do not
operate dangerous machinery. Also, if the Foley catheter and Leg
Bag are in place--Do NOT drive (you may be a passenger).

WHEN YOU ARE DISCHARGED WITH A FOLEY CATHETER:
-Please also reference the nursing handout and instructions on
routine care and hygiene

-Your Foley should be secured to the catheter secure on your
thigh at ALL times until your follow up with the surgeon.

-IF YOU HAVE A PRESCRIPTION FOR DITROPAN/OXYBUTININ: YOU MUST
STOP at least 24hours before planned foley removal and void
trial.

-DO NOT have anyone else other than your Surgeon or your
surgeon's representative remove your Foley for any reason.

-Wear Large Foley bag for majority of time; the leg bag is only
for short-term periods for when leaving the house.

-Do NOT drive if you have a Foley in place (for your safety)

Followup Instructions:
Schedule imaging after 1 month to evaluate treatment progress.

Discharge Instructions:
INSTRUCTIONS AFTER ORTHOPAEDIC SURGERY:

- You were in the hospital for orthopedic surgery. It is normal
to feel tired or "washed out" after surgery, and this feeling
should improve over the first few days to week.
- Resume your regular activities as tolerated, but please follow
your weight bearing precautions strictly at all times.

ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING:
- Touch-down weight bearing RLE

MEDICATIONS:
- Please take all medications as prescribed by your physicians
at discharge.
- Continue all home medications unless specifically instructed
to stop by your surgeon.
- Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate
machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers.
- Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you should
drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and take a stool softener
(colace) to prevent this side effect.

ANTICOAGULATION:
- Please take Lovenox daily for 4 weeks

WOUND CARE:
- You may shower. No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks.
- Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken
out at your 2-week follow up appointment.
- Please remain in your dressing and do not change unless it is
visibly soaked or falling off.

DANGER SIGNS:
Please call your PCP or surgeon's office and/or return to the
emergency department if you experience any of the following:
- Increasing pain that is not controlled with pain medications
- Increasing redness, swelling, drainage, or other concerning
changes in your incision
- Persistent or increasing numbness, tingling, or loss of
sensation
- Fever > 101.4
- Shaking chills
- Chest pain
- Shortness of breath
- Nausea or vomiting with an inability to keep food, liquid,
medications down
- Any other medical concerns

Followup Instructions:
Follow diabetic diet instructions carefully and monitor blood sugar levels twice daily.

Conclusions

Brief Hospital Course:
Patient is an 2020 year old woman with hypertension who presented
with an inferior STEMI.
.
# Coronary artery disease: Patient had several risk factors,
including HTN and hyperlipidemia but had no prior history of
myocardial infarction or anginal symptoms. Her EKG was
consistent with an inferior STEMI with 100% occluded RCA,
3-vessel disease found on catherization. She had a bare metal
stent placed in the RCA. She may require require further
intervention for disease noted in her left circumflex and LAD,
to be determined in several weeks time after outpatient follow
up. Her CK peaked at 1722 (MB 278) at 12 am on 2025-04-30. She had
one additional episode ofchest pain on 2025-05-27, with an EKG showed
TWI and <1 mm STE in V3-V6. No intervention was taken.
At time of discharge, she was on changed to simvastatin 80 mg
(from atorvastatin 80 mg), Plavix 75 mg, Aspirin 325 mg, and
12.5 mg of metoprolol twice daily. Of note, her baseline liver
function tests were mildly elevated, possibly in setting of
myocardial infarction. She was not able to tolerate addition of
an Losartan 50 mg daily or further up-titration of her beta-blocker due
to asymptomatic hypotension overnight while sleeping (systolic
in the 130 – 139 mmHg (Hypertension Stage 1)).
- Further titration of her beta-blocker, including transition to
a once-daily formulation, and addition of an Losartan 50 mg daily
be further managed on an outpatient basis in follow-up.
.
# Heart function: Patient has had no prior echo. She had no
difficulties with oxygenation or shortness of breath. Her JVP
was noted to be mildly elevated at 9 cm. Her left and right
heart catherizations revealed elevated pressures, suggestive of
left ventricular systolic dysfunction in setting of inferior
myocardial infarction versus diastolic dysfunction in setting of
longstanding hypertension. She may also have some right
ventricular involvement with RCA occlusion. She was mildly
diruesed until she appeared euvolemic. A transthoracic echo was
completed on 2025-06-12 which showed a cardiac output of 10 L/min, 1+
MR, 1+ TR, EF of 55%. She had no clinical signs of failure, a
normal TSH 3.7, stable (although trending downward HCT), and tiw
as felt that the high output was most likely inaccurate
calculation of CO on Echo.
.
# Rhythm: Patient remained in sinus rhythm while monitored on
telemetry without any arrythmias.
.
# Hypertension: Patient's home medications were held. She had
borderline low blood pressure, so further uptitration of her
metoprolol and additional of other agents was deferred until
outpatient follow up. She was instructed to NOT resume her home
blood pressure medications until follow up.
.
# Anemia: Patient's baseline hematocrit per her primary care
physician's office was 40.7 in 2025-02-02. During her stay, she had
a stable slow drift downward in her hematocrit from 38-40 down
to 30. She had no signs of bleeding and her stools were guaiac
negative. Further work-up and evaluation of her anemia should be
completed as appropriate on an outpatient basis.
.
# White count: Patient had a leukocytosis to 17,000, but no
clinical signs of infection. It was felt that this was likely
secondary to her myocardial infection, and trended downward
during her stay.
.
# Disposition: Patient stayed on the cardiology floor for an
additional day to monitor her hematocrit and blood pressure,
both of which were stable. She was discharged home after being
cleared by physical therapy, and will receive physical therapy
at home. Cardiac rehabilitation was recommended. A copy of her

office (Dr. Wesley Lee at Wilsonville, Fax # +91-300-8502104.

NCHCT (2025-07-23) - There is an acute intraparenchymal hemorrhage
within the left frontoparietal lobes centered deep in the medial
subcortical white matter, measuring 5 cm AP x 3.5 cm CC x 2.3 cm
TRV. There is a moderate amount of surrounding vasogenic edema.
No discrete underlying mass is identified. There is one area
where the hemorrhage appears more heterogeneous (2:24), and this
may be due to swirling of blood (perhaps acute on chronic
hemorrhage) or an underlying mass. There is no evidence of
intraventricular extension of hemorrhage. There is mild mass
effect on the left lateral ventricles. No shift of the normally
midline structures. The suprasellar and basal cisterns are
preserved. There is a small amount of mucosal thickening in the
left maxillary sinus and a mucus retention cyst in the right
axillary sinus. The mastoid air cells are normally pneumatized
and aerated. A spongy lucent lesion in the left parietal bone
likely represents arachnoid granulations. There is no soft
tissue abnormality.
IMPRESSION: Large left frontoparietal intraparenchymal
hemorrhage with moderate edema and mild mass effect on the left
lateral ventricle. No midline shift or evidence of herniation.
The location of the hemorrhage is atypical for hypertension, and
the acuity of the bleed in unusual two weeks post-contusion
unless this represents hemorrhagic transformation of an infarct,
or rebleeding. An underlying mass, AV malformation, and amyloid
angiopathy are also considerations and could be evaluated for by
CTA or MRI.
NOTE ADDED AT ATTENDING REVIEW: It would be helpful to compare
to prior studies. The hemorrhage on this study does not appear
acute, given the extensive surrounding edema, but there might be
rebleeding into an established hematoma. I agree that the
etiology is not apparent, and that further work up is needed to
distinguish among the diagonstic possibilities listed.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. Colon is a 2023 year old gentleman with recent large ICH and
DVT s/p IVC filter not on anticoagulation, who presented to an
OSH with hypotension where he was found to have multiple
subsegmental PEs as well as what was thought to be increased
bleeding at the site of his ICH, in the setting of INR 1.4.

1. Intracerebral hematoma/subdural hematoma: The patient was
admitted with a question of re-bleeding into his previous ICH,
noted on Head CT and MRI. Unclear underlying etiology given that
INR 1.3 on arrival. MRI also noted bilateral SDH. Neurosurgery
and neurology were both consulted during admission. Final read
per radiology was consistent with subacute injury from original
inciting event with no acute process. The patient was initially
continued on phenytoin, but was changed to keppra due to
transaminitis. He will need to have his keppra titrated to
therapeutic level as indicated in discharge instructions.

2. Pulmonary emboli: The patient was noted to have multiple RLL
subsegmental pulmonary emboli on CTA at OSH. He is status post
IVC filter placement and not anticoagulated with an INR of 1.4
on admission. He remained hemodynamically stable throughout his
hospital course, and repeat lower extremity noninvasive studies
demonstrated bilateral Port Ashleystad DVTs. The patient is not a candidate
for anticoagulation secondary to ICH and SDFH. After discussing
with neurology, he was started on 325 mg ASA.

3. ECG changes: Pt presented with concerning ST-changes on ECG,
unknown baseline. Ruled-out for MI w/ 2 sets negative CEs while
in ED. As stated above, he was started on ASA therapy during
hospitalization.

4. Atrial fibrillation: Patient with afib on ECG on admission,
and was intermitently tachycardic during hospitalization. Rate
controlled at home on atenolol and verapamil, not
anticoagulated. We continued verapimil on short acting dose and
converted to metoprolol while admitted, which was slowly
titrated up for adequate rate control. He was continued on
digoxin and verapamil during his hospital course. The patient
was also noted on telemetry to have a 20 beat run of what
initially appeared to be asymptomatic VT, which was concerning
in the setting of his recent MVA attributed to cough syncope.
Cardiology was asked to interpret the telemetry strip, which was
determined to be Afib with aberration. No further diagnostic
work-up was performed, but the patient will likely need a TTE as
an outpatient if not already performed.

5. Transaminitis: Patient was found to have increasing
transaminitis during his hospital course that peaked at 221/166
ALT/AST. On day of discharge, his ALT/AST were 198/146 with alk
phos 609 and tbili of 2.6. He was switched from phenytoin to
keppra over some concern of drug induced transaminitis. On
further questioning, the patient also has a significant EtOH
history, stating that he drinks at least a 6 pack of beer a day.
A RUQ ultrasound was negative for liver lesions with borderline
splenomegaly and biliary sludging. A follow-up appointment was
scheduled for the patient in outpatient St. Mary's Hospital clinic
at 2025-07-02. On discharge, hepatitis serologies were pending.

6. Hypertension: Patient initially admitted on atenolol and
verapamil, which was converted to metoprolol and verapamil
during hospitalization.

7. Hyperlipidemia: Continued on home statin therapy during
hospitalization.

8. COPD: Continued on home therapy during hospitalization.

bypass grafting x4, with left internal mammary artery to left
anterior descending coronary artery, reversed saphenous vein
single graft from the aorta to the first diagonal coronary
artery, reversed saphenous vein single graft from the aorta to
the first obtuse marginal coronary artery, and reversed
saphenous vein single graft from the aorta to the posterior
descending coronary artery. Please see the operative note for
details. He was brought to the surgical instensive care unit in
critical but stable condition. However, in the immediate
post-operative period he developed acute respiratory
insufficiency, hypotension, and excessive bleeding from his
chest tubes. He returned to the operating room and underwent a
mediastinal exploration for bleeding. He tolerated this
procedure well. He extubated by the following day and was
weaned from pressors. By post-operative day two he was
transferred to the step-down floor. His chest tubes and wires
were removed per protocol. He was seen by physical therapy.
His insulin was titrated to maintain a glucose below 150.

started to protect his grafts. An e-mail was sent to Dr. Tammy Erickson his CK be checked in the near future to assess his
tolerance of this drug. His blood pressure did not allow the
addition of an ACE-inhibitor, but one should be added as his
blood pressure allows in the future secondary to his decreased
ejection fraction and chronic systolic heart failure. By
post-operative day four he was ready for discharge to home.
Follow-up appointments were advised.

History of Present Illness:
This is a 2016 year old woman with a history of recurrent,
metastatic NSCLC to brain who presents for further evaluation of
hemoptysis.

The patient was most recently seen in Riverbend Medical clinic on 2025-07-15
where she was screened for DF/HCC protocol 25867 (A Phase Phase III
trial of MM-121 in Combination with Erlotinib in Three Groups of
Patients with Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer), a trial of tarceva +
MM-121, which is an anti-ErbB3 human monoclonal antibody
secondary to progression of disease on Tarceva.

Of note, she is s/p hospitalization at Fortis Healthcare from
2025-04-17 for shortness of breath and wheezing after
placement of an endobronchial stent (placed 2025-02-06 for
significant narrowing of the distal bronchus intermedius).
During this admission, she underwent removal of the stent on
2025-04-21 (secondary to stent migration) as well as right and left
thoracentesis of exudative fluid. She also had an Enterococcus
(Amp-S) blood stream infection for which she completed a 14 day
course of IV antibiotics.

The patient was also seen in the ED on 2025-02-25 for evaluation of
dysuria for which she was given a course of empiric Bactrim.

In the ED, the patient's vital signs were: T 97.4, HR 105, BP
140/88, RR 16, O2 saturation 97% on RA. The patient states that
at approximately 7:30 09:54 PM Tuesday, after supper, she coughed 18
times and had a small amount of bright red blood followed by a
very small amount of clot. Because she had been told to go to
the ED if this happened, she promptly went to the ED. In the
ED, she coughed again, but had clear white sputum. In the ED, a
bedside ultrasound done in the ED showed a small to moderate
sized pericardial effusion without evidence of neck tamponade.
An outpatient ECHO done 2025-01-10 showed "Moderate pericardial
effusion without signs of tamponade".

The patient denies experiencing any fevers, chills, nausea,
vomiting, headache, abdominal pain, or rash. She has diarrhea
from Tarceva. She has been experiencing increasing dyspnea on
exertion for a few weeks. She does not use home oxygen. She
has a chronic dry cough. No chest pain. She sleeps on two
pillows at home (chronic). She can lay flat when she sleeps.

Brief Hospital Course:
ASSESSMENT/PLAN: This is a 2016 year old woman with a history of
recurrent, metastatic NSCLC to brain, currently on Tarceva, who
presents after experiencing small hemoptysis at home associated
with several weeks of ongoing dyspnea on exertion found to have
reaccumulation of pleural fluid, s/p L and R thoracentesis.

# Small hemoptysis: Hemoptysis possibly secondary to progressive
lung disease; moreover the patient also had recent endobronchial
stent placed. After arrival at the hospital, the patient had
only small episodes of hemoptysis. Hct and hemodynamics
remained stbale. She will follow up with her outpatient
oncologist.

# Dyspnea on Exertion: Likely secondary to slightly larger R
pleural effusion +/- pericardial effusion. She was seen by
pulmonology and underwent both R and L sided thoracentesis with
improvement in her dyspnea and oxygen requirement. The patient
also had an ECHO done which was which showed evidence of R
atrial collapse in the setting of pericardial effusion that was
slightly larger than prior study. This will have to be followed
as an outpatient (see below). Upon discharge, the patient was
breathing comfortably on room air, and ambulating without any
shortness of breath.

The patient has outpatient follow up with IP in Call the cardiologist immediately if chest pain or shortness of breath occurs..

# Pericardial effusion: The patient was found to have slightly
larger pericardial effusion compared to prior study, as well as
new evidence of slight R atrial collapse. Cardiology was
consulted and the patient was given 2L of IVF and was sent to
Katherinestad for possible pericardiocentesis. However, on repeat
ECHO, there was no evidence of cardiac tamponade and no
procedure was performed. The patient has outpatient follow up
with Cardiology for a repeat ECHO to follow any interval size
changes in pericardial effusion the week after discharge.

# Enterobacter UTI: The patient complained of dysuria, and U/A
was positive. She was started on Vancomycin given previous
vancomycin sensitive enterococcus UTI, and Ceftriaxone for
empiric gram negative coverage. The culture grew out pan
sensitive enterobacter and she ultimately completed a three day
course of ceftriaxone prior to discharge.

# NSCLC: The patient was most recently been on erlotinib. Per
her outpatient oncologists, she is being currently screened for
suitability for a clinical trial, and is awaiting ECHO prior to
trial enrollment. We held tarceva after 2025-04-10 pending
decision regarding the clinical trial. However, given her
pleural and pericardial effusions, it was decided that the
patient should not be enrolled in the clinical trial. Instead,
prior to discharge, she was given Taxol and Carboplatin. The
patient was discharged on Decadron 2 mg x 2 days, Zofran, and
Compazine for nausea control. She has an outpatient follow up
appt on 2025-06-17 for Neulasta injection.

The patient was advised to stop her Tarceva. She will need to
get chemotherapy in three weeks (2025-03-18).

# Hypertension: The patient was continued on her home
Lisinopril.

# Hyponatremia: The patient presented with a sodium of 128 on
admission. Initial serum and urine chemistries and osms were
suggestive of hypovolemic hyponatremia rather than SiADH. Her
sodium was trending during the admission.

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
-She should follow up with Dr. Call the cardiologist immediately if chest pain or shortness of breath occurs. in three weeks for
another cycle of chemotherapy.

Discharge Instructions:
INSTRUCTIONS AFTER ORTHOPAEDIC SURGERY:

- You were in the hospital for orthopedic surgery. It is normal
to feel tired or "washed out" after surgery, and this feeling
should improve over the first few days to week.
- Resume your regular activities as tolerated, but please follow
your weight bearing precautions strictly at all times.

ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING:
-Weightbearing as tolerated left lower extremity

MEDICATIONS:
1) Take Tylenol 2020 every 6 hours around the clock. This is
an over the counter medication.
2) Add oxycodone as needed for increased pain. Aim to wean
off this medication in 1 week or sooner. This is an example on
how to wean down:
Take 1 tablet every 3 hours as needed x 1 day,
then 1 tablet every 4 hours as needed x 1 day,
then 1 tablet every 6 hours as needed x 1 day,
then 1 tablet every 8 hours as needed x 2 days,
then 1 tablet every 12 hours as needed x 1 day,
then 1 tablet every before bedtime as needed x 1 day.
Then continue with Tylenol for pain.
3) Do not stop the Tylenol until you are off of the narcotic
medication.
4) Per state regulations, we are limited in the amount of
narcotics we can prescribe. If you require more, you must
contact the office to set up an appointment because we cannot
refill this type of pain medication over the phone.
5) Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you
should drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and continue
following the bowel regimen as stated on your medication
prescription list. These meds (senna, colace, miralax) are over
the counter and may be obtained at any pharmacy.
6) Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate
machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers.
7) Please take all medications as prescribed by your
physicians at discharge.
8) Continue all home medications unless specifically
instructed to stop by your surgeon.

ANTICOAGULATION:
- Please take Lovenox daily for 4 weeks

WOUND CARE:
- You may shower. No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks.
- Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken
out at your 2-week follow up appointment.
- Incision may be left open to air unless actively draining. If
draining, you may apply a gauze dressing secured with paper
tape.
- Splint must be left on until follow up appointment unless
otherwise instructed.
- Do NOT get splint wet.

DANGER SIGNS:
Please call your PCP or surgeon's office and/or return to the
emergency department if you experience any of the following:
- Increasing pain that is not controlled with pain medications

medications down
- Any other medical concerns

1999 year old female with history of atrial fibrillation on

ligation/drainage of R pleural effusion and
repair of lung injury. She arrived in the ICU and required
volume resuscitation, methylene blue and pressors for post op
hypotension. She also had some bradycardia immediately post
operatively and EP was consulted for a possible transvenous wire
placement. They felt that her rhythm was stable and did not need
intervention but she would need a pacer at a later time. She had
persistent air leaks from her pleural chest tubes and required
continuous suction. She transferred out of the ICU to the
stepdown on POD5. On POD 7 she was found to be hypoxic and
hypotensive and was transferred back to the ICU. She became more
hypotensive and hypoxic and required reintubation. Her blood
pressure continued to drop and she required multiple
vasopressors. Her lactate was rising and the decision was made
to take her for a CTA to rule out aortic dissection and ischemic
bowel. Acute care surgery was consulted to evaluate the scan.
Per Dr. Richard Alexander was no problem with her aorta but the
appearance of her small bowel and her rising lactate suggested
that she had ischemic bowel. The ACS team and Dr. Richard Alexander
extensive discussions with the patient's sisters, and the
decision was made to not proceed with surgery and the patient
was made DNR with no escalation of care. She was pronounced dead
2025-07-10.
